DOC.HEAD: Arrow Shot at Greyhound Bus in Cleveland
DOC.TEXT: An arrow was shot at a Greyhound bus Friday as it was leaving a Cleveland terminal en route to Pittsburgh, police said. There were no injuries and no arrests, said police Lt. Martin Flask. Flask said the bus carrying 59 passengers was leaving the terminal at about 2:40 a.m. when the arrow embedded in a window on the passenger side, four rows from the door. He didn't know whether it shattered the window. The driver didn't report the incident until he had the bus on the interstate, when he radioed his dispatcher, Flask said. About 6,300 drivers and 3,000 other workers at the Dallas-based company went on strike March 2. Greyhound does not plan to resume talks until attacks against buses driven by replacement workers stops and the union softens its wage demands, said company spokesman George Gravley. He said there have been 20 shootings since the strike started, with no serious injuries reported.

DOC.HEAD: Buckey Retrial Delayed Due to Defense Lawyer's Back Trouble
DOC.TEXT: The retrial of Raymond Buckey on eight counts of child molestation in the McMartin Pre-School case was postponed Friday because his defense lawyer has back trouble. Superior Court Judge Stanley Weisberg said examination by an independent physician revealed that medication would alleviate pain from a herniated disk suffered by attorney Danny Davis and he moved the trial to April 9. The trial was originally scheduled to begin next week. ``I have a herniated disk and it is from sitting on this case for six years,'' Davis said outside the court. Asked if he agreed to the delay, Buckey said, ``Yes, your honor.'' Deputy District Attorney Joe Martinez said, ``The witnesses are very unhappy about this. They consider this another ploy by Danny Davis.'' The prosecutor estimates it will take six months to try Buckey on the eight counts. ``I just want to go to trial. I want to have this case over,'' Martinez said. Ray Buckey, 31, was acquitted in January of 40 of 53 molestation counts in the first McMartin trial. His mother and a co-defendant, Peggy McMartin Buckey, was acquitted of all counts against her. The trial lasted nearly three years and cost taxpayers more than $10 million. The jury deadlocked on the other 13 counts against Ray Buckey and the trial judge declared a mistrial on those charges. Prosecutors refiled the 13 counts, but dropped five to strengthen their case. If convicted on all eight counts, Buckey could be sentenced to 15 years in prison, although time he served while awaiting trial and good behavior could reduce that to about 7{ years.

DOC.HEAD: Twins Reunited in Jail After Escape Switch
DOC.TEXT: A man who escaped from prison by swapping clothes with his identical twin was back behind bars _ and so was his brother. Anthony Litton had been halfway through a two-year burglary sentence at Cardiff prison south Wales when he walked out of prison Tuesday. Police said he was caught in a friend's house 15 miles from the prison and returned to jail Friday. On Wednesday, Terry Litton was charged with helping the escape. The twins, aged 19, have their first names tattooed on their necks and the escape was only noticed when a fellow prisoner told guards.

DOC.HEAD: Military Rolls Into Vilnius, Lithuania Decries Psychological Warfare
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with president sending telegram to Moscow, report more than 100 vehicles; picks up 12th pvs, `In Washington...' Minor editing to TRIM and CONFORM
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos VIL6,7,9, MOS14
DOC.TEXT: A column of about 100 military vehicles rolled through the Lithuanian capital before dawn Saturday in what apparently was another bid by the Kremlin to unnerve leaders of the breakaway republic. Lithuanian leaders condemned the maneuver and accused the Soviet Union of waging psychological warfare against the small Baltic republic, which declared independence on March 11. Nervous Lithuanian legislators passed a resolution transferring power to the senior diplomat of independent Lithuania in Washington in case of emergency, and several of them walked about 100 yards from legislative chambers to a highway overpass to watch the column rumble through the city at 4 a.m. ``This is absurd, armored vehicles don't usually drive through the middle of town in the middle of the night,'' Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimeira Prunskeine told reporters at the legislature. ``We're not afraid, but we don't know what they want, and we don't know what they will do in the next few hours,'' she said. The convoy moved along the main highway through the heart of Vilnius in the early morning darkness without stopping. A spokesman for the Lithuanian parliament said he had seen the convoy pull into a military base at Siaures Miestelis on the north side of the capital. Audris Butkavicius, a Lithuanian deputy who said he talked to some of the soldiers, said they told him there were about 1,000 paratroopers in the column. There were at least 22 tanks and armored personnel carriers and dozens of green military trucks. The parliament's information deparment quoting witnesses said there were 59 tanks and 50 other vehicles. Deputies, who were still meeting in the Supreme Council legislature to finish forming their independent government, said they had not been notified in advance of the convoy's movement. After deputies checked out the column's movement, they broke up and began to go home. Gorbachev and his advisers have pledged not to use force to halt Lithuania's formation of an independent government. But Lithuanians are concerned the Soviet military will forcibly try to detain soldiers who deserted and returned to their native land after the declaration of independence. Saturday was the deadline for them to return to their units. A top military adviser to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev, indicated Friday the military would try to round up the deserters, ``even if some people don't like it.'' Gorbachev also told the republic's president, Vytautus Landsbergis on Thursday that Lithuania should stop signing up volunteer forces, and sought a response from the Lithuanian leader within two days. Landsbergis, in an early morning telegram to Moscow, said the volunteers would not replace Soviet KGB border guards and uniformed police, as Gorbachev suggested the Lithuanians would. Speaking about Saturday's maneuvers, Landsbergis said: ``Tension is rising with this demonstration of military force, with this frightening of people with Soviet soldiers.'' In Washington, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Friday afternoon, ``The situation appears to progressively get worse.'' The republic is working to restore the independence lost to Stalin's army in 1940. U.S. officials said the Soviet Union had ordered two American consular officers out of Lithuania, giving them 12 hours to leave. U.S. officials said other foreign diplomats and some journalists also had been told to leave the Lithuanian capital. The diplomats, Leningrad-based consuls Douglas Wake and Jon Purnell, said Friday night in Vilnius that they had heard nothing about the order for them to leave. While Fitzwater said the diplomats ``will comply,'' he said the United States was ``not given a reason'' by Moscow for the expulsion. He said the Soviet chief of protocol relayed the expulsion notice to officials at the U.S. embassy in Moscow. He said the two officials were in Vilnius ``on routine reporting and analysis as they do for the embassy.'' ``They are staff people in our consulate in Leningrad,'' he said. ``They're not spies.'' Wake, the U.S. diplomat, said U.S. officials regularly traveled to Lithuania in the course of their consular work, but declined to comment further on his mission there. Later Friday, Fitzwater said it was ``unclear what specific actions have been taken against journalists. But we are opposed to any infringements on freedom of the press.'' Soviet officials on Friday continued to increase their pressure on Lithuania to renounce its declaration of independence from the Soviet Union: _The Soviet Union informed Poland it was suspending visa-free travel for Poles and Lithuanians across the border, the official Tass news agency said. _A military helicopter with a Soviet red star emblazoned on its side dumped leaflets on downtown Vilnius containing a copy of Gorbachev's directive that the republic of 3.8 million respect Soviet law. _Foreign Ministry officials said Soviet embassies would review foreigners' visa applications to travel to Lithuania, to keep out people ``inclined to engage in illegal activities,'' Tass said. It did not elaborate. The Soviet Union forcibly annexed Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia a half-century ago as part of an agreement between Josef Stalin and Adolf Hitler. President Bush said Friday that any attempt by the Soviets to intimidate Lithuania or to use force ``is bound to backfire. That is inevitable.'' Lithuania issued an appeal to the world for support late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Man Repossess Car, Finds Baby in Back Seat
DOC.TEXT: A car Reggie Lane repossessed had an unexpected accessory _ a 19-month-old baby comfortably asleep in the back seat. ``I thought I was going to be charged with kidnapping,'' Lane said. Police received two calls within minutes of each other Thursday, one from the mother and another from Lane, the surprised and nervous owner of an auto recovery business. The 22-year-old woman reported her car had been stolen and her baby kidnapped. The woman said she stopped at her aunt's house to make a telephone call and locked the car doors with the baby sleeping in the back seat. Lane and his partner, who would identify himself only as Steve, said they broke into the car and drove away. Lane later pulled into a service station, and when his partner pulled in behind him, he got out and noticed the baby. ``I said: `Oh, God! There's a baby in back,''' Steve said. ``We've found guns and drugs in some of the cars we've picked up, but never a baby.''

DOC.HEAD: Keating Lawyer Later Hired By Agency Overseeing S&L Bailout
DOC.TEXT: A federal agency overseeing part of the savings and loan bailout last year awarded a $49,000 no-bid contract to an attorney who had pressed regulators not to seize the California thrift that later suffered a $2 billion failure. Margery Waxman was awarded the five-month contract by Mary K. Bush, the acting director of the Federal Housing Finance Board, one of several agencies established under the S&L bailout plan to regulate the nation's 12 regional Federal Home Loan Banks. The finance board replaced the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. In 1988, Waxman represented the Lincoln Savings and Loan when the bank board's San Francisco office was urging its Washington headquarters to seize the thrift. In a May 1988 letter to Lincoln's owner, Charles Keating, Waxman said she had lobbied board officials and told Keating, ``You have the board right where you want them.'' Waxman worked with Ms. Bush in the early 1980s at the Treasury Department. The Waxman contract was one of three Ms. Bush awarded last year, without competition, to longtime friends. The housing board is overseen by the Department of Housing and Urban Development and its chairman is HUD Secretary Jack Kemp. HUD officials said Friday that Kemp met with Ms. Bush this week and told her he was cutting her powers and assuming final authority for all agency contract awards. A $37,000 no-bid consulting contracts went to Wendell W. Gunn, who was Kemp's chief of staff for several months last year. The third was a $100,000 contract with an Atlanta management consulting firm whose partners include Kevin Coyne, also a former colleague of Ms. Bush's at the Treasury Department. Work on all three has been completed. A spokesman for Ms. Bush said she awarded the contracts because she knew the recipients had the expertise to help the agency. The contracts were not put out for bid because the housing finance board receives no tax dollars and so is not subject to competitive procurement guidelines. Kemp's top deputy, HUD Undersecretary Alfred DelliBovi, said Friday that Kemp was not aware of the contracts until this week. DelliBovi said Kemp knew Gunn was advising Ms. Bush but did not know he was being paid and would not have approved of such an arrangement because of Gunn's past work at HUD. DelliBovi said Kemp continues to support Ms. Bush, whose expected appointment as chairwoman has not been announced by the White House some seven months after the agency was created. The name of Waxman, of the Washington office of the law firm Sidley & Austin, surfaced in connection with the Lincoln case last week when House Banking Committee Chairman Henry Gonzalez, D-Texas, released her letter to Keating and said it suggested ``a fix was in'' at the bank board. In the letter, Waxman told Keating she successfully lobbied M. Danny Wall, then the director of the now-defunct board. ``As you know, I have put pressure on Wall to work toward meeting your demands and he has so instructed his staff,'' Waxman wrote. Ten days later, despite recommendations from its San Francisco office, the Bank Board declined to take action against the thrift and took the unusual step of shifting oversight responsibilities from San Francisco to Washington. Wall last week denied being pressured by Waxman and her law firm denied any impropriety. Keating has gained notoriety because of his large contributions to five senators who intervened with regulators on his behalf.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Hopes Supercomputer Pact Leads to Japanese Trade Breakthrough
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration has its first payoff after 10 months of pressuring the Japanese to buy more American products, but members of Congress are warning much more needs to be done. The administration announced Friday an agreement designed to boost sales of U.S.-manufactured supercomputers in Japan by removing some restrictions imposed by the Japanese government. The agreement, which is expected to be formally signed in April, should open a $130 million-market for supercomputers purchased by Japanese universities and other government agencies. The breakthrough came late Thursday night following two days of intensive negotiations. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said the new pact ``should give us full and effective access'' to the Japanese government market. It marked the first success for the administration since it put Japan on a ``hit list'' last April of countries accused of erecting unfair barriers to sales of American goods. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, in Los Angeles for talks Friday with Japanese Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, said that with the agreement, ``We're showing that we can make some progress.'' Supercomputers were among three product areas singled out for negotiations. Little progress has been reported so far in talks on American-made satellites and wood products. ``Are (supercomputer concessions) all we want?'' Brady said. ``No. Are we going to get more? Yes. When, I can't say. I hope soon.'' The Japanese are facing a June 19 deadline to show a willingness to open their markets or face possible U.S. retaliation in increased tariffs on Japanese products sold in America. Members of Congress have been pushing the administration to take a tougher line in the trade negotiations with Tokyo, pointing to the $49 billion deficit the United States is running with Japan. That is close to half the total U.S. trade deficit last year. Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo., said the supercomputer agreement was encouraging but would have to be followed by increased sales. ``Japan must recognize that promises without performance are simply unacceptable,'' Danforth said. Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., noted a 1987 agreement by the Japanese to buy more American supercomputers had not produced results. He said U.S. negotiators shouldn't declare victory too soon. ``Nonetheless, progress is always encouraging. I hope this is a sign that the United States and Japan can jointly work out their trade frictions,'' said Baucus, who is chairman of the Senate Finance trade subcommittee. In addition to the product talks, the administration is conducting separate discussions on broader structural impediments to trade such as exclusionary Japanese business practices. Brady met with Hashimoto as a follow-up to trade discussions held by President Bush and Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. A U.S. trade official, briefing reporters in Washington on Friday, said the Japanese showed new urgency in the latest round of computer talks, apparently reflecting the impact of the Bush-Kaifu meeting. ``Their negotiators came with instructions to make a deal,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``We hope the Japanese will perceive the same kind of guidance in the other issues.'' Negotiators handling the structural impediments talks met at a remote hideaway in the Virginia countryside earlier this week in advance of more formal discussions in Washington April 2-3. However, U.S. officials said the discussions near Warrenton, Va., failed to make any progress. There have been reports from Tokyo that Kaifu is preparing trade concessions in these areas in hopes of dampening growing protectionist sentiment in Congress. Under the computer agreement announced Friday, the Japanese promised to open the procurement process for supercomputers to foreign firms and to base government purchase decisions on quality as well as price.

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Commandant Defends Tanker Tracking System
With PM-Hazelwood Trial, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Commandant Paul Yost defended the Coast Guard's method of tracking vessels through Prince William Sound, instead blaming human error for the Exxon Valdez oil spill a year ago today. Nevertheless, the Coast Guard will install a new radar system better able to track tankers, especially in bad weather, Yost said Friday. ``The system was never designed to track tankers outside the (Valdez) Arm,'' Yost said. Bligh Reef, where the Exxon Valdez grounded, is near the end of the arm. The new radar system probably will cover Bligh Reef, although the area never has been considered difficult to navigate, Yost said. Yost's comments came the day Exxon Valdez skipper Joseph Hazelwood was sentenced to spend 1,000 hours helping clean beaches fouled by the spill March 24, 1989, and to pay $50,000 restitution. The Coast Guard plans hearings to determine if Hazelwood's maritime master's license should be revoked, Yost told a news conference. Exxon fired the captain shortly after the accident. His future also is clouded by more than 100 lawsuits filed by assorted victims of the spill, the nation's worst. The spill poured nearly 11 million gallons of Alaska crude into the pristine sound, killing countless birds, fish and other animals. Hazelwood was convicted of the misdemeanor charge of negligent discharge of oil. He was acquitted of two other misdemeanors, operating a vessel while intoxicated and reckless endangerment, and a felony, criminal mischief. Yost appeared to partially absolve Hazelwood of responsibility, noting he wasn't on the bridge at the time of the accident. ``A fully qualified third mate ran the vessel aground,'' he said. It was clear from the trial and from other evidence that human error caused the grounding, Yost said. No matter what technological changes are introduced or what laws are enacted, the Coast Guard cannot guarantee against similar groundings, he said. ``We've got to be very careful we don't have a spasm response'' to the spill, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Former billionaire Adnan Khashoggi, once considered the world's richest man, says he's worth only about $54 million. But the Saudi financier continues to live in a lavish Fifth Avenue duplex created out of 16 apartments and valued at $26 million. Khashoggi _ the middleman in the ill-fated Iran-Contra arms-for-hostage deal _ showed the place off to Barbara Walters in an interview on ABC's ``20-20'' that aired Friday. The apartment offers fantastic views of the Manhattan skyline, has a dining room table made of lapis lazuli and a swimming pool next to a bedroom that has a 10-foot-long bed covered with a sable bedspread. Khashoggi told Walters that he was never worth the billions people said he had. He said it was more like $1 billion, but a series of financial setbacks reduced that to $54 million. He is about to go on trial in federal court in New York with Imelda Marcos, widow of deposed Philippine leader Ferdinand Marcos. Khashoggi is accused of helping her the Marcoses conceal a series of New York real estate deals.

Julio Martinez, ousted in December as Gov. Mario Cuomo's commissioner for drug treatment, says he'll be outside the governor's office Monday _ selling hot dogs. He got a city permit Tuesday to become a street vendor outside the state Capitol and has invested about $10,000, including $3,000 for a cart, in the business. ``I've got balloons that say, `He's back _ Knishener Martinez,'' Martinez said. ``It won't be high profile. That's my past. My future is selling hot dogs, knishes and sodas.'' Knishes, regular fixtures at New York City hot dog wagons, are pieces of dough folded over a filling, usually potato or meat. Martinez was forced out of his $87,300-a-year job as director of the Division of Substance Abuse Services after investigative reports alleged he had directed lucrative state contracts to friends that produced little or no drug treatment. Martinez denied any wrongdoing and there have been no allegations that he personally profited from the contracts. Martinez, 46, a former heroin addict who co-founded the Phoenix House drug-treatment agency, said his new venture wasn't intended as a slap at Cuomo. ``The governor was good to me. He's one of my heroes,'' Martinez said. ``I took it on the chin, but life goes on ... I'm doing this because Julio Martinez has bills to pay.''

Marla Maples has an offer to appear on ``Hee Haw'' _ if she brings along Donald Trump. Ms. Maples, who has been linked with the billionaire by the tabloids, has been sending out a resume that lists a stint as ``Missy'' on the country music variety show, the Nashville Banner reported, quoting an unnamed source. But the show's producer rebutted the claim. ``I don't know where this came from, and to my knowledge she has never been a guest on the show,'' Sam Lovullo told the Banner on Thursday. Lovullo, however, said he'd be glad to book the actress onto the show, but only ``if she'd bring Trump along for the cornfield.'' In New York, Ms. Maples' spokesman, Chuck Jones, said: ``It's not relevant whether she has or has not been on the show ... If it's on the resume, it's on the resume, and I just don't have any comment.'' Trump's separation from his wife, Ivana, became public last month.

Ralph David Abernathy has been hospitalized for a sodium imbalance that caused him to be lethargic, but the civil-rights leader was ``not in great danger,'' his physician said. Abernathy, 63, was in fair condition Friday at Crawford Long Hospital of Emory University, said Dr. Robert Kaufmann. Abernathy was taken there Thursday night. Abernathy could be hospitalized a week or so, depending on how he responds to treatment, Kaufmann said. He was ``somewhat lethargic, and not as alert as he usually is,'' the doctor said. Abernathy was diagnosed with hyponatremia _ an electrolytic imbalance, or low sodium count _ in his bloodstream. The sodium deficiency was probably triggered by nausea Abernathy suffered two days earlier, coupled with diuretics he takes for high blood pressure, Kaufmann said. A sodium imbalance can be life-threatening, but Abernathy is responding to treatment, Kaufmann said.

Howie Long, who helped his Raiders teammates bring Los Angeles a Super Bowl championship in 1984, is teaming up with young AIDS victim Ryan White to raise money to fight the deadly disease. The two were in Beverly Hills Friday to work out final details for Monday's pre-Oscar gala sponsored by Athletes and Entertainers for Kids. Milton Berle will be the host. Sponsors hope to raise $250,000 for the Ryan White National Education Program and Services for AIDS Education, Substance Abuse and Self Esteem. Although exhausted by a series of appearances Friday, White said he has no intention of missing the party. ``I'm really looking forward to it,'' he said by phone in a nearly inaudible voice. ``It's a good thing, it's important.'' White, 18, a hemophiliac who lives in Cicero, Ind., contracted aquired immune deficiency syndrome six years ago from a tainted blood transfusion. He is one of the longest-living AIDS survivors. ``I supposedly work with extremely tough people _ mentally and physically. But he's by far the toughest person I've ever been around,'' said Long.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian-Americans Rally Forces for Independence
With PM-US-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Washington rally begins 4 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: In a quiet corner of Chicago's Southwest Side, world politics have taken center stage. Tens of thousands of Lithuanian-Americans live here, and on Friday many made phone calls, wrote letters and sent telegrams urging the Bush administration to take a stronger stand in support of Lithuania's independence from the Soviet Union. Lithuanian-Americans in other cities also were collecting donations to send to their relatives and friends and prepared for a Lithuanian independence rally today near the Lincoln Memorial in Washington. At Nida's Delicatessan and Restaurant in Chicago, the Bush administration's stand was virtually the only topic of conversation. ``Everybody's talking about it,'' said owner Liutas Mockunas. ``Everybody is listening to the news ... People are disappointed by President Bush's policy, they're really upset.'' ``Are we going to have to see massacres like (China's) Tiananmen Square to get the Bush administration to wake up?'' asked Daiva Meile, spokeswoman for the Lithuanian American Council in Chicago. ``Everyone is extremely upset that Bush has not come out forcefully for Lithuanian independence.'' Early today, the Soviet Union apparently stepped up pressure against the breakaway republic as an armored column of almost 100 military vehicles rolled through the center of Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital. On Friday, the Kremlin ordered foreign diplomats and some journalists to leave Lithuania as tensions mounted in the Baltic republic, officials of the Bush administration said. In one of his strongest statements on the issue to date, Bush on Friday warned the Soviets against military intervention, saying the United States backs the Lithuanian peoples' ``right to self-determination.'' But Lithuanian-Americans said the administration has fallen short in supporting Lithuania since it declared its independence from the Soviet Union on March 11. ``We are concerned about President Bush's lackadaisical attitude,'' said Fran Salutas, co-host of Lithuanian-American Radio, a show broadcast from Chicago each Saturday and monitored closely by the city's large and tight-knit Lithuanian community. ``We need moral and political support from the United States.'' Chicago Lithuanians worked Friday to fill buses that would drive overnight to get to the Washington rally, while Lithuanians from the Boston area who could not make it to Washington planned a simultaneous demonstration near Bush's summer home in Kennebunkport, Maine. ``We are frustrated,'' said Gintaras Cepas, chairman of the Boston branch of the Lithuanian American Council. ``All we're really asking for is moral support _ vocal moral support for what was a democratic decision by the people of Lithuania.'' Lithuanians, who flocked to the Boston area in the 19th century to work in the burgeoning textile mills of Lawrence and Lowell, have maintained close ties to their heritage, Cepas said. ``We don't see a silver lining right now ... and that's kind of scary,'' he said. In Los Angeles, the Lithuanian community mounted a telephone and letter-writing campaign to fuel U.S. support for the independence movement. Activist Antanas Mazeika said many of California's more than 50,000 Lithuanian-Americans were calling the White House opinion line and sending letters and telegrams to the president and other politicians. ``We are trying to push (Bush) to be more responsive,'' Mazeika said. ``We feel at this time it is very urgent for Lithuanians. It is a dangerous time.''

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to fix cycle designator.
Census Changed With Nation Through History
DOC.TEXT: The first time this nation took its own measure there were fewer than 4 million Americans, most living on farms or in small towns. It's a far different mix of a quarter-billion people, scattered from Maine to Hawaii, that are being counted in the upcoming 21st census. Americans began getting their census forms on Friday, the Census Bureau said, as the first of an estimated 95 million forms began arriving in mailboxes across the nation. The Postal Service says all the forms should be delivered by next Tuesday. The changes in family and lifestyle, population size, location and employment have been charted every decade by the census. Indeed, the U.S. national head count is one of the longest regular series of such efforts in any country. Yet the concept of taking a census is ancient, dating back at least to biblical times when the Roman census brought Joseph and Mary to Bethlehem. Unlike Mary and Joseph, Americans don't have to go to the census. It will come to them, mostly through the mail. Census takers will travel only to those places where address lists couldn't be obtained, or where people don't mail back their forms. Delivering the forms and bringing them back will cost the Census Bureau nearly $44 million in postage, the Postal Service reports. President George Washington was in his first term when federal marshals went out in the summer of 1790 to take the first national head count. Secretary of State Thomas Jefferson was in charge. Completed in 1792, that census reported there were 3,929,214 Americans. This year's census is scheduled for April 1 with a report due to the president on Dec. 31. Analysis of all the 1990 data will go on for years. Census takers traveled by foot, boat, stagecoach and horseback in 1790. Those were about the only choices. Horses are still used to reach some Indian reservations. Census takers in 1790 asked only a few questions and then posted lists of their findings in public places. People who had been missed were expected to add themselves to those lists. There are long and short forms today which ask dozens of questions _ too many some contend, though government officials say they need the data to set policy and operate social programs. Information provided is kept confidential now and census takers can go to jail if they reveal information about any individual. That first census found 4.5 persons per square mile and Rhode Island was the most crowded state at 63.4 per square mile. The whole nation in 1987 had 68.8 per square mile and New Jersey was the most crowded that year with 1,027.3 people per square mile. There were five big cities in 1790. Five, that is, that had at least 8,000 people _ New York, Boston, Philadelphia, Baltimore and Charleston, S.C. The population was 80.3 percent white and 19.7 percent black in 1790. By 1988 it was 84.3 percent white, 12.3 percent black and 3.3 percent other races. Americans will also have more ways to find out about the results of the census. There were 103 newspapers and periodicals in the country in 1790. As of 1987, the nation included 1,645 daily papers and 11,566 magazines.

DOC.HEAD: Contras Agree to Immediate Demobilization; Ortega Praises Accord
LaserPhotos NY4,NY5
DOC.TEXT: U.S.-backed Nicaraguan Contra rebels agree to begin immediate disbanding of their forces in Honduras, breaking a deadlock in the way of the peaceful transition of power in their homeland. The agreement, reached Friday after talks by the Contras, Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo and representatives of President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, was praised by President Daniel Ortega, whose Sandinistas have fought the rebels for nine years. ``This is an accord that recognizes a national consensus and this national consensus that will put an end to the war and bring peace to Nicaragua,'' Ortega said in Managua, the Nicaraguan capital. The Contras agreed Friday to begin demobilizing the 12,000 troops in Honduran base camps immediately and said they should all be back in Nicaragua by April 20, five days before Mrs. Chamorro's pro-U.S. government is inaugurated. The Contras said another 4,000 fighters in Nicaragua would move into ``security zones.'' The accord was announced in Tegucigalpa by Obando y Bravo, the Roman Catholic archbishop of Managua. A communique issued at the end of the seven-hour talks said the U.S.-backed Contras were ready to disband because the Feb. 25 general elections had ``established a process of democratization'' in Nicaragua. Ortega, Mrs. Chamorro and President Bush, who has asked Congress for a $300 million aid package that includes $45 million for demobilization, have all called upon the rebels to disband. The agreement to dismantle the Contras appears to remove the biggest stumbling block to the transfer of power. The outgoing Sandinista government had said they could not relinquish control of the armed forces as long as the Contras refused to demobilize. The senior Contra military commander, Israel Galeano, had said the rebels wouldn't put down their guns as long as the Sandinistas kept theirs. Ortega was at the airport to greet the cardinal and Mrs. Chamorro's negotiators when they returned to Managua Friday night from the Honduran capital. ``I am going to give instructions immediately to the Foreign Ministry and the Defense Ministry to take steps to apply the letter of this accord,'' he told a news conference. ``It is possible that there won't be a single armed Contra in Nicaragua on April 25th.'' But Ortega also said he was concerned that Galeano had not signed the accord. ``We hope that this accord will be accepted and respected by all members of the Contra who are in Nicaraguan territory and that we can save the Nicaraguan people from a bloodbath,'' he said. Antonio Lacayo, one of Mrs. Chamorro's negotiators, said it is up to the Contras to make sure Galeano respects the accord. Ortega said there were between 4,000 and 6,000 Contra rebels inside Nicaragua preparing for a major military offensive for the days prior to the inauguration. The demobilization accord should put an end to any plans for an offensive, he said. The head of the Contra negotiating team said 12,000 rebels living in base camps in Yamales, Honduras, along with 42,000 relatives would be home by April 20. ``The Nicaraguan Resistance begins its return to Nicaragua today,'' rebel negotiator Oscar Sovalbarro, said. ``The process will culminate on April 20 with the goal of reincorporating its members into the civilian society.'' Another 4,000 Contras in Nicaragua would move into security zones supervised by Obando y Bravo and the United Nations, which has observer and demobilization missions in the region, he said. The agreement calls for an immediate cease-fire to be monitored by the United Nations and Obando y Bravo, who said the Sandinistas should ``cease attacks on the rebels'' as a gesture of good faith toward the pact. ``We trust in Obando y Bravo's moral force,'' Sovalbarro said. Mrs. Chamorro's team promised pensions for Contra widows and orphans and to wounded rebel veterans in ``recognition of their patriotic labors.'' The Chamorro delegation also agreed to set up a commission including representatives of the new government and of the Contras to monitor demobilization. The commission and humanitarian aid for the rebels and their families were conditions the Contras set for demobilization at the outset of Friday's talks. The rebels went into the talks with a long list of demands, including several _ such as the demobilization of the Sandinista army _ that would have required the agreement of the Sandinistas. The Sandinistas were not represented at the talks. Ortega agreed to the Feb. 25 elections, which were monitored by several thousand international observers, as part of a Central America accord on demobilizing the Contras. Within hours of her upset victory, Mrs. Chamorro had called upon the rebels to disband, saying, the democracy they had been fighting for had arrived in Nicaragua and there was no longer any reason to fight.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Gives Thrift Bailout Reprieve
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's savings and loan bailout has a reprieve from legal disarray, at least until a federal appeals court can review a lower court ruling that thrift regulators were appointed unconstitutionally. U.S. District Judge Royce C. Lamberth on Wednesday barred the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision from seizing Olympic Savings and Loan Association of Berwyn, Ill. But on Friday, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit lifted the order. It said regulators could take control of the S&L, but forbade them from liquidating the thrift and selling its $1.1 billion in assets. Lamberth had ruled that acting thrift office Director Salvatore R. Martoche and his predecessor, M. Danny Wall, had no authority to order the takeover because they were not nominated by the president and confirmed by the Senate. The appeals court made no decision on the merits of Lamberth's reading of the Constitution, but it said barring a takeover of Olympic could hurt the public. ``While (Olympic) may have a strong likelihood of success on the merits (of its case), the harm to the public outweighs the harm to (Olympic) in this instance,'' the appeals court wrote. Government attorneys had argued Lamberth's injunction could cost taxpayers millions of dollars by encouraging a flood of similar suits from other weak thrifts. In a reply, attorneys for Olympic said allowing regulators to seize the thrift would make its suit pointless. ``Olympic will clearly suffer irreparable injury,'' they wrote. The appellate court gave the two sides deadlines for filing written arguments and scheduled a hearing before a three-judge panel on April 11. Meanwhile, Bush is moving on another front to blunt the effect of the suit by nominating a former top Labor Department attorney, T. Timothy Ryan Jr., to a five-year term as director of the thrift office. The Senate Banking Committee could hold a confirmation hearing on Ryan as soon as next week.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Offended by Some Art, But Opposes Censorship
DOC.TEXT: President Bush says he opposes government censorship even though he is offended by ``some of the sacrilegious, blasphemous depictions that are portrayed by some to be art.'' ``I am deeply offended by some of the filth that I see and to which federal money has gone,'' Bush told a luncheon of regional news editors at the White House on Friday. He made the comment in response to a question about his administration's opposition to restricting National Endowment for the Arts funds for controversial art. Congressional conservatives have criticized that position, which was outlined by NEA Chairman John Frohnmayer this week at a congressional hearing. The critics, contending his administration is flouting a congressional ban against funding obscene art for this fiscal year, have proposed tighter constraints on art funding. However, Frohnmayer said the White House opposes extending the restrictions to the next fiscal year. Bush said Friday he wants the matter handled administratively by Frohnmayer rather than by new legislative standards. ``I am against censorship, but I will try to convince those who feel differently in terms of legislation that we will do everything in our power to stop pure blasphemy,'' Bush said. Still, he contended he did not want to ``risk censorship or getting the federal government into telling every artist what he or she can paint.'' Bush said he was thinking of two examples of ``blasphemous material that has no business getting one cent of the taxpayers' money.'' He said he did not want to say what they were. At the question-and-answer session, Bush also: _Indicated he would back moving the shipping lanes away from California shores to help guard against oil tankers fouling beaches, but said he wouldn't support banning the tankers from the coast. _Renewed his plea to Congress for passage of his embattled $800 million aid package for Panama and Nicaragua. _Said it's not ``time to change policy on sanctions'' against South Africa. ``I want to see more progress'' from South African President F.W. de Klerk, he said, adding however that he also does not believe the economic sanctions against Pretoria should be increased. _Said his administration ``would rejoice in being able to help a democratically elected government in Cuba'' but there is none on the horizon. President Fidel Castro, he said, ``is swimming against the tide'' of democracy in the world. _Spoke against making the District of Columbia a state. ``This is a federal city and my view is it should remain that,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Terror in Haiti Continues With 17 Killed, 20 Wounded in Attacks
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Gangsters and soldiers fatally shot 14 members of civilian defense groups and angry mobs captured and killed three thugs in a wave of attacks that has followed Haiti's return to civilian rule. The state hospital said it treated at least 20 people for gunshot and machete wounds, and sporadic gunfire was heard Friday in most parts of the capital. At least 40 people have been killed since Sunday in nightly shootings widely blamed on gangsters and those still loyal to ousted leaders Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril and Jean-Claude Duvalier, according to radio reports Friday. Avril resigned March 10 following a week of nationwide demonstrations against his military government. Three days later a provisional government led by Ertha Pascal-Trouillot took office and the army pledged to support her. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot, a Supreme Court justice, is to pave the way for elections in three to six months. The Unity Assembly, a coalition of civic and political leaders that helped negotiate Avril's departure, attributed the violence to rightist thugs angered by the shift in power from the military to civilians. ``After this night of intimidation, the army high command owes the people an explanation,'' said center-leftist politician Dejean Belizaire, a member of the coalition. The coalition urged residents to form the civilian defense groups, known as ``vigilance brigades'' to compensate for a dearth of police protection. The army had tolerated the civilian patrols. But on Thursday, a communique read by radio stations said because of the ``widespread violence'' the high command was urging civilians to disband the neighborhood groups, to ``not interfere with'' the work of soldiers. ``The army alone has the responsibility of maintaining order,'' the communique said. Before dawn, soldiers attacked a neighborhood self-defense group in the St. Joseph slum, killing three members. Shortly after midnight, soldiers killed two others in separate incidents, according to Radio Metropole and Radio Haiti Inter. Gunmen killed two other civilian defense group members, Radio Metropole said. A wounded youth speaking on the Roman Catholic Church's Radio Soleil said a truckload of soldiers opened fire on neighborhood self-defense youths in the La Saline slum, killing seven. He said soldiers removed the bodies and warned him and several others wounded in the shooting to keep quiet. Radio reports said angry residents killed three thugs, apparently former members of the Tonton Macoutes, the feared secret police who served under the brutal, 29-year Duvalier family dictatorship. Most of the Macoutes sought obscurity after Duvalier fled to exile in France in 1986. But hundreds linked up with the army and police and are believed responsible for much of the violence plaguing Haiti, a Caribbean nation of 5.1 million people and the poorest country in the Western Hemisphere. The involvement of soldiers in attacks this week appears to indicate some soldiers remain loyal to Avril, despite their pledge to the new civilian administration. Belizaire said, however, that paramilitary gunmen may be disguising themselves as soldiers, and said some self-defense groups ``have been infiltrated by thugs.'' Many members of the 1,100-man Presidential Guard, supposedly confined to quarters since Avril was ousted, are believed to remain hostile to the shift in power to Avril's former enemies. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot governs with a 19-member State Council, composed of prominent civilians, some of them persecuted by Avril during his 18-month tenure. Jean-Claude Duvalier fled to exile following a popular uprising in February 1986. He was replaced by Lt. Gen. Henri Namphy, who was ousted by Avril in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: US Protests Expulsion Of Diplomats From Lithuania
DOC.NOTE: EDS: ADDS 2 grafs at end with Quayle comment.
DOC.TEXT: The United States is protesting the ouster of U.S. diplomats from Lithuania and President Bush is cautioning the Soviets that force against the secessionists would be ``bound to backfire.'' The protests were delivered Friday in Washington and in Moscow after two American consular officials were given 12 hours to leave Vilnius, the capital of the breakaway Baltic republic. The Soviet foreign ministry gave no explanation in telephoning the order to the U.S. embassy in Moscow, U.S. officials said. The two Americans, Douglas Wake and Jon Purnell, had gone to Vilnius from Leningrad to assess the standoff between local authorities demanding national recognition and Soviets determined to hold the USSR together. Other foreign diplomats were ordered to leave, along with a number of journalists, according to the officials who spoke on condition of anonymity. The actions could reduce the information reaching the outside world about the independence movement in Lithuania and the Soviet effort to maintain authority there. There was no immediate word of U.S. retaliation. And even with the protests, the administration again sought to minimize tensions. ``It's not being treated in a crisis-like way from our standpoint,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. He again appealed for a peaceful settlement, said U.S. options were limited and that the administration wanted to ``keep the rhetoric down.'' Bush declared on Friday that the United States stands with ``the brave men and women of Lithuania'' in their struggle for independence. And, he said, ``Any attempt to coerce or intimidate or forcibly intervene against the Lithuanian people is bound to backfire. That is inevitable.'' The president did not threaten any U.S. response, however. Fitzwater, meanwhile, said ``the situation appears to progressively get worse.'' Tass, the Soviet news agency, said the situation in Vilnius was approaching ``anarchy in all its manifestations.'' Meanwhile, Soviet Ambassador Yuri V. Dubinin said after a meeting with Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger that he had no information from Moscow about the expulsions. Richard Boucher, a State Department spokesman, said they had discussed Lithuania and Soviet emigration. Earlier, Bush said at a luncheon meeting with visiting media representatives, ``We know that the Soviet Union has a longstanding interest in Lithuania, but those interests can only be addressed through dialogue and negotiation.'' ``We want to see the people of Lithuania make their independent determination on what their future is going to be, and not the Soviet Union,'' Vice President Dan Quayle said from Scottsdale, Ariz. ``Let is hope and let us pray that it is resolved without violence and that the people of Lithuania can go free,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Analyst Believes NASA Can Solve Station Repair Problem
DOC.TEXT: Astronaut William Fisher says he is confident NASA will find ways to cut down on the number and length of space walks the proposed space station will need to keep it running. ``This is an engineering problem,'' said Fisher. ``Engineering is what NASA does better than anything in the world.'' Fisher and NASA engineer Charles R. Price head a space agency committee that recently said the station will need impossibly large amounts of maintenance. They stuck to their estimate after meeting with NASA executives Friday, but said it's only ``our preliminary, first cut at this data.'' Fisher, a physician, and Price said in their study that the station _ as now conceived _ would require 2,284 hours of maintenance each year by astronauts working in the harsh environment of open space. After The New York Times published those findings on Monday, congressional space committees expressed their concerns and three of them will hold hearings next week. ``No, I haven't changed my mind; no, I haven't been pressured,'' Fisher told reporters after Friday's review. But, he said, the numbers were obtained by asking all NASA space station contractors to total the amount of time they think it will take astronauts to fix what breaks. ``The number we have come up with in our preliminary first cut at this data is 2,284 hours in EVA time,'' Fisher said. EVA, for extra-vehicular activity, is NASA's term for space walks. Fisher said that's 32 percent higher than estimated in a similar study last October. He said that would require an average of 3.7 space walks a week. William B. Lenoir, NASA's space flight boss, who conducted Friday's review told reporters he would prefer no more than one space walk a month. ``I do think there's room for it to go down,'' Fisher said. ``It's our hope we can drive it down significantly. The function of the next four months is to take piece-by-piece the components of this number and see how much of its real and to see how much we can cut down on it.'' The space station, expected to cost more than $30 billion by the time it's completed and manned in 1999, is undergoing final design reviews now with the first construction trips into orbit scheduled for 1995. Fisher and Price said their study, initiated by NASA, is part of those reviews.

DOC.HEAD: Duchess' Second Baby Girl 6th In Line
DOC.TEXT: The Duchess of York gave birth to a 7-pound, 1{-ounce daughter by Caesarian section and the child, the second for Sarah Ferguson and her husband Prince Andrew, is sixth in the line of succession. Well-wishers cheered and popped champagne corks outside London's Portland Hospital following the birth Friday evening. Both the 30-year-old mother and her child were well, the hospital said. No name has yet been announced for the baby, but she will be known as Her Royal Highness, Princess (baby's name) of York. The Duchess of York's father, ex-army major Ronald Ferguson, said at his home at the village of Dummer 50 miles southwest of London, he had no idea what names the parents would choose. The baby is the second girl for the royal couple and is the sixth grandchild of Queen Elizabeth II. The new baby, daughter of the queen's second son, is sixth in line to the British throne after her sister, Princess Beatrice of York, who was born Aug. 8, 1988. Andrew was present at the delivery, a hospital statement said. The Caesarian section was carried out because the baby was in a breech position, a Buckingham Palace spokesman said. ``It was the wrong way round,'' he said. The duchess had spent the last week at the palace in London instead of at her country home. She arrived at the hospital Friday in a chauffeur-driven car, which drove her to a side entrance to avoid crowds of press photographers who staked out the area for the past several days. Andrew joined her two hours later after driving the 150 miles from Devonport naval dockyard where he is a flight commander on the Royal Navy frigate Campbeltown. As tradition dictates, a notice was posted on the railings at Buckingham Palace giving news of the birth. It read: ``Her Royal Highness the Duchess of York was safely delivered of a daughter at 7:58 p.m. today. Her Royal Highness and her child are well.'' Andrew's elder brother Prince Charles, 41, is first in line to the throne, followed by Charles' sons, Prince William and Prince Harry. Then comes Andrew, 30, then Beatrice. The queen's unmarried youngest son, Edward, 26, is now seventh in line of succession. Her 39-year-old daughter Anne, the Princess Royal, is eighth and has a son and daughter, Peter and Zara, who are ninth and 10th.

DOC.HEAD: Democratic Study Faults Administration's Defense Budget
DOC.TEXT: A Democratic study says Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's proposal to close military bases as a cost-saving measure is an attempt to divert attention from an inflated defense budget. The report released Friday criticized the Bush administration for its $307 billion fiscal 1991 defense budget that increases spending over last year, including money for strategic weapons such as the B-2 stealth bomber. ``In the face of dramatic changes in the external threat faced by the United States, the president has proposed nominal growth in defense spending for not only the coming year but for the foreseeable future,'' the Democratic Study Group said in its report. The Pentagon has argued that the budget fails to keep pace with the 2.1 percent increase in inflation. The study faults Cheney for requesting new legislation to close military facilities, thus ending the congressional oversight of Pentagon decisions on the bases and bypassing the recent process in which an independent commission recommended which bases to close. Complicating matters was Cheney's January announcement of the candidates for closure or realignment before the department had completed its review, the study said. ``The administration's alternative process involves listing bases being `considered' for closing long before final decisions are made _ thereby creating maximum opportunity for full-blown lobbying campaigns against possible cutbacks,'' the study said. Cheney's recommendations called for closing or scaling back more than 72 domestic facilities and 14 overseas installations. Members of Congress, including Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, have criticized Cheney's list as partisan. The defense secretary has declined to give exact figures on the savings from the base closings. The study, ``The Great Base Closing Ploy: Creating A Political Tempest to Shield A Bloated Defense Budget,'' said that 19 of 21 proposed base closings are in Democratic districts. ``Of the 41,638 civilian jobs affected by the closings, 41,139 or 99 percent were in Democratic districts,'' the report said. The Pentagon, in response to the partisan charge, noted that Democrats are the majority party in the House.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Legislators passed a resolution in memory of a former colleague, only to learn that former House member William Longworth was still alive. At the request of state Rep. Larry Giordano, the House adjourned Thursday with a resolution honoring Longworth, a legislator from 1949 to 1968. Rep. Joseph N. Hermann, who presided over the session, said he was surprised to hear his friend was dead, since he'd spoken to Longworth about a week ago. When he got home Thursday night, Hermann called Longworth's home to offer his condolences to Mrs. Longworth. ``Would you like to talk to Billy?,'' Mrs. Longworth asked. ``Here he is.'' Hermann said he told Longworth: ``You're supposed to be dead.'' Longworth, 75, joked Friday that he had been reincarnated. ``I got a kick out of it,'' he said. Giordano said he filed the resolution after read an obituary of a relative of Longworth and thinking it was the former lawmaker. ``Larry's intent was tremendous,'' Hermann said. ``Larry's a big-hearted man. He thought he was doing the right thing.''

DOC.HEAD: Senators Urge Alcohol Testing of Pilots
DOC.TEXT: Two senators are urging Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner to move quickly to require random alcohol testing of airline pilots and other transportation workers. ``There is no excuse for pilots drinking and flying,'' Sen. Ernest Hollings, D-S.C., and John Danforth, R-Mo., said in a letter to Skinner on Friday, citing the March 8 arrest of a Northwest Airlines cockpit crew. Legislation sponsored by the pair that would require random alcohol tests has been passed by the Senate but remains bottled up in the House Public Works Committee. ``We urge you to exercise the full extent of your authority to ensure that an incident such as that which occurred March 8th on Northwest Airlines never happens again,'' the senators wrote. The Transportation Department is reviewing comments it solicited from November through March 9 on alcohol testing before proposing a specific program, said Hal Paris, a department spokesman. DOT issued rules last November for testing transportation workers for drugs. The three-man Northwest crew flew a Boeing 727 with 91 passengers from Fargo, N.D., to Minneapolis on March 8 while legally intoxicated, investigators say. All three were all fired by the airline and charged by federal and state officials with operating an aircraft while under the influence of alcohol.
DOC.HEAD: HHS Proposes New Regulations on Mentally Ill and Retarded
DOC.TEXT: New regulations proposed by the Department of Health and Human Services would put the burden on states to ensure that the mentally ill and mentally retarded get appropriate care in nursing homes. The proposal Friday would put into effect a law passed by Congress in 1987 requiring states to set up programs to screen nursing home applicants and find more appropriate placements for mentally ill and mentally retarded applicants who do not need nursing facility care. Another proposed regulation would require nursing homes to meet new training and competency standards for nurse aides. The screening requirement took effect Jan. 1, 1989, although no regulations were in place. The Health Care Financing Administration notified state Medicaid directors at the time that compliance was required, and provided preliminary guidance to the states. Failure of a nursing home to meet the terms of the screening requirement could result in its termination from the Medicaid program. The proposed rule outlines the specific details of the preadmission screening programs and requires an annual review of current nursing home residents with mental illness and retardation.
DOC.HEAD: Consumer Group Contends $100 Million in Mental Health Funds
DOC.TEXT: Squandered

A federal program to provide community mental health services to the poor and uninsured has failed because up to $100 million was squandered building for-profit hospitals with swimming pools and tennis courts, a consumer group charges. Half of 575 community mental health centers funded under the program are violating federal regulations that require them to be non-profit, to provide certain essential services and to make some services available to the poor, Public Citizen Health Research Group said Friday. ``One of the most visible consequences of the failed program has been a significant increase in the number of seriously mentally ill homeless and an increase in the number of mentally ill persons in jails and prisons,'' the group's report said. ``The Community Mental Health Centers program has been an abysmal failure.'' A report by the House Government Operations subcommittee on human resources and intergovernmental relations chaired by Rep. Ted Weiss, D-N.Y., said its investigation has revealed the same kinds of violations. Weiss called for a General Accounting Office investigation to determine the extent of the problem. And the inspector general of the Department of Health and Human Services is beginning an investigation in response to a request by HHS Undersecretary Constance Horner, a spokeswoman for the inspector general said. Alan Leshner, deputy director of the National Institute of Mental Health, said officials are aware of problems with the program and 10 months ago began to take steps to correct them.

DOC.HEAD: Hazelwood Lawyers Call Sentence Excessive
LaserPhoto AG1
DOC.TEXT: Joseph Hazelwood's attorney accused the judge of ``Hazelwood bashing'' in ordering the Exxon Valdez's ex-skipper to pay $50,000 and help clean beaches fouled when his tanker hit a reef a year ago today. Hazelwood's lawyers said the 1,000 hours of community service ordered Friday by Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone are excessive and the amount in restitution is illegal and arbitrary punishment for a single misdemeanor conviction for negligence. Defense attorney Thomas Russo accused Johnstone of playing to the media and trying to override the jury's verdict Thursday that absolved Hazelwood of more serious intoxication and recklessness charges. During sentencing, the judge denounced Hazelwood for drinking before his ship sailed and for being off the bridge when it went aground and caused the nation's worst oil spill. ``This is another instance of Hazelwood bashing,'' Russo said, ``and in light of the jury verdict this type of demagoguery should stop.'' He said 90 percent of Johnstone's comments were directed at issues that the jury had already decided. He said if blame is to be leveled, people should begin looking at the Coast Guard, oil companies and the state itself. ``The judge's speech, which in my mind was designed for the media, was out of step with reality,'' he said. ``To continue this notion that Captain Hazelwood bears all the responsibility for what happened in Prince William Sound is ridiculous. It's got to end.'' As he imposed the sentence, Johnstone said: ``This isn't a run-of-the-mill misdemeanor.'' The judge said he wanted to quell public outrage, something Hazelwood attorney Michael Chalos said he had seen little of. ``Whatever outrage I've seen was directed at larger entities,'' Chalos said. The judge's sentence also met with the disapproval of the jury forewoman, Lori Wing, who was in the courtroom with four other jurors. ``I had high hopes he would walk out of here a free man and get on with his life,'' she said. Johnstone, sounding angry, said he had hoped the 43-year-old skipper would make a public apology. But lawyers said they advised Hazelwood of Huntington, N.Y., to stay silent because of more than 100 civil lawsuits still facing him. Johnstone also imposed the maximum 90 days in jail and $1,000 fine but suspended that sentence. He suggested that imprisoning Hazelwood would not restore the environment, but having him clean beaches might help. ``I think Captain Hazelwood has been deterred,''' he said in shunning jail time. ``It's very unlikely he would be given the opportunity to operate another tanker. He has suffered shame. ``But there is community outrage and something has to be done to provide condemnation and reaffirmation. I'm sure deep down he is very shameful.'' Hazelwood's attorneys said they thought the sentence would be overturned on appeal, in part because the order to pay restitution to the state was illegal. Dick Madson, another lawyer for Hazelwood, said that in almost any crime a judge can assess an amount that goes to the victim but it partially must be based on the defendant's financial status. Defense attorneys said Johnstone chose an arbitrary figure without measuring Hazelwood's ability to pay. A 12-member jury found Hazelwood guilty Thursday of a misdemeanor charge of negligent discharge of oil. But he was acquitted of three more serious charges, including a felony, that he was reckless and drunk during the disaster that blackened the rocky shoreline of Prince William Sound. Hazelwood faced a maximum 7\ years and $61,000 fine on all four charges. The judge acknowledged that pending litigation might delay Hazelwood's arrival at Prince William Sound. But he said if the cleanup there is finished by the time appeals are resolved, then Hazelwood could do other environmental work. The Exxon Valdez, a 987-foot tanker, ran aground on March 24, 1989, and gushed nearly 11 million gallons of oil into the pristine sound. It killed countless birds, fish and wildlife in the scenic area.

DOC.HEAD: Important Events in Struggle of Nicaraguan Rebels
With PM-Nicaragua,Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Important events in the conflict between Nicaragua's governing Sandinistas and the U.S.-supported Contra rebels: _July 19, 1979: The Sandinista National Liberation Front enters Managua, two days after dictator Anastasio Somoza flees. _November 1980: First attacks by anti-Sandinistas who become known as Contras, short for the Spanish word for counterrevolutionary. _February 1981: Reagan administration suspends aid to the leftist Sandinistas. _November 1982: First reports emerge of covert U.S. aid to the Contras. _April 6-7, 1984: Commandos operating from U.S. ships plant mines in Nicaraguan ports. _April 9: Nicaragua asks the World Court to order the United States to stop helping the Contras. The Reagan administration refuses to recognize the court's jurisdiction. _May 1, 1985: Reagan announces trade embargo against Nicaragua. _June 27: The World Court says U.S. support of the Contras violates the U.N. charter's ban on use of force. _June 25, 1986: House approves $100 million in military and humanitarian aid to Contras. _Aug. 13: The U.S. Senate approves military aid package. _Oct. 5: An American-manned cargo plane is shot down over Nicaragua. Surviving crew member Eugene Hasenfus is captured and implicates the CIA in Contra-supply operations. Hasenfus is subsequently freed. _Nov. 25: U.S. Attorney General Edwin Meese says some profits from the sale of American arms to Iran were secretly diverted to the Contras in an operation under Marine Lt. Col. Oliver North. _Aug. 7, 1987: Five Central American presidents sign a regional peace plan that calls for an end to foreign aid for irregular forces and prohibits one country from allowing its territory to be used by guerrillas to attack another country. _Feb. 3, 1988: Congress cuts off military aid to the Contras but continues other aid. _April 1, 1988: A formal 60-day truce begins following first direct meeting between Sandinistas and Contras. _May 31: The Sandinistas decide to extend the cease-fire on a month-to-month basis; the Contras say they consider the truce indefinite. Fighting slackens. _September: Contra-Sandinista talks break down; thousands of Contra guerrillas begin moving out of the Nicaraguan hinterland into base camps in Honduras. _Feb. 14, 1989: Five Central American presidents agree the Contras should be demobilized. In exchange, Ortega agrees to free and fair elections in 1990. _April 28: President Bush signs a $49 million non-lethal aid package for the Contras that will run out three days after the 1990 elections. _Aug. 7: The Central American presidents formalize the demobilization accord, asking the United Nations and the Organization of American States for help. But the rebels are not signatories to the pact, which says demobilization must be ``voluntary.'' _Aug. 26: Contra Commander Israel Galeano says the rebels will ignore the demobilization accord and U.S. advice and starts moving his troops back to Nicaragua. _Nov. 1: Ortega lifts the 19-month-old cease-fire after several attacks and the infiltration of thousands of Contra troops. Fighting surges briefly. _Dec. 12: Ortega and four Central American presidents issue a communique calling for the demobilization of both the Salvadoran guerrillas and the Contras. _Feb. 25, 1990: Elections monitored by thousands of international observers are held. Ortega suffers a stunning upset at the hands of a nation weary of war and economic ruin. _Feb. 27: The Sandinistas say the Contras have to demobilize before they will hand over control of the police and armed forces. President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro calls on the Contras to disband, saying the elections mean there is no reason to keep on fighting. _March 8: Ortega warns that thousands of armed Sandinista supporters will rise up in arms if the Contras don't lay down their arms. _March 13: President Bush lifts the economic embargo and asks Congress for $300 million in aid, including $45 million to demobilize and relocate the Contras. _ Friday: The Contras agree to disband their 12,000 troops in Honduran base camps and say the 4,000 fighters in Nicaragua will move into secure zones monitored by the United Nations and Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo.

DOC.HEAD: Study Says Hydrogen Could Explode In Nuke Waste Tanks
DOC.TEXT: Some nuclear waste storage tanks at the Hanford nuclear reservation could explode and spew radiation into the air because of hydrogen gas building up inside them, a new federal study says. Experts don't fully understand the danger, but don't believe an explosion is imminent, a Department of Energy official said in announcing the study results Friday. Gas buildup in the tanks, which hold waste from the processing of plutonium for nuclear weapons, was first noticed in 1977. ``The worst case is any explosion that could cause the dome to collapse and send the contents up to the air,'' Hanford manager Mike Lawrence said. ``I can't sit here and say it's not going to happen.'' Department officials think the danger of explosion is low, and the potential for release of radioactive material even lower, Lawrence said. That's because the tanks are made of 1{-foot-thick steel-reinforced concrete and are buried as much as 8 feet deep. Hydrogen is accumulating in 20 of Hanford's 169 storage tanks, Lawrence said. The gas is formed by the breakdown of organic material added to the tanks in the 1970sin an effort to recover radioactive strontium, Lawrence said. ``We've taken every precaution we can think of, but I can't give you an absolute guarantee,'' Lawrence said. ``This is something where we don't fully understand what is going on.'' No storage tank at Hanford has ever exploded, but a blast that spread radioactivity over a wide area in the Soviet Union in 1957 is believed to have been in a waste storage tank. A 1989 report by the Soviet news agency Tass said 10,000 people were evacuated after a 1957 explosion. The CIA has said deaths were in the hundreds, and analysts note that 30 central Soviet villages disappeared from maps after the disaster. The 560-acre Hanford reservation in southeast Washington dates back to the Manhattan Project of the 1940s that produced the first atomic bomb. While plutonium processing continues there, much of the work involves cleaning up waste produced over the last five decades. The danger came to light in a study by Westinghouse Hanford Co., the main Energy Department contractor at Hanford. The study was prompted by concerns raised in Congress late last year about the possibility of ferrocyanide exploding in the tanks. Although the ferrocyanide threat was ultimately found to be low, scientists discovered the hydrogen was a greater danger than had been previously thought, Lawrence said. Scientists hope to produce a plan for dealing with the problem by June. Meanwhile, precautions are being taken with the one tank in which the problem is worst: All transfers of waste in or out of the tank have been stopped, and care is taken to avoid generating heat or sparks nearby. That tank is one of Hanford's 20 newer double-walled storage tanks, and holds 1 million gallons of radioactive waste. The waste level has risen and fallen by as much as 33 inches because of hydrogen gas buildup, Lawrence said. Hydrogen concentration in the tank has been measured at up to 5 percent at an exhaust vent, and may have been higher down near the source. A 5 percent hydrogen buildup is considered potentially flammable, and an 18 percent buildup is considered potentially explosive, Lawrence said. The waste rise was first noticed in 1977, and scientists since 1984 have tried various methods to reduce the gas, including injecting water into the waste slurry and lancing the surface crust with pipes to relieve pressure. Those measures failed, Lawrence said. Lesser hydrogen buildup also has been spotted in four other double-shell tanks, and in 15 of the reservation's 149 older single-walled storage tanks, Lawrence said.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Patrol Bogota, Election Delay Sought Following Shooting
DOC.TEXT: Three political parties sought to delay May's presidential election following the assassination of a leftist candidate. Soldiers patrolled the capital following rioting sparked by the killing. In a statement sent to local media, the godfather of Colombia's drug traffickers, Pablo Escobar, denied government accusations he ordered Thursday's slaying of Bernmardo Jaramillo of the Patriotic Union Party. The government dismissed the denial. Shortly after Jaramillo's slaying, Colombians took to the streets of Bogota, shattering windows and burning buses to protest what they said was government involvement. Jaramillo was the 1,044th Patriotic Union member to be killed in the past six years and many slayings have been atttributed to right-wing death squads. The Patriotic Union has claimed Colombia's army and police are involved in the death squads to quell a leftist insurgency. Jaramillo was the second presidential candidate slain in recent months. The capital was quiet Friday but armored cars with 20mm cannons and jeeps mounted with machine guns cruised the city of 6 million people. The government banned alcohol sales and closed all private schools in Bogota. The president of the Patriotic Union, Diego Montana, said in a televised interview Friday his party was withdrawing from the presidential elections. The Patriotic Union, Conservative and Communist parties all asked the governing Liberal Party of President Virgilio Barco to postpone the May 27 elections, saying they feared for the safety of their candidates. Shortly after Jaramillo's slaying, a telephone caller who claimed the assassination for the Medellin cocaine cartel said drug traffickers were renewing their war with the government. The caller also said Cesar Gaviria, the Liberal Party candidate, would be the next victim. On Jan. 18, traffickers declared a unilateral cease-fire in a 5-month-old war with the government. They appealed for the government to stop extraditing suspects to the United States. The government war began following the assassination of Sen. Luis Carlos Galan on Aug. 18. Hours after Galan's death, Barco began efforts to extradite drug barons to the United States. In Colombia, traffickers often intimidate or bribe judges to ensure light or no sentences. The protests in Bogota began when Jaramillo was slain at Bogota's international airport Thursday. A 16-year-old youth, who reportedly received $750 for the killing, was wounded and captured, but three other attackers apparently escaped. Unrest continued into the pre-dawn hours Friday in poorer neighborhoods of the capital. Bursts of submachine gun fire from snipers in one neighborhood killed a soldier, the army said. Four policemen and a civilian were wounded. Later Friday, police cleared streets of roadblocks made from the burned vehicles and burning tires. In central Barrancabermeja, the site of Colombia's main oil refinery, workers of the state oil company Ecopetrol reacted to the assassination by staging a 48-hour walkout. Another 48-hour strike was declared in the northwestern region of Uraba, where Jaramillo began his political career. On Friday, Escobar sent a letter to Colombian news media denying his complicity. He suggested other drug traffickers were to blame, according to the Colombian radio networks RCN and Caracol. But on Friday, the National Security Council reiterated that Escobar, head of the Medellin cartel, ordered Jaramillo's assassination. A communique from the council said security forces monitored a telephone call in which Escobar ordered the assassination. The unidentified youth captured after Jaramillo's slaying said he was hired in Medellin to kill the candidate, but investigators said he would not say who hired him.

DOC.HEAD: Maryland Voters Won't Get Abortion Law; Guam Measure Delayed
DOC.TEXT: A complicated legislative compromise to put abortion before Maryland voters apparently has been derailed, and a federal judge on Guam temporarily blocked the U.S. island territory's new abortion law, the nation's strictest. Either the Guam law or a less stringent measure awaiting the governor's signature in Idaho could be the vehicle to challenge the U.S. Supreme Court's landmark 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision that legalized abortion. The Maryland measure, which emerged from the state Senate after an eight-day filibuster by anti-abortion forces, was rejected Friday by a House of Delegates committee. The unusual arrangement would have required the legislature to pass two measures: one permitting unrestricted access to abortions during the early stages of pregnancy, the other restricting abortion to cases of rape, incest or dire threat to the mother. In essence, the voters, through referendum, would have decided between the two measures. Legislators who advocate abortion rights generally opposed the compromise, while anti-abortion lawmakers favored putting the issue before the electorate. ``We think the process would be far too confusing for voters,'' said Delegate Patricia R. Sher, a Democrat who supports a woman's right to choose abortion. Abortion-rights forces, she added, feared the amount ``of money that the churches would bring in here would be awesome.'' Democratic Sen. Francis X. Kelly, a leading abortion foe and one of 16 senators who mounted the filibuster, noted that the group's original goal _ to block the abortion-rights bill _ was met. ``I can't say I'm unhappy,'' Kelly said, ``But from the experience, I believe the voters should decide. It's a shame the voters won't be able to.'' The House Environmental Matters Committee voted 13-12 against the package Friday night. The measure could be revived on the House floor, but that was considered unlikely because of House Democratic leadership opposition. In Agana, Guam, U.S. District Judge Alex Munson issued a temporary restraining order Friday blocking enforcement of the territory's new law, a few hours after residents and medical groups filed a class-action lawsuit. He scheduled a hearing for Monday on whether to extend his order. Guam's law, which Gov. Joseph Ada signed this week, prohibits abortions except when a pregnancy endangers the life of the mother. It makes it a felony to perform abortion or aid in the procedure, and a misdemeanor for a woman to solicit or have an abortion, or for a person to solicit a woman to have an abortion. It provides for a referendum Nov. 6 for voters to decide whether to retain the law. The lawsuit alleges the measure violates constitutional guarantees of privacy, due process, free speech, equal protection and religious freedom. Also Friday, Idaho Gov. Cecil Andrus was the target of a brief sit-in by high-school students demanding he veto an abortion bill approved by the legislature Thursday. The measure, the strictest yet approved by a state legislature, would ban abortion except in cases of non-statutory rape reported within seven days, incest if the victim is younger than 18, severe fetal deformity or threat to the mother's life or health. Andrus, an opponent of abortion, hasn't said if he intends to sign the bill. Abortion-rights groups in California, Michigan, Wisconsin, Rhode Island and North Carolina have threatened to boycott Idaho potatoes if Andrus fails to veto the bill.

DOC.HEAD: Li Zhen, China's First Woman General, Dies At 83
DOC.TEXT: Li Zhen, a Long March veteran and Communist China's first woman general, has died, an official newspaper said today. She was 83.
