The China Daily said Li died March 11 but gave no cause of death. President Yang Shangkun and ranking military officers paid last respects to her at a ceremony Thursday, the newspaper said. Li was promoted to major general in 1955 and until 1988 was the only woman general in the People's Liberation Army, the China Daily said. The 3.5 million- member army is now believed to have four women generals. Official biographies say she was born in Liuyang, Hunan province and given away by her parents at age 6. In 1926, she fled from her husband and joined the Communist Party, and the next year participated in the Autumn Uprising in Hunan, Mao Tse-tung's first attempt to lead peasants in a rebellion against local authorities. She took part in the 1934-35 Long March, the Red Army's epic escape from the ruling Nationalists to northern China, and held various political positions in the army. The Communists defeated the Nationalists and took power in China in 1949. She served as director of the Political Department of the Chinese military force in Korea during the 1950-53 Korean War.

DOC.HEAD: Alaska Governor and Coast Guard Collide on Spill Effects
With PM-Hazelwood Trial, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Cleanup crews are gearing up for a second season of trying to erase the signs of the nation's worst oil spill, but there's little agreement on just what needs to be done. Alaska Gov. Steve Cowper, who toured Prince William Sound, spoke Friday of deformed herring eggs and streams bereft of young salmon. But Coast Guard Commandant Adm. Paul Yost, in his own news conference Friday, disputed the governor's gloomy assessment of the damage wrought by spill from the grounded Exxon Valdez a year ago today. Yost said he learned from his own visit to four heavily oiled shores this week that cleanup still is needed. But he said Exxon's 1989 efforts and the effects of winter storms and waves made a ``major, major difference.'' ``There is a tremendous improvement in the situation,'' Yost said. For its part, Exxon Corp. is proposing a cleanup _ smaller than last year's $2 billion effort _ that the state considers inadequate. Cowper told reporters: ``There is a lot of cleanup work left to do this summer.'' ``The indications are that there is biological damage. We hope it isn't long-term,'' said Cowper, who on Thursday visited shores blackened when the Exxon Valdez ran aground on Bligh Reef and spilled nearly 11 million gallons of Alaska crude. Cowper released preliminary data from the state Department of Environmental Conservation that suggests damage to salmon and herring fisheries in some streams that enter the sound. At one heavily polluted site, a normally rich salmon stream on Latouche Island, ``not a single small salmon exists this spring,'' Cowper said. Though results of the state data are not definitive, he said, ``it indicates that the oil in the substrata killed whatever was there.'' The governor also said 90 percent of the herring roe at another site have shown aberrations. Dramatic measures may be required in this summer's cleanup program to save the fisheries and other resources, Cowper said. Yost said he doubts the existence of state biological data mentioned by Cowper. If the state is holding ``secret'' data it should be released immediately, he said. Cleanup is scheduled to begin May 1, after the Coast Guard determines on a ``mile-by-mile basis'' what kind of treatment will be required this year, Yost said. The Coast Guard has final say on details of cleaning an estimated 120 miles of shore affected by the spill. Exxon contends it should use less intrusive measures than it did in last year's effort, which depended on such drastic techniques as blasting oil-fouled rocks with hot water or steam. Oil-eating bacteria are a possible weapon, company officials have said. Cowper said he would urge more intrusive techniques _ including such unproven tactics as bulldozing shorelines _ if they get rid of the oil and allow micro-organisms and other life to re-colonize the fouled areas.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``We're not afraid, but we don't know what they want, and we don't know what they will do in the next few hours.'' _ Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimeira Prunskeine after about 100 Soviet military vehicles rumbled through the Lithuanian capital of Vilnius.

``Those who lose our primaries must reject the temptation to cling to a sense of personal injury and defeat. They must unite behind the party's candidate.'' _ Virginia Gov. L. Douglas Wilder, discussing how all Democrats must strongly support the party's presidential nominee in 1992.

``This is an accord that recognizes a national consensus and this national consensus that will put an end to the war and bring peace to Nicaragua.'' _ Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega, whose Sandinistas have fought the rebels for nine years, upon the announcement that the Contras have agreed to disband.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil's President Softens Harsh Economic Reforms
DOC.TEXT: President Fernando Collor de Mello softened harsh anti-inflation measures that have almost paralyzed the economy, lifting restrictions on bank withdrawals for some poorer Brazilians and charities. Collor announced the adjustments just one day after saying his measures, which threatened to plunge the nation of 150 million into recession, were ``not negotiable.'' In his announcement Friday, he maintained the basic structure of the 8-day-old plan, which includes an 18-month freeze on savings account withdrawals of more than $1,200 and a limit on money market withdrawals to $600. The emergency measures froze $115 billion in savings. The president appealed to Brazilians to save and warned spending could lead to higher annual inflation, now at 2,700 percent. ``We have begun slowly to open the tap and irrigate the economy,'' Collor said in a nationally televised meeting with congressmen and Cabinet ministers. The adjustments announced Friday allow special bank withdrawals in certain cases, such as for retired people, recently laid-off workers, truckers, charities, union funds and farmers with employees to pay. It was not immediately clear whether any amount for additional withdrawals was specified. The freeze, which was maintained for the rest of the country, has caused a brutal shortage of cruzeiros, the local currency. Sales at stores and restaurants have plummeted, and businesses have begun laying off employees. Collor urged Brazilians to ``just buy what is strictly necessary'' and avoid a spending boom, which would cause prices to rise. ``Prices are falling because there aren't enough cruzeiros in the marketplace,'' he said. ``Don't spend money on superfluous items _ bargain, bargain, bargain, and make your money go farther.'' The Mar. 16 plan froze prices for a month and guaranteed a wage increase in March of 73 percent, equal to February inflation. The cost of living in March is expected to reach 85 percent. The president also appealed to businessmen not to fire workers and implied banks could face retaliation if they don't cooperate more ``vigorously'' with the plan. Collor predicted that ``in 30 or 45 days inflation will be totally under control.'' According to some union estimates, more than 30,000 workers were fired in the past week. Hardest hit were construction workers, including some 19,000 let go in the southern state of Parana alone. In Sao Paulo, Brazil's biggest city and financial center, federal police arrested four executives of the Eldorado supermarket for raising prices despite the freeze. A poll conducted in Brazil's 10 largest cities published Friday in the Folha de Sao Paulo newspaper showed 81 percent of the population supported the measures. Only 5 percent opposed them. The 26 economic reform measures became law immediately but can be repealed by Congress within 30 days. The reforms also included drastic spending cuts to eliminate a budget deficit, higher taxes for the rich and a new currency. Collor said he would limit payments on the $115 billion foreign debt this year to just $5 billion, about half last year's total.

DOC.HEAD: Residents Battle Police in Protest of Gas Leak, 42 Injured
DOC.TEXT: More than 500 protesters battled police, demanding the closure of a wastewater treatment plant that leaked chlorine gas, police and witnesses said today. Forty-two people were reported injured. A gas leak from the plant in southern Taiwan Thursday sent 540 area residents to the hospital. Chlorine can be lethal in high concentrations but otherwise causes burning eyes and sore throats. Before the clash, irate protesters punched the plant manager and forced him to inhale from the leaky gas tank, the mass-circulation China Times reported. He required medical treatment, the report said. During a 30-minute battle Friday night, protesters hurled rocks and bricks at police, who fought back with clubs, witnesses said on condition of anonymity. Angry protesters also smashed a police van, they said. In all, 42 people were injured in the clash, police said. Witnesses said the clash was touched off when 800 policemen in full riot gear tried to prevent the protesters from entering the Kaohsiung wastewater treatment plant, 215 miles south of Taipei. After the battle, several protesters sneaked into the plant and turned off equipment, triggering another clash with police who tried to stop them, witnesses said. The residents' demand to shut down the plant was rejected by Kaohsiung Mayor Su Nan-cheng, who said without it the city's industrial wastewater would have to be discharged into rivers. Protest leader Chen Han-sheng and a policeman were hospitalized in serious condition with head injuries. Twenty policemen were among those treated for minor injuries and released from hospitals, police said. The mayor told 300 residents gathered outside the plant today that authorities had taken measures to stop the gas leak. The crowd dispersed after he agreed to discuss other demands, including calls for lower taxes, and health insurance and other compensation.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rejects Much of $150 Million Xerox Lawsuit Against Apple
DOC.TEXT: A judge rejected most of a Xerox Corp. lawsuit contending that Apple Computer Inc. pirated the screen display responsible for much of the popularity of its revolutionary Macintosh personal computer. Xerox said it would appeal Friday's ruling by U.S. District Judge Vaughn Walker. The $150 million lawsuit, filed in December, alleged that Apple derived the software for its Lisa and Macintosh computers from Xerox computer programs. The lawsuit alleged that Steven Jobs, co-founder of Apple, had seen a demonstration of a Xerox program called Smalltalk at Xerox's Palo Alto Research Center in 1979, and that he and other Apple employees copied the concept. Jobs left Apple in 1985. Smalltalk was the first computer language to use a mouse, a small, hand-held device used to manipulate information on a computer screen. Since then, most personal computer makers have adopted the mouse and so-called windows programs that let the average person operate a personal computer without learning complicated, typed-in commands. Instead, they use the mouse to move a pointer around the screen and execute commands. Vaugh dismissed five of six counts in the Xerox lawsuit. The dismissed counts involved allegations of unfair competition and attempts to have Apple copyrights invalidated. The only remaining count sought a declaratory judgment stating that Xerox owns the copyright to its Star program, one of those it accuses Apple of pirating. In a news release from its Stamford, Conn., headquarters, Xerox said: ``This ruling does not mean Apple has not taken substantial portions of Star and claimed them as their own. The court merely held, we believe erroneously, that Xerox did not have standing to present facts in support of that contention. ... We intend to appeal.'' From Apple's Cupertino headquarters, spokeswoman Carleen LeVasseur responded: ``We welcome the ruling in every way. I'm confident that the sole remaining issue will be dismissed in the near future.'' Referring to the remaining accusation, LeVasseur said, ``Apple has never disputed the validity of Xerox's registration.'' Apple responded at the time of the lawsuit that Xerox's concepts weren't protected by copyright any more than birds or trees were protected by the copyright on a painting. The lawsuit said Xerox had never licensed Apple to use the Star computer program or its graphics. It also accused Apple of gaining unauthorized access by hiring several Xerox employees in the late 1970s and early 1980s, including Star software developers. The lawsuit claimed Apple employees saw the Star program at the trade show in Houston in June 1981 and copied substantial portions into its Lisa and Macintosh Finder.

DOC.HEAD: Car Loaded With Explosives Explodes Outside Economy Ministry
DOC.TEXT: A car packed with explosives blew up as it passed the Economy Ministry, killing the driver and wounding six passers-by, including a policeman, a mother and her 6-month-old baby, police said. Police said no group took responsibility for the bombing Friday, but the leftist Shining Path rebels have stepped up attacks in recent days. Police blame them for the assassinations of four congressional candidates in five days, including one in Lima on Friday. The violence is aimed at undermining the government by sabotaging elections April 8. The unidentified motorist was driving along a busy avenue in downtown Lima late Friday and apparently intended to park the car before the ministry. But before he could stop, the vehicle exploded and struck another car. Six people nearby were wounded, including the driver of the second car, a policeman guarding the entrance to the ministry, and a woman and her 6-month-old baby. The political assassinations have prompted the government to declare a state of emergency in Lima and place national police on alert as additional security for the election. The government also announced Friday it was reimposing a state of emergency in nearby Callao. The Maoist Shining Path has been fighting Peru's elected governments since 1980. It launched its armed insurgency in the southern highlands, and now operates throughout the Andean region and in the jungles of the northeast. The government says more than 18,000 people have died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Estonian Communists Meet with Secession in Mind
With PM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Estonia's divided Communist Party is meeting with independence for their republic topping the agenda, but party leader Vaino Vyalyas is making it clear he intends a more cautious approach than Lithuania. In a report Friday to the party congress, he emphasized the need for party reform and support for Estonian independence according to his secretary, Nina Slavina, and Radio Moscow, but Vyalyas talked of negotiations with Moscow. Another major topic at the congress is a possibile party split with Moscow. The party heard a draft program which declared that the party supports ``the independence of the Estonian state on the basis of the free expression of the people's will, with due account for processes taking place in the Soviet Union and Europe,'' the Soviet news agency Tass reported. However, the program described the path to independence as ``an arduous and controversial process that requires ... legal foundation and the establishment of a solid economic and social basis.'' It said Estonian independence should ``proceed through negotiations between Estonia and the Soviet Union,'' Tass reported. Vyalyas chided the neighboring Baltic republic of Lithuania for its March 11 declaration of independence from Moscow. He said, in remarks monitored in London, that the Estonian Communist Party ``does not approve of all the political steps taken by the new Lithuanian parliament.'' Baltic states Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia were forcibly incorporated into the Soviet Union in 1940 following the signing of a pact between dictators Adolf Hitler of Nazi Germany and Josef Stalin of the Soviet Union in 1939. Moscow has not recognized Lithuania's independence declaration. Final results of Estonia's election on Sunday, made public Friday, indicated that the independence-minded People's Front won 46 of 105 seats in new legislature, Tass said. The front also enjoys support by some small parties. About 55 lawmakers also are members of the Communist Party, which embraces 106,000 of Estonia's 1.6 million people. The Communists are split, however, among People's Front supporters, backers of the Free Estonia movement, and followers of Russian-speaking groups. Tass said election results would make it hard for Estonians who want independence to get the two-thirds majority needed to push through a parliament decision on independence. Russian-speaking members strongly oppose such a move and can join with Free Estonia to block it, the agency said. Estonian activists, however, say they expect Free Estonia to support the independence drive with some reservations. Before the party congress, the Communist Party was split between those who wanted to cut off from Moscow, as Lithuania's Communists did in December, and those supporting the Moscow party platform. Ms. Slavina said a compromise proposal was submitted to the Congress. Tass said the draft program should unite all ``honest Communists'' wanting to contribute to the development of democratic Socialism in Estonia. It also said Estonia's Communist Party ``abandons the practice of administrative socialism and utopian models of the future.'' No details of the compromise proposal were immediately available. Radio Moscow said the congress was also to consider a draft resolution on the party's history, attributing its faults to its never having been independent. The resolution condemns ``the false policy and activity of the party'' that have had serious consequences for the Estonian people and the Estonian independence, and says the party, together with Moscow and party authorities there, ``bears responsibility for acts of force against the Estonian people.''

DOC.HEAD: Grand Jury Won't Charge Killer of Homeless Man
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Ptah is cq in 6th graf
DOC.TEXT: A grand jury declined to indict a man who fatally injured a homeless man in a subway platform brawl two months ago. ``I never meant to hurt that unfortunate man who attacked me,'' Rodney Sumter, 39, said at a news conference Friday after the grand jury's decision was released. ``I pray to God that he rests in peace.'' Sumter had said he was acting in self-defense to protect his 3-year-old son when the incident occurred Jan. 21. Witnesses said the homeless man verbally abused, spat on and punched Sumter. ``He has been vindicated,'' said Mel Sachs, Sumter's attorney. Sumter and his son Ptah, now 4, had been awaiting the train home after seeing a movie. Sumter initially was charged with first-degree manslaughter in the death despite a public outcry that the killing was justified. ``It is our policy to submit every homicide case to the grand jury for investigation,'' said Manhattan District Attorney Robert Morgenthau. ``This case underscores the vital function the grand jury plays in the criminal justice system.'' The homeless man, a regular denizen of the subway station, was never identified. He was buried Feb. 14 in an unmarked grave in Queens. The grand jury's decision was not condemned by advocates of the homeless. ``We're delighted that the grand jury has absolved Mr. Sumter, who is as much a victim as the homeless man who died,'' said Keith Summa of the Coalition for the Homeless.

DOC.HEAD: Indian Troops Complete Withdrawal From Sri Lanka
DOC.TEXT: The last Indian peacekeeping soldiers withdrew from Sri Lanka today after 30 months of a stalemated jungle war against Tamil guerrillas. A Sri Lankan naval band played ``Auld Lang Syne,'' and Sri Lankan soldiers unsheathed swords in a guard of honor for the departing Indians, who came to enforce an agreement supposed to end the guerrilla war. About 2,000 soldiers _ the last to be withdrawn from a force that once numbered 125,000 _ sailed from from the eastern city of Trincomalee for Madras, in southern India. ``You have made a great sacrifice, there is no doubt about that,'' Sri Lanka's defense minister, Ranjan Wijeratne, told the camouflage-uniformed troops. At least 1,155 soldiers died fighting guerrillas of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, the largest militant group demanding an independent Tamil nation. The Indian troops arrived in northern and eastern Sri Lanka in July 1987 under an India-Sri Lanka accord to disarm the Tamil Tigers and several other Tamil separatist militant groups. While most groups surrendered their arms, the Tamil Tigers reneged on the accord in October 1987 and turned their guns on the Indian soldiers who had once trained them. The Tigers claimed the provisions of the accord, which promised limited autonomy, did not meet their aspirations. As the jungle war continued, India sent more reinforcements. At one point about 125,000 soldiers patrolled the northeast. Last summer the new government of President Ranasinghe Premadasa reached an agreement with the Tigers and asked India to pull out its troops by July 29, 1989, the second anniversary of the peace accord. At that time, Indian forces controlled most of the larger towns in northern and eastern Sri Lanka, but the Tamil Tigers ran an effective underground movement from the dense jungles and swamps. New Delhi stalled on the withdrawal request for about six months, leading to diplomatic standoff between officials of the two countries. In January, after the new Indian government of Prime Minister V.P. Singh took office, India and Sri Lanka agreed on a March 31 deadline. The long stay brought severe criticism in both Sri Lanka and India. Many Indian newspapers said the troops were needlessly fighting ``somebody else's dirty war.'' ``We've been ordered to leave and that's what we are doing,'' said a commando at the Trincomalee dock, pushing back his red beret to wipe sweat from his forehead. ``We don't think we have lost a war. We're just obeying orders.'' Across the bay from where Magar sailed, Tamil Tigers patrolled Trincomalee's streets accompanied by Sri Lankan soldiers and police, the forces which desperately tried to put down the Tamil rebellion between 1983 until the Indians' arrival in 1987. In recent months, the Tamil Tigers have joined other groups in negotiations with the Sri Lankan government. Tamils, who make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, wanted to set up a separate homeland in the northern and eastern districts where most of the country's Tamils live. The Tamils claimed they were discriminated in jobs, education and the use of Sinhala language by the majroity Sinhalese. The predominantly Buddhist Sinhalese make up 75 percent of the population and control the government and the military. Tamils are mostly Hindus. Besides the Indian troop casualties, 10,000 Sri Lankans have died in the Tamil insurgency. In addition, the 1987 peace accord and the presence of Indian soldiers, sparked a backlash by chauvinist Sinhalese guerrillas that cost 6,000 lives since 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Human Rights Groups Urge Government to Protect Hijacking Suspect
DOC.TEXT: Human rights groups and lawyers called on the government today not to extradite a Chinese hijacking suspect to what they say could be his death in China. Zhang Zhenhai, who is being held for the Dec. 16 hijack of a Chinese airliner with 233 people aboard to Japan, is facing extradition despite his claim that he was fleeing persecution because of his political activism. The Air China Boeing 747, on a flight from Beijing to New York, flew to Fukuoka in western Japan after it was commandeered and was refused landing permission by South Korea. ``We will do everything we can in order to keep Mr. Zhang from being sent back to China,'' said Shoichi Kawaguchi, a member of the Foundation for Asian Human Rights. He said lawyers, university professors and groups supporting Asian workers and students are seeking ways to stop the government from repatriating Zhang. Zhang's trial on charges of air piracy opened Friday at the Tokyo High Court. The court must decide by April 22 whether to agree to a Chinese request that the 35-year-old man be sent back to China. Japanese authorities handed over Zhang's wife and young son to China within hours after the Chinese jetliner landed at Fukuoka, prompting public criticism that officials had not done enough to investigate whether they were leaving China for political reasons. In Friday's court session Zhang repeated statements he has made to investigators that he fled China to seek political asylum after he taking part in the pro-democracy movement in Beijing last spring. However, prosecutors told the court Zhang hijacked the aircraft to escape criminal charges in China and find work in Japan, the reports said. Court and Justice Ministry officials were not available for comment today because of the weekend holiday. The prosecutors said testimony from Zhang's wife and acquaintances provided by China said the defendant had never participated in anti-government activities. A coalition of groups including the National Christian Council of Japan and the Catholic Council for Justice and Peace have demanded the Justice Ministry and Tokyo High Court not repatriate Zhang and called for him to be tried in Japan. ``We are not saying the hijacker should be forgiven,'' the groups said in a statement. ``But Japan seems to be trying to repatriate Zhang without a full investigation into the case. Such an attitude raises questions from the standpoint of the constitution, international law and humanitarianism.'' Kazuyo Iwaki, one of three lawyers defending Zhang, has said Japanese officials should not assume that he will not be executed if he is extradited. The Chinese government has told Japan it will not execute Zhang.

DOC.HEAD: Xinjiang Officials Worried About Ethnic Trouble
DOC.TEXT: Leaflets calling for an end to Chinese rule have appeared in China's westernmost region, raising concern of ethnic violence, an official from the Xinjiang Autonomous Region said today. The sparsely populated desert region in China's northwest is home to 25 different minority groups _ including several large Moslem groups _ who account for 62 percent of Xinjiang's population. Amudun Niyazi, chairman of the Xinjiang People's Congress standing committee, told The Associated Press that there has been no violence in the region so far. But he said authorities recently have discovered handbills, leaflets and other materials ``instigating separatist activities'' circulating through the region, one of China's largest ethnic minority areas. Niyazi said most of the material has come from former Xinjiang residents now living overseas, but declined to provide other details. In the past few months, news reports from Xinjiang have hinted of ethnic trouble. Editorials and commentaries stressing the need for unity and stability and denouncing ``separatist'' activities have increased markedly. China violently imposed its rule on the region in the 1950s, slaughtering those who took part in anti-Chinese revolts. Since then, the ethnic groups have largely accepted Beijing's domination, although tensions remain and ethnic trouble has surfaced from time to time. The largest ethnic groups include the Moslem Uygur and Kazakh minorities, central Asian groups with close ties to people living across the border in the Soviet Union. In January, the region's armed police were ordered to intensify riot training and intelligence work as a prevention against unrest. Xinjiang's delegates to the National People's Congress, holding its annual session in Beijing this week, were earlier quoted by the Xinjiang Daily as saying, ``Currently, Xinjiang still has a small number of separatists, who present the greatest threat to Xinjiang's stability. ... We must be on the alert.'' The delegates called them ``the scum of the Chinese people'' and said they were carrying out their activities under the guise of advocating religious freedom and democracy. Xinjiang Communist Party Secretary Song Hanliang, who toured southern Xinjiang in February, told party members, ``Every place and (work) unit now has some `hot spot' problems,'' and urged them to ``handle the problem while it is still in the embryonic stage.'' In the early 1980s, there were sketchy reports of a series of anti-Chinese rebellions. In May, Moslems protesting a Chinese book that they said desecrated their religion stormed party headquarters in Urumqi. Official reports said 43 trucks were overturned and smashed and 150 policemen injured. One person was sentenced to life imprisonment for ``pillage'' and at least nine others received jail terms.

DOC.HEAD: CDC Pulls Registration Of 3 Monkey Importers Over Virus Scare
DOC.TEXT: The national Centers for Disease Control halted imports by three of the nation's largest monkey dealers effective today amid concerns over the spread of deadly Ebola virus in monkeys in at least two research centers. CDC Director William L. Roper said CDC inspectors had found ``inadequate'' isolation and quarantine conditions at the three suppliers this week. The concerns arose after Ebola virus _ known in pre-AIDS days as the deadliest virus in the world _ was spotted in the United States in November in three monkeys at the Hazleton supplier in Virginia. In January, an Ebola-related virus turned up in a monkey in a Pennsylvania laboratory. ``Humans can be infected but it's not very common,'' said Dr. Susan Fisher-Hoch of the CDC. Medical researchers and drug manufacturers on Friday urged Roper not to ban imported lab monkeys, saying that could set back efforts to find cures for AIDS and other serious diseases. Roper said in notices Thursday to Worldwide Primates of Miami, Charles River Primates Corp. of Port Washington, N.Y., and Hazleton Research Products Inc. of Reston, Va., that effective today, ``your registration to import non-human primates into the United States will be revoked.'' The three are among four importers who handle 90 percent of U.S. monkey imports, CDC officials said. The fourth supplier was inspected and found to be in compliance with CDC guidelines, and no action has been taken there. Dr. W.E. Tucker Jr. of the pharmaceutical giant Burroughs Wellcome Co. argued against a ban during a special CDC meeting. ``If a ban is put into effect it will seriously affect our efforts to develop agents to treat very serious diseases,'' he said. Monkeys often are used for AIDS research, and banning them could cut AIDS research by 50 percent, said Dr. Frederick King, director of the Yerkes Regional Primate Center in Atlanta. ``I'm for not throwing out the baby with the bath,'' King said. ``We must take all precautions ... but we must not needlessly sacrifice the research which depends on these primates,'' said Dr. Vance Gordon of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association.

DOC.HEAD: Three Killed In Christian Fighting
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces battled with howitzers and mortars north of Beirut early today, stirring fears of a new round of all-out fighting in the Christian enclave. Police said three people were killed and seven wounded in the fighting in Kesrouan province between Gen. Michel Aoun's troops and the Lebanese Forces militia led by Samir Geagea. The latest fighting raised the casualty toll since Aoun moved against Geagea Jan. 30 to at least 765 killed and 2,123 wounded, most of them civilians. Both sides accused each other of provoking the latest clashes, the most serious violation of a March 3 cease-fire in the 310-square-mile Christian enclave. The two armies had fought each other to a standstill before the cease-fire arranged by a three-man committee of neutral Christian mediators. Fears that a new flare-up was looming have been raised by the mediators' failure to work out a political settlement to end struggle for domination of the estimated 1 million Christians in the enclave. Tens of thousands have fled in recent weeks because of the fighting _ the bloodiest confrontation between Christian forces since the Christian-Moslem civil war erupted in April 1975. A police spokesman, who cannot be named under standing regulations, said a large-scale battle ``appears to be in the offing, especially if the mediation committee is unable to work out a settlement.'' That would mark another serious setback for an Arab League-brokered peace accord aimed at ending the nearly 15-year-old civil war. Syrian-backed President Elias Hrawi, elected Nov. 24 to implement the peace plan, has not been able to extend his authority in the Christian enclave because Aoun refuses to recognize him and rejects the accord. Beirut's independent An-Nahar daily quoted unidentified government sources as saying the United States has informed ``officials that Aoun must step down in favor of the legitimate authority'' of Hrawi. The report did not elaborate. But the United States, like all countries with which Lebanon maintains diplomatic relations, recognizes Hrawi as head of state. Aoun, 54, considers himself the sole legitimate authority in Lebanon. In September 1988, Aoun, the army commander, was named head of a caretaker military government by outgoing President Amin Gemayel before his six-year term expired with Parliament unable to elect a new head of state. Hrawi, a Maronite Catholic like Aoun and Geagea, sacked Aoun as army chief and interim prime minister in November. But Aoun has refused to quit either post. He considers Hrawi's election unconstitutional on the grounds that Parliament, elected in 1972 before the civil war began, is no longer representative of the nation. Aoun rejects the peace accord endorsed by Parliament in the Saudi Arabian resort of Taif in October because it does not guarantee the withdrawal of 40,000 Syrian troops from Lebanon. The Syrians entered Lebanon in 1976 under an Arab League peacekeeping mandate. Geagea recognizes the presidency and has made cautious signals welcoming the Taif accord.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Bias Throughout State Justice System
DOC.TEXT: Bias against women in the California justice system is often blatant, sometimes subtle, and apparent in the sharp contrast between the opinions of female and male judges, a state report found. The report released Friday said gender bias in the state would decline if the proportion of women judges increased above the current 13 percent _ a figure already nearly twice the national average. ``The gender bias that we have found in the judicial system reflects the society,'' said Los Angeles County Superior Court Judge David Rothman, co-chair of a state Judicial Council committee that produced the study. ``As judges we have an obligation to do something about it,'' he said. A theme common to many of the findings was ``the lack of credibility with which women are regarded in the courts,'' said Los Angeles County Superior Court Judge Judith Chirlin, vice-chair of the study. She said bias shows up in many ways: judges who call a male expert witness ``doctor'' but ask a woman with the same credentials whether she prefers ``Miss'' or ``Ms.'' Another tendency by many male judges is to doubt women's stories that their husbands beat them or molested their children. The report offered 65 recommendations, including simplifying and speeding up procedures for restraining orders against domestic violence, improving health care for female prisoners, and putting anti-bias provisions into the judges' code of conduct, the law school curriculum and the bar exam. The study was begun in 1986 by Chief Justice Rose Bird and continued by successor Malcolm Lucas after Bird's defeat in the 1986 election. The study cited a survey last year of 473 California judges that showed some sharp differences in attitudes between men and women on the bench. Forty percent of the male judges, but only 22 percent of the women, thought domestic violence cases should be dealt with by counseling instead of prosecution; 47 percent men but 75 percent women disagreed with a statement that domestic violence allegations were often exaggerated; 7 percent men but 45 percent women said they had heard other judges make remarks demeaning to women. Many of those comments were chronicled, most of them anonymously: a male judge who told a female lawyer not to try ``any of your feminine tricks ... any of your emotionalism,'' another who asked two women lawyers if they'd had a ``cat fight,'' others who invariably asked the woman in a group of lawyers if she could type up a settlement agreement. The study said demeaning comments were more likely to come from lawyers than judges. Committee members, speaking to reporters, also said individual remarks by judges, however shocking, were not as pervasive a problem as others covered by the report, such as the difficulties encountered by women in divorce courts, domestic violence cases and prisons. ``Most of the gender bias is institutionalized,'' Watson said. For example, she said, members visiting the main women's jail in Los Angeles County found pregnant women who had not seen a doctor for four months. They also said mothers awaiting trial for a year were not told where their children had been placed and were given only one change of underwear a week. Chirlin said another important finding was the low status, and relatively meager budgets, of family law courts. ``Any issues relating to families and kids are, quote, women's issues, and are seen as less important,'' she said. The report urges an increase in family court judges and a study of the adequacy of child support levels.

DOC.HEAD: 27 Injured in Emergency Escape From Airplane Leaking Fuel
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-seven people were injured today during the emergency evacuation of a Cathay Pacific Airways jet that began leaking fuel after landing at Tokyo's Narita airport, officials said. During the evacuation, the strong winds rocked the inflatable escape chutes, knocking the passengers to the ground, officials said. Of the 27 injured, three suffered broken leg or pelvic bones. All but one were released later today after treatment in a hospital, hospital officials said. Passengers said they heard a loud noise and felt a shock when Flight 508 from Hong Kong, with 300 people aboard, touched down in strong winds. The TriStar jet, made by Lockheed Corp., began leaking large amounts of fuel. It was halted as it taxied toward the gate and the decision was made to evacuate the passengers, police said. Airport officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the plane's left wing was damaged. The cause of the accident was being investigated, the officials said. Due to the strong winds, seven flights to Narita were diverted to Haneda, Tokyo's domestic airport, the officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Snow in the Midwest; Rain Down South
DOC.TEXT: A storm that moved across the Midwest today dumped more snow in Kansas and Missouri and threatened a winter redux in the Northeast. Snowfall accumulation early today had reached as much as 8 inches in northern Missouri and 7 inches in parts of central Kansas. Light snow also fell today south of Indianapolis, in southwestern Pennsyvania and in Cincinnati and Louisville, Ky. The storm front threatening southern Ohio was expected to bring up to 5 inches of snow overnight to West Virginia and between 2 and 4 inches to Philadelphia. Snow also was expected today in New York, New England and portions of South Dakota, Nebraska and Iowa. Elsewhere, unseasonably warm temperatures were expected to extend across the Southwest, and thunderstorms were to scatter over the southern Plains. Forecasters predicted highs today in the 80s and 90s in the Southwest and Florida, and in the 40s and 50s across much of the nation's midsection. Thunderstorms produced inch-thick hail near the Oklahoma towns of Mountain Park and Meers on Friday. In the Florida Panhandle, some of an estimated 2,500 evacuees began moving back to their flood-damaged homes on Friday as swollen rivers began receding. The flooding stemmed from torrential rains in Alabama and Georgia a week ago. The nation's high Friday was 97 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif. DOC.HEAD: CIA Official Says No Coverup in Iran-Contra
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 2nd graf to complete ref to Poindexter.
DOC.TEXT: A CIA employee says there was no attempt to cover up a missile shipment to Iran, only ``a great deal of confusion'' over the 1985 delivery of Hawk missiles central to the Iran-Contra affair. Norman Gardner testified on Friday that John Poindexter and William Casey, the late CIA director, did not orchestrate a false cover story about the U.S. government's role in the November 1985 shipment of 18 Hawk missiles. Poindexter, who was President Reagan's national security adviser at the time, is accused of conspiracy, obstructing Congress and making false statements by saying he didn't find out until January 1986 that Hawks had been delivered to Iran. Casey told Congress on Nov. 21, 1986, the same day as Poindexter's alleged lies, that the CIA had been asked by Israel to arrange to fly ``bulky cargo'' to Iran. The plane's crew, said Casey, was told it was oil drilling equipment. Casey and Poindexter had attended a meeting the previous day to go over Casey's upcoming congressional testimony. Gardner later reported to the White House on how Casey's appearance went on Capitol Hill. ``Did you tell Admiral Poindexter that the cover story wasn't holding up very well?'' Iran-Contra prosecutor Christian Mixter asked Gardner. ``No, I didn't,'' said Gardner, denying there was a false cover story. Gardner said that after much review in November 1986, it was determined that the CIA found out Hawk missiles were aboard the plane when the flight to Iran already was under way. ``The CIA shipped'' the missiles yet ``didn't know'' they were missiles? U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene asked. The missiles were being shipped from Israel, explained Gardner. ``But this was the CIA's airline,'' said Greene. ``That's right,'' replied Gardner. Hours after Poindexter briefed congressmen and Casey testified on Nov. 21, 1986, the national security adviser tore up a presidential document ratifying the Hawks delivery. The politically embarrassing document, called a finding, depicted the shipment as part of an arms-for-hostages deal. Neither Poindexter nor Casey had told Congress of the finding's existence. The CIA director sent it directly to Poindexter in November 1985 with instructions to keep it secret from anyone ``below our level,'' although by November 1986 Gardner knew of its existence, too. According to Gardner's notes of the meeting, Poindexter told House Intelligence Committee members that Reagan did not approve the shipment. Why didn't Gardner speak up and disclose the finding? asked Mixter. Because ``it was not done before the shipment,'' responded the CIA employee, explaining that it had been drafted a day or two after the missiles were delivered. Gardner, at the time special assistant to the agency's then-deputy director of operations, Clair George, is now the CIA's deputy director in the office of congressional affairs.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Meets With Federal Mediators, Declines to Reopen Talks
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound says it won't move to reopen talks with picketing drivers until the union tries to end strike-related violence. The union says the comments by Anthony P. Lannie, Greyhound vice president and the company's chief negotiator, are ``nothing more than a subterfuge to avoid going to the bargaining table.'' Lannie met for two hours Friday with Bernard E. DeLury, the director of National Mediation and Conciliation Service, but no new talks with the union were scheduled. ``We will not bargain with a gun pointed at us,'' Lannie said after the meeting. The mediation service said both sides were ``maintaining an ongoing dialogue'' with the agency and that there was a ``prospect of resuming negotiations in the near future.'' The company broke off talks last Sunday, accusing union leaders of failing to negotiate and of stepping up violence. ``We do not condone violence _ our position on that is clear,'' said Nick Nichols, a spokesman for the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions. Lannie said wages, job security and grievance procedures _ key issues in the strike _ did not come up in Friday's meeting as company officials and federal mediators focused on ways to end strike violence. Since the strike began March 2, 21 buses driven by replacement workers have been shot at and several more have been pelted with bricks and rocks, the company said. There were no serious injuries. The latest incident occurred Friday night in Tucson, Ariz., when a bus en route to El Paso was struck by one bullet as it crossed the picket line, said Greyhound spokeswoman Melanie Scofield. The bullet struck the windshield, she said. None of the 21 people aboard were injured. Scofield said the driver decided to maintain his schedule and did not report the shooting until he arrived in El Paso. Earlier Friday, a bus carrying 59 passengers was the target of a bow and arrow attack in Cleveland. No one was hurt. Also Friday, a striking driver was hit by a bus in Atlanta and was taken to a hospital for observation, Nichols said. More than 60 pickets have been struck by buses, hit by security guards or injured in other incidents over the three weeks, Nichols said. On the second day of thestrike, a veteran Greyhound driver was crushed to death on the picket line by a bus driven by a replacement in Redding, Calif. No charges were filed. Lannie said the union could join the company in offering rewards for information leading to the arrest of people responsible for the violence and urge union members to turn in anyone who commits an illegal act. ``The union has not cooperated with the authorities. They've not taken any affirmative action to bring this violence to a halt. To take a hands-off, we-don't-know-anything approach is absurd,'' Lannie said. Nichols said the union has told members it would support prosecution for those responsible for violence or property damage. ``As to putting bounties on people's heads, we believe that local law enforcement agencies are best trained and best equipped to investigate these matters,'' Nichols said. Nichols said negotiators representing the 6,300 drivers and an estimated 3,000 other Greyhound workers had hoped federal mediators could prod the company to resume talks. ``We can be there on an hour's notice,'' Nichols said. Both sides accused the other of skewing the figures on proposed wage increases. Greyhound said it's offering $63 million over three years, while the union wants $180 million. The union says it's asking for $40 million and charges that the company's proposal is not ``hard money'' because it is contingent on profit increases. Greyhound operates the only nationwide intercity bus service. The strike has affected many smaller communities for which buses are the only public transportation.

DOC.HEAD: Antarctic Expedition Leader Arrives in Minnesota
DOC.TEXT: The co-leader of a team that crossed Antartica by ski and dogsled told several hundred cheering fans welcoming him home that he was thrilled to return to ``your warm hearts.'' Co-leader Will Steger and the other five members of the International Trans-Antarctica Expedition arrived Friday night at Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport. The expedition had left the airport for Antarctica on July 26. It completed its 3,741-mile trek at Mirnyy on the Indian Ocean on March 3. The team also included co-leader Jean-Louis Etienne of France, Geoff Somers of Great Britain, Victor Boyarsky of the Soviet Union, Keizo Funatsu of Japan and Qin Dahe of China. On Friday night, a group of girls sang for the team and people in the crowd carried posters with ``Congratulations'' and ``Welcome Back'' written in French, English, Japanese, Russian and Chinese. Steger, of Ely, Minn., hugged his parents and then greeted 35 to 40 relatives before clasping hands with well-wishers. ``I can't tell you how thrilled we are to come back to Minnesota and your warm hearts,'' Steger said. ``The only thing that really kept us going was the love and prayers of the people back home. We are so thankful just to be alive.'' Steger said that he didn't learn about such events as the fall of the Berlin Wall for several weeks or, in most cases, until he arrived in Australia this month and read a magazine reviewing 1989. The team traveled to the Australian cities of Sidney and Perth, then to Paris and London before flying to Minneapolis. After festivities today on the lawn of the state Capitol, the team is scheduled to leave Sunday for Washington, D.C.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
An Wang, Founder Of Major Computer Firm, Dies After Long Cancer Battle.
LaserPhoto BX3
DOC.TEXT: An Wang, the slight, Chinese-born engineer whose development of a major computer firm was a classic American success story, died today at Massachusetts General Hospital after a long fight against cancer at age 70. Hospital spokesman Martin Bander said Wang died at 5:31 a.m. ``He was operated on originally on July 14 of last year for esophageal cancer, a very difficult form of cancer,'' Bander said. ``He was admitted to the Mass General cancer center on March 6 after suffering some setback.'' He began Wang Laboratories in 1951 above an electrical fixtures store in Boston with a work force of one: himself. Wang went on to develop the magnetic core, a small doughnut-shaped ring of iron that was the basic element of computer memory until the microchip was introduced in the late 1960s. A native of Shanghai, Wang was a schoolteacher's son who had come to the United States in 1945 and went to Harvard as a graduate student. When his firm began to grow quickly, Wang moved it northwest of Boston to Lowell. The growth of Wang Laboratories took off in 1964 after he introduced a desktop calculator and began development of office computers. Once rated the fifth-richest man in America, Wang spread jobs to other areas and the company now has about 23,000 employees worldwide. His wife, Lorraine; sons, Fred and Courtney; and daughter, Juliette, had been at his hospital bedside regularly during his hospitalization, according to company spokesman Paul Guzzi. Wang turned the company's presidency over to his son, Fred, at a time when the computer industry was entering a time of difficulty. Fred Wang later stepped down but An Wang continued as chief executive officer. The company last year reported bank debt totaling $575 million, according to Guzzi, but a retrenchment and sale of assets cut that to less than $100 million. Wang's success gave him a chance for philanthropy and support for education and the arts, including development of the new Wang Center for the Performing Arts in Boston.

DOC.HEAD: Talk Show Host Calls Chung Controversial Name
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: A radio talk show host in a small station outside the nation's capital has twice referred to CBS television anchor Connie Chung as ``Connie Chink,'' says a published report. ``I referred to her as Connie Chink because I thought she was making fun of President Reagan,'' Cliff Kincaid, who had been criticizing media coverage of John Poindexter's trial, told The Washington Post on Friday. ``I was making fun of her liberalism and I joked about her name. I'm sorry if people were offended about it. But my point was to draw attention to the offensive way she had referred to President Reagan's videotaped testimony in the Poindexter trial,'' Kincaid said. ``It's a play on words on her last name. It's a slang term. It's not a vulgar term.'' Kincaid said his comment contained ``perfectly acceptable language'' and that he did not consider the word ``chink'' racist because it ``is like the term honky.'' Kincaid's on-air remarks came while discussing Chung's appearance Thursday on the ``CBS Evening News.'' He said: ``The Dan Rather bias wasn't there, no, I guess he was on vacation. Connie Chink, uh ... Chung, uh, Chung was sitting in for him. I'm sick of people in the media like Connie Chink getting on his back!'' Kincaid made the comments during his conservative talk show on the low-powered radio station in Silver Spring, Md., just outside the nation's capital. The station is owned by former presidential hopeful and televangelist Pat Robertson and his Broadcast Equities, Inc., which two weeks ago started simulcasting its continuous conservative programming to Robertson's stations in Charlotte, N.C., and Oklahoma City. Melinda Yee, executive director of the Organization of Chinese Americans, said, ``We will call for a public apology to the Chinese-American community.'' Program director Michael Del Giorno said Kincaid would not be fired. ``It was a slang, not a vulgarity,'' Del Giorno said.

DOC.HEAD: Guatemala Criticized Over Human Rights Abuses
DOC.TEXT: The country's human rights ombudsman says the government has been ineffective in breaking up death squads killing people at the rate of about one a day this year and abducting dozens of others. ``In Guatemala the agents of human rights violations persist. Government- level efforts to preserve (human rights) are useless,'' Ramiro de Leon Carpio said Friday in a report to the Guatemalan Congress. ``There are extremist sectors involved in the violation of these rights, which have caused the disappearance of many people and the murder of others,'' de Leon Carpio said. ``Clandestine jails have not ceased to operate,'' he added. ``Demands are presented daily for their disappearance, but no positive results are being obtained,'' he said. He said at least 20 people have been assassinated in the last 15 days in the San Marcos area on Mexico's southern border. At least 54 were killed in January and February throughout Guatemala, he said. In the first two months of 1990 at least 52 people disappeared and 23 threats were reported, he said. The president of the Congressional Human Rights Commission, Oliverio Garcia, chastized the administration of President Vinicio Cerezo ``for its negligence in the investigation of these events and the capture of the responsible parties.'' Earlier this month, the United States recalled its ambassador from Guatemala for a week to protest the government's failure to stop politically motivated killings. ``Guatemala's democracy continues to be challenged by acts of terrorism and human rights abuses perpetrated by extremists who seek to undermine the democratically elected civilian government,'' State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said at the time. Guatemala returned to civilian government in 1986 after three decades of military rule in which an estimated 100,000 people died and 40,000 disappeared. Cerezo blames the violence on a rightist campaign to destabilize his government. Last year he faced two coup attempts by army officers. The United States provides Guatemala with about $90 million in annual aid.

DOC.HEAD: Report on Soviet Internment Camp Where Thousands of Germans Died
DOC.TEXT: Authorities have discovered mass graves containing thousands of victims of a former Soviet internment camp from the Stalin era, an East German newspaper reported today. Among those killed at the camp were Nazi prisoners of war such as SS members, police officers, Nazi party officials and former soldiers in Adolf Hitler's army, the Berliner Zeitung said. But the newspaper said victims also included ``many innocent people'' and teen-agers. The youngest victim was 12 years old, it quoted a surviving inmate as saying. The report did not say how many thousands of bodies were found. The camp was run by the Soviet Union's dreaded NKVD state security force, a forerunner of the KGB, according to the report. A local historian discovered the remains earlier this month at Fuenfeichen near Neubrandenburg, 80 miles north of Berlin, the East Berlin newspaper said. Berliner Zeitung quoted West German estimates that 65,000 men, women and children died in Red Army imprisonment at the end of World War II. It likened the ``Stalinist terror'' to Nazi death camps. The report, accompanied by a graphic photograph of an uncovered skeleton, would have been impossible before the peaceful revolt that toppled hard-line East German Communist leader Erich Honecker in October and set the country on course for democracy. East Germany, formed out of Soviet-occupied Germany after the fall of Hitler's Third Reich, was a particularly staunch Soviet ally for decades but now is dealing publicly with its past. This includes reports on brutality in the postwar period when the Soviet bloc was in the iron grip of Kremlin chief Josef Stalin. Berliner Zeitung noted that many German Communists and socialists were also killed in Soviet camps. Forest wardens and farmers knew about Fuenfeichen but kept silent until now, the newspaper said. The camp operated from April 1945 until October 1948. Many inmates were taken to the Soviet Union when the Red Army closed it and were never heard from again, the report said. It said one prisoner who died there had just been released from a Nazi camp and was arrested by the Soviets because he resisted the expropriation of his home.

DOC.HEAD: Precede DAMASCUS
Syrian, Egyptian Leaders Meet For First Time Since 12-Year Rift Ended
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with Mubarak-Assad meeting
DOC.TEXT: Presidents Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and Hafez Assad of Syria today met for the first time since ending a 12-year rift between their countries, joining other Arab leaders in Libya, a news report said. The leaders were attending ceremonies marking the 20th anniversary of the expulsion of British forces from Libya, the Libyan news agency JANA said in a report monitored in Rome. The news agency said Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi welcomed Assad, Mubarak and Sudanese leader Omar Hassan el-Bashir, who were among the leaders at the ceremony in Tobruk on the Mediterranean coast in eastern Libya. Assad's foreign visits are rarely announced in advance, and his trip to Tobruk surprised officials in his own government. JANA said Mubarak and Assad met at the Libyan air base where the ceremony was being held. It was their first meeting since the two countries resumed diplomatic ties in December after mediation by Saudi Arabia and Jordan. The report did not say what they discussed. Assad broke ties after Egyptian President Anwar Sadat made a dramatic visit to Jerusalem in 1977, the opening move in two years of negotiations that resulted in the Egypt-Israel peace accord signed by Sadat. Most other Arab countries broke ties with Egypt when it signed the treaty with Israel in 1979, and the feud had been a major obstacle to Arab cooperation. But links have been restored since a 1987 Arab summit decided to allow Egypt back into the Arab fold. Libya, long allied with Syria in a radical front, has also been patching up its differences with Egypt. In Cairo, Egyptian officials said today that Mubarak planned talks with Gadhafi on international and Arab issues and recently improved relations between the two countries. The 1970 British pullout from Tobruk's el-Adem air base took place the year after Gadhafi overthrew the monarchy in a military coup and established a republic. U.S. forces withdrew from Libya in June 1970. Libya was under British and French administration from 1942, when the Germans and Italians were driven out in World War II, until independence in 1951. But the British retained the air base until the year after Gadhafi toppled the Libyan monarchy in 1969. Gadhafi renamed the base after Egypt's late president, Gamal Abdel Nasser.

DOC.HEAD: Khmer Rouge: Vietnamese Launching Counteroffensive
DOC.TEXT: Khmer Rouge commanders claim that elite Vietnamese troops have been secretly sent back into Cambodia to block a guerrilla advance on the country's second largest city. The guerrilla officers, interviewed Friday in a jungle base, said Vietnamese troops disguised in Cambodian uniforms have mounted a series of counterattacks in a wide area of territory seized earlier by the Khmer Rouge. The Soviet-backed Vietnamese maintained about 100,000 troops in Cambodia for several years until Hanoi claimed it withdrew its forces in September 1989. Cambodia has denied repeated claims that Vietnamese forces have returned, and the Vietnamese army newspaper Quan Doi Nhan Dan said Friday that the allegations were ``groundless reports cooked up by the Khmer Rouge and spread by foreign mass media.'' The Communist Khmer Rouge, one of three guerrilla groups fighting the government in Cambodia, has seized hundreds of square miles of territory in the northwestern province of Battambang and threatened the capital, Phnom Penh. ``The Vietnamese reinforcements are a major obstacle to us capturing Battambang,'' the Khmer Rouge division commander, Gen. Yat Thim, said. ``In February the Vietnamese sent many reinforcements to Battambang, and have mounted operations against us on many occasions this month.'' The rare interview with a Khmer Rouge commander took place at a jungle base near the Thai frontier recently captured from government forces. The explosions of mines being cleared and detonated by the guerrillas could be heard at short intervals. Western analysts at the Thai-Cambodian border confirmed that Vietnamese troops were fighting in northwestern Cambodia, but the reports did not specify the number of troops involved. ``There is no doubt the Vietnamese are back,'' said one Western analyst, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``They are now attacking the Khmer Rouge in several areas of Battambang.'' The Khmer Rouge's military objectives are unclear, but Yat Thim confirmed the guerrillas intend to seize Battambang, Cambodia's second largest city and center of the country's most fertile rice-growing region. The Khmer Rouge produced three captured Vietnamese soldiers on Friday who they said were seized in the recent fighting. The three were clearly Vietnamese, but their accounts could not be independently verified. ``We were sent back to Cambodia because the government couldn't beat the resistance alone,'' said a manacled lieutenant, Ly Guan Thien, through an interpreter. ``We were told to put on Cambodian uniforms so we wouldn't be recognized.'' He said he was captured early this month when his unit of 150 Vietnamese was attacked by the Khmer Rouge in Battambang province. Pvt. Long Ngoc Tho said he arrived in Cambodia in early February with 500 other Vietnamese troops and was captured 12 days later in fighting around the gem-mining town of Pailin. ``There are now many of us in Cambodia,'' he said. ``We were told that we needed to help Cambodia fight the enemy.'' The Khmer Rouge and two non-Communist groups fighting the government made major gains after the Vietnamese pullout. But since last month, a counteroffensive has forced the guerrillas to give up some ground. Vietnam invaded Cambodia in late 1978, ending a nearly 4-year-long Khmer Rouge reign of terror. During their rule, hundreds of thousands of Cambodia's 8 million people were executed or died from famine and civil unrest.

DOC.HEAD: Rioters Loot Stores, Burn Cars Amid Wave of Strikes
DOC.TEXT: Scores of unemployed people broke shop windows, looted stores and set cars aflame in Port Gentil in the latest protest of austerity measures in this West African nation, a newspaper said today. Many people were wounded and many shops and schools shut down before the unrest in Port Gentil ended Friday afternoon, several hours after it began, the Union reported, without supplying specific figures. Security forces were dispatched from Libreville, to reinforce those in Port Gentil, 100 miles south of the capital, daily said. The rioting came two days after workers at the government's Gabon Refining Company and U.S.-based Mobil Oil Corp. in Port Gentil joined the wave of strikes that has gripped Libreville for three months. The Union reported that employees at the government refinery also damaged company cars Friday, but it did not say how. Workers are demanding higher salaries and more fringe benefits as Gabon enters the third year of an austerity program imposed as a condition of further credit from Western nations and institutions. Many workers have been laid off in that time, but it is not known how many of Gabon's 1 million people are out of work. The unrest also comes as the country holds a national conference to draft constitutional changes to broaden democracy. Civilian President Omar Bongo has ruled this oil-producing nation as a one-party state since 1968.

DOC.HEAD: Military Rolls Into Vilnius, Local Elections Begin
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs last 3 grafs with 2 grafs to UPDATE with Tass president saying state of emergency possible.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos VIL1,2
DOC.TEXT: About 100 Soviet military vehicles rumbled past Lithuania's Parliament building early today, and nervous lawmakers voted to transfer power out of their Baltic republic if they are assaulted or arrested. After the convoy roared through, the Lithuanian capital was quiet, and polls opened for elections to local governing councils. A deadline for Lithuanian deserters to return to their Soviet military units passed with no immediate reports of action being taken to round them up. In Moscow, a U.S. Embassy spokesman said two U.S. diplomats ordered out of Lithuania by the Soviet government on Friday would comply with the order. But he could not confirm the officials actually had found transportation out of the Baltic republic and left. In referring to today's maneuver, Lithuanian President Vytautus Landsbergis told the Supreme Council legislature: ``We felt we were really in an occupied country. An alien power sent forces and we don't know why. ``Tension is rising with this demonstration of military force, with this frightening of people with Soviet soldiers.'' The legislators, who were in session about 300 feet from the path of the convoy when it rumbled through Vilnius about 4 a.m., passed a resolution transferring power to the senior diplomat of independent Lithuania in Washington in case of a Soviet assault or their arrests. Since Lithuania declared independence from Moscow on March 11, Soviet leaders have repeatedly warned the Baltic republic to return to the Soviet Union. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has called the move illegal but said he would not use force against the republic of 3.8 million people. Lithuania, a formerly independent republic, was crushed by Stalin's army in 1940 and annexed by the Soviet Union. Moving the column into Vilnius increased the military pressure on the Lithuanian government by making it simpler for Moscow to send the troops quickly into action. But it appeared calculated to enter the city when it was deserted, seemingly to avoid confrontations. ``This is absurd, armored vehicles don't usually drive through the middle of town in the middle of the night,'' Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimeira Prunskeine told reporters at the legislature. ``We're not afraid, but we don't know what they want, and we don't know what they will do in the next few hours,'' she said. Official Lithuanian sources said vehicles containing at least 1,000 paratroopers armed with automatic weapons rumbled along the main highway through the heart of Vilnius without stopping. There were at least 22 tanks and armored personnel carriers and dozens of green military trucks. The parliament's information department quoted witnesses as saying there were 59 tanks and 50 other vehicles. No incidents were reported. A spokesman for the Lithuanian Parliament said he saw the column enter a military base at Siaures Miestelis on the north side of the capital, where it stayed. On Thursday, Gorbachev told Landsbergis that Lithuania should stop signing up volunteer forces, and sought a response from the Lithuanian leader by today. He also has demanded Lithuanians surrender their firearms. A senior military adviser to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev, indicated Friday the military would try to round up the deserters, ``even if some people don't like it.'' Landsbergis, in a telegram to Moscow early today, said the volunteers would not replace Soviet KGB border guards and uniformed police, as Gorbachev suggested the Lithuanians would. Romas Gudaitis, a Lithuanian representative to the national parliament in Moscow, said he handed a letter Friday to Gorbachev's second-in-command, Anatoly I. Lukyanov, asking national legislators for negotiations. He said Lukyanov, the chairman of the Supreme Soviet, categorically rejected the request. On Friday, Foreign Ministry officials said Soviet embassies would review foreigners' visa applications to travel to Lithuania, to keep out people ``inclined to engage in illegal activities,'' the official Soviet news agency Tass said. It did not elaborate. The Soviet Union also told Poland it was suspending visa-free travel for Poles and Lithuanians across the border, the official Soviet news agency said. In Tokyo, the head of Tass said today he believes that a state of emergency might be declared in Lithuania, although it was unclear what that would mean. ``Just because they have formed a (independent) legislature, they are mistaken to think that they can secede,'' Tass President Leonid Kravchenko told the Japanese NTV television network.

DOC.HEAD: Last Anniversary Ceremony for Sainthood Candidate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with pope's message. Pickup 7th graf ``What Monsignor...''
DOC.TEXT: Local Roman Catholic leaders say they hope Monsignor Oscar Romero, murdered in church 10 years ago today, will be declared a saint by the Vatican. ``Monsignor Romero is already a saint for the people of Latin America. What the Vatican does would be a recognition of his popular canonization,'' said Father Rogelio Pedraz, a close friend and colleague of Romero. Local and foreign religious dignitaries attended ceremonies Thursday, Friday and today for Romero, who was slain by a single bullet through the heart as he said Mass at a hospital chapel March 24, 1980. The killing was blamed on right-wing death squads, but no suspects were ever arrested. In Rome today, Pope John Paul II sent a message to Romero's successor, Archbishop Arturo Rivera Damas, expressing the hope that the slaying will serve as a call to ``reconciliation and pardon.'' The message did not mention efforts to make Romero a saint. In announcing plans to propose Romero for beatification, the first step toward sainthood, the church has instructed its officials to ensure observation of the ``non cultu'' edict. That is a reference to a decree Pope Urban VIII issued in the 17th century that public ceremonial tribute to a candidate for sainthood would diminish the nominee's chances. Only one archbishop delared a saint was assassinated in church _ Thomas Becket, killed 820 years ago by four local knights who supported Henry II's feud with the cleric. Pedraz, director of the publishing house of the Jesuit-run Central American University, says canonization could take up to 30 years. ``What Monsignor Romero finally leaves us as a lesson is that it is not possible to kill him,'' said Juan Jose Garcia, director of the university's human rights institute. ``The figure of Monsignor Romero does not end when he dies. There begins the process of his resurrection, a resurrection that means his return to life in today's circumstances.'' To the despair of 5 million Salvadorans, today's circumstances do not differ greatly from those of 1980, when the country was descending into fratricidal war. ``It is a great sadness that, 10 years after the murder of one who spoke with such passion of the need for peace, El Salvador is still locked firmly in the embrace of mutual enmity and fierce civil war,'' said the New York-based rights organization Americas Watch. The group commented in a report titled ``A Year of Reckoning: El Salvador a Decade after the Assassination of Archbishop Romero.'' Cruel irony attends the 10th anniversary. The nation is governed by the rightist Arena party founded by cashiered army major Roberto D'Aubuisson. Former President Jose Napoleon Duarte accused him of being mastermind of the conspiracy to kill Romero. D'Aubuisson denies involvement in the murder. Despite evidence incriminating several alleged members in a far-rightist plot, no one has been arrested or tried for the slaying. Some officials have called the case closed. The anniversary comes just four months after another heinous crime against men of the cloth. Before dawn on Nov. 16, army troops broke into the residence of six Jesuit professor-priests at Central American University, roused them from their beds, forced them to lie face down on the lawn and shot them in the head. Then they killed the priests' housekeeper and her daughter. ``These two events _ the murder of Archbishop Romero in 1980 and the slaying of the Jesuits in 1989 _ stand as bookends to the decade offering harsh testimony about who really rules El Salvador and how little they have changed,'' Americas Watch said. ``Ten years later, priest-killing is still a preferred option for those who simply will not hear the cries for change and justice in a society that has had too little of either.'' Romero and the Jesuits exercised what in modern theology has come to be called ``the preferential option for the poor.'' They lived humbly and described and condemned exploitation, inequality, oppression and repression. For their outspokenness, they were labeled subversives by the radical right. Romero ``was a pastor, a prophet, a friend, a brother and a father to the entire Salvadoran people, especially the poorest, the weakest and most downtrodden,'' the local church said in a publication dedicated to his memory. ``He was the voice of those without voice.'' The day before he was killed, in his final homily, Romero issued an impassioned appeal to soldiers to disobey orders to torture and murder. ``In the name of God, in the name of this suffering people whose cries rise to heaven more loudly each day, I implore you, I beg you, I order you in the name of God: Stop the repression,'' he said. The government and rebels in recent weeks have talked separately with a representative of U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar about resuming peace talks broken off last November. ``We hope that in the year of this 10th anniversary the war ends,'' said Monsignor Gregorio Rosa Chavez, auxiliary bishop of San Salvador. ``Because it is possible to end the war this very year, the year of the beginning of his canonization. He told us how we could have avoided all this suffering, but his voice was not heeded. We hope that now, with more serenity, his voice will be heeded and that finally the violence will end and peace will arrive.''

DOC.HEAD: Baker Trip Makes No Progress on Angolan Cease-fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts new 2nd graf with Shevardnadze comment, subs grafs 8-9, `Zairean President ...' with 4 grafs to CORRECT name of river to Congo, sted Zaire, inserts new Shevardnadze quote. Pickup 10th graf pvs, `Meanwhile, two...'
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III has failed to make much progress toward producing a new cease-fire in the 15-year-old Angolan civil war, a senior U.S. official said today. But Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze said the United States and Soviet Union had agreed to ``exert all our efforts'' to encourage peace in southern Africa. Baker, on the last leg of his six-day trip through Africa that included stops in South Africa and newly independent Namibia, met with Angolan rebel and government leaders to seek a solution to their long conflict. ``The Angolans are still proposing what they call a Biafran solution,'' said the U.S. official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The official was referring to Nigeria's policy toward defeated rebels who had sought independence for the country's eastern region in the 1960s. Nigeria brought many former rebels into the federal government, giving them a voice in national affairs. ``But the Angolan rebels haven't been defeated,'' the U.S. official said. Guerrilla forces loyal to Jonas Savimbi control about one-third of the mineral-rich country in southwestern Africa. Baker held brief talks with Savimbi on Friday night. Savimbi, who has been supported by the United States, repeated a pledge to honor a cease-fire if the Angolan government would begin negotiations to end the war. Zairean President Mobutu Sese Seko received Baker today on his riverboat, the Kamanyola, on the Congo River. Mobutu has sought to mediate the Angolan conflict, but a cease-fire he brokered in June quickly broke down. Baker refused to comment on the talks except to say: ``We had almost three hours that were constructive and helpful.'' In Harare, Zimbabwe, Shevardnadze said the Soviet Union was optimistic about the prospects of peace in Angola and Mozambique, where guerrillas are fighting the Soviet-backed governments. ``There is a certain degree of readiness by both the leaders of these countries and their opponents to engage in dialogue,'' Shevardnadze said. Meanwhile, two attorneys of the U.S. Lawyers Committee for Human Rights accused Zairean security forces of attacking them and stealing their briefcases on March 15. The New York-based committee said in a letter to Baker that five men beat Americans Peter Rosenblum and Kenyan Makau Mutua outside their hotel in downtown Kinshasa. Bystanders chased the attackers but abandoned their pursuit when one shouted that he belonged to the security forces, the letter said. Zaire's intelligence service denied it was involved in the attack. The letter asked Baker to raise the incident in today's talks with Mobutu. Baker did not say whether he had, but the talks were to have included bilateral relations. Zaire is a top beneficiary of aid from the United States. Amnesty International, the human rights organization, has for years accused Mobutu's administration of arbitrarily detaining and torturing opponents.

DOC.HEAD: Berlin Wall Opening a Windfall for West Berlin Tourism
DOC.TEXT: The opening of the Berlin Wall in November helped make 1989 a record year for tourism in West Berlin, according to a report published Saturday. The West Berlin Statistics Office said 2.4 million visitors came to West Berlin in 1989, a 12 percent increase over 1988. The figures do not include visitors from East Germany or tourists who did not stay in hotels, the report said. The Berlin Wall was opened Nov. 9 at the height of the pro-democracy revolution. The number of tourists skyrocketed in December, when 183,000 registered visitors came to West Berlin. It was an increase of 48 percent over December 1988. Americans led the number of foreign visitors, with 8,200, followed by 6,000 Dutch, 5,700 British and 4,700 French tourists.

DOC.HEAD: Actress Alice Sapritch Dies at 73
DOC.TEXT: Screen, stage and television actress Alice Sapritch died Saturday of a heart attack, police said. She was 73. The black-haired Armenian actress, born in Istanbul in 1916, cut a familiar figure on the Left Bank for decades, with a turban atop her head and cigarette held firmly between her fingers. Ms. Sapritch arrived in France in the early 1930s to study drama at the prestigious National Conservatory. By 1939, her imposing presence landed her the role of Hamlet's mother. She worked on stage through the 1940s, appearing in ``The Dialogue of the Carmelites'' and ``L'Aiglon.'' Her stage work continued into the 1970s, but her real success came in movies and television. Her work on the screen included ``Who is Polly Magoo?'' in 1966, ``The Folly of the Great'' in 1971, ``The Concierge'' in 1973, ``The Brontes'' in 1979, and ``Adam and Eve'' in 1984.''
