Sapritch married the journalist and dramatist Guillaume Hanoteau in 1950. They divorced 22 years later. The couple had no children.

DOC.HEAD: Christian Clashes Raise Fears of All-Out War
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces battled with artillery and machine guns through the night and again Saturday, raising fears of a new round of all-out war for control of Christian territory. Three people were reported killed and eight wounded in the battles, which took place in east Beirut and in the Kesrouan province north of the city. Most of the victims have been civilians. The clashes were the most serious since a cease-fire was declared March 3 between the troops of Gen. Michel Aoun and Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces Militia. The truce has been violated repeatedly. A police spokesman, who cannot be named under standing regulations, predicted all-out warfare would break out again if a mediation committee is unable to work out a political settlement between the rival Christian groups. A Christian source close to the mediators said: ``The gap separating Geagea and Aoun remains very wide. The mediators haven't been able to bring them closer.'' The source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the committee was ``convinced that its efforts have reached a dead end, but doesn't want to announce failure, hoping that a miracle of some sort might emerge.'' Meanwhile, Beirut's independent An-Nahar daily quoted unnamed government sources as saying the United States has informed ``officials that Aoun must step down in favor of the legitimate authority'' of President Elias Hrawi. It did not elaborate. The United States, like all nations with which Lebanon has diplomatic relations, recognizes Hrawi as head of state. Aoun refuses to accept his authority because he was elected as part of a peace accord the Christian general opposed. Aoun rejected the accord because it did not include a timetable for the withdrawal from Lebanon of Syrian troops. Aoun considers the Syrians, who entered Lebanon in 1976 under an Arab League peacekeeping mandate, to be an army of occupation. Geagea recognizes the presidency and has made cautious signals welcoming the peace accord. The Moslem Voice of the Nation radio quoted unnamed government sources as saying the government was considering ``ways of intervening to stop the intra-Christian fighting amid increasing signs that a fierce confrontation might break out.'' It did not say whether this might involve military action against Aoun.

DOC.HEAD: Alec McCowen Recites `St. Mark's Gospel'
DOC.TEXT: The respected British actor Alec McCowen is back, again reciting ``St. Mark's Gospel,'' and it is mesmerizing. The solo performance opened Wednesday night, to play through April 15, at the off-Broadway Lamb's Theater. McCowen learned the second and shortest of the four Gospels in the New Testament of the Bible during 16 months in 1976 and 1977. He has been occasionally speaking it in theaters ever since, including previous engagements here. He is ``acting'' more now. Previously, he delivered the story primarily by voice. And there are more props. Instead of one chair, there are now three which he moves around. When Jesus is on a ship, the actor turns a chair and sits on it backwards. When a madman speaks, his hand goes in front of his face, palm out. When a blind man speaks, a hand covers his eyes. Temple officials speak with plummy, self-satisfied voice and expression. This makes surprisingly little difference. ``St. Mark's Gospel'' fascinates however McCowen delivers it, to a audience familiar with its story or not, believers or not, first-time hearers or those who've heard it before. This Gospel concentrates on Jesus' ministry. He is baptized by John the Baptist, chooses his disciples, goes to many villages to cast demons out of people, cures illnesses and handicaps and teaches by telling parables. In this Gospel, the common people figure out the parables better than the disciples. This Gospel doesn't have many women in it. Jesus' mother isn't mentioned. The stories of Mary Magdalene, Mary and Martha and the woman at the well aren't told. The writing style is never flowery. McCowen's hair now is gray; his closely trimmed beard is white. He doesn't wear a suit, as when he first did ``St. Mark's Gospel'' here. Now he wears a dark red sweater over a shirt and gray slacks. In an introduction he explains that he uses the 1611 King James version of the Bible. He says that Peter is believed to have told this story to Mark. One thing that McCowen's acting has done is to give ``St. Mark's Gospel'' more amusing moments than before. Before James and John ask Jesus if they can sit beside him in heaven, he looks all around to see if anybody is eavesdropping. Arthur Cantor produced. Lloyd Sobel did the subtle lighting.

DOC.HEAD: 100 Injured, 12 Missing in Storm
DOC.TEXT: A storm lashed northern Bangladesh overnight with heavy rain and strong winds, sinking two boats and destroying hundreds of houses made of mud and straw, police and news reports said. Twelve people were missing. At least 100 people were injured when more than 1,000 houses collapsed in Mymensingh and Manikganj districts, said the Dainik Bangla newspaper. A ferry capsized and sank Friday night in the Padma river near Manikganj, about 25 miles north of Dhaka, police said. They said 36 people were rescued but 10 others were missing. Another boat carrying 10 people sank in the Buriganga river near Dhaka and two children were missing, police officials said.

DOC.HEAD: 25 Killed in Fireworks Explosion in India
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS to fireworks, sted firecrackers, throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Fireworks stored in a southern Indian temple exploded today, killing at least 25 people and severely injuring more than 70, news reports said. The blast occurred at a Hindu temple in Malanada, 1,380 miles south of New Delhi in Kerala state. Press Trust of India said the fireworks were to be used today in an annual festival, which was canceled. Thousands of people had arrived at the temple for the celebrations, PTI said. It said 30 of the injured suffered severe burns and were in critical condition. The temple floor was covered with blood and half-burned fireworks, Press Trust said. The news agency said the explosion was touched off by a fire, but it did not say what caused the fire.

DOC.HEAD: Parents Overcome Drugs, Youth To Help School
LaserPhoto WX11
DOC.TEXT: When the principal at J.C. Nalle Elementary School recently asked for community volunteers to sub for her teachers at lunch time, more than two-dozen parents jumped right in. For the teachers, it was a welcome opportunity to grab a 90-minute break from the rigors of an innner-city school day. For parents, it was a gratifying means of getting involved in the education of their children. ``The parents came in overwhelmingly,'' school principal Shirley Williams said of the lunch program, which was designed to honor teachers during American Education Week. ``And the teachers were pleased.'' Stronger parental involvement in schools is a key aim of the national education strategy developed by the Bush administration and the nation's governors. The policy stresses that ``parents should play an active role in their children's early learning.'' But instituting such a policy in the drug-infested neighborhoods surrounding Nalle is no mean feat. Nearby Drake Place was described by Time magazine as one of the nation's meanest streets. ``Many children at Nalle at one time or another have been a witness to a crime or have been affected by a crime,'' said Ms. Williams, noting the drug epidemic has torn down traditional family structures. Yet, said the Rev. Nathaniel Thomas, president of the school's Parent Teacher Association, ``In spite of the drug abuse or other conditions, parents still want the very best for their children. But the challenge is how to help them and how to get us the necessary support.'' Most of the parents are in their early to mid-20s _ ``so very young themselves that they are seeking guidance as well,'' he said. Thomas, who has a daughter at Nalle, said he became active at the school about the time Ms. Williams became principal because ``I attended the school as a child and my parents still live in this community.'' ``I refuse to run away from my roots,'' he said. ``This is where the seed was planted, right here. In spite of all the problems that exist now we can change that by way of a cooperative network among the teachers, principal and parents.'' President Bush recently criticized parents for ``thinking of education as a service we can hand over to the school boards, much the same way we expect our cities to provide electricity or water.'' Bush's criticisms came as the national PTA released a survey of parents that found less than half had visited their children's schools to participate in a back-to-school night or to attend parent-organization meetings last fall. Many of the parents cited lack of time or work commitments as a deterrent to participation. Parents of the 413 black students attending J.C. Nalle have additional problems. The school is located in a neighborhood where, during the 1988-89 school year, ``there was a crime committed there almost every night,'' Ms. Williams said. Some parents struggle themselves with drug and alcohol problems. To ensure parental awareness of a student's progress, Ms. Williams requires parents must pick up their children's report card. Only a few refuse to do so. ``Just today one little boy was just beaming because his mother was here to pick up his report card,'' said Ms. Williams. ``It didn't matter that she was more than a month late.'' Ms. Willians, who has been principal at Nalle for the past 18 months, said the ``key is getting them (parents) to trust you and letting them know that they are welcome in the schools, that you have the same concern for their children and that the staff is flexible, willing to listen and help their children be successful.'' The first challenge for Ms. Williams and Thomas has been to establish an active PTA. But few parents can afford to supplement many of the extracurricular activities school officials insist are essential, so Ms. Williams and other school officials are searching for corporate sponsors too. Thomas has persuaded Howard University's School of Education to establish a partnership with Nalle to provide educational counseling, staff development and cultural enrichment opportunities for faculty, students and parents. Nalle currently has five ``parent partners'' assisting teachers in the school. The parents usually start out as volunteers and later are paid small stipends to work about four hours twice a week. Helen Williams, a parent who has volunteered, worked as a parent partner and now is an aide. She has a fifth grader at Nalle, and her oldest son attended. ``I know a lot of parents who don't work and could come up and help the teachers,'' said Mrs. Williams, who is not related to the principal. ``But a lot of them didn't finish school and figure they can't teach the children because they don't know a lot of things themselves.'' Ms. Williams, the principal, said some of the parents have values different from those taught in the school. ``Children go by peer pressure and the code of the street. You don't talk about things that go on,'' she said. ``But those things cannot exist here at a public school. You come in and if there's a problem we will talk about it. We're going to listen and we're going to try to guide the kid to understand. We don't want to put the home down, but as I say to parents, `We have a standard and we must measure up to the standard.'''

DOC.HEAD: Strikers Loot Stores, Burn Cars
DOC.TEXT: Scores of unemployed people went on a rampage in Gabon's economic capital of Port Gentil, breaking shop windows, looting stores and setting cars aflame, the state-run Union newspaper reported Saturday. The daily newspaper said numerous people were wounded and many shops and schools shut down before the unrest ended Friday afternoon, several hours after it began. Security forces were dispatched from the capital, Libreville, to reinforce those in Port Gentil, it said. This oil-producing country is in the third year of an austerity program imposed as a condition of receiving further credit from Western nations and institutions. Workers are demanding higher salaries and more fringe benefits. Many workers have been laid off in recent months, but it is not known how many of Gabon's 1 million people are unemployed.

DOC.HEAD: Political Changes Cause Review of US-Backed Stations
DOC.TEXT: The White House will review all the government's overseas broadcasts to determine what changes should be made in response to political upheaval in Eastern Europe. The review, to be headed by the National Security Council, will examine the radio programs of the Voice of America and of Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty, according to a letter from President Bush's National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft. ``The President strongly shares your view that the dramatic opening of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union requires us to look afresh at all our broadcasting activities,'' Scowcroft wrote Rep. Dante Fascell, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. Among its other tasks, the review panel will consider a suggestion by Fascell that a presidential commission be appointed to offer recommendations about the long-term future of the radio stations, Scowcroft said. Since World War II, the administration has used its radio stations as instruments of foreign policy to influence events around the world, especially in Communist countries. An alternative to the strict state-controlled media in those countries, the American stations drew a clandestine following of millions of listeners. The U.S. programs were often jammed. VOA broadcasts in 43 languages around the world. Radio Free Europe-Radio Liberty, based in Munich, targets only Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. Their combined budgets are about $400 million. The stations have already begun changing programming to reflect the changes in the Communist world. Growing emphasis has been placed on ``how-to'' programs that instruct listeners in one-time Communist countries about life in the Western world. Special emphasis is placed on programs about starting up businesses and call-in shows with experts on such subjects as writing constitutions and laws. Members of Congress have proposed a bill that would re-examine the direction of the government's broadcasting, which has been hit by increasing budget problems in recent years. Testifying at a House hearing on the subject last week, Rep. James Scheuer, D-N.Y., urged that the mission of the radio stations be changed. ``It simply doesn't make sense to spend hundreds of millions of dollars to increase our ability to penetrate Eastern Europe ... when they probably will be showing the CBS Evening News or CNN _ and probably even The Cosby Show'' on their networks within a few years, Scheuer said.

DOC.HEAD: Australian Election to Close to Call
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with preliminary results showing deadlock between two major parties. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Australians voted in parliamentary elections today, and preliminary returns showed a tie between Prime Minister Bob Hawke's governing Labor Party and Andrew Peacock's conservative opposition. Hawke said he will remain as a caretaker prime minister until official election results are released. The voting was so close, the election may not be decided until Thursday when postal ballots are counted. Computer projections gave Hawke's ruling party 73 seats _ two short of the majority it needs to form a government in the 148-seat House of Representatives. Peacock's coalition was also expected to capture 73 seats, with independents taking parliament's other two seats. A preliminary count of 82 percent of the ballots also showed the Liberal and Labor parties running neck-and-neck, television stations said. Labor had 85 seats entering the election; Peacock's Liberal Party, 45; and its coalition partner, the National Party, 18 seats. Speaking to reporters after the ballots closed Hawke sounded confident that his party would win an unprecedented fourth consecutive term. ``When the counting is finalized, I will, on behalf of the Australian Labor Party, be in a position to form a government,'' he said. But Peacock also said that he was optimistic that his party would capture the vote. ``I still think we are in with a very decent chance,'' said Peacock, who is making his second bid for prime minister. ``We are quite optimistic and believe we will shortly be in a position to form a government,'' he said. Television commentators said the election could be decided by 2,500 voters stranded by a hurricane in Kennedy, a small town in the northern state of Queensland. They will cast their votes on Sunday when floodwaters clear. Forty of the 70 Senate seats were also contested today,but the results will probably not be known for two weeks because of the complicated voting system. Australia has 10.6 million eligible voters among its 16.5 million people, and voting is compulsory. The election concentrated on Australia's economic policies, and an opposition victory would not dramatically affect foreign policy. Australia is a close U.S. ally, and President Bush said he hoped to visit the country before the year's end. Hawke said a victory for his 7-year-old administration would allow it to complete its economic reforms. Australia's sagging economy has been the focus of a largely uneventful five-week campaign during which Peacock claimed Hawke's policies weren't working and that the country faced a recession. Hawke, the nation's most enduring and popular Labor Party leader, campaigned on his record of economic reform, even though the foreign debt has grown to $100 billion. Peacock has criticized the government because of the country's high home mortgage interest rates, now at a record 18 percent. Hawke came to power in 1983, was re-elected the following year and again in 1987. He has said that, if re-elected in this race, he will seek a fifth term before retiring.

DOC.HEAD: Nuclear Power Debate Still Lively 10 Years After It Finished
DOC.TEXT: When Swedes voted in a referendum 10 years ago to phase out nuclear energy, they thought they put the question to rest. They were wrong. Many in this country, which depends on nuclear power for half its electricity, are having second thoughts about the decision to stop building new reactors and to close the 12 existing atomic power stations by the year 2010. A recent poll said 54 percent of 2,500 Swedes queried wanted to keep nuclear power after 2010, compared with 30 percent four years ago. Friday was the 10th anniversary of the passage of the referendum. It brought new calls to rethink the idea of closing the first reactor in 1995 and a second in 1996. In a possible sign they want to back out of the timetable, Environment Minister Birgitta Dahl and Industry Minister Rune Molin wrote in a joint article that their No. 1 priority was to protect full employment. ``The day the dismantling leads to loss of jobs, factories closing and rationing electricity, the nuclear power lobby will win its strongest arguments,'' they wrote in Friday's Dagens Nyheter daily. The two, who have been at loggerheads in the past over energy policy, promised to come up with a long-term strategy later this year. Advocates of nuclear power cite tightened safety regulations. ``The safety and security have been extraordinarily good,'' said Bo Wergens, a leader in Sweden's profitable pulp and paper industry. It relies heavily on nuclear power, which is relatively cheap. Critics note that in Sweden's frigid climate, most homes are overheated and homeowners barely notice the bill. By some estimates, closing the stations would double the consumer cost of electricity. The debate on nuclear energy dominated politics here for nearly a decade. It was partly responsible for the ouster of the Social Democrats in 1976 after 44 unbroken years in power. The issue is still so contentious that the three non-socialist opposition parties failed to unite in a coalition last month to replace the Social Democrats, who quit over economic policy. The Social Democrats returned to office by default. The 1980 referendum was called a few months after the nuclear accident at Three Mile Island in the United States. Reinforcement came in 1986, when the explosion at the Chernobyl plant in the Soviet Union sent a cloud of contamination over central Sweden. But despite lessened fears today, the anti-nuclear lobby is still strong. Dozens of black-clad women gathered outside Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson's office Friday, carrying pictures of children over the slogan: ``Innocents in a radioactive world.'' ``We think nuclear power is dangerous, that Sweden and all other countries should abstain from it as soon as possible,'' said Christer Skaneberg, a legislator for the Environment Party. ``The right signal would be for the government to close one reactor this year,'' said Lennart Daleus, arguing that Sweden has a surplus of energy. Daleus led the anti-nuclear campaign in the referendum. The government has been debating how to replace nuclear power. The other half of Sweden's power is hydroelectric, but the environmentally conscious Swedes also passed legislation forbidding the exploitation of the remaining pristine rivers of northern Sweden. Concerns of global warming, which scientists believe is caused by high levels of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, prompted other regulations to reduce emissions. Oil-fueled stations, which in the 1970s supplied 40 percent of the electricity, today are used as peak-hour supplements.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Revolution Hits Its Roughest Patch
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: In the streets, tax protesters burn Margaret Thatcher's effigy, and in the inner sanctums of her nervous Conservative Party there is talk of trying to dump her this autumn. In the latest blow, the Conservatives have suffered their most spectacular by-election defeat in 50 years, losing the traditionally staunch Tory district of Mid-Staffordshire to the opposition Labor Party by a landslide. Even after Friday's humiliation, Mrs. Thatcher's closest supporters are convinced she will ultimately triumph. But the Thatcherite free-market revolution has hit its roughest patch since she swept to power in 1979. Mrs. Thatcher has weathered tough spells before. But this time, things look dangerously different for the prime minister who has dominated Britain through the 1980s and challenged every institution, from the welfare state, through lawyers' monopolies to the labor unions. What began as a blip in inflation in the spring of 1988 has burgeoned into a crisis undermining the core of her political success: the sense she gave millions of Britons _ even those who did not like her _ that they were better off with her. Thatcher aides argue that the by-election defeat was largely a traditional mid-term protest. But it is an ominous protest in which a Tory majority of 14,654 became a Labor majority of 9,449 _ a swing of 21.4 percent. ``There was never a widespread acceptance of her enterprise culture,'' Robert Skidelsky, professor of international studies at Warwick University, said in an interview. ``But she was accepted as a very strong leader, someone who had got the economy under control and brought a tremendous increase in living standards in real terms. ... Suddenly all that has started to come unstuck and her strongest claim to rule is undermined.'' In the past 20 months, a doubling of interest rates in an attempt to curb inflation has sent the cost of home loans and other credit soaring. Hardest-hit are millions of new homeowners, small businesses and skilled blue-collar workers _ people who symbolize Thatcherism itself. Meanwhile inflation, just 3.3 percent two years ago, remains above 7 percent. ``In the beginning I thought her ideas were brilliant,'' said Sheila Jackson, who lives with her husband, a $230-a-week plasterer, and two children on a public housing estate in Weymouth, southern England. ``We were going to buy our house this year. Now that's on hold because of the interest payments ... you feel you're getting nowhere with her. I'm ashamed to say I voted for her.'' This sudden loss of spending power is worsened by a property tax reform that was supposed to be Thatcherism's master stroke, but is looking like a serious political miscalculation. By changing the system from graded levies on property to a straight head tax on every adult, Mrs. Thatcher thought she could show voters that Tories run local government more cheaply than the Labor socialists. Instead, the so-called poll tax is costing the average household about one-third more _ $1,107 _ from April 1. Demonstrators have fought running battles with police and invaded town halls all over England. The Conservatives have sunk to their lowest ratings for nearly two decades, 21 points behind Labor. The 64-year-old prime minister faces a fundamental quandary. She has built her prestige on a refusal to shirk unpopular measures for the sake of popularity. To back down is simply not in her nature. But unless she relents on the tax, she will alienate voters as well as members of her own party, who fear for their seats in the next election. Many Britons have long regarded Europe's first woman prime minister as dogmatic, bossy and extreme. Surveys marking her 10th anniversary in power last May showed majorities still oppose some key tenets of her mission to demolish socialism, such as selling off state-owned industries and reforming the national health, education and legal systems. But until now, the grocer's daughter from Grantham, central England, could demonstrate that whatever the intelligentsia thought, she was in touch with ordinary people: tough on crime, patriotic enough to wage war for an obscure colony like the Falkland Islands, strong enough to face down powerful trade unions. The new tax has made even her staunchest supporters wonder. ``It was a blunder, putting at risk for the first time Mrs. Thatcher's claim to be the authentic voice of middle England,'' Peregrine Worsthorne commented in London's right-wing Sunday Telegraph. No one is writing off Mrs. Thatcher's chances of leading the Conservatives to an unprecedented fourth successive victory at the next election, which must be held by mid-1992. ``I am very happy in the business I do, very happy indeed,'' she said recently. Last November, however, she faced a challenger for the first time at the annual election of party leader. Although she won handsomely, there is now at least a possibility her critics will try again this year. If she loses, she automatically ceases to be prime minister. ``The idea that Mrs. Margaret Thatcher may no longer be prime minister by the autumn must now be taken seriously,'' said the respected weekly, The Economist. The favorite as successor is Michael Heseltine, 57, a charismatic former defense secretary who projects himself as the Tory who will usher in a kinder, gentler post-Thatcherite age. Thatcher aides argue that inflation and interest rates will inevitably fall by year's end, if only because the government must create a pre-election recovery. But even then, Mrs. Thatcher seems in for a much tougher ride. She is in some ways a victim of her own successes. Many Britons have forgotten or never knew life without her, when Britain was plagued by strikes, inflation touched 26 percent and the top income tax rate was 83 percent. Now, more than two-thirds of Britons own their homes, compared with 50 percent in 1979. Stock holders have trebled to 9 million, largely through sales of state-owned enterprises, including British Airways, the national phone company, and British Gas. The average Briton's earnings, now $388 a week, have risen by 26 percent in real terms since 1979, according to official figures.

DOC.HEAD: Report On Soviet Internment Camp Where Thousands Died
DOC.TEXT: An East German newspaper on Saturday reported the discovery of mass graves of thousands of people who died at a former Soviet prison camp set up after World War II. It said many were innocent civilians. The dead included Nazi war prisoners, such as members of the paramilitary SS, Nazi party officials and soldiers in Hitler's army, Berliner Zeitung reported. But among the victims were ``many innocent people'' and children, it reported. The youngest victim was 12 years old, it quoted a surviving inmate as saying. There was no word on how the victims died. A local historian discovered the remains this month at the camp, which was in Fuenfeichen, 80 miles north of East Berlin. It was run by the dreaded NKVD state security force, a forerunner of the Soviet KGB, according to the report. Berliner Zeitung quoted West German estimates that 65,000 men, women and children died in Red Army imprisonment at the end of World War II. It likened the ``Stalinist terror'' to Nazi death camps. The report, accompanied by a graphic photograph of a skeleton, would have been impossible until the peaceful revolt that toppled East Germany's hard-line Communist regime in October and set the country on course for democracy. East Germany, formed out of Soviet-occupied Germany after the fall of Hitler's Third Reich, was a particularly staunch Soviet ally for decades but now is dealing publicly with its past. This includes reports on brutality in the postwar period, when the Soviet bloc was in the iron grip of Kremlin chief Josef Stalin. Berliner Zeitung noted that many German Communists and socialists were also killed in Soviet camps. Nearby residents and farmers knew about Fuenfeichen but kept silent until now, the paper said. The camp was in operation from April 1945 until October 1948. Many inmates were taken to the Soviet Union when the Red Army closed the camp and were never heard from again, the report said. It said one prisoner who died had just been released from a Nazi camp and was arrested by the Soviets because he resisted the expropriation of his home.

DOC.HEAD: Rural Kentucky Students Chat With Kids Across Globe Via Computer
DOC.TEXT: Wheelwright High School may be tucked in a remote corner of rural eastern Kentucky, but these days its students are trading information and greetings with counterparts everywhere from Homer, Alaska, to Bogota and London. But these modern-day pen-pals are communicating by computer, not paper and pen. Kisha Cotton, 17, wrote about growing up in a rural Appalachian hollow and her first encounter with racism at a beauty pagent. The essay was posted on a computer bulletin board and read by students across the world. Miss Cotton, who is black, was astonished at some of the responses. ``Some of the kids said they never met a black person or got a letter from one,'' said Miss Cotton. ``Some of the kids didn't know black kids went to school with white kids.'' The experience will help her handle racism when she leaves home for college next fall, she said. The computer conferences _ some carefully structured around a single subject, others more loosely organized to allow students to communicate on various topics _ are organized by the BreadNet computer network, based at Middlebury College in Vermont. Schools use their own computers to link up with the central computer at Middlebury. A core group of about 60 schools is taking part in the general program, while other schools are taking part in single-topic conferences, said Hugh Coyle, administrative director of Middlebury's Bread Loaf School of English. Students at Wheelwright High are amoung about 70 groups around the world currently involved in a conference on environmental issues, called ``World Class,'' said William W. Wright Jr., BreadNet director. ``It does bring some of the kids alive. It engages them and sparks active learning,'' said Wright. ``Using technology this way has engaged students in a way that ... video does not.'' The participants here shared some of the messages received from other countries. Some students in Toronto, Canada, facetiously noted that ``it's hard to imagine that inside our freezing igloos we find space for a computer.'' They added that they were taking part in the environmental exchange ``to make the world a better and cleaner place.'' While the Canadians cited concerns about acid rain, a group of geography students from the United Arab Emirates sent in information about the land and history of the Middle East and the environmental problems raised by rapid population growth and pollution generated by the oil industry. Conferences run several weeks and follow a structured format. Students read magazine articles and work in groups to pose questions for experts or answer queries from other students. The teams also use the network to research a specific topic, such as depletion of the Earth's ozone layer. ``They send facts we don't know about and we send facts they don't know about,'' said Haley Caudill, 18. ``Gathered with what we have, it really helps with a better understanding.'' Sen. Albert Gore, D-Tenn., will be an ``on-line guest'' Monday and Tuesday to respond to students' questions on the environment, said Wright. BreadNet was created in 1984 as part of a summer graduate program for rural high school teachers at Middlebury. Besides letting students interact by computer, the network enables rural teachers to stay abreast of changes in the their profession and serves as a support group after they return home, said Wright. Wheelwright teacher Carol Stumbo, whose journalism class is working on BreadNet, described the students' enthusiasm as contagious. ``They have managed to get the entire school involved to some degree,'' she said. ``Having them hooked up is very important because you can do two things,'' Ms. Stumbo said. ``You can give them a sense of where they're from and you can broaden them.'' Principal Lonnie Slone called the computer conferences ``one of the greatest things to happen at the school.'' ``When you live in Floyd County at the head of Left Beaver, you might feel a bit isolated,'' Sloan said. ``But with this system, you're in a community.'' Inspired by environmental issues discussed on BreadNet, Wheelwright students organized an essay contest and a cleanup project on Beaver Creek, which runs in front of the school. They persuaded the city council in this town of 850 people to proclaim April 22 as Earth Day. Early next month, BreadNet will launch a writing conference addressing racial stereotypes, called ``Across Ethnic Lines.'' Students in about 30 classrooms from Moscow, Idaho, to Lima, Peru, will take part. Wheelwright High School students, still busy on their environmental project, won't be participating in the ethnic project. But just by participating in BreadNet, they have helped weaken their own stereotype of eastern Kentucky as a region of illiterate hillbillies, said Slone. ``They realize they're just like all other students all over the world,'' said Slone.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS four new grafs after 4th graf pvs to UPDATE with Jackson quotes; pick up 5th graf pvs: Earlier, Virginia ...
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson today told moderate and conservative Democrats hoping to guide their party back to the White House that they must unite around the ``mainstream values'' of working Americans. ``The Democrats must find common ground as the party of those who live on their paychecks,'' said Jackson who has twice sought the Democratic presidential nomination. Jackson told the annual convention of the Democratic Leadership Council that all factions of the party must come together. He said that was possible because Democrats are increasingly united on such issues as choice in abortion, fighting crime and drugs and government aid to those in need. ``We're talking about mainstream values and that's a wider stream than many thought,'' Jackson said. ``If it's morally right, it can't be politically wrong for long.'' He also told the group, however, that civil rights do not represent a privilege. Jackson said that in the past Democrats have questioned whether they could win as ``the party of inclusion.'' He said some progressives wanted to start a third party following Ronald Reagan's victory and the Republican capture of the Senate a decade ago. Meanwhile, Democrats ``argued that the party would benefit by excluding or attacking so-called special interest.'' ``We contended that we had to stay and build a rainbow coalition,'' Jackson said. ``Make our party bigger and stronger.'' He said registration drives brought in a bumper crop of new voters who helped the party regain control of the Senate in 1986. ``The mainstream is becoming a mighty river, uniting many streams,'' Jackson said. Earlier, Virginia Gov. L. Douglas Wilder told the group that all Democrats must strongly support the party's presidential nominee in 1992. The meeting of the leadership council, formed by conservative and moderate Democrats to counter the party's purported leftward drift, occurs as the party's governing Democratic National Committee continues its spring meeting in Indianapolis. Wilder, the nation's first black elected governor, told the council, ``Those who lose our primaries must reject the temptation to cling to a sense of personal injury and defeat. They must unite behind the party's candidate.'' Texas Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, a potential candidate in 1992, was warmly received by the 900 people at the DLC conference Friday as he led attacks on the Republican administration. Speakers accused President Bush of timidity in foreign policy and hypocrisy on taxes. Bentsen said the president's proposed budget contains $20 million in ``crypto-taxes'' disguised as user fees, surcharges and other levies. He called Bush's repeated no-new-taxes stance as ``pure bushlips.'' Asked about 1992, he said he is not planning a run for the presidency. The 69-year-old senator was the Democratic nominee for vice president in 1988. Democratic Chairman Ron Brown divided his time Friday between New Orleans and Indianapolis and denied the scheduling conflict between the DLC and the DNC was a sign of party division. He also denied his disagreement with Bentsen over Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan's proposed cut in Social Security payroll taxes showed a lack of party unity. Brown called Friday for the party to endorse the Moynihan plan. Bentsen said a rollback of last year's Social Security tax increase might be in order, but that Moynihan's cut, at $50 billion, would be too costly. ``Just because we don't have every `i' dotted and every `t' crossed doesn't mean we are not unified,'' Brown said. ``We're having an open and honest discussion about very complicated Matters.'' House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt of Missouri chided Bush for failing to react strongly to changes in Central America, Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. ``Our president refuses to risk not even one percentage point of his 82 percent popularity polls to ask us to do what needs to be done,'' Gephardt told the council.

DOC.HEAD: Condor Comeback Takes Wing with Two More Hatchings
DOC.TEXT: The hatchings of two healthy California condors late last week and the possibility of eight to 10 chicks in all this breeding season could accelerate the program to return the endangered species to the wild, a zoo official said. A 5.8-ounce bird named Kareya, from the Karok Indian word meaning ``creator of all things,'' emerged at 4:30 a.m. Friday, the first of the vulturelike chicks to hatch at the Los Angeles Zoo, said spokeswoman Cindy Richardson. Its gender won't be known for about three months. Kareya's hatching came only a little more than 24 hours after the second chick of the 1990 breeding season, Honsi, was hatched early Thursday at the San Diego Wild Animal Park. It was less than two years ago that the first California condor chick was hatched after being bred in captivity. A chick named Molloko was hatched at San Diego on April 29, 1988, amid national fanfare. The latest hatchings nudged the total population of the species to 35, all in the two zoos. There were only 27 known California condors when all were taken into captivity for breeding in 1987. Scientists are trying to breed enough of the birds, which can have a wingspan of nearly 10 feet, to begin returning some to their natural habitat. Wildlife officials had planned on releasing the first of the condors sometime between 1993 and 1995. But Michael Wallace, curator for birds at the Los Angeles Zoo, said the captive breeding program has achieved such success that the first birds could be released in the Los Padres National Forest next year. Officials hope to establish a wild flock there while they keep a healthy captive flock, he said. Other release areas could include the Grand Canyon or Northern California. Two eggs are under incubation in Los Angeles, and four in San Diego, making for a possible record breeding season, Wallace said. The incubation period for condor eggs is about two months. Under the captive breeding program, four chicks were hatched last year, in addition to the one hatched in 1988. The condor's breeding season runs from January through April. In 1984, eight eggs were taken from the wild and hatched. ``We're hoping for between eight to 10 youngsters this year,'' Wallace said. Kareya, like Honsi, appeared healthy and hungry, zoo officials said. ``It's had its first feeding of minced mice,'' Wallace said.

DOC.HEAD: Serbia Takes Control Of Police, Troop Movements Reported
DOC.TEXT: The government deployed soldiers across the troubled province of Kosovo to restore order Saturday following renewed unrest sparked by a mysterious illness affecting hundreds of ethnic Albanians. At the same time, the Serbian republic announced it was assuming direct control of Kosovo's police, a move that could increase tensions. The police force is dominated by ethnic Albanians, who form 90 percent of Kosovo's population. The minority Serbs and Montenegrins have accused them of failing to provide adequate protection to minority groups in Kosovo, a province within Serbia. More than 60 people have died in ethnic violence in the province in the past year. The latest unrest was triggered by a mysterious illness that hospitalized about 1,000 people, most of them ethnic Albanian children and teen-agers, last week. The victims suffered lung and skin irritation, and there were allegations by ethnic Albanians they had been poisoned. Most of the patients had been released by Saturday, but hospital sources said a few were still arriving for treatment. The cause of the illness had not been determined. A dozen military tanks were on the outskirts of Podujevo on Saturday, 20 miles north of the provincial capital of Pristina. Troop movements were also reported at Pec, Vucitrn, Titova Mitrovica, Djakovica and Prizren, Radio Belgrade said. With an overwhelmingly ethnic Albanian population, Podujevo is considered a hotbed of the group's struggle for the autonomy Kosovo lost when Serbia assumed direct control of its judiciary and education a year ago. A Western journalist who demanded anonymity said he saw police headquarters in Podujevo surrounded Saturday by at least 40 policemen in battle gear. He said police carrying submachine guns were all over the city. Jim Fish, a British reporter for the British Broadcasting Corp., told The Associated Press he was detained by police for two hours and questioned when he returned to Podujevo following a visit to a nearby village. He said he passed a column of tanks outside Podujevo. A French medical team was reported en route to Kosovo to try to determine the cause of the mysterious illness. Serbian authorities have said there is no medical evidence to back claims of poisoning, but ethnic Albanian activists on Friday sought a second opinion. The Croatian daily newspaper Vjesnik reported that at least one Serb policeman and one Serb schoolgirl also sought treatment in Titova Mitrovica, north of Pristina, for the illness.

DOC.HEAD: Fireworks Kill at Least 25 at Hindu Temple
DOC.TEXT: Fireworks stored in a shed caught fire Saturday and erupted in a massive blast that killed at least 25 people and injured more than 70 at a festival in southern India, news agencies reported. The fireworks were in a shed next to a Hundu temple and were to be used in a fireworks competition marking the end of the 10-day festival in Malanada, 1,380 miles south of New Delhi, United News of India reported. Press Trust of Indian put the death toll at 25, but United News said it was 26. The festival had been scheduled to end Friday night with a shower of light in a competitive display by two major fireworks manufacturers, United News said. But a heavy downpour delayed the event. About 2:30 a.m. Saturday, fire broke out in the shed where one company had stored its fireworks, the news agency reported. It said many of the victims were employees of the fireworks company. Temple officials thought the fire might have been caused by a short circuit in the shed, which had been provided with a temporary electrical connection, United News said. But it said other sources thought it was sparked by a cigarette discarded by someone seeking shelter from the rain.

DOC.HEAD: American F-14 Fighter Lands on Nose in Northeast Brazil
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. F-14 fighter plane suffered minor damage Saturday when its front wheel gave out on landing and it came to rest on its nose, a civil aviation official said. The official, who would only identify himself as Moreira, said neither the pilot nor co-pilot was injured. Moreira said the F-14 was based on an aircraft carrier from Recife, 1,500 miles northeast of Rio. The pilot landed at the airport in Recife after reporting a problem with his landing gear, Moreira said. TV Globo, Brazil's largest commercial network, showed film of the plane nose-down on the runway with several fire engines nearby. Globo said the fire engines covered the runway with anti-fire foam.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Paul Newman took the day off from his salad dressing trial here to search for a site to locate a second camp for children who are seriously ill. Newman has already established the Hole In The Wall Gang Camp in Ashford. It entertains boys and girls ages 7 to 17 with cancer or other life-threatening illnesses. Newman's lawyer, Leo Nevas, said Newman went to Florida on Friday to scout locations for the second camp, which will also aid children with serious diseases. ``All the seed money will come from him,'' Nevas said, while others will provide donations to keep the camp going. Nevas said plans are also under way to site a third camp in England, which would be supported with donations made overseas. Newman founded the Ashford camp in June 1988 on 300 acres around a lake. His gourmet food company, Newman's Own Inc., donated $7 million in startup costs, while other funds were raised for construction and an endowment. The camp offers horseback riding, boating, baseball, tennis and other summer activities for youngsters, who are supervised by medical professionals from Yale-New Haven Hospital. The camp was named after a gang of outlaws in the movie, ``Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid,'' which starred Newman and Robert Redford. Nevas was unsure when the second or third camps would be built. Newman and Newman's Own are being sued in Bridgeport Superior Court by a Connecticut delicatessen owner who claims he was promised stock for helping to launch the company. Newman denies any deal. The Academy Award-winning actor took Friday off, but has been in court since the trial began Tuesday. He's expected to testify this week.

``The Marriage of Figaro'' set in the Trump Tower? ``Don Giovanni'' in Spanish Harlem? Avant garde director-playwright Peter Sellars says ``Bravo!'' Sellars, conductor Craig Smith and administrator Robert Canon announced Friday the creation of a new company to stage the productions at the Colonial Theater in January 1991. The group will stage five performances of Sellars' updated ``The Marriage of Figaro,'' set in the Trump Tower and conducted by Smith. The first full season will be in 1991 to 1992, according to a news release. It will also include Sellars' ``Don Giovanni,'' set in Spanish Harlem, and ``Cosi fan tutte,'' set in a diner on Cape Cod. Plans for Boston Opera Theater were released after months of speculation that the trio would form a company after Canon resigned as general manager of Sarah Caldwell's Opera Company of Boston in April 1989. Canon said the company would feature modern productions of standard repertory and development of new works by living American composers. Sellars, the former director of the Boston Shakespeare Company, is known for his unusual and often controversial stagings of plays and operas.

Master chef Julia Child thinks she knows how to make broccoli pleasing to the presidential palate. Mrs. Child's ``Broccoli a la Bush'' involves blanching cut broccoli, then sauteing it in olive oil and garlic. The garlic, while not completely overpowering the vegetable, creates an altogether different taste, she said. Mrs. Child whipped up a quick recipe using the vegetable banned from the chief executive's plate on a WWDB-FM radio show on Friday morning. ``President Bush would love to eat broccoli if it was prepared in this way,'' Mrs. Child said. She called ``Broccoli a la Bush'' the first recipe created as a solution to 10 tons of the vegetable the White House has received from growers objecting to the president's decision to ban broccoli from his plane, Air Force One. Mrs. Child, author of seven cookbooks, is on a 12-city tour for the American Institute of Wine & Food, discussing her philosophy on cooking. Bush told reporters he hasn't liked broccoli ``since I was a little kid and my mother made me eat it, and I'm president of the United States and I'm not going to eat any more broccoli!''

Polish Solidarity leader Lech Walesa will visit Norway next month, six years after he failed to personally receive his Nobel Peace Prize. Walesa arrives April 25, at the start of a Scandinavian trip which will include Denmark, Sweden and Finland, said Kaare Sandegren, of the Norwegian Confederation of Labor Unions, which invited Walesa. The Nobel laureate will meet the Norwegian committee which selects peace prize winners, as well as government, union and business leaders, Sandegren said Friday. Danuta Walesa accepted the 1983 peace prize in Oslo on her husband's behalf, because Walesa feared that he would be barred from returning to Poland if he left.

U.S. Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos says Mexico and the United States could learn a lot from each other about educating their youth. Cavazos was awarded an honorary doctorate from the University of Guadalajara on Friday and stressed the importance of relations between the two countries in his address. ``Knowledge of other countries was, in the past, a subject of study for academic reasons,'' he said. ``But in the future it will be a crucial element of economic competitiveness in a peaceful, multipolar world.'' He urged greater educational cooperation between the United States and Mexico, which share a 2,000-mile border.

Blues musicians such as Koko Taylor and the Kinsey Report with Big Daddy Kinsey are planning to say so long to one of their own this weekend. The musicians will gather Sunday at B.L.U.E.S. Etcetra for a fund-raiser to help cover the medical and funeral costs for Larry ``Big Twist'' Nolan, who died March 14. He was 53. ``His songs also made me miss him,'' wife, Yvonne Nolan. ``Some of his songs gave me the blues.'' Ken Morton of Alligator Records, which recorded the album ``Big Twist and the Mellow Fellows'' in Chicago, said the show would both celebrate Nolan's memory and help raise money for his family. ``There undoubtedly will be a big turnout of musicians,'' he said. ``There will be some kind of jam session at the end.'' Sunday's lineup includes the Mellow Fellows, as well as Taylor, Lonnie Brooks and the Kinsey group. Nolan, who once tipped the scales at 385 pounds, spent the latter part of his life in excruciating pain, said guitarist and bandleader Pete Special. For the past two years, he underwent dialysis treatment, and more recently he underwent back surgery.

DOC.HEAD: Pryor Moved From Intensive Care, May Resume Fishing Trip
DOC.TEXT: Doctors took Richard Pryor out of intensive care Saturday, four days after the actor-comedian suffered a mild heart attack, hospital officials said. Pryor's agent said Pryor may resume his fishing vacation after he is released from the hospital. Pryor, 49, was admitted to Wesley Hospital after suffering a heart attack Tuesday. He was listed in stable condition Saturday. The hospital administrator, Douglas Killer, said Pryor probably would be discharged by Tuesday. ``He's fine and progressing well,'' the hospital official said. ``We're very pleased with him. It's given him quite a fright but he's in good spirits.'' Killer said the comedian was watching video cassettes in his room. Pryor, star of ``Harlem Nights,'' ``Stir Crazy,'' and many other films, collapsed while vacationing on the Gold Coast strip in northeastern Australia. He was admitted to hospital with chest pain, later diagnosed as a minor heart attack. His agent, Guy McElwaine, said Pryor was in Australia to fish on the Great Barrier Reef for marlin ``and then planned to go to New Zealand to fish for trout. He may still do that, depending on how he's feeling.'' The comedian was burned severely and nearly killed in 1980 while freebasing cocaine, which involves heating the drug over an open flame. He recounted that experience and other hardships in his life in the films ``Richard Pryor Live on the Sunset Strip'' and ``Jo Jo Dancer, Your Life is Calling.'' Other film credits include ``See No Evil, Hear No Evil,'' ``Brewster's Millions,'' ``Critical Condition,'' ``Richard Pryor Here and Now,'' ``Richard Pryor Live in Concert'' and ``Richard Pryor Is Back Live in Concert.'' Pryor is due to start filming ``My Silent Partner'' with Gene Wilder in May.

DOC.HEAD: Suits Draw Attention to Risks Of Quick Weight-Loss
DOC.TEXT: As word of lawsuits against Nutri-System Inc. spreads, the telephones at a law firm here handling the case are getting a workout. Hundreds of calls have been logged from dieters complaining of gallbladder problems or seeking information after shedding pounds under the Nutri-System regime of specialty pre-packaged foods. ``This phone stays on my ear constantly,'' said attorney Robert Fiore, who is representing some of the 19 women who filed separate suits last week. ``We've received calls from all over the United States and Canada. We're just trying to deal with the influx now.'' The company defends its program as safe and says the gallbladder problems are coincidental. Although Fiore said he was unprepared for the response, some experts in diet and nutrition say they've spent years studying the perils of obesity and rapid weight loss, both of which can affect the gallbladder and blood pressure. But they say the popular Nutri-System program should not singled out. It can provide several hundred more calories a day above some liquid diets, the focus of several studies on gallbladder problems. ``As a nation we are grossly overweight and that is a problem in itself,'' said Miami dietitian Joyce Julien. ``But often these extremely low-calorie diets can lead to an increase in gallstones and hypertension. I think these suits are just the tip of the iceberg.'' Presently, there are no direct federal regulations on the $5 billion a year commercial diet industry. On Monday, however, a congressional committee will hold the first of a series of hearings on those promising a quick path to slim bodies. Among those scheduled to testify before the Committee on Small Business are Federal Trade Commission Chairman Janet Steiger, several physicians and former followers of extremely low-calorie diets _ some under 1,000 calories a day. ``It's a wide-open field right now,'' said D. Ann Murphy, a staff member of the U.S. House Subcommittee on Regulation, Business Opportunities and Energy. ``The public is so interested in quick loss that there's tremendous opportunity for abuse.'' Nutri-System has nearly 1,600 weight-loss centers in all 50 states, Canada, the United Kingdom and Australia. It offers a 1,000- to 1,500-calorie-a-day meal program and can cost several hundred dollars to enroll, depending on weight-loss goals and special promotions offered. The Dade Circuit Court suits against Nutri-System claim the company's weight-loss program caused gallstones and led to surgical removal of the organ, which produces and stores bile used in digestion. The company, one of the nation's most heavily marketed diet programs, said the suits are without merit. It claimed the risk of gallbladder disease among the obese can be reduced by prudent dieting. ``There's been many studies to show that overweight people have a higher incidence of gallbladder problems,'' said Nutri-System spokesman James Kemper Millard at the company's Willow Grove, Pa., headquarters. ``We just want the facts out. We don't want this to be another `Martians have landed' story.'' The company is privately held and does not release financial reports. Millard said Nutri-Systems encourages about a two-pound-a-week weight loss. The American Medical Association does not set a standard or limit for weight reduction. The 60,000-member American Dietetic Association recommends rapid weight-loss programs only for those more than 30 percent overweight. ``The consensus is that there appears to be a link between rapid weight loss and gallbladder problems, but it dosen't necessarily have to be a diet by a company. It could be something the person goes on themselves,'' said Dr. Georgia Andrianopoulos, an assistant professor at the University of Illinois' Obesity Treatment Center. Nancy Wellman, president of the American Dietetic Association, said some of the reported gallbladder problems could be from people who cut back on established diets, such as Nutri-System. ``We are a country where most problems can be solved in a half-hour TV show,'' said Wellman. ``Too many people opt for the quick solution to lose weight without worrying about the consequences.''

DOC.HEAD: Flood Toll: Thousands Homeless, 15 Dead, Millions in Damage
DOC.TEXT: The Deep South is wringing itself out after a week of flooding turned entire towns into muddy lakes where buildings poked up like knotty tree stumps, but the toll of shattered lives is mounting. About 6,000 people lost their homes or had property damage in Alabama, federal officials estimated Saturday. Hundreds more had to seek shelter in Georgia and the Florida Panhandle, where swirling floodwaters kept emergency crews on alert through the weekend. Florida Gov. Bob Martinez toured the flood-ravaged farming town of Caryville on Saturday. He promised house-to-house damage assessments, portable toilets, drinking water and food. Emergency management officials said flooding did more than $100 million in damage in Alabama, and high water there and in Georgia was blamed for 15 deaths _ mostly people whose cars sank on submerged roads. Searchers in south Alabama continued to look Saturday for Army Spec. Mary Helen Garrison, 21, missing since March 18. Her car was found submerged in a ditch Tuesday. The southeastern Alabama town of Elba, which lies along the banks of the Pea River, was hit hardest by the flooding. The town was submerged under about 12 feet of brown, trash-filled water when its earthen levee collapsed early March 17 after 16 inches of rain fell in two days. Nearly half of Elba's 4,400 residents had to be evacuated, and most could not begin returning to homes and businesses for three days. Legal records turned into soggy mush as water reached the second floor of the Coffee County Courthouse. ``A lifetime of hard work for some disappeared into the raging floodwaters,'' Alabama Gov. Guy Hunt said Saturday in his weekly radio address. ``A lot of our people have never witnessed such devastation from flood before.'' Raging floodwaters also washed out dozens of roads and bridges in southern Alabama. Volunteers in Geneva, located downstream from Elba, saved that city's levee only by working feverishly in a human chain pitching sandbags for two days. The flooding reached into western Alabama, where waters rose to the ceiling inside Brewton City Hall. And in the central part of the state, coffins bobbed to the surface from shallow graves when a cemetery flooded in Selma, and about 160 animals had to be taken to higher ground when the Montgomery Humane Society flooded. President Bush declared Elba and the rest of Coffee County a disaster area Wednesday, making residents eligible for low-interest loans and grants to cover uninsured losses. On Friday, 25 Alabama counties were added to the declaration. ``You're talking about damage that would take years and years and years to repair,'' said Robert Crowder, commission chairman in Houston County. Country singer Hank Williams Jr. pledged receipts from an April 1 concert in Birmingham to the relief effort. Hunt said officials in Charleston, S.C., which is still recovering six months after a battering from Hurricane Hugo, also offered aid. While most of the water receded from Elba, Florida Panhandle residents to the south were fording flood-covered streets, hoping to find their homes intact. ``It just kind of stuns you a little bit,'' said Lamar Fortune of Caryville, Fla. The lumber worker had to wade through 2 feet of brown water late in the week to get home after the Choctawhatchee River expanded out of its banks. In Georgia, where four died in flood-related traffic accidents, Macon residents were urged to boil drinking water after the Ocmulgee River surged into a sewage treatment plant. Raw sewage poured directly into the Chattahoochee River in Atlanta and Columbus because of flooded treatment facilities. But the flooding seemed especially cruel in Alabama, where unending waves of severe weather have killed 35 people since mid-November, including at least 11 in the past week. Twenty people died when a tornado rampaged through Huntsville in north Alabama in November, and five died in a Christmas cold snap that included wind-chill factors of 40 degrees below zero. Violent weather is nothing new to the South, which has regular brushes with tornadoes, hurricanes, crop-killing freezes and flooding. But to have such a cluster of wicked weather is unusual, said Paul Pettit, a National Weather Service meterologist in Montgomery. ``And we're really not out of the flood season. March, April and May are the prime time for severe weather'' in Alabama, said Pettit.

DOC.HEAD: Hungary's Election at a Glance
With AM-Hungary, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a look at Sunday's Hungarian election: AT STAKE: _ There are 386 seats in the parliament, or National Assembly, elected for a four-year term. An additional eight seats will be allotted to the eight main national minorities. ELIGIBLE VOTERS AND RULES: _ There are more than 7.8 million eligible voters, choosing from among 29 parties. Only 12 parties are running nationally, and the 17 others are contesting only a few races. Twenty-one parties fielded no candidates. A second round of voting is mandatory if no party wins an absolute majority. Runoff elections are also possible in individual races where there is no clear majority. _ All Hungarian citizens who have reached 18 years of age by March 25 or are considered adults because they are married are eligible to vote. ELECTION SUPERVISION: _ The Vienna-based International Helsinki Human Rights Association has a delegation in Hungary monitoring the election campaign and the election itself. _ The Council of Europe, based in Strassbourg, planned to send a delegation to monitor the election. _ Former Vice President Walter Mondale led a 50-member international delegation acting as observers for the election. MAIN PARTIES RUNNING: _ Twelve parties fielded candidates on a national scale. The six frontrunners, acccording to a March 12 Gallup poll were: the Hungarian Democratic Forum; the League of Free Democrats; the Independent Smallholders' Party; the Hungarian Socialist Party; the Social Democratic Party of Hungary, and the League of Young Democrats. The Hungarian Democratic Forum is a centrist party with 21,000 members, fielding 174 candidates. Chairman: Jozsef Antall, 58. The League of Free Democrats is a liberal party with 20,000 members, fielding 169 candidates. Chairman: Janos Kis, 46. The Independent Smallholders' Party is a rural party with 60,000 members, running 165 candidates. Chairman: Vince Voeroes, 79. The governing Hungarian Socialist Party is a West European-type socialist party, established by reformists in the Communist Party. It has 62,000 members and has 170 candidates. Chairman: Rezsoe Nyers, 67. The Social Democratic Party of Hungary is a member of the Socialist International, has 12,000 members and is fielding 74 candidates. Chairwoman: Anna Petrasovits, 36. The League of Young Democrats is a liberal youth party that sets an age limit of 35 years for its more than 5,000 members. It is fielding 80 candidates and is led by a steering committee. ISSUES: _ The primary issue is the economy, with a $20 billion foreign debt, much of it accrued to finance the domestic debt. The electorate and the parties are equally aware that any new government has very little room to maneuver. With growing unemployment, job security is an issue, but cutting state subsidies and privatization can only mean a growing jobless rate. _ Other issues include the lot of the Hungarian national minorities in neighboring countries and that of domestic minorities _ Gypsies, for instance. Also, some complain that a full-scale Soviet troop withdrawal is proceeding too slowly.

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Militants Kill Five, Kidnap One
DOC.TEXT: Moslem militants killed five people who opposed their fight for independence from predominantly Hindu India and kidnapped a former legislator, officials said Saturday. At least 195 people, mostly Moslem demonstrators, have been killed in the northern state of Jammu-Kashmir since Jan. 20 when the government launched a crackdown on the separatists. State officials said four of the five people killed Friday and Saturday were Moslems. They were identified as a deputy police superintendent; the 73-year-old local leader of the Communist Party of India; the grandson of another prominent Communist leader; and a man accused of being a police informer. The fifth victim was a civilian, the sources added, speaking on condition of anonymity. It was unclear if he was Hindu or Moslem. The former state legislator, Mir Mustafa, was pulled out of his car at gunpoint Saturday near his home in Badgam, 12 miles west of Srinagar, officials said. Srinagar has been a focal point of the fighting between government troops and separatists. Family members and highly placed sources in the government of Jammu-Kashmir said no group has claimed responsibility for the abduction and no demands were issued. Mustafa was an independent member of the state legislature. The governing body was dissolved in January when the federal crackdown was ordered. In December, Mustafa helped negotiate a prisoner exchange in which the kidnapped daughter of Home Minister Mufti Mohammad Saeed was swapped for five prominent members of the radical Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front. The front is one of several Moslem militant groups waging a campaign of bombings and assassinations to press demands for the independence of Kashmir, a part of Jammu-Kashmir state. Jammu-Kashmir is the only Moslem-majority state in India. The secession movement has been simmering since 1947, when the state of Kashmir was divided between India and Moslem Pakistan. The eastern part of the state is governed by India. The western slice of Kashmir is under Pakistan's control. The two countries went to war twice over Kashmir, and their armies still face each other along the disputed frontier.

DOC.HEAD: New York Governor Signs Expanded `Shield Law' For News Media
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mario Cuomo expanded New York's ``shield law'' on Saturday to protect the news media from having to surrender to the courts most information collected by reporters and television crews. ``Enactment of the bill is particularly appropriate this year as we celebrate the bicentennial of the First Amendment,'' Cuomo said in signing the legislation. ``Since 1735, when Peter Zenger was acquitted of libel charges, New York has led the way in the protection of freedom of the press.'' Cuomo, a Democrat who is expected to seek election this year to a third term, announced his action just before speaking at a meeting of the New York State Society of Newspaper Editors. While New York's shield law, adopted in 1970, had protected information gathered on a confidential basis from sources, recent state court rulings had said there was no such protection for information gathered without a promise of confidentiality. Under the expanded law, unpublished information or that supplied without a pledge of confidentiality doesn't have to be given up by news organizations in most circumstances. A court could still order the information divulged if it determined the material was critical to a case and not obtainable from any alternative source. ``The bill strikes an appropriate balance between the principle of a free press embodied in the First Amendment and a defendant's right to a fair trial,'' said Cuomo. The legislation was passed, 47-5, on Wednesday by the Republican-controlled state Senate. In January, the Democrat-controlled Assembly had approved it 119-11. The legislation gives New York one of the strictest protections for journalists of any state in the nation, according to lawyers for several news organizations. A similar bill failed to pass the state Senate by two votes in the waning hours of the legislative session last year. As was the case in 1989, the opposition to the legislation this year was led by state Sen. Emanuel Gold. ``I don't think there's a newspaper in the world that doesn't preach in favor of good citizenship,'' said Gold, a New York City Democrat. ``It seems in some situations, the newspapers can't be bothered by the requirements of good citizenship.'' Cuomo noted that approval of the legislation was pushed by the New York Publishers Association, the New York State Broadcasters Association, Capital Cities-ABC, CBS, NBC, The Associated Press and the Gannett Co.

DOC.HEAD: Lantos Praises Labor Dept. Plan To Stem Pension Fund Fraud
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 4th graf pvs, bgng: The Labor, to CORRECT employers to employees
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of a House panel studying the health of the nation's $1.7 trillion pension system praised a Labor Department proposal designed to crack down on fraud and abuse in the system. Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., who is chairman of the House Government Operations employment and housing subcommittee, called Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole's plan ``prompt and inclusive.'' In the past, members of Congress have criticized the way the Labor Department policed the nation's pension system and suggested that fraud and abuse could rival the savings and loan crisis. The Labor Department's proposal, outlined last week in a letter to Lantos' panel, increases fines for fraudulent transactions and makes it easier for employees to bring lawsuits against pension fund trustees who mismanage assets. It also provides rewards for people who inform the government of fund violations. Some of the changes stemmed from recommendations from acting Labor Department Inspector General Raymond Maria, who has been feuding with the agency over the way it investigates pension fraud. ``They went twice as far as we thought they would,'' Lisa Phillips, an aide to Lantos' subcommittee, said Friday. Phillips predicted some lawmakers would try to go farther by adding provisions to provide greater protection of pension payments when companies terminate plans to capture their surplus assets. Labor Department spokeswoman Johanna Schneider said the agency would have to review further changes before taking a position. Under the department's plan, employees who win suits against trustees who mismanaged pension plans would have their legal fees paid by the trustees personally rather than through pension assets. In addition, the plan lets Mrs. Dole pay a ``bounty'' to informers of as much as 10 percent of any fines collected by the government for pension violations. Penalties for illegal transactions would increase to 10 percent of the amount of the transaction. Fines are now 5 percent of the transaction. The agency's plan also implements new audit procedures that require accountants to do a full audit of pension plans on their own rather than relying on the statements of state examiners. Mrs. Dole already has asked Congress to add 100 enforcement officers to the department's Pension and Welfare Benefits Administration. The Labor proposal does not include Maria's recommendation that the inspector general's office be allowed to pursue criminal investigations of pension and welfare fund violations. Maria wanted Congress to in effect overturn a Justice Department ruling that prohibited inspectors general from conducting criminal investigations. Phillips said the House subcommittee was not likely to go against the Labor Department on the issue because lawmakers considered it a ``turf war'' between the Justice Department and inspectors general. Maria had known he was not going to be named to the post permanently; President Bush last week nominated Julian De La Rosa, executive secretary of the St. Louis police board, as his replacement.

DOC.HEAD: Pomp Marks Departure Of Last Indian Troops; Rebels Take Back Region
LaserPhoto COL3
DOC.TEXT: Serenaded by ``Auld Lang Syne,'' the last Indian soldiers withdrew from this northeastern port city Saturday after a deadlocked 2{-year-old jungle war against Tamil guerrillas. Sri Lanka's navy band played and its honor guard unsheathed swords as the 2,000 Indian soldiers _ the last of an estimated 125,000 _ marched aboard the troop carrier Magar, which left for Madras in southern India. The departure was a week ahead of the pullout deadline. ``You have made a great sacrifice, there is no doubt about that,'' Sri Lankan Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne told the troops. At least 1,115 Indian troops died fighting the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, the largest Tamil militant group fighting Sri Lanka's Sinhalese-dominated government for an independent homeland. About 10,000 Sri Lankans have died in the insurgency, which started in 1983. As the troop carrier chugged out into the bay, Tamil Tigers patrolled Trincomalee's streets, along with Sri Lankan soldiers and police. India, which also has a large Tamil minority, sent soldiers into Sri Lanka in July 1987 to help enforce a treaty that granted the Tamil minority limited autonomy in the northeast if they put down their weapons. The Tigers refused to do so, and began battling the Indian soldiers. President Ranasinghe Premadasa of Sri Lanka reached an agreement with the Tamil Tigers last summer and asked India to withdraw its troops by July 27, 1989, the second anniversary of the peace accord. India stalled on the request, saying a rapid withdrawal could lead to a bloodbath. But in his election campaign last fall, India's new prime minister, V.P. Singh, promised to withdraw the troops. A deadline of March 31 was set. The Sun, a leading Sri Lankan newspaper, said the withdrawal signals the end of a ``chapter that is historic as much as traumatic to this nation and its people. For most people in this country, the ultimate withdrawal of the Indian troops is a joyous scent.'' Many Indian newspapers criticized the military operation, accusing their government of fighting ``somebody else's dirty war.'' Others called it a military disaster because India did not succeed in disarming the Tamil separatists. The Tigers now control the area Indian soldiers once occupied. A senior leader of the guerrilla organization, contacted by telephone, said the Tigers had no immediate comment on the pullout. The leader, who spoke on condition of anonymity, was reached in the Tiger-held town of Jaffna. ``The soldiers' morale is high. We don't think we have lost a war. We're just obeying orders,'' said an Indian commando on the Trincomalee dock, pushing back his red beret to wipe sweat from his forehead. In addition to the Indian-Tamil violence, the July 1987 accord also sparked a backlash by ultranationalist Sinhalese, who felt the Tamils had been given too many concessions. They began a violent campaign that has left at least 6,000 people dead since 1987. Tamils, who are mostly Hindus, make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people. The predominantly Buddhist Sinhalese make up 75 percent of the population. Tamils claim they suffer discrimination. India became involved in the conflict because of the sympathies of its own politically powerful Tamil population. Most Indian Tamils live in the southern state of Tamil Nadu, which is separated from Sri Lanka by a stretch of sea 20 miles wide.

DOC.HEAD: Notes on Hungary's First Free National Elections in 43 Years
With AM-Hungary, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Campaign rivalries were played out in ``poster wars'' before Sunday's parliamentary election. Some observations on the last few days of the campaign and related events:

Party militants vented their emotions in the ``poster war.'' Rivals competed in papering over each other's ads, and some wags livened up placards they found too staid. One wit looking ahead to the day after the elections couldn't resist a poster by the Hungarian Democratic Forum, a centrist party with a strong following. To the placard boasting, ``Today, the MDF Is Tomorrow,'' he added: ``But The Day After, You're Yesterday.''

One of the few controversies of the campaign centered around another Forum poster that critics said awakened thoughts of violence. The poster showed the back of the head of a bull-necked Soviet officer with the Russian phrase, ``Comrades, It's All Over.'' With a full-scale pullout of Red Army troops in progress and a general diminishing of Soviet influence in Hungary's internal affairs, Democratic Forum officials said the message was meant to signal the end of an era. But numerous Hungarians _ including Socialist Party chairman Rezsoe Nyers, a reformed Communist _ said the phrase and imagery bring forth associations of lining an enemy up against the wall and shooting him in the back of the head.

Most Communist images _ red stars, Lenin statues and hammers and sickles _ have been removed from view across Hungary over the past few months. But a plea to save at least some of the Communist legacy came from an unexpected quarter. The League of Young Democrats, the first opposition party to openly challenge Communist rule, wants a park created for all the displaced Lenin statues. Given that the founder of Bolshevism is almost always shown pointing ahead into the communist future, the park would have scores of Lenin statutes, their fingers pointing accusingly at each other.

For at least one public figure, Sunday's elections are even more historic than is generally thought. Interim President Matyas Szueroes considered them the first truly democratic vote in 1,100 years. ``In Hungary's 1,100-year history in Central Europe, these elections will be unique in a sense,'' Szueroes said Saturday in his election message. ``This will be our first true opportunity to decide, vote and choose freely.''
