Szueroes apparently was alluding to contraints on voters even during the period of parliamentary democracy that began in 1848 and ended during World War II.

DOC.HEAD: Panamanian Pledges To Stem Money Laundering
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 3rd graf pvs, bgng: Ford, who, to CORRECT to last week
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Guillermo Ford of Panama said Saturday his new government is moving quickly to stifle the laundering of drug profits through Panama's banks. At a joint news conference with Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, Ford declared ``We're partners in a joint venture. We are committed to this battle.'' Ford, who last week lobbied Congress for a $500 million aid package, declared that ``The United States is not imposing anything on us. We are cooperating'' on the bank issue. Already, he noted, the new government has enacted a law which imposes stiffer fines for failure to report major cash transactions than those faced by U.S. banks. The penalties range from $100,000 to $1 million. Ford and Thornburgh met for about 30 minutes in the attorney general's office. ``Good friends can discuss everything in 30 minutes,'' Ford said. Thornburgh said ``The most important thing we did was exchange phone numbers. We're going to be working together on drug trafficking and money laundering. And we pledged to make available a number of key people to one another.'' Ford said ``We're not telling the world that we are no longer going to be a financial center. But we are going to be a decent, honest financial center.'' On Thursday, the House Banking Committee, moving with unusual speed, approved 48-0 a bill that would authorize the Treasury Department to revoke the charters of U.S. banks caught laundering drug money. Bank officers could be banned from the profession for life. The bill also reaches out to savings and loans, credit unions and even state-chartered banks, whose federal insurance could be revoked. The measure reflected congressional disappointment in the Justice Department's recent settlement of a money laundering case in Tampa, Fla., earlier this year. In that instance, two units of the Bank of Commerce and Credit International pleaded guilty to money laundering and conspiracy involving, among others, Panama's Gen. Manuel Noriega, now awaiting trial in Miami on drug charges. BCCI agreed to forfeit $14 million in deposits and $1 million in interest. While federal prosecutors hailed it as the largest criminal penalty ever imposed against a bank, congressional critics said it wasn't enough when measured against BCCI's assets of more than $20 billion. The institution is based in Luxembourg and has offices in 73 countries.

DOC.HEAD: Beaten Teen Tells Police Group Had Death Penalty For Dating Outsiders
DOC.TEXT: A band of Satanism-influenced youths called the Legion of Doom mandated the death penalty for members who dated outside the group and tried to carry out the sentence on an 18-year-old member, police charged. Members of the legion skipped school, played at Satanism and lived together as a family by their own rules, investigators said. They established death as the penalty for violating the dating rule, and the warrant was a piece of paper with a black dot on it. Troy Collins, 18, was handed his dotted paper in the woods west of Palm Beach on March 16, just before he was beaten with tire irons, chains and baseball bats, said Palm Beach County sheriff's detectives. Collins was listed in stable condition Saturday at Wellington Regional Hospital. In all, three juveniles and four adults were charged with attempted first-degree murder and with criminal mischief, sheriff's officials said. Another juvenile was charged as an accessory after the fact, and another with carrying a concealed firearm. More arrests are likely, sheriff's Detective Paul Friedman said Saturday. John Mears, 19, and Misty Perkins, 18, were released after posting bail, booking clerks said. Francis Essley and David Turner, both 21, remained in the county jail Saturday. After Collins regained consciousness Tuesday, he told deputies about the group and how members baited him into the woods under the guise of fighting a rival gang. Once there, he found he was to be punished for dating a non-member, he said. Collins told detectives he heard one member yell ``Kill him! Kill him!'' as he was being kicked and beaten. Collins said he escaped by losing his attackers in the woods. One of the juveniles confessed to participating in the attack, but the others gave conflicting stories and reasons for the attack, detectives said. There were ``15 to 20, if not more,'' legion members ranging in age from 14 to 21, Friedman said. Detectives are investigating the role of one boy's father, who allowed the group to stay with him and his son in a shabby concrete house west of the city. ``He knew what was going on,'' Friedman said, without elaborating. ``None of them lived at home. Most of them resided at the house,'' he said. ``It's a very loosely formed group of kids. It's got satanic overtones, but I would not say they're satanic ritualists.'' In searching the house Wednesday, deputies said, they found a bloody chain, baseball bat with hair on it and blood-soaked clothes and shoes. Satanic inscriptions and the words ``Legion of Doom'' were painted on walls inside the house.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Fears End to Soviet Immigration as Exit Route Closes
DOC.TEXT: Officials said Saturday they feared thousands of Jews could be left stranded in the Soviet Union after the national Soviet airline decided to stop selling tickets to emigres moving to Israel via Budapest. The decision by Aeroflot, the Soviet carrier, followed a move by Hungary's Malev airline to suspend flights of Soviet Jews to Israel due to threats of attacks by Arab radicals. ``We refuse to believe that the Soviet Union ... is subject to giving in to any type of terrorism,'' said Gad Ben Ari, spokesman for the quasi-governmental Jewish Agency. The Agency is partially responsible for the immigration and absorption of Jewish immigrants. ``We really can't understand the decision and are checking to find out the meaning of it,'' he said. ``If true, then it is definitely going to significantly damage the process of immigration to Israel.'' The majority of the thousands of Soviet Jews expected to immigrate to Israel this month were scheduled to travel via Budapest. Other smaller transit points are still open, but ``practically speaking, the Jews are stuck,'' said Ben Ari. Israeli officials said charter flights could be found to replace the Malev flights from Budapest to Israel, but this will not help if the emigres are unable to reach Budapest to begin with. Hungarian officials said they cut the Malev flights after threats from Arab extremists earlier this month. The pro-Iranian Lebanese group, Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine, threatened to attack any airline involved in the transport of Soviet Jews to Israel. Soviet television said Friday that Aeroflot would not sell tickets to emigrants traveling to Budapest from Moscow, Leningrad or Kiev. The television said Aeroflot would still transport businessmen and tourists. An Arabic newspaper reported Friday that Soviet and Israeli officials have been visiting Cyprus and Greece to discuss setting up a maritime line to bring Soviet Jews to Israel. The London-based Al Hayat newspaper quoted unnamed Greek and Arab sources as saying the ships could sail between the Black Sea port of Odessa and the Israeli port of Haifa. Officials in Cyprus and Greece could not be reached for comment and under new censorship regulations, Israeli officials are barred from commenting on routes taken by new immigrants. The Soviet Union has been under strong pressure from Arab states to limit the number of Jews immigrating to Israel. Arab states fear that Soviet immigrants will be sent to live in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, strengthening Israel's hold on the disputed territories. Israel says it has no policy of directing Soviet Jews to the occupied lands, home to almost 1.7 million Palestinians. PLO chairman Yasser Arafat repeated his call to end Soviet Jewish immigration to Israel in a statement Friday. ``For what reason do they come to my country instead of choosing Canada, a country still underpopulated, or Australia, or Latin America, or the Scandinavian countries, or the United States?'' Arafat said on Moroccan television. Israeli government statistics show that 16,700 Soviet Jews immigrated to Israel from Jan. 1, 1989, to Feb. 1, 1990. Of those, about 200 moved into the occupied territories. About 750,000 Soviet Jewish immigrants are expected in Israel this decade, due to eased exit policies in the Soviet Union and tighter U.S. entrance requirements.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Recovering After Mauling By Pit Bull
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Garry cq in 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: A 5-year-old boy mauled by a pit bull was recovering Saturday after surgery to repair painful bite wounds, hospital officials said. Garry Chisholm's condition was upgraded from serious to fair following the Friday night surgery, said Mark Morelli of Children's Hospital of San Diego. ``This morning, the youngster is awake and well-oriented, but in considerable discomfort,'' Morelli said Saturday. He said Garry would remain hospitalized for several days. Authorities said the boy was mauled Friday after he jumped a fence into a neighbor's back yard where the dog was kept. He was bitten on the back and side of the head and suffered multiple scrapes on his arms, back, chest and face. The pit bull's owner, Gabino De La Torre, found the shaken, bleeding youth when he and a friend returned home from the beach. The dog was placed in quarantine by the San Diego County Department of Animal Control. Agency officials said they will decide by Tuesday whether it will be destroyed and are also considering what legal action, if any, would be taken.

DOC.HEAD: Angry Citizens Drive Honecker Out of His House
DOC.TEXT: Angry citizens surrounded Erich Honecker's house and forced the disgraced Communist leader and his wife to move out Saturday, a day after they had moved in, a government spokesman said. The ailing 77-year-old Honecker and his wife, Margot, moved Friday from their two-room apartment in a parish home outside East Berlin to a better-equipped government residence about 50 miles away. They returned to the church refuge after just one night, because protesters gathered outside the new residence and created a ``dangerous situation,'' government spokesman Andreas Bauer said. West German television showed scores of irate residents surrounding the official motorcade as it carried the couple away. Some thumped on the roof of the Honeckers' car and made obscene gestures. The Lutheran church has been sheltering the ousted leader since Jan. 30. Nationwide pro-democracy demonstrations led to Honecker's downfall Oct. 18 after 18 years of hard-line rule. He faces trial on charges of high treason but is not jailed because he suffers kidney cancer. A pastor's couple, Sigrid and Thomas Holmer, gave the Honeckers shelter in their parish home after no one else wanted to take them. Mrs. Holmer said the couple had received bomb threats since then. The army refused to let the Honeckers live at a military base, saying it could not guarantee their safety.

DOC.HEAD: Gardner Reopens Pillaged Rooms; Museum Curators Bemoan Situation
DOC.TEXT: Art lovers saw empty spaces on the walls Saturday as the Gardner Museum reopened two rooms hardest hit by last week's multimillion-dollar art theft that has left curators worried about protecting works to valuable even to be insured. The FBI has circulated composite sketches of the two thieves, two international auction houses have posted a $1 million reward for information leading to the return of the works, and the museum has received tips on their whereabouts. The FBI has asked museum officials not to comment on the investigation for fear of slowing it, a museum spokesman said. But curators elsewhere are not optimistic. Sometimes, they say, art not recovered soon after being stolen doesn't resurface for years. ``Police tell us the word is out on the street that you can get money for art and antiquities,'' said Constance Lowenthal, executive director of the International Foundation for Art Research in New York. ``Museum trustees are thinking, `What if this happened to us?''' Wearing police uniforms, two men talked their way into the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum early on March 18 and made off with 11 paintings and prints by such artists as Rembrandt, Degas and Vermeer. They also swiped an ancient Chinese vase and a gilded eagle from a flagpole. The locations where the stolen paintings were mounted will not be filled because of restrictions in Mrs. Gardner's will about changing artwork, said museum spokesman Barry Wanger. He said the rooms have such a profusion of artwork, however, that the empty spaces are not startling. ``People visiting the museum for the first time probably won't notice so much,'' he said. Considered too well-known to be sold on to a legitimate collector, the haul from Mrs. Gardner's collection has been estimated to be worth hundreds of millions of dollars. Investigators offer several theories on why the treasures were stolen. A private collector with a penchant for the priceless might have commissioned the theft, a sort of ``Dr. No'' scenario that curators say is mostly the stuff of spy novels. The lesser-known works might be sold on the black market and resurface in respectable galleries in a few years. Or, most likely, the thieves might ransom the treasures either for the reward or for insurance money, though Gardner officials revealed this week that the works were not insured for theft. What is worrisome is that jumbo art heists seem to be increasing in both scale and frequency as art prices soar on the legal market. The loss in just a few recent thefts is staggering: _ Oct. 27, 1985: Five armed men steal nine impressionist paintings by painters such as Monet, Renoir and Berthe Morisot from the Marmottan Museum in Paris. One of the paintings, ``Impression: Sunrise,'' is the work that gave impressionism its name. The take: $12.5 million at 1985 prices. _ May 21, 1986: Thieves steal 18 paintings including Vermeer's ``Lady Writing a Letter With Her Maid'' from Russborough House in Blessington, Ireland. The take: $40 million. _ Feb. 8, 1988: Burglars break through a skylight into the Colnaghi Art Gallery in New York City and steal 27 Old Master paintings and drawings. The take: $6 million. Security consultants say museums are lagging in efforts to prevent art theft. Guards hired to protect multimillion-dollar paintings often are paid little more than minimum wage and given scant training. In addition, only a handful of police or federal agents across the country are trained to investigate art heists, and international laws make it easy to transport works across national borders. ``There's no duty on art,'' Lowenthal said. ``You couldn't just bring $20 million in cash into the country, but you could bring in a painting worth that much.'' The biggest problem in the long run, Lowenthal said, is that as more priceless works are stolen and art prices grow ever higher, museums won't be able to replace the art they lose. ``Museums just can't afford to replace expensive works,'' Lowenthal said. ``You can always get another Warhol print. You can't replace a Vermeer.''

DOC.HEAD: Source: Transition To Market Economy Planned, But Unemployment Feared
DOC.TEXT: Advisers to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev are working on a package of drastic reforms to convert the stagnant centrally controlled Soviet economy into a market system, an informed source said Saturday. But they are concerned the measures could cause widespread unemployment and force the government to institute a sweeping welfare program in a country where until recently, unemployment did not officially exist. ``The main problem is how to guarantee employment and take care of the needy,'' said the source, who is part of the team developing the new proposals. ``It all has to be worked out very carefully.'' Despite the note of caution, the source gave no indication Gorbachev has backed off his determination to press for radical measures to wrest the already sick economy from its downward slide. The source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the transition to a market economy might lead to a sharp increase in unemployment, which last year reached 27 percent in some areas of the country. He indicated the reform could make it necessary to initiate a widespread welfare system. The source provided the first independent confirmation of a published report that a drastic, 17-point economic reform program is being forged following Gorbachev's ascension to a new, stronger presidency. The report was circulated last week by the Soviet Interfax news agency, an affiliate of Radio Moscow. The package, designed by a team of economists, includes a reform of prices now set by state planners without regard to costs. Among other things, this has led to some farmers feeding their animals bread, which is cheaper than grain. Any lifting of price controls is expected to bring quick, dramatic inflation. The source said economists working on the plan were encouraged by the example of Poland, which decided to adopt a market system as quickly as possible to shorten the inevitably painful transition period. Soviet leaders have preferred to be slower and more cautious. Poland's Solidarity-led government last year lifted price controls over a six-month period, which led to enormous price increases. But there are signs the initial chaotic reaction is abating. Inflation in Poland dropped from a monthly rate of 60 percent to 70 percent in January to a projected 6 percent in March. Once-empty stores have been stocked, and the Polish zloty has been made convertible thanks to a Western aid program. ``Look, in Poland it worked,'' the source said. ``There are dangers, of course, and we have to be careful. But we don't have any other choice.'' One such danger is unemployment. In Poland, the number of workers out of jobs jumped to 150,000 and might reach 400,000 as inefficient enterprises are closed, Polish experts say. In the Soviet Union, efforts to streamline bloated factory payrolls are leaving millions of people unemployed. Last October, the Communist Party daily Pravda said joblessness, which officially didn't exist during the doctrinaire Communist period, reached 27.6 percent in Azerbaijan. It was 20 percent or higher in the Central Asian republics of Tadzhikistan and Uzbekistan, Pravda said. According to Interfax, the package of proposed bills and executive orders includes selling many government-owned factories through stock sales to individuals and foreigners, and making the ruble convertible on world currency exchanges. Immediately after his inauguration this month, Gorbachev pledged drastic economic reform. Western diplomats speculated he needed the security and powers of the five-year term as president to risk the upheaval that might accompany the measures. Interfax quoted experts as saying the public is unprepared for the changes contemplated. ``There can be no doubt that transition to a market economy is our top priority,'' said V. Belkin, an Academy of Sciences economist. ``What worries me ... is that it provides for an overnight introduction of the market the way they did in Poland. The model of that country may not work here, because public opinion is not prepared to accept it.'' Belkin warned that ``serious social problems'' could result. V. Mayevski of the academy's Institute of Economics also warned of the social ramifications of the planned economic steps. ``A sharp increase in prices cannot be ruled out, as happened in Poland, and there may be rampant unemployment, because the structure of production in this country is inadequate,'' he said. ``In the long run, that scenario will lead to economic progress. But before that considerable sacrifice will have to be made.''

DOC.HEAD: 23 Killed in Tractor Collision with Truck
DOC.TEXT: A farm tractor and wagon hauling 44 people to a funeral collided with a truck in western India on Saturday, killing 23 people and injuring 26 others, Press Trust of India said. The collision occurred near the village of Motipura, about 425 miles southwest of New Delhi in Gujarat state, the news agency said. The tractor and wagon were carrying 44 people to a relative's funeral in another village, Press Trust said. It did not say how many people were in the truck. Tractor-pulled wagons are often used to carry large groups of people to weddings, funerals and festivals in rural India.

DOC.HEAD: Believers Say Virgin Mary Apparitions Foretold Fall of Communism
DOC.TEXT: An apparition of the Virgin Mary in Yugoslavia that has drawn millions of believers foretold the collapse of communism in Eastern Europe, say participants at conference on visions of the mother of Jesus. ``It just seems too coincidental to have her appear and then all of a sudden the communist regime starts falling apart,'' said Robert Lacher, 54, of Wexford. The two-day eastern regional conference on visions of the Virgin Mary started Saturday at Duquesne University. The conference is focusing on the increased number of reported messages and what believers see as their tie to communism's collapse, sponsors said. The recent spate of visions of Mary and apparitions, defined as the apparent touching and talking with the Virgin, started in 1981 in the Yugoslavian city of Medjugorje when a group of six youngsters heard her message, said John O'Keefe of the Our Lady of Peace Ministries in Pittsburgh. Since then, more than 16 million people have traveled to the city, said the Rev. Kenneth J. Roberts of Florissant, Mo. Another apparition reported was by a 12-year-old girl and her mother in Hrushiw, Ukraine, on April 26, 1987, one year to the hour after the Chernobyl nuclear accident in the Ukraine, a Soviet republic. Another reported message was to a housewife in Na Ju, South Korea, sponsors said. The Roman Catholic Church is investigating all three apparitions. The church has officially recognized previously reported messages from the Virgin Mary, but they approved them only after the visions had stopped, Roberts said. In fact, Catholic priets and nuns are the most skeptical of these current apparitions, he said. Roberts claims he had a vision during March 1988 on one of his many visits to Medjugorje. He first saw the pulsating sun, then a ``mighty wind'' blew him over from a kneeling position while he was inside the church. ``I was changed from a doubter to a believer,'' Roberts said. Lacher said such visions may indeed take place, but the fact that the Catholic Church hasn't yet recognized most of them keeps him from being a true believer. He said he attended Saturday's conference to learn more and perhaps erase some of his doubt. ``I think something is happening,'' Lacher added. ``What is happening is good. It's bringing a lot of people to prayer.'' The convention center in downtown Pittsburgh was filled with those who journeyed from across the country and Canada. The center was decorated with statues of the Virgin Mary, and soft, soothing music was piped in over the speaker system before Mass and the program. The more than 5,500 attending the conference had to stand in a line stretching about a quarter of a mile in freezing temperatures.

DOC.HEAD: Syrian, Egyptian Presidents Hold First Meeting, Call For Arab Unity
DOC.TEXT: In their first encounter since ending a 12-year rift in December, the presidents of Egypt and Syria met in Libya on Saturday and called for Arab unity, the Libyan news agency JANA reported. The leaders joined Sudan's president and Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi in marking the 20th anniversary of the expulsion of British forces from Libya, JANA reported. Syrian President Hafez Assad told reporters that without unity, ``I believe there will be no happy life'' for Arabs, said the news agency report monitored in Rome. It quoted Egypt's President Hosni Mubarak as saying Arabs need unity to withstand the challenges of the U.S. and European economic blocs. The report did not say what the two discussed during their meeting. Assad broke ties with Egypt in January 1977 after the Egyptian president at the time, Anwar Sadat, made a dramatic visit to Jerusalem. The visit was the opening move in two years of negotiations that led to the Egyptian-Israeli peace agreement. Most other Arab countries cut ties with Egypt when it signed the treaty with Israel in 1979, and the feud had been a major obstacle to Arab cooperation. But links have been restored since a 1987 Arab summit decided to let Egypt back into the Arab fold. Libya, long allied with Syria in a hard-line radical front, has also been patching up its differences with Egypt. JANA said Gadhafi welcomed Assad, Mubarak and Sudanese leader Omar Hassan el-Bashir at the ceremony in Tobruk, on the Mediterranean coast in eastern Libya. Gadhafi expressed a ``feeling of happiness, delight and pride in our brothers,'' the report said. Gadhafi said Arab countries had to overcome differences of the past and unite in the face of dangers threatening the Arab world. ``What I have been saying for 20 years is now a fact,'' he said. ``All Arabs now feel that unity has become a necessity. ... If we quarreled yesterday, we make it up today. All differences are blown away on the wind.'' The 1970 British pullout from Tobruk's el-Adem air base took place the year after Gadhafi overthrew the monarchy in a military coup and established a republic. Gadhafi renamed the base after Egypt's late president, Gamal Abdel Nasser. U.S. forces withdrew from Libya in June 1970.

DOC.HEAD: Former U.S. Vice President, Others See Fair Elections Shaping Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for AM-Hungary-Mondale listed on news digest.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Hungary, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Former Vice President Walter Mondale said Saturday he expects no cheating in Hungary's national elections and had heard of no irregularities beyond what could be expected in a U.S. campaign. ``I got up this morning and somebody said, `They've been tearing down campaign signs,' '' said the Minnesota Democrat. ``I said, `What are you talking about? That could be Minneapolis.''' Mondale was vice president under Jimmy Carter from 1980 to 1984 and the unsuccessful Democratic candidate in the 1984 presidential election. He and Jan Carnogursky, the deputy premier of Czechoslovakia, are among the 65-member international delegation in Hungary to observe voting Sunday in Hungary's first free national election in 43 years. Carnogursky said his country, which in June holds its first free election in more than four decades, could learn from the Hungarian process. ``We expect nothing unusual to disturb the democratic process Sunday,'' Carnogursky said. Mondale said a ``dark streak'' in pre-Communist Hungarian politics _ anti-Semitism and ethnic intolerance _ showed up in some campaigning. ``There has been some language used by some politicans that some consider signals'' of religious and racial intolerance, Mondale said. He refused to go into details, saying only that politicians of leading parties ``admit it's around, but they do not think it's going to be a basic determinant.'' ``All the party leaders we talked to are clearly trying to avoid that historic mistake that cursed not only Hungarian politics but Eastern European politics for so long,'' said Mondale. Sponsors of the delegation's visit are the National Democratic Institute and the National Republican Institute, organizations of the U.S. political parties. Delegation members plan to tour polling stations and talk to voters on Sunday as part of the monitoring process. The two institutes have sponsored similar delegations to observe elections in Haiti, Nicaragua, Panama, the Philippines and elsewhere, and plan to send missions to other Soviet bloc countries planning elections. Both U.S. parties sent delegations to Hungary during the campaign to instruct the country's fledgling political parties in the art of electioneering, unknown in Hungary since 1947. While the monthlong official campaign featured TV advertising, debates, and posters plastered across towns and villages, it lacked mailing lists and other super-sophisticated techniques of U.S. presidential or congressional contests.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Watching Lithuanian Developments
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS with 18 grafs to UPDATE with Scowcroft warning, remarks by U.S. and Lithuanian officials. Picks up 7th graf pvs, bgng: Harlow said
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, on Saturday warned that any Soviet use of force or intimidation in Lithuania ``would be counterproductive'' to U.S.-Soviet relations. Scowcroft said the Bush administration would take appropriate measures in response to what it considered excessive Soviet pressure or an increase in tensions in the Baltic republic. He did not elaborate but said military action was not a likely option. ``We would not ignore it,'' however, he warned. ``They're under no doubt about how we feel.'' Bush, spending the weekend at the presidential retreat at Camp David, Md., was receiving periodic telephone reports from White House aides as Soviet military vehicles rolled through the streets of Vilnius a day after expelling two U.S. diplomats. ``We're watching it carefully,'' White House spokesman Bill Harlow said. Scowcroft made his comments in a telephone interview when asked to explain Bush's remark Friday that any Soviet ``attempt to coerce or intimidate or forcibly intervene against the Lithuanian people is bound to backfire. That is inevitable.'' Scowcroft said such actions ``would be counterproductive for the Soviets ... because it could affect the relationship _ our relationship.'' Scowcroft said Bush's comment could be read as ``a slight escalation of the rhetoric as the Soviets have escalated their action.'' While the Soviets have indicated they ``consider it their internal matter, none of our business,'' Scowcroft said, ``it has to be our business because it could affect the relationship.'' between Washington and Moscow. In an interview Saturday on CNN's ``Newsmaker Saturday'' Lithuanian Consul General Ancietas Simutis said Lithuanians were seeking moral support from the United States. ``We don't expect that the United States will go to war on behalf of Lithuania,'' Simutis said. ``And we are against any violence in or by Lithuanians or Russians or anybody. We believe in democratic procedures.'' Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., said the United States must make clear to Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev the consequences of its actions in Lithuania. ``What the Bush administration owes Gorbachev and the American people is candor,'' Lantos said on the CNN program. ``We must lay out for Gorbachev now what the consequences would be of military action. ... We have to tell Mr. Gorbachev that kicking out American diplomats, kicking out the press of the Western world is not the way to move towards peaceful negotiations. I very much hope that Mr. Gorbachev's intelligence and statesmanship will prevail, and he will turn back from this military intimidation that we have seen during the last 24 hours.'' One U.S. official said that while the administration was concerned about developments, it appeared that it was ``not at all a crisis situation'' on Saturday. Another official, also speaking on condition of anonymity, said it appeared the Soviets might not take any sudden action, but if they did increase the pressure on secessionist Lithuania, they would do so gradually. The official said it did not appear there would be ``some cataclysmic thing like martial law.'' Bush did not have any national security advisers with him for the weekend, but top National Security Council officials were at work at the White House. Harlow said he knew of no phone calls by Bush to Soviet or other foreign leaders regarding the Lithuanian situation. The State Department on Friday protested the expulsion of two U.S. diplomats, Douglas Wake and Jon Purnell, from Lithuania. The Lithuania matter was raised in a meeting between Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger and Soviet Ambassador Yuri Dubinin in Washington on Friday, officials said. In addition, officials from the U.S. Embassy in Moscow were ``talking to their foreign ministry all the time,'' to underscore U.S. concerns, State Department spokeswoman Sondra McCarty said Saturday. ``We're still monitoring the situation. We're still concerned,'' she said. She said she could release no additional update on the status of the two diplomats expelled from the Baltic Republican on Friday. But a U.S. Embassy spokesman in Moscow said Saturday they would comply with the order to leave although he could not say whether they had done so yet. Meanwhile, in Tokyo, the head of the official Soviet news agency, Tass, said today he believes a state of emergency might be declared in Lithuania, although it was unclear what that would mean. Tass has reported that Soviet embassies would review foreigners' visa applications to travel to Lithuania, to keep out people ``inclined to engage in illegal activities.'' In Washington, members of the Lithuanian-American community pressed ahead, despite snowy weather, for an evening vigil to show solidarity with the Lithuanians. They called on Bush to recognize Lithuania's independence, which the president has declined to do even though the United States never officially recognized the Soviet Union's forced annexation of Lithuania in 1940. ``His statements on Friday were a little bit better,'' said Jonas Alsenas of the Lithuanian-American group. Alsenas applauded Bush's statement that the United States supports Lithuania's right to self-determination, but criticized the U.S. stance on the new Lithuanian government. ``Even though they don't recognize the forcible incorporation of Lithuania, they still won't recognize this democratically elected government,'' Alsenas said. The weather hampered plans for the hastily called Saturday vigil at the Lincoln Memorial, but organizers still looked for a few hundred Lithuanian residents of the United States, saying some had come from around the country.

DOC.HEAD: Detained American Leaves for Home
DOC.TEXT: An American follower of the Hindu ``Path of Bliss'' cult who was attacked by anti-cult villagers and then held in solitary confinement nearly two months left for home Saturday. Patricia Munday suffered a deep gash on her forehead Jan. 26 when she was attacked near the headquarters of the secretive Ananda Marg sect in Purulia, a village in West Bengal. The local communist government of West Bengal has long accused the Hindu cult of using black magic. The followers of Ananda Marg, which means ``path of bliss,'' deny they practice black magic but acknowledge using human skulls in their meditation and ritual dances. The secretive group claims 4,500 followers around the world. ``In ordinary circumstances, I would have certainly stayed and fought my case, but after seven weeks of virtual incarceration, constant harassment and humiliation, I cannot bear these mental tortures any longer,'' Ms. Munday was quoted as saying in a statement issued by Ananda Marg. The statement said Ms. Munday continued to suffer from headaches, insomnia, occasional amnesia and numbness in her arms and legs after her detention by state police. Ms. Munday, who comes from Waitsfield, Vt., left New Delhi on Saturday, said Ananda Marg member Susan Andrews. It was not known when she would arrive back in Vermont. Ms. Munday, 39, was allowed to leave India after the country's supreme court ruled that West Bengal police could no longer detain her. The police had confined Ms. Munday to one room in a nursing home and barred all visitors after she tried to lodge a complaint against her attackers. Membership in the group is not a crime, and Ms. Munday was never charged. Ms. Munday was a member of a United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees team that won the 1981 Nobel Peace Prize for helping refugees in Somalia. She originally planned to stay in India and challenge the West Bengal government's authority to detain her, her lawyers and Ms. Andrews said. ``But it was just dragging on for six, seven weeks,'' said Ms. Andrews, of Toronto. ``She was just going stir crazy. She just said, `I can't hang out any longer.''' U.S. Embassy consular officers had been in contact with Ms. Munday but did not accompany her to the airport, an embassy spokesman said. Ms. Munday made her own travel plans. Ananda Marg has long aroused the suspicions of West Bengal officials and rural villagers. It was founded in the early 1950s by Prabhat Ranjan Sarkar, an accountant who worked for the government railroad system in Bihar, a state adjoining West Bengal. In 1971, Sarkar was imprisoned and charged with aiding and abetting the murders of six ex-followers of Ananda Marg. He was convicted and spent seven years in prison before his conviction was overturned. ``Ananda Marg is very much misunderstood,'' Ms. Andrews said. ``Some people are even saying that they kill people and use their skulls.'' She acknowledged, as witnesses have reported, that cult members use human skulls in their meditation but said this was intended as a way of showing that ``all of the attractions of the flesh are pared down. We have to fix our minds on an internal truth.'' Little information is available on the group's activities because members are bound by an oath of secrecy. The group has said it strives to create a social, economic and spiritual order that will replace both capitalism and communism and rid society of sectarianism and parochialism.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Child Shot; Family Accuses Settler
DOC.TEXT: A 6-year-old Palestinian was shot in the head Saturday and critically wounded as his family was tilling land near a Jewish settlement in the occupied West Bank, an army spokesman said. Tarek Mustapha el-Halabi was rushed to Mokassed hospital in Arab east Jerusalem. He underwent surgery to remove a bullet that entered his skull above the left eye, hospital officials said. El-Halabi's parents told Arab reporters and army investigators they were working their land near the village of Rujeib, a mile south of the West Bank city of Nablus, when two settlers shot their son. The town is near the settlement of Itamar. The army could not confirm the report. A military spokesman said no troops were in the area and that police were investigating the incident. Arab reports said the settlers opened fire after Palestinian youths stoned their car. Also Saturday, troops backed by helicopters raided the West Bank village of Anabta and detained dozens of Palestinian activists, the army said.

DOC.HEAD: Bright and Brief
DOC.TEXT: The Cincinnati Zoo has introduced its twin babies, the first successful polar bear births at the zoo in 40 years. The bears were born Dec. 13, but photographers were not allowed to focus on the cubs until Friday. The cubs _ sex still undetermined _ weighed in this week at 18 and 15 pounds and their health appears excellent, zoo keepers said. The mother, Amy, and the father, Icee, were corporate-sponsored gifts to the Cincinnati Zoo, where they arrived in 1984. The cubs are the first that Amy and Icee have produced. Polar bear births in captivity are rare, Cincinnati Zoo officials said. Icee will be transferred soon to the Columbus Zoo in a temporary breeding loan. Polar bears are native to the Arctic. International conservation programs protect the bears' migration and den areas and restrict hunting of the animals.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Embrace Moynihan Proposal
DOC.TEXT: The Democratic Party on Saturday endorsed a proposal by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan to cut Social Security payroll taxes as party leaders grope for ways to steal popularity from President Bush. In a session marred by a controversy over supposedly racist and anti-Semitic campaign tactics by Rep. Gus Savage, D-Ill., Democrats also agreed on rules and schedules for the 1992 presidential campaign season. A resolution at the spring meeting of the Democratic National Committee urged Congress to support the proposal forwarded several weeks ago by Moynihan, D-N.Y. The resolution is non-binding, and Democratic leaders in Congress have opposed such a cut as irresponsible when Congress is trying to cut the deficit. Adopting a more aggressive pose toward the Republican administration, Democratic Party chairman Ronald H. Brown dubbed the GOP the party of ``debt and taxes.'' For years, the Democrats have labored uncomfortably under Republican attacks calling them the ``tax and spend'' party. Brown expressed relief over ``getting the rules process behind us'' with what he called ``the most peaceful accord'' in the past 20 years. But the chairman's pleasure at getting the rules debate out of the way and getting the party on record in support of the Moynihan proposal, was tempered by the controversy involving Savage. Savage was accused of verbally attacking whites and Jews during his recent primary campaign. ``We abhor and oppose racism and anti-Semitism in any form,'' Brown told a news conference. ``I don't care to get into attacking Gus Savage as an individual although he's chosen to attack me on a couple of occasions,'' said Brown. Savage recently referred to the party chairman, who also is black, as ``Ron Beige.'' Brown later issued a new, stronger statement saying that ``racism and anti-Semitism is disgusting in any context. ... I intend to contact Congressman Savage and let him know in no uncertain terms that the chairman of the party and the party itself abhors and condemns his remarks.'' While the party officials were meeting in Indianapolis, Democratic elected officials were getting together in New Orleans for a meeting of the Democratic Leadership Council. At the party meeting in New Orleans, a succession of speakers mncluding Sens. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Tex., and Sam Nunn, D-Ga., Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia and House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt outlined their view of the party's agenda for the decade. Jesse L. Jackson gave a speech at the gathering in which he adhered to the new mainstream tone of the party. ``The Democrats must find common ground as the party of those who live on their paychecks,'' said Jackson, who has twice sought the Democratic presidential nomination. Jackson said Democrats are increasingly united on such issues as choice in abortion, fighting crime and drugs and government aid to those in need. ``We're talking about mainstream values and that's a wider stream than many thought,'' Jackson said. In additional to the payroll tax cut, which the Democrats were portraying as a boon to the middle class, the party was also pushing education and the environment as issues that can be used against Bush. The new party rules adopted in Indianapolis had few major changes from those that governed the campaign for the 1988 Democratic presidential nomination. Most significant were provisions requiring states to use proportional representation to allocate delegates chosen in caucuses or primaries. The party also could strip of a state of up to 25 percent of its delegation for failure to comply with rules. The proportional representation rule bars states from holding primaries in which national convention delegates are elected directly rather than allocated among the presidential candidates on the basis of the percentage of the vote their receive in individual congressional districts. The new rules also allow states to hold primaries or caucuses starting the first Tuesday in March. In 1988, the starting date was the second Tuesday in March. The traditional exemptions were preserved for Iowa, New Hampshire, and Maine. The party also solidified the rule requiring that a candidate receive at least 15 percent of the popular vote in order to qualify for delegates. States were barred from raising that percentage.

DOC.HEAD: Jet Crew Saw Small Plane 3 Seconds Before Runway Crash, Board Says
DOC.TEXT: The crew of an Eastern Airlines 727 that struck a twin-engine plane on an Atlanta runway in January saw the other craft just three seconds before the collision, federal documents show. The jetliner's pilots also said the smaller aircraft had no lights on at the time of accident, which occurred at about 7 p.m. The pilot of the Beechcraft BE-A100 was killed and the co-pilot injured on Jan. 18 when the plane was struck by the jetliner's right wing on a runway at Atlanta Hartsfield International Airport. No one aboard the 727 was injured. The Federal Aviation Administration decertified but has since recertified the controller in the tower who lost track of the Beechcraft after it landed. The safety board this week released the transcript of a cockpit voice recording in which the tower spoke with pilots of the Beechcraft, the Eastern plane and a Continental flight that landed just ahead of the small plane. In the transcript, the first sign of trouble appears to be registered by the first officer of the Eastern flight, who says ``Oh,'' followed by an ``expletive'' and then ``Oooooh.'' Three seconds later the recording registers the ``sound of impact.'' ``God bless,'' the first officer says. Two minutes further into the transcript the pilot is quoted as saying the smaller plane ``had no lights.'' ``He had no lights,'' said the first officer. ``I didn't see him till he was right there,'' said the pilot. ``He was, yeah ... there were no lights,'' said the first officer. Eastern Flight 111 was arriving in Atlanta from Montreal with an intermediate stop in New York. The EPPS Air Service Beechcraft was on a short flight from nearby Peachtree Airport. FAA spokesman Roger Meyers, reached in Atlanta, noted that the agency had said in January that the runway should have been clear before the Eastern plane was given permission to land. A report from the safety board said radar showed the distance between the Eastern jetliner and the Beechcraft was 1.2 miles at the time that the smaller plane crossed the threshhold of the runway. FAA regulations call for a distance of 2.5 miles until the tower begins to guide the planes visually. At that point, separation is up to the air controller's judgment, he said. He said the agency is satisfied that regulations concerning the separation of the planes were followed.

DOC.HEAD: Missippi University's Talent Show Plagued By Skirmishes
DOC.TEXT: An intercollegiate talent competition sponsored by a University of Southern Mississippi fraternity and sorority erupted into fights, sending four people to a hospital and one to jail, school officials said. At least four fights were reported on campus following the ``Step'' competition at Bennett Auditorium. Omega Psi Phi fraternity and Delta Sigma Theta sorority, both black organizations, sponsored the annual talent competition Friday night that drew a crowd of 700 to 800 people. ``It got out of hand,'' said USM public relations director Bud Kirkpatrick. ``The incident that precipitated everything inside the Step program was that a person stood up and proceeded to hit a judge.'' The fighting also apparently involved a rivalry between two organizations from another college, Kirkpatrick said. He said he did not know the names of the groups or which colleges they represent. ``There were five or six other schools competing with our students,'' Kirkpatrick said. ``It was between two groups from the same institution. Apparently there is an intense rivalry between the two groups. One had just finished performing when the other made some remarks.'' A dance scheduled for the Sports Arena after the talent show was canceled shortly before a scuffle erupted there, said Deputy Billy Magee. Fights also were reported at residence halls. Three men were taken to Forrest General Hospital for treatment of lacerations and other minor injuries, and a fourth was admitted for treatment of cuts, a possible ruptured eardrum and possible concussion. ``As best as we can determine they are not USM students,'' USM President Aubrey K. Lucas said. ``We do not know if they are students elsewhere.'' Authorities said one person was arrested after he was found with a car tire tool in his pants. He was charged with a misdemeanor count of carrying a concealed weapon.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Perplexed By Brutal Suicide
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: Officials have not been able to determine why a man committed suicide by hurling himself into a landfill incinerator. James Burnett and a friend had been smoking marijuana and sipping cough syrup in their truck parked near the landfill Thursday afternoon when Burnett walked over to the incinerator and climbed in, witnesses said. ``It wasn't a matter of tripping,'' said Manatee County sheriff's Detective Ned Foy. ``He climbed a ladder and threw himself in.'' Sheriff's spokesman Dave Bristow said Burnett, 30, a gardener who often hauled trees and brush to the incinerator, ``made remarks to his friend ... that made it plain he wanted to die.'' Burnett's friend Greg Mayers told investigators Burnett was depressed. Dr. John Wilson, with the county medical examiner's office, said soot in Burnett's lungs showed he was alive for several seconds in the 1,250-degree heat.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Party Expells Two Former Ministers
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party expelled two former Cabinet ministers Saturday as part of a major restructuring under way since the revolution that ended the Communists' monopoly on power. State television announced that the once all-powerful Central Committee decided to expell former Foreign Minister Bohuslav Chnoupek and former Interior Minister Vratislav Vajnar. Several other Communists who once led the country have also been ousted from the party, including former President Gustav Husak and former general secretary Milos Jakes. Husak, Jakes and their associates were responsible for 21-years of hard-line policies following the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact invasion that crushed the ``Prague Spring'' reforms of 1968. They lost power in a peaceful revolution late last year that propelled a coalition government dominated by non-Communists to power and installed former dissident Vaclav Havel as president. Communists, including current premier Marian Calfa, have been deserting the former ruling party en masse ever since. The television report said the party, estimated to have some 1.7 million members before the revolution, currently has 1 million members. In Prague, some 70 percent of one-time Communists have turned in their party cards, the television said. The report also said the Communists agreed to give up their huge Central Committee headquarters in Prague, and other buildings in the capital, including the Institute of Marxism-Leninism, a large Communist party hotel and a historic center for the Social Democrats.

DOC.HEAD: Former Police Agents Accuse Politician of Being Collaborators
DOC.TEXT: Former secret police agents have denounced the leader of East Germany's Social Democratic Party, but he denied their charges that he was a regular police collaborator, a West Germany news magazine said Saturday. Meanwhile, West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl said a united Germany should put the past behind and live in peace with Poland, its eastern neighbor. The allegations about Social Democratic chairman Ibrahim Boehme mirrored similar allegations against Lothar de Maiziere, leader of East Germany's Christian Democratic Union, Der Spiegel reported. De Maiziere, who is slated to become East Germany's first non-Communist premier, also has denied the allegations. Der Spiegel said it had no proof of secret police links of either politician, only claims by former agents. Two former agents alleged that Boehme used three code names while acting as an informer for the Stasi, the once-feared East German secret police that ruthlessly suppressed any dissent, the magazine said. Boehme's Social Democrats finished second to the CDU in the March 18 elections, the first free balloting in East German history. East Germans have been obsessed with the Stasi since their popular revolution overthrew hard-line Communist leaders. They stormed its East Berlin headquarters in January and forced the government to dismantle the agency. East Germany's week-old democracy has been hounded by reports that many members of the new 400-seat parliament might have had links with the secret police. The leader of one party, Democratic Awakening, resigned just three days before this month's elections after admitting he had collaborated with the Stasi. In Mainz, West Germany, on Saturday, Kohl addressed the Polish boundary issue by saying that ``the idea now is to draw the line'' on the past and provide ``clear assurances on the borders'' of postwar Europe. ``I want Germany to live in peace and, if possible, in friendship with its Polish neighbors,'' the West German chancellor told a meeting of his Christian Democratic Union party. Poland worries that a united Germany could try to reclaim areas awarded to Poland after the collapse of Nazi Germany. The territory comprises one-third of present-day Poland, which has sought a peace treaty with both German states before unification. Millions of Germans were expelled from Poland after World War II, and they form a conservative force in West German politics. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said she believes Kohl personally remains opposed to signing a formal treaty guaranteeing Poland's western border, Der Spiegel reported. ``I have heard Helmut say: `No, I won't guarantee anything, I don't recognize the current borders,''' Der Spiegel quoted Mrs. Thatcher as saying in its latest issue. At the same time, she said she accepts that a united Germany will become the most powerful country in Europe. ``We just have to get used to the idea that there will be a country in Europe in the future that will be more powerful than all the others,'' she said in the interview, which Der Spiegel provided in advance to other news media before publication Monday. Mrs. Thatcher has been wary of hasty moves toward unification by West Germany, already the strongest member of the European Economic Community.

DOC.HEAD: East European Elections At a Glance
With AM-Hungary, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a look at the election process in East European countries.

BULGARIA: The Balkan country of 9 million plans to hold its first multi-party elections since World War II in June, under terms worked out between the governing Communists and opposition parties and groups. Still undecided is the goal of the elections. The opposition would like them to be for a Constituent Assembly, which would adopt a new democratic constitution and election law and then call full-fledged free elections within one year. The Communists would like voters to choose a new full parliament.

CZECHOSLOVAKIA: The first free multi-party elections are scheduled June 8-9 for the 350-member bicameral Parliament. On Dec. 29, the current Parliament elected former dissident playwright Vaclav Havel president to replace Communist hard-liner Gustav Husak, who resigned.

EAST GERMANY: The first free elections in East Germany's 41 year history were held March 18. An Alliance of parties favoring quick unification with West Germany won 48.15 percent of the vote for 192 seats in the 400 seat Parliament. They are negotiating to form a coalition government.

HUNGARY: The first free multi-party elections in 43 years will be held in Hungary on Sunday. At stake are the 394 seats in Parliament. On Nov. 26, Hungarians voted freely for the first time in a referendum on whether to elect a new president before or after the parliamentary elections. They chose by a narrow majority to have the presidential vote postponed.

POLAND: The once-banned Solidarity Free Trade Union overwhelmingly defeated the Communist Party in partially democratic elections last June. Solidarity formed the first government in Eastern Europe not dominated by Communists, under Premier Tadeusz Mazowiecki, a Solidarity activist and journalist.

ROMANIA: Free, multi-party elections have been scheduled by the interim revolutionary government for May 20. They will be the first since 1937 in Romania. The elections will be for a Constituent Assembly with two chambers comprising 235 seats in the lower house and 152 in the Senate.

SOVIET UNION: In March of last year, Soviet citizens for the first time were able to choose candidates in elections for a new Congress of People's Deputies, electing even dissidents such as Andrei Sakharov. The Soviet Parliament legalized multiple political parties for the entire country March 13. In February, in the Baltic republic of Lithuania, the Sajudis People's Front won a two-thirds majority of deputies in the new Parliament, thus becoming the Soviet Union's first freely elected, non-Communist dominated, legislature. In March, the parliament elected the first non-Communist president of a republic, Sajudis leader Vytautus Landsbergis. Free elections were also held in the Baltic republics of Latvia and Estonia on March 18.

YUGOSLAVIA: The first multi-party elections in Yugoslavia's 45-year Communist history are due in most of the country's six republics and two provinces April 8-12. The reformist government of Premier Ante Markovic has put forward a bill that will legalize a multi-party system in the country.

ALBANIA: The last bastion of Stalinist rule has rejected democratic reforms. The Communist leadership, which broke with Moscow in the 1960s, has made clear it has no intention of relinquishing its leading role or staging free elections.

DOC.HEAD: Snow From The Plains To The East Coast
DOC.TEXT: A storm blew snow over the mid Atlantic states Saturday after dumping up to 9 inches of snow on parts of Missouri, and a cold front returned temperatures to winter levels across much of the nation. Seven traffic deaths were blamed on icy, snow-covered roads in the south-central part of the country. A week and a half ago the middle Atlantic Coast states had record high temperatures in the 80s which brought cherry blossoms and other flowers out early. On Saturday, a light coat of snow covered some of those blossoms and buds. Winter storm warnings were posted Saturday for parts of Maryland, Virginia and West Virginia, where 4 to 8 inches of snow was possible. Atlantic City, N.J., had 1.5 inches of snow by early afternoon. About 2 inches fell during the morning in southwestern Pennsylvania. In the south-central states, light snow, sleet and freezing drizzle continued Saturday in the wake of the storm. Missouri got up to 9 inches of snow Friday, the biggest March snowfall at Kansas City in 12 years. Three traffic deaths were blamed on the weather. ``Weather in Missouri always presents a challenge,'' said Vince Acquaviva of the National Weather Service in St. Louis. ``I would say March in Missouri is impossible. March can be a cocktail, with a little bit of everything _ snowstorms, thunderstorms, tornadoes.'' On March 24, 1912, residents of Kansas City began to dig out from 25 inches of snow that fell in 24 hours, nearly twice that of any other storm on record there. Olathe, Kan., got 37 inches of snow, a single storm record for Kansas. Parts of Kansas got 7 inches of snow and reported three weather-related traffic deaths. ``Most roads are packed and very hazardous throughout the state,'' said a spokesman for the Kansas Highway Patrol. Oklahoma got a mixture of snow and sleet Friday, with thunder and lightning, and had one traffic death. The storm later produced heavy snow in the Ohio Valley, with 8 inches at Linton in southern Indiana and 5 inches in southern Ohio at Cincinnati and Hillsboro by sunrise Saturday. Elsewhere Saturday, light snow lingered over parts of eastern Colorado, western Nebraska and western Kansas. Temperatures were generally only in the 20s Saturday afternoon from the western Plains to the upper Great Lakes, and in the Northeast, with readings in the teens in Wyoming and Montana. The cold front produced a sharp temperature contrast across Texas. Temperatures at midday ranged from 23 at Amarillo to 81 at McAllen. Waco was at 42 while College Station, just 75 miles to the southeast of Waco, had a reading of 72. Morning lows were below the freezing mark from the Rockies to New England, and in the teens and single digits and lower from Montana and Wyoming to Michigan. Billings, Mont., had a record low of 5 above zero. Saturday's low for the Lower 48 states was 15 below zero at West Yellowstone, Mont.

DOC.HEAD: Salvadoran Faithful Mark Archbishop's Assassination
DOC.TEXT: The poor, the humble and the devout flocked by the thousands Saturday to honor the memory of Roman Catholic Archbishop Oscar A. Romero on the 10th anniversary of his assassination. More than 1,000 people jammed the unfinished downtown cathedral in San Salvador, and several thousand more listened to the Mass piped through loudspeakers to the plaza and streets outside. A 20-block march commemorating Romero preceded the religious service. It was led by 16 bishops, including Roger Mahoney of Los Angeles; Leo Mattieson, of Amarillo, Texas; and Nicolas D'Antonio of New Orleans, La. Romero was slain March 24, 1980, as he said Mass at a hospital chapel. Although the Christian Democratic government of 1984-89 compiled evidence implicating extreme rightists, no one has been arrested or charged in the murder. No high-ranking official from President Alfredo Cristiani's conservative administration or his Republican Nationalist Alliance were present. The late former President Jose Napoleon Duarte, a Christian Democrat, accused Arena founder Roberto d'Aubuisson of having ordered Romero's assassination. Cardinal Agostino Casaroli, the Vatican secretary of state, sent a message that said Pope John Paul II ``joins the service in spirit and raises a prayer that the sacrifice of that pastor become a new call to reconciliation and forgiveness.'' The message was read at the Mass. El Salvador's decade-old civil war, which began engulfing this nation about the time Romero was killed, continues unabated. The death toll surpassed 72,000 late last year when leftist rebels launched a monthlong offensive. The Metropolitan Cathedral, which has been under construction for 30 years and has been closed for worship since October, was reopened for the commemoration. The facade was festooned with huge banners quoting scripture. One, citing John 10.15, read: ``I give my life for my flock.'' The service is to be the last public religious homage to Romero in decades, because he will be formally proposed for beatification, the first step toward sainthood, in coming weeks. Church doctrine prohibits public homage to candidates for sainthood. Local church officials and many in the Vatican say prospects are good for Romero's eventual sainthood, but they say the process will take up to 30 years. Archbishop Thomas Becket of Canterbury was murdered at the altar in 1170 and later canonized. On Saturday, marchers carrying white flags, palm fronds studded with paper flowers and portraits of Romero chanted: ``Saint, pastor and prophet; Monsignor Romero lives in the hearts of the people.'' Most marchers were peasants in sandals with worn or mended clothing, but many city dwellers also joined the procession and attended the Mass. Some marchers carried portraits of six Jesuit priests allegedly murdered by army troops on Nov. 16. Romero and the slain Jesuits exercised what in modern theology has come to be called ``the preferential option for the poor.'' They lived humbly and condemned exploitation, inequality and oppression. Many rightists called them subversives. Catalina Rivera, a 62-year-old peasant woman who had traveled four hours by bus from La Libertad province to listen to the Mass, said: ``Monsignor Romero helped us all by announcing the truth. That is why they killed him. Because the truth hurts those who don't want to hear it.'' El Salvador suffered from a terrible wave of repression in 1980 and later years, when rightist death squads and government troops kidnapped, tortured and executed hundreds of suspected leftists every month. In his last homily the day before he was killed, Romero issued an impassioned appeal to soldiers to disobey orders to torture and murder. ``In the name of God, in the name of this suffering people whose cries rise to heaven more loudly each day, I implore you, I beg you, I order you in the name of God: Stop the repression,'' he said. ``For being the voice of those without voice, he was violently silenced,'' said San Salvador Archbishop Arturo Rivera Damas, Romero's successor, in Saturday's homily.

DOC.HEAD: NRC Upgrades Investigation Into Vogtle Site Emergency
DOC.TEXT: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has upgraded its investigation into a power outage that shut down one reactor last week at Georgia Power Co.'s nuclear Plant Vogtle. NRC spokesman Ken Clark said the decision to upgrade the investigation from an ``augmented inspection'' to an ``incident investigation,'' made Friday night in Washington, was made because of safety and regulatory concerns. A site emergency was declared at the Waynesboro plant Tuesday when a truck backed into a utility pole, knocking out electricity. Only one of the plant's two nuclear reactors, Unit 2, was in operation and automatically shut down. No one was evacuated and no radioactive materials escaped, but the reactor has yet to be restarted. ``This came up because the NRC management believes it is necessary because of the safety significance and potential regulatory questions raised'' by the emergency, Clark said of the decision. Among other things, the investigation is to determine why it took utility officials an hour to notify emergency authorities of the problem. The plant is supposed to notify the surrounding counties and state officials of any incidents within 15 minutes. But Burke County was not notified for 45 minutes and the state for an hour, said Georgia Emergency Management Agency spokesman Harry Heath. Georgia Power spokesman John Thrasher said ``we plan to cooperate fully,'' but refused further comment. The company agreed not to restart Unit 1 until the investigation is complete. The plant's other reactor, Unit 2, was shut down for refueling at the time of the outage. Its cooling system was without power for 36 minutes because a back-up diesel generator didn't start immediately. The generator was started manually.

DOC.HEAD: Factionalism Spills Over Into Congress
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 4th graf, ``The United States xxx to CORRECT 1978 to 1979
DOC.TEXT: The splintered rebel movement in Afghanistan has produced its share of factions in Congress over how to allocate U.S. dollars for groups fighting the Soviet-backed government. As Rep. Charles Wilson, D-Texas, jokingly put it, the only way to get everyone back under the same tent is to ``bring the Red Army back.'' At issue is not only how the CIA spends $600 million a year in taxpayer money on covert operations against the government headed by Najibullah, but also whether to continue that level of aid. The United States began supplying weapons to Afghan rebels after the Soviet Union sent troops into Afghanistan in late 1979. Although Soviet troops pulled out of Afghanistan last year, Najibullah remains in power. The dispute has focused in particular on the amount of aid being received by Gulbaddin Hekmatyar, the leader of one of seven rebel factions. In addition to complaints that the aid is being distributed unfairly is one that Hekmatyar is a Soviet agent. The question of where Hekmatyar's allegiances lie was raised by reports written by a group of staffers working out of the office of Rep. Bill McCollum, R-Fla. Evidence suggests Hekmatyar ``and his key commanders work for the USSR to a certain degree,'' according to a report prepared by the House Task Force on Terrorism and Unconventional Warfare. Hekmatyar ``is definitely devoted to fighting the U.S.'' and has cooperated with Iran and other radical Muslims to that end,'' the paper said. The task force is part of the House Republican Research Committee, of which McCollum is a member. The report said Hekmatyar was a member of the communist party in his youth and has maintained close contacts with the Soviets. Hekmatyar recently joined with Afghan Defense Minister Shahnawaz Tanai who waged an unsuccessful coup attempt March 6 against Najibullah, whose regime receives an estimated $300 million in weapons a month from the Soviet Union. Rep. Don Ritter, R-Pa., also says there is a ``growing discontent in Congress'' with the CIA's reliance on Pakistan's Inter-Services Intelligence to deliver aid. Ritter complained that the Pakistanis have unfairly favored Hekmatyar's over the other rebel groups. Wilson, a staunch supporter of the rebels, said he is unprepared to defend Hekmatyar but considers it ``absolutely false'' to suggest he is a KGB plant. ``I'm absolutely 100 percent satisfied with the job the CIA is doing,'' said Wilson, a member of the House Intelligence Committee. Robert Peck, the State Department's former top analyst on Afghanistan, said Hekmatyar may be a problem but there was no evidence of his being a Soviet agent. Donald J. Morrissey, the Republican task force's legislative director, said the papers did not necessarily represent the views of the task force members, but were intended to encourage debate. Indeed, they have in a period when U.S. policy is in flux. Rep. Porter Goss, R-Fla., a task force member with expertise in the intelligence field, said he viewed the report as a ``speculative document'' that ``wasn't quite as persuasive'' as the authors probably intended. But Goss said the paper underscored the feeling on Capitol Hill that lawmakers ``are trying to come to grips'' with what to do about Afghanistan. Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., chairman of a House subcommittee on Asia, has suggested conducting the debate in public rather than in private. Ritter may call for a cutoff in aid until he is assured Pakistan is giving money to the right people. Wilson, who has visited Afghanistan and is considered one of the most knowledgeable lawmakers on the issue, advocated ``keep doing what we are doing.'' ``There is a lot of impatience in Congress,'' he said, adding it is ``going to be difficult'' to keep aid levels at their current amount. But ultimately, Wilson said the U.S.-backed rebels should prevail and gain control of their country, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Atwater Spends Second Night in Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Lee Atwater planned to spend a second night in the hospital so doctors could adjust medication the Republican Party chairman is taking as part of his treatment for a brain tumor, an aide said Saturday. Atwater was ``upbeat'' and watching movies at George Washington University Hospital in Washington, where he was admitted Friday after complaining of queasiness, said Leslie Goodman, spokeswoman for the Republican National Committee. Goodman said Atwater planned to undergo a radiation treatment Saturday, one of the five he must take weekly to shrink the non-malignant tumor on the right side of his brain. The tumor was discovered earlier this month. Atwater, 39, was rushed to the same hospital March 5 after collapsing during a speech. Atwater was hospitalized for several days but returned to work a week after the seizure. Atwater was named to head the RNC after managing George Bush's successful presidential campaign. He managed South Carolina Sen. Strom Thurmond's 1978 campaign and played major roles in both Reagan-Bush campaigns.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Lithuania
Head of Lithuanian Legaton in Washington Designated Chief Diplomat
DOC.TEXT: Stasys Lozoraitis Jr. is fluent in half a dozen languages. Russian is not one of them, though he confesses a desperate need to know it. Still, ``it is a question of principle,'' he says. Lozoraitis is the man in charge of the musty, 40-room mansion on 16th Street, a mile from the Soviet embassy, which serves as the legation of free Lithuania, as it has for nearly 70 years. But for the last 50 of those years, Lithuania was not free. Two Sundays ago, the building was filled as the Lithuanian legislature pondered a declaration of independence from the Soviet Union, whose troops overran the nation in 1940. ``I think all the 500 Washington Lithuanians came,'' said Lozoraitis. ``Little children holding balloons, men and women bringing whiskey bottles, cookies, or just smiles. Poles _ though not yet those from their embassy down the block _ Estonians, Latvians, Armenians, Americans.'' And then the news arrived _ sent via a fax machine that Lithuania's new president, Vytautus Landsbergis, had smuggled home after visiting Lozoraitis, a old school chum, in Washington last summer. ``The vote was for freedom!'' cried Lozoraitis. With that, the celebration began. Another message arrived Saturday. The legislature had formally declared that its power would fall, symbolically, to the Washington legation and Lozoraitis if the Soviets crush the new government. A similar role was occupied for 45 years by Lozoraitis' father, until his death, at age 88, five years ago. Just days before the Soviet troops arrived in 1940, free Lithuania's last foreign minister had sent this message to his embassies: ``If catastrophe strikes, please consider Stasys Lozoraitis chief of our nation's diplomatic corps.'' The elder Lozaraitis, using gold reserves transferred from Lithuania to Sweden as the Soviets moved in, ran not only the Washington legation and four U.S. consulates, but diplomatic outposts-in-exile in the Vatican, Great Britain, Canada and Venezuela. According to his son, it has been the only diplomatic service in history to hold to its mission for more than a half century after its country was conquered. ``For 50 years,'' said Stasys Lozoraitis Jr., ``we have carried on, Working, living, dying. It is such a pity my father isn't here to see all our efforts come to such a conclusion.'' Throughout the legation are symbols of hope. Above the fireplace in the great hall hangs a painting of a white knight, the national symbol. A mural of the 600-year-old nations 1918 Declaration of Independence adorns the front hall. On a white-skirted table in the grand salon, an old photograph depicts Lozoraits's bearded grandfather _ a politician and philosopher _ with the grandfather of Landsbergis. Lozoraitis, who declines to give his age, had just entered his teens when his father, a former foreign minister, was sent off to Italy ahead of the invading Soviet tanks. In Italy, the son helped his father with diplomatic reports _ he says he was 15 when he decoded his first cipher _ but resisted diplomacy as a career. He wanted to fight. And he did, as a member of an underground group which rescued Jews and American prisoners of war. ``As far as my family was concerned, I was absolutely irresponsible,'' he recently told The Washington Post. ``We would put these people in cars and drive them to Catholic monasteries or convents or the Vatican. I was arrested once by the Germans, but through friends my father saved me.'' His exploits during the war also took him back into the Baltic states, and he acknowledges that he has since visited Lithuania more than once _ though not officially. ``I would not go to the Soviet Embassy to ask for a visa to my own country,'' he said. Before taking over for his father in Washington, the son was a journalist for Vision, an international economics magazine, and learned several languages along the way. But not Russian. ``It is a question of principle. And I am sorry, because I need it very much,'' he said. In a recent interview with the MacNeil-Lehrer News Hour, Lozoraitis expressed the belief that Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev will hold true to his pledge not to use force against the new Lithuanian government. ``We are not threatening the political position of Gorbachev,'' he said. ``If he lets us go, his stature as a political figure will only increase, and he will remain in history.'' But Saturday, the Soviet Foreign Ministry ordered foreign diplomats out of Lithuania, and a military convoy rumbled through the Vilnius, the capital. And Lozoraitis was left to pray that he will not have to take the symbolic torch of power a nervous legislature was prepared to bestow upon him. The State Department, for years, has tiptoed around the legation's status. The United States has never recognized the forcible incorporation of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania into the Soviet Union, and throughout the Cold War has called upon Moscow to release its ``captive nations.'' On the other hand, it has not accredited the diplomatic corps-in-exile headed by Lozoriatis, nor has it recognized the new government.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Ministers Sign Agreement Abolishing Visas, Horn Given Merit Award
DOC.TEXT: West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher Saturday signed an agreement that abolishes the visa requirement between his country and Hungary. He also presented a merit award to Foreign Minister Gyula Horn, apparently for Hungary's decision to open its borders last year to East Germans seeking a better life in the West. The exodus of East Germans sparked the peaceful revolution that led to East Germany's first free elections last weekend. Hungarians were to go to the polls Sunday for their first free, multiparty elections in 43 years of Communist rule. Visa-free travel between West Germany, a member of NATO, and Hungary, a member of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact, goes into effect May 1. Genscher and Horn also signed three other bilateral agreements on education and management training for Hungarians. ``It remains unforgotten that Hungary was the first to cut the Iron Curtain,'' Genscher told Horn after the signing ceremony. Hungary began dismantling the barbed wire barriers along its western border with Austria in May. The open border was used by thousands of East Germans, fed up with 40 years of hard-line Communist rule, to flee to West Germany via Austria. ``As Hungary stood valiantly by our side in a difficult hour of our history, we will not leave Hungary in the lurch on her way'' to democracy and a market economy, Genscher said. Addressing a concern that has dominated the Hungarian election campaign the past few days, Genscher also said he hoped the rights of minorities, including those of the ethnic Hungarians in Romania, would be respected. Hungarians feel a sense of kinship for the estimated 1.7 million ethnic Hungarians in Transylvania, an area that belonged to Hungary for centuries before being ceded to Romania after World War I.

DOC.HEAD: Doubts Raised On Contra Disbandment Accord
DOC.TEXT: An agreement to disband the Contra rebels was in doubt Saturday because the outgoing Sandinista government had not signed the pact and because of renewed fighting. The accord, signed Friday in Tegucigalpa, Honduras, by representatives of the U.S.-backed rebels and the new government, calls for a truce and immediate disbanding of the Contras. The process would be completed before President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro takes office April 25 for a six-year term. However, no delegates from the Sandinista government took part in talks that led to the pact or signed the accord. Also, there has been renewed fighting in the past week between Sandinista and Contra forces, and one rebel commander said his fighters will not lay down their arms until the Sandinista Army does. The latest clash occurred Friday, when about 100 rebels ambushed two army vehicles in the area around Jinotega, a town about 100 miles northeast of Managua. The Defense Ministry said 12 soldiers died and eight were wounded. Four Contras were killed, the ministry said.
