Medical sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said in a telephone interview that the attack occurred about the time the accord was being announced in Tegucigalpa. President Daniel Ortega has repeatedly said the Contras must disband before Mrs. Chamorro's inauguration if there is to be a peaceful transfer of power. After learning of the accord, Ortega told a rally of youth supporters in Managua late Friday that ``the weapons are now in the hands of the people.'' Ortega, quoted Saturday by the Sandinista newspaper Barricada, did not elaborate. But his remark seemed to be a reference to recent reports that the Sandinista army had distributed hundreds of weapons among supporters in the provinces. There have also been reports that the Sandinista army will not yield control to the new government. The party newspaper voiced concern in an editorial, saying: ``There is still worry over the plans that the Contras have been preparing to launch a great offensive.'' It said ``infiltrations from Honduras continue, and that weapons are being hidden.'' The editorial also pointed out that Contra military chief Israel Galeano Cornejo, known as Commander Franklyn, had not signed the pact for disbanding the rebels. He took part in the seven hours of talks, but his deputy, Oscar Sovalbarro, signed the accord. Antonio Lacayo, Mrs. Chamorro's representative, signed for the incoming leadership of the United National Opposition. The document was witnessed by Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Managua. Sovalbarro later told reporters about 12,000 rebel fighters and their families living in Honduran jungle camps planned to start demobilizing over the weekend. The accord also calls for observers from the United Nations and the Organization of American States to supervise the disbanding and resettlement of the rebels and their families. Mrs. Chamorro's landslide victory in elections Feb. 25 ended a decade of leftist Sandinista rule that was marked by close military cooperation with Cuba and the Soviet Union. Shortly before the accord was reached, rebel commander Osvaldo Galeano Cornejo accused the Sandinista army of ``repressing the peasants'' in his area in southern Nicaragua. He said his forces will not demobilize until the Sandinista army does the same. ``If we demobilize now, we would be leaving all these peasants without protection,'' Galeano Cornejo, 22, the brother of Israel Galeano Cornejo, told The Associated Press in an interview early Friday. About 4,000 Contras are believed to be stationed in Nicaragua in a north-south corridor from the Honduran border to Costa Rica. Under the accord, they will move into security zones supervised by Obando y Bravo and the United Nations.

DOC.HEAD: Train Hits Bumping Block At Station, 30 Reported Injured
DOC.TEXT: An Amtrak train arriving from New Orleans hit a bumper at the end of a track at Union Station on Saturday, derailing cars and injuring at least 30 people, authorities said. ``The `City of New Orleans' train No. 53 struck the bumping block at the end of the track, apparently throwing quite a few people who were standing waiting to get off,'' said Amtrak spokesman John Jacobsen. Trains normally would stop short of the bumper. Eight of the 10 cars derailed, Jacobsen said in a telephone interview from Washington, D.C. He said the train was supposed to be traveling at about 3 mph in the station, but police Patrolman John LeCompte said there were reports that the train came in too fast. Jacobsen said the railroad was still investigating and hadn't determined whether the accident was caused by human error or mechanical failure. He said no damage to the train or the station was immediately visible. ``It wasn't a serious accident from a railroad point of view,'' Jacobsen said. ``But when you are standing up it's just like standing on an escalator _ if it stops fast, you fall down. People get thrown, somebody else's suitcase hits them in the head ....'' The train was carrying 254 passengers when it pulled into the station just before noon, Jacobsen said. At least 30 people were taken to at least six hospitals, most complaining of muscle, back or neck pains, hospital spokesmen said. Late in the afternoon, many were still being evaluated in emergency rooms, but it appeared most would be treated and released, the spokesmen said.

DOC.HEAD: Second Baltic Republic May Make Move Toward Independence
DOC.TEXT: The head of the Latvian People's Front said Saturday the first act of the republic's new parliament will be a vote on independence. Dainis Ivans, President of the Latvian People's Front, said the vote could come within six weeks, provided the pro-independence group has enough support in parliament. The Front and other independence supporters won more than a 50 percent majority in the first round of elections for Latvia's new parliament earlier this month. Ivans said they need to win only six more of the 35 remaining races to have the two-thirds majority needed for an independence vote. Ivans was in Vilnius to meet with leaders of the popular fronts of Lithuania and Estonia to coordinate the Baltic republics' campaigns for independence. Independence supporters took control of Lithuania's parliament in recent elections, and the republic declared itself independent on March 11 after five decades of Kremlin rule. Lithuania is in a confrontation with the Kremlin over its declaration of indpendence and demands for talks on the issue. Soviet tanks rolled through Vilnius Saturday in a show of force. However, Ivans said at a news conference late Saturday night that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev promised the Latvians last week that he will begin negotiations with them on independence. Ivans said the Kremlin and Latvia have agreed to set up committees to deal with the details of separation, including politcal, economic and ecological issues. Ivans said the new Latvian parliament will hold its first session by early May, and among its first acts will be to recognize Lithuanian independence. He said increasing Kremlin pressure on Lithuania could prompt Latvian and Estonian independence activists to speed their moves toward independence as a way to support Lithuania.

DOC.HEAD: Environmental Group Asks for `Tuna Free Zone'
DOC.TEXT: An environmental group is asking voters to ban the sale of canned tuna caught with huge drift nets that also trap dolphins and other marine life. The United Community Action Network in Portland filed an initiative petition with the Multnomah County Elections Division on Friday seeking to declare the county the world's first ``tuna free zone.'' Initiative backers must collect 14,148 valid signatures over six months to put the measure on the November general election or a special election ballot. ``When we talk to people at the door, they have a lot of sympathy for this issue,'' said Tom O'Keefe, director of the 7-month-old conservation group. ``Oregon has always been on the cutting edge of environmental issues, and this gives them the opportunity to speak loud again.'' The measure would exempt the sale of canned tuna caught without the use of drift nets, or purse seines, which contribute to the death of an estimated 120,000 dolphins every year. The National Marine Fishery Service estimates that 6 million dolphins have been killed since worldwide fleets started using the nets in the 1950s. The United States, the only nation that regulates the use of the huge nets, still allows a quota of 20,500 dolphin deaths a year.

DOC.HEAD: School Worker Arrested in Death of 8-Year-Old Boy
DOC.TEXT: A fired elementary school employee was arrested Saturday for investigation of killing an 8-year-old student whose gagged and charred body was found in a roadside brush fire, authorities said. Greg S. Smith, 21, was booked for investigation of murdering Paul Bailly, a student at the Los Angeles school where Smith was a playground supervisor, said Lt. Joe Harwell of the Ventura County Sheriff's Department. An autopsy was performed but the county coroner was waiting for the results of tests before declaring the cause of death. There were no obvious injuries to the boy other than the burning and it was a possible he burned to death, Harwell said. The crime appalled people who work nearby or live in the chapparal-covered hills west of Los Angeles' burgeoning San Fernando Valley suburbs. ``It's the kind of thing that makes you wonder what kind of animal does this kind of thing,'' said county Supervisor Madge Schaefer. The body was found Friday by firefighters responding to a brush fire in semirural Susana Knolls. A pair of handcuffs was found at the scene. Harwell said detectives assume they were used on the boy. Smith, a resident of the Canoga Park section of Los Angeles who has no criminal record, was fired from Darby Elementary School in the San Fernando Valley suburb of Northridge two or three weeks ago. ``All we know at this time is he was terminated for cause, evidently some problems there at the school,'' Harwell said. Vince France, detective commander of the sheriff's major crimes division, said the firing involved ``inappropriate behavior.'' He refused to elaborate. The boy was in a ``latchkey'' program of supervision for students before and after school and Smith had been a supervisor, Harwell said. The boy was last seen by his parents when he was dropped off at the gate of the school at 7 a.m. Friday. Records show he never arrived at school, and he was reported missing when he failed to come back to his Canoga Park home. The body was found about 11:50 a.m. Friday. Witnesses had reported seeing a charcoal gray Honda or Toyota sedan in the vicinity of the fire and detectives were watching Smith's home and Honda sedan when he drove off at 5:30 a.m. Saturday. Harwell alleged that Smith spotted the surveillance and tried to evade the detectives. He was initially arrested for investigation of reckless driving and evading arrest, and booked later in the murder case. Bailly's body, clad in a T-shirt, shorts, socks and sneakers, was found less than 100 feet from Black Canyon Road. A flammable liquid had been used to set the blaze. ``It's a particularly brutal crime, senseless,'' France said.

DOC.HEAD: General Assembly Disposes of Abortion Issue After Bitter Fight
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `Abortion-rights...will do,' to CORRECT that potato boycott intended to force governor to veto the bill. Pick up 11th graf pvs, `The Idaho...
DOC.TEXT: Legislators who favor abortion rights decided Saturday not to press a threat to force a House of Delegates vote on abortion measures killed in committee the night before. Also Saturday, 98 people were arrested in nearby Pasadena for massing their bodies before the doors of a suburban abortion clinic to block women from entering, Anne Arundel County police said. Abortion-rights forces decided against trying to force their bill to the House floor because of opposition from the Democratic leadership, said Delegate Samuel Rosenberg, a Baltimore Democrat and abortion-rights leader Forcing the bill out of committee would have been ``an extraordinary procedure, and it would set a precedent that many people don't want to set,'' Rosenberg said. He insisted, however, that the bill had the votes to pass in the House. The decision was the final chapter in a 10-day abortion debate in the Maryland General Assembly that produced a lot of drama but no legislation. While the abortion clinic demonstration by Project Rescue coincided with the close of debate by lawmakers in Annapolis, group spokeswoman Dee Silverman said the demonstration had been planned several months ago. The demonstrators were arrested under a new law, signed into effect in July and aimed at just such demonstrations, which prohibits interference with entrance or departure from a medical facility. The failed Maryland compromise was approved by the state Senate to end an eight-day filibuster on abortion. The unusual arrangement would have required the legislature to pass two measures: one permitting unrestricted access to abortions during the early stages of pregnancy, the other restricting abortion to cases of rape, incest or dire threat to the mother. Complicated referendum procedures would have dumped the matter in the laps of the voters in November. Anti-abortion forces are looking to legislation in Idaho and the U.S. territory of Guam for a vehicle to challenge the U.S. Supreme Court's landmark 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision that legalized abortion. Guam enacted the nation's strictest abortion law, but a federal judge temporarily blocked it after a class-action lawsuit Friday. In Idaho, where the most restrictive abortion measure passed by any state legislature was approved Thursday, the focus of the debate shifted to the economic ramifications. Abortion-rights interests in California, Michigan, Wisconsin, Rhode Island and North Carolina have threatened to boycott Idaho potatoes unless Gov. Cecil Andrus vetoes the bill. Andrus opposes abortion but has not said what he will do. The Idaho Legislature voted to ban abortion except in cases of non-statutory rape reported within seven days, incest if the victim is younger than 18, severe fetal deformity or threat to the mother's life or health. Some Idaho legislators were surprised by the threatened potato boycott. ``Oh, my Lord,'' said state Rep. Steve Antone, one of nine potato growers in the Legislature who all voted for abortion restrictions. ``It would be a tremendous blow to the state.'' He added that the possibility of a boycott ``didn't occur to us at the time.'' But state Sen. Mark Ricks, who co-chaired the abortion hearings, said a potato boycott would not have much effect this year, because potatoes are in short supply and prices at all-time highs. Barbara Labadie, Republican co-chair of the Michigan Women's Political Caucus, said she usually serves her family potatoes three or four times a week. But now, she said, ``We'll just switch to rice and noodles.''

DOC.HEAD: Peace Groups Protests Outside Georgia Submarine Base
DOC.TEXT: Scores of canoes carrying anti-nuclear demonstrators entered a restricted area at the Kings Bay Naval Submarine Base on Saturday to protest deployment of the first submarine to carry Trident II missiles. The protesters agreed to leave the area peacefully and police and Coast Guard officials reported no arrests. The demonstration was organized by the Greenpeace environmental group and two other organizations. A Greenpeace ship, the 60-foot ketch Mondcivitano, took part. About 75 people gathered for the protest in anticipation of the upcoming departure of the USS Tennessee, which will carry 24 Trident II missiles, said Greenpeace spokeswoman Shannon Fagan. Each Trident II missile carries eight warheads. Lt. Cmdr. Patricia McMillan, public affairs officer for Kings Bay, said the protest had ``no effect on the operations'' of the base. ``The Navy is committed to protecting the rights of groups to conduct peaceful non-intrusive protests,'' she said, reading from a statement. ``However, freedom of speech and freedom of navigation do not equate to freedom to obstruct or endanger the legitimate activities of the U.S. government through dangerous actions by protesters.'' Ms. Fagan said there was concern that the submarine had already gone to sea because neither the boats that entered the security zone nor Greenpeace officials flying over the base could spot the sub in the bay.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Calls for End to Exploitation of Black Farm Workers
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela said Saturday the country's black farm laborers are being exploited and called on rural towns to end segregated public facilities. ``No white farmer has yet gone to prison for the murder of one of their workers, nor will that happen for as long as farmers continue to enjoy the protection of local police and magistrates,'' the anti-apartheid leader said at an African National Congress rally in Nelspruit. He cited the case of a white farmer who was recently fined only $34 after his black worker died as a result of a beating. Mandela said the white towns in eastern Transvaal province, where he spoke, were deeply racist and should immediately end segregation of recreational areas and other public facilities. The government announced Friday it intends to allow state-funded schools to become multi-racial by January if 90 percent of the parents at a particular school favor the move. President F.W. de Klerk has been pushing a series of racial reforms. He has called for ending the apartheid system of racial segregation and for holding talks on allowing the black majority an equal political role with whites. De Klerk has also said the law allowing municipalities to segregate public facilities would be repealed this year. In February, the president released Mandela, who had been in prison since 1962 on a life sentence for sabotage and plotting to overthrow the white government. Mandela, vice president of the ANC, has been campaigning virtually non-stop since then for an end to apartheid. At Saturday's rally, he called for an end to the land tenancy system that allows farmers to require the entire families of black laborers to work. He condemned the lack of legal protection for farm workers and said they should be allowed full trade union rights. Mandela also demanded an inquiry into reports that Mozambican guerrillas have bases inside South Africa. President Joaquim Chissano of Mozambique has said he accepts de Klerk's assurances that the South African government no longer supports the Mozambique National Resistance guerrillas. But Mozambican government officials believe the guerrillas still receive support from across the border, and South African newspaper reports have recently cited new evidence of such backing. Mandela called on de Klerk to appoint a commission to investigate. In Soweto, the largest black township outside Johannesburg, police fired tear gas Saturday to disperse thousands of protestors marching toward municipal offices to demand better services. They also demanded that the town council resign. Journalists said some protesters pelted riot police with stones during a 10-minute battle, but no one was reported injured.

DOC.HEAD: Legislators Exchange Macabre Jokes As Tanks Roll By
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for AM-Lithuania-Media listed on Digest.
DOC.TEXT: For nearly four hours in the predawn dark, Lithuanian legislators joked nervously and prepared for the worst as Soviet tanks headed toward the capitol, then rolled on by without firing a shot. While the city slept early Saturday, 98 members of Parliament watched and traded macabre jokes as paratroopers armed with automatic weapons, 59 armored vehicles and 50 trucks clanked toward the building. From midnight until nearly 4:00 a.m., they did not know if Lithuania's attempt to declare its independence from the Soviet Union would end in blood 13 days after it began. Despite Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's promise he would not use force, the psychological warfare escalated during the week with ultimatums, demands that Lithuanians disarm and shows of military force. ``We were almost sure they would not'' use force, said legislator Audres Butkavicius. But as the hours wore on Saturday morning, after Lithuanian police alerted the Parliament to the column of armor 45 miles from Vilnius, the jokes tended toward lines such as, ``Remember Allende,'' and ``Remember Czechoslovakia,'' said legislator Valdas Katkus. The references were to the Marxist president of Chile who died in a 1973 coup and the 1968 Soviet-led invasion that ended Czechoslovakia's Prague Spring reforms. ``We decided we were equal forces,'' since the first report put the number of vehicles in the column at 98 _ the same number of deputies still in the parliament chamber after midnight, said legislator Juozas Karvelis. ``Some people were nervous, especially when they noticed that the Communist Party leaders were not among us,'' Karvelis said. ``We decided they knew something and we didn't.'' Karvelis' was joking, but his quip displayed an element of doubt about the status of Lithuanian Communist leaders. Most of those elected in the republic's recent parliamentary elections broke with Moscow to support Lithuanian independence. The Comminist Party leader, Algirdas Brazauskas, said he left the session Friday evening and slept right through the excitement. As the lawmakers who remained smiled and joked, they prepared for the worst. Their concern was heightened because two Soviet ultimatums expired on Saturday: one threatening forcible capture of Lithuanian deserters from the Soviet army and the other ordering a halt to the organization of a Lithuanian border guard. At 2:25 a.m., the parliament's press office sent an urgent message to international news media saying the tanks were just 18 kilometers away. ``Please help spread the news,'' it pleaded. By that time, Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis had suggested adoption of a resolution stating that in the event of Soviet aggression, government power would be delegated to the man who has served as Lithuania's diplomatic representative in Washington for years, Stasys Lozoraitis. Deputies rangled over the wording, finally prompting an exasperated Landsbergis to warn that the Soviet troops could arrive before they acted. At 2:43 a.m. the legislators adopted the resolution. Less than an hour later, about 30 deputies raced from the building building to lean over a railing 100 yards away and watch the armor rumble past, a seemingly endless row of headlights in the dark. At that point they still did not know if the force would veer off the highway to take over the city. Butkavicius said he found a soldier from the neighboring sympathetic republic of Latvia who told him the unit was heading for the Siaures Miestelis army base in north Vilnius. Karvelis said there was still enough concern that 10 lawmakers spent what remained of the night in the parliament building with Landsbergis in case the army came to arrest him. ``We are not afraid,'' Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene said at 4:00 a.m. ``But we don't know what they want, and we don't know what will happen next.'' It was not just Lithuania's fate that seemed uncertain Saturday morning, said legislator Volodya Yarmolenko. ``If the situation is destabilized here, it will be destabilized throughout the Soviet Union,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Poll: Majority of Japanese Think Japan Trade Policies Are Unfair
DOC.TEXT: A majority of Japanese say their country's trade policies with the United States are unfair, and they also say they're losing respect for this country, a poll has found. The poll, reported in the April 2 issue of Newsweek magazine, found that 48 percent of Japanese surveyed think Tokyo should make it easier for Americans to sell their products in Japan. The poll found 52 percent of Japanese feel Japan's trade policy is unfair. Another Newsweek poll published Oct. 9, 1989, found the same percentage of Americans believed the same thing. Seventy-seven percent of Japanese polled said the main reason for the trade gap is that Japanese products offer more value and quality than American goods. Forty-two percent of Americans said the same thing in the October survey. The new poll also found the Japanese are losing respect for the United States, that relations between the two nations are worsening, and that 82 percent believe abuse of illegal drugs and alcohol hurt the U.S. economy. The Gallup Organization's Japanese affiliate, Nippon Research Center, conducted the new poll and the Gallup Organization conducted the October poll. The Nippon Research Center interviewed 785 Japanese adults between Jan. 19 and Jan. 24. For the Oct. 9 poll, 600 adults were interviewed Sept. 28 and 29. The margin of error for both polls is plus or minus 4 percentage points. Among the findings of the Japanese poll: _That 33 percent of Japanese have less respect for the United States than they did five years ago. Only 13 percent said they have a lot of respect for the United States. _That 31 percent believe relations between the two nations are getting worse, with 54 percent saying it is at least somewhat likely that Japan will become an enemy of the United States. In the October U.S. survey, 52 percent of Americans said Japan's economic power was a greater threat to the United States than the Soviet Union's military power. The poll did find some positive views of the United States among Japanese. A large majority, 73 percent, saw the United States as a superpower with few problems, while only 16 percent saw this country in an irreversible decline.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Greet Polar Expedition Team
DOC.TEXT: A high school band played and children sang and read poems Saturday as 7,000 people welcomed members of the International Trans-Antarctica Expedition and their dogs back to Minnesota. ``This is the greatest moment in my life right here,'' expedition co-leader Will Steger told the crowd in front of the State Capitol. ``We certainly felt your prayers. It got us through some almost seemingly impossible situations.'' Steger, of Ely, and his five fellow adventurers, each representing different nations, made the longest unmechanized passage across the frozen continent. Their 3,100-mile, 219-day ski and dog sled journey ended March 3. Gov. Rudy Perpich said the expedition symbolized the potential for international cooperation, and proclaimed Saturday International Trans-Antarctica Day. ``Our journey into the future, like the journey across the Antarctic, cannot be made solely by one country or by one people,'' Perpich said. ``It must be made by all of us as partners.'' Some of the dogs that pulled the sleds across the continent were introduced to the crowd. ``I also want to recognize the true heroes and the real ambassadors of the expedition, the dogs,'' Steger said. ``It was their strength and their power that pulled the burden on this trip.'' A chilly wind blew across the ceremony. ``I had a feeling that Minnesota was colder that Antarctica,'' said Soviet researcher and team member Victor Boyarsky. ``But after this warm welcome, we are very, very hot.'' Tim Setterdahl, a sixth-grade student from Rio, Ill., read part of a winning essay he wrote calling for an international treaty to preserve Antarctica. ``Antarctica is supposed to be a peaceful place and it should stay the way it is now, peaceful,'' the 11-year-old read. ``If a war ever happened, it would never be the same again.'' Steger and expedition co-leader Jean-Louise Etienne of France have expressed concern that Antarctica's pristine environment could be destroyed by nations competing to exploit its potential mineral wealth. The other team members were Geoff Somers of Great Britain, Keizo Funatsu of Japan and Qin Dahe of China. The six men were scheduled to be in Washington, D.C., on Monday for appearances at the National Press Club. A Senate reception was set for Monday night and, on Tuesday, they are to appear at a White House ceremony.

DOC.HEAD: International Rafting Competition In Smoky Mountains
DOC.TEXT: More than 250 people from 14 nations have been competing and getting to know each other for the past week along fast-flowing rivers in the Great Smoky Mountains. ``Rapid Diplomacy'' and ``Paddling for Peace'' say signs around the Nantahala Outdoor Center, a rafting complex on the Nantahala River near Bryson City where most events are being held in the Nantahala '90. It's the first international white water rafting rally held in the United States. ``I think it is a great, great opportunity to bring people together and let everyone share their feelings,'' said Costa Rican rafter Gilda Montenegro. The contest ends Sunday. The event originated with the Soviets. For years, they held a competition in Siberia for themselves. Last year, they invited Americans and others. At the end of the Siberian event, Payson Kennedy, chairman and founder of the Nantahala Outdoors Center, invited competitors to hold the 1990 event there. Whitewater rafting has become a big money-maker in western North Carolina and adjacent Georgia and South Carolina. The Soviet Union sent 11 teams with more than 75 people to compete in Nantahala '90, which ends Sunday. One Soviet rafter, Gene Bokov, is a newspaper editor who has just been elected a senator in the country's first free elections in 70 years. Nationalities have been left behind. The Americans and Soviets have a joint team. The Nepalese team borrowed some Americans. A United Germany team already includes an East German. Eugene Dodolev, a Soviet reporter-TV producer, took leave of the competition Thursday and went hitchhiking to explore the nearby town of Andrews. ``America is exactly like I expected,'' he said in excellent English learned from listening to Beatles records. ``Big cars. Big skyscrapers in New York. Big houses. Big Macs. Big plates with lots of food. Big country.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Names Key Aides to New Government Council
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Saturday named his key Communist Party aides to a new presidential advisory council in a move to transfer political power from the party to the government. The top advisers _ Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and Alexander N. Yakovlev, as well as the chiefs of the military and secret police _ are among five members of the party's ruling Politburo selected for the Presidential Council. The official Tass news agency said Gorbachev also picked two well-known writers, an economist, and two parliamentarians to serve on the council. Although Gorbachev assumed the position of president more than a year ago, real power remained with the party. The party has been controlled by its Central Committee of a few hundred of the party elite, the top leaders in the Moscow-based Politburo and Gorbachev himself as general secretary. However, the party has been under attack from many quarters for its handling of the economy and other matters. Earlier this year, it renounced its 70-year monopoly on power. By presidential decree, the new council will be housed in the Kremlin, where Gorbachev also will have his presidential office. New constitutional amendments establishing a strong presidency provide for the president's appointment of a Presidential Council to be ``responsible for implementing the major lines of domestic and foreign policy and ensuring the security of the country.'' The prime minister, Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, is the only ex-officio member of the council. There is no fixed number of appointees, nor any requirement that council members meet as a group. But the council offers Gorbachev a mechanism for bringing his chosen aides and advisers into the government, instead of relying on their positions in the party leadership to give them regular access to him. In addition to Ryzhkov, Shevardnadze and Yakovlev, the panel will be composed of Yuri D. Maslyukov, head of the State Planning Committee, which controls the centrally planned economy; Vladimir A. Kryuchkov, chairman of the KGB; Gen. Dmitri T. Yazov, the minister of defense; Albert Kauls and Venyamin Yarin of the Congress of People's Deputies; writers Valentin Rasputin and Chingiz Aitmatov of Kirghizia; and economist Stanislav S. Shatalin. Kauls runs the Adazhi agricultural production firm in Riga, Latvia, that has been cited as a model for moving from a centrally planned to a market economy. Yarin is a worker at a steelmaking complex in Nizhni Tagil in the Ural Mountains.

DOC.HEAD: Vice President Blasts Soviets on Lithuania
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling of Caucasus in grafs 7-8.
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union is entitled to pursue deserters from its army but should not act against the independence movement in Luthuania, Vice President Dan Quayle said Saturday. ``What is happening is a very subtle display of force that, in fact, is trying to intimidate the people of Lithuania not to go ahead with their independence,'' Quayle told reporters in Arizona, en route to a vacation in Hawaii. The United States is ``squarely on the side of Lithuania'' and has never recognized the ``agreement between two evil men, Hitler and Stalin,'' that made Lithuania part of the Soviet Union, Quayle said. Since Lithuania declared its independence from the Soviet Union on March 11, Soviet leaders have warned Lithuania to return and Friday a military adviser to Soviet president Mikhail Gorbachev said they would try to round up deserters in Lithuania after a deadline passed for them to return. While the Soviet Union should not threaten Lithuania, ``if the Soviet Union is applying disciplinary measures to people in their own military, that's a different situation,'' Quayle said. ``I do not know what kinds of contractual agreement a member of the Soviet army has when he or she signs up,'' Quayle said, but there is a ``certain element of discipline that is absolutely imperative in any armed force.'' Quayle also drew a distinction between turmoil in the Caucasus region, where Quayle said Soviet military intervention was justified to prevent ethnic violence, and the situation in Lithuania, which he described as an independence movement. The Caucasus battle ``was a civil disorder'' where the Soviet Union ``had the responsibility to keep law and order,'' the vice president said. ``Lithuania is an entirely different situation, this is not one group fighting against another group on an ethnic basis,'' Quayle added. He declined to say what counter measures the United States might take, but felt sympathy for Gorbachev in the situation. ``This will be a test to see if new thinking is going to continue in the Soviet Union or whether there will be a relapse to the old way of thinking,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Industry Minister Wants End to Daylight-Savings Time
DOC.TEXT: The capital's half-dozen timekeepers worked furiously Saturday to set 2,500 public clocks an hour ahead, but the industry minister thinks it's time Europe did away with the daylight-savings ritual. France and the 11 other nations of the European Community added one hour to their clocks at 2 a.m. Sunday to take advantage of an extra hour of evening sunlight through the summer. Industry Minister Roger Faroux, however, wants to end the practice, citing a recent ministry report showing the benefits are nil and that nearly half the population dislikes the change. ``The French like less and less being told what hour to get up and what hour to sleep,'' Faroux was quoted as saying in Saturday's editions of the newspaper Le Parisien. ``It's rude to impose changes on citizens in their private lives.'' France went to daylight-savings time in 1976 along with Belgium, the Netherlands, Luxembourg and Spain as an energy-savings measure to deal with the oil crisis. The European Community has coordinated the practice among members so that their clocks get turned forward the last Sunday of March. The agreement expires next year, however, and Faroux wants France to lobby the EC to keep clocks on one 24-hour cycle all year long. Faroux says the amount of energy saved by daylight-savings time is negligible now that France is powered mostly by nuclear energy. Last October, he asked the National Assembly to open an investigation into the benefits of the extra hour. A survey conducted during the investigation showed 44 percent of French citizens oppose daylight-savings time and 57 percent feel it has not improved their quality of life. An end to the twice-annual change could find favor with Paris' six official clock-keepers. They make a two-day, 435-mile circuit twice a year to reset hands and bells and keep the capital's 2,500 clocks on the hour. ``The Parisians are really picky about time,'' said chief clock-keeper Marc Bintz. ``One pendulum badly set can set off a miniscandal in a neighborhood.''

DOC.HEAD: European Body Opens Arms to Eastern Europe, Soviets
DOC.TEXT: A group of 23 Western nations said Saturday it will open its arms wider to membership by Eastern Europe's fledgling democracies. However, some officials reminded would-be members of the group's stringent standards for protecting human rights. Delegates at the two-day meeting of the Council of Europe reached broad agreement that the Soviet Union and its former East European satellites are genuinely interested in building democracies, despite shaky foundations. Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Yuri Kashlev described the meeting as ``very satisfying.'' ``The message was that the Council of Europe opens its doors to the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe,'' he said. The meeting was billed as the widest all-European forum since World War II. Most of the 23 members of the council, which is based in Strasbourg, France, were represented by foreign ministers. Founded in 1949, the group is the oldest postwar organization striving for European unity. It has been overshadowed, however, by the better known European Community. The Kremlin once ridiculed the council as a propaganda tool for the capitalist West and its North Atlantic Treaty Organization, even though the United States is not a council member. But now Moscow sees the group as a possible cornerstone for Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's vision of a common European home that might eventually replace NATO and the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. Irish Foreign Minister Gerard Collins, chairman of the European Community Ministers' Council, welcomed closer cooperation with the East. He said such collaboration would not slow the process of creating a single EC market after 1992. ``It's indubitable that the Community will continue to be the motor behind economic cooperation and development,'' he said. Earlier, Catherine Lalumiere, the Council of Europe's secretary-general, told a news conference: ``All countries of Central and Eastern Europe affirmed they have pluralistic democracies and respect for human rights as principle goals.'' ``We want to give them assistance to realize those objectives,'' she said. But several Western delegates _ including William Waldegrave, East European expert for Britain's Foreign Ministry and Spanish Foreign Minister Francisco Fernandez Ordonez _ said the council should strictly maintain its defense of human rights when considering new members. After four decades of totalitarian rule, some Eastern European nations are seeking help in creating new penal codes and overhauling once token parliaments. Hungary, Poland, Yugoslavia and the Soviet Union already hold what officials call ``special guest status'' in the Council of Europe. Bulgaria, East Germany and Czecholovakia have applied for similar status. Yugoslavia, Poland and Hungary have requested full membership. Council officials said Friday that Hungary could join before the end of 1990.

DOC.HEAD: An Wang, Founder of Computer Company
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with reaction from Dukakis, Kennedy. Pick up 7th graf pvs, `Wang felt...' Tobey is cq in 11th graf.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BX3, BX4
DOC.TEXT: An Wang, a shy inventor whose one-man shop set above a hardware store grew under his leadership into a billion-dollar competitor in the world computer market, died Saturday of cancer. He was 70. Wang died at Massachusetts General Hospital, where he was admitted March 6 after a setback in a long fight against cancer of the esophagus, said hospital spokesman Martin Bander. He was first operated on July 14 for the cancer, which recurred this month, Bander said. He held more than 40 patents and was inducted into the National Inventors Hall of Fame in March 1988. He received the Medal of Liberty from President Reagan. Wang, a slight, Chinese-born engineer, began Wang Laboratories Inc. in 1951 above an electrical fixtures store in Boston. The company grew to become a leader in office word-processing equipment in the 1970s. He developed the magnetic core, a product central to the fledgling computer industry. The small ring of iron was the basic element of computer memory until the microchip was introduced in the late 1960s. ``An Wang was the personification of the American dream. His genius and his generosity made it possible for others to reach their dreams,'' Gov. Michael S. Dukakis said in a statement Saturday. ``Dr. Wang's genius helped spark the high-tech revolution, and his vision helped guide it,'' Sen. Edward M. Kennedy said in a statement. ``In addition, his commitment to social justice made him a pioneer in employee relations as well.'' He was ``quiet, humble, brilliant, decisive, caring, a great man, a one-of-a-kind person,'' said Paul Guzzi, a Wang spokesman sometimes called his right-hand man. ``I think all of us who have been associated with him know he was a great man.'' Wang felt strongly enough about his company to fire his own eldest son, Frederick, as chief operating officer and president after huge losses were posted in the late 1980s. The growth of Wang Laboratories accelerated in 1964 after Wang introduced a desktop calculator. He steered his company around the plunge of the calculator market by focusing on the development of office computers. ``Looking at the results of the company over a long period of time, clearly, you have a visionary there,'' said Tobey Choate, vice president of information technology consulting at Arthur D. Little Inc. Because of the company's growth, Wang moved it northwest of Boston to Lowell in 1976. The move helped revitalize the declining manufacturing city. A leader in word processing equipment in the 1970s, Wang Laboratories stumbled in the 1980s. Analysts criticized the company for sticking with its proprietary systems instead of moving quickly into IBM-compatible machines. In recent years, its sales of minicomputers have been hurt by competition from powerful personal computers and workstations. Harsh retrenching and the sale of non-strategic assets has cut the company's bank debt from $575 million last summer to under $100 million, with more cuts to come, Guzzi said. The cutbacks have trimmed the company's worldwide work force from 28,000 to about 22,500, said Ed Pignone, another Wang spokesman. Frederick Wang, who became company president in 1986 at age 36, stepped down in August after a weekend of discussions with his father, who had remained chief executive officer. In December, the company announced it would offer new products compatible with industrywide standards. Guzzi said Richard W. Miller, a former General Electric executive who succeeded Frederick Wang, is in charge of the company and will continue with the planned strategies. The board of directors plans to meet Wednesday to review candidates for chief executive officer, Guzzi said. Choate, the technology consultant, said the loss of the company's founder could hurt morale at a crucial time. ``Clearly, he was the spiritual leader at the company,'' Choate said. ``Take away people's spiritual leader and you take the wind out of their sails.'' Wang's success enabled him to be a philanthropist. He supported education and the arts, including development of the Wang Center for the Performing Arts in Boston. ``I think it's a terrible loss. He was an exceptional man and someone I looked up to personally,'' said Josiah Spaulding, who heads the center. Wang's gift of $3.5 million to the center in 1983 propelled the theater from a terrible financial position and deteriorating image to a success, Spaulding said. A native of Shanghai, Wang was a schoolteacher's son who came to the United States in 1945. He received a doctorate in physics from Harvard University in 1948. A small man who favored bow ties, Wang shied from publicity, declining interviews and keeping public appearances to a minimum. ``He was very private, and in many ways led a very private life,'' Guzzi said. Wang is survived by his wife, Lorraine; two sons, Frederick, who remained with the company working on special projects, and Courtney, a Wang vice president; and a daughter, Juliette, a student. Funeral arrangements are pending.

DOC.HEAD: Colombian Opposition Parties Suspend Campaigns in Wake of Killing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To ADD President Barco's first name, SUB 6th graf, `They demanded...' Pickup 7th graf, `Barco, of...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BOG1,2
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of people lined the streets Saturday to mourn a presidential candidate allegedly slain by drug traffickers. Opposition parties suspended their campaigns and demanded postponement of the May election. Bernardo Jaramillo was shot point-blank Thursday at Bogota's airport. Police blamed drug traffickers. Drug traffickers killed the governing party's presidential hopeful, Luis Carlos Galan, in August, sparking a bloody war between the government and drug lords. ``The right to life has disappeared completely,'' the Conservative Party candidate, Rodrigo Lloreda, told reporters late Friday at a news conference. ``The government is not even providing that minimum guarantee.'' The Conservative Party, the country's main opposition, joined Jaramillo's Patriotic Union and other leftist parties late Friday in suspending their campaigns. They demanded that President Virgilio Barco postpone the May 27 presidential election and provide additional security for candidates. The communique from the opposition parties did not suggest a new date for elections. Barco, of the governing Liberal Party, did not respond to the demands. The party's leader in the House of Representatives, Norberto Morales, said the election should take place on the date prescribed by law. Jaramillo's body was carried from the Capitol building to Bogota's main cemetery Saturday in a symbolic funeral. He will be buried Sunday in his hometown of Manizales, 120 miles northwest of Bogota. Radio reports said some 20,000 people, many of them crying and waving white handkerchiefs, lined the streets. Several small explosions intended to cause panic occurred during the ceremony, but authorities controlled the situation using riot police and armored cars, said police spokesman Luis Enrique Avila. No injuries were reported. The Liberal Party put off its Saturday convention until after Jaramillo's burial. The governing party is expected to ratify as its candidate Cesar Gaviria, who won a March 11 primary. By law, Barco cannot run for re-election. Colombia's intellegence police said their investigations had shown that the leader of the Medellin cocaine cartel, Pablo Escobar, ordered Jaramillo killed. Escobar denied the charge in a letter Friday to the Patriotic Union. Diego Montana, president of the Patriotic Union, repeated his suggestion that the government was indirectly responsible for Jaramillo's death. ``I don't know how a government that permits the elimination of the opposition can call itself Liberal,'' he said during a joint news conference with Lloreda. Disturbances broke out Thursday almost immediately after Jaramillo's death. One soldier was killed by a sniper and six police officers were wounded before the street fighting was controlled early Friday, Avila said. The government has repeatedly denied the Patriotic Union's accusations that military forces have carried out an extermination campaign against the party. Assassins have killed 1,044 of its members in the last four years. Police investigations have held that most of the assassinations were perpetrated by hitmen working for drug traffickers. The communique from the opposition parties said foreign observors should oversee the electoral process in Colombia. The document was also signed by the Communist Party, the Socialist Workers' Party and the April 19 Movement, a former guerrilla group that laid down its arms earlier this month.

DOC.HEAD: Hazelwood's Post-Trial Reflections: `I'm More Cynical Now'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 18th graf to CORRECT birthplace to Georgia sted Oregon.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY15
DOC.TEXT: In the worst of times, when Joseph Hazelwood's name was splashed in headlines and the lawsuits rolled in like the tide, the Exxon Valdez skipper remembers identifying with the persecuted hero of a classic novel. ``The book was `Les Miserables,''' he said, ``and it seemed like I was Jean Valjean with a hundred inspectors chasing me around in the sewers of Paris.'' Later, in an Anchorage courtroom, he remembered a line he had read about the justice system being ``a meat grinder, a sausage grinder _ you go into it in one form and you come out something else.'' ``I went in there reasonably starry-eyed that justice would be done ...,'' he said. ``If anything, I'm more cynical now.'' Hazelwood, who had just been acquitted of three major charges and convicted of a low-level misdemeanor in the nation's worst oil spill, reflected Friday on the year that changed his life in his first interview since his trial began two months ago. Later in the day, he was sentenced to pay $50,000 restitution and spend 1,000 hours helping clean up the oiled beaches of Prince William Sound. He was asked in the interview how he felt about all the wildlife killed as the result of his oil spill. ``It was a terrible tragedy,'' he said. ``There's no getting around it. ``It will affect me as it will affect everybody for a long time.'' The 43-year-old skipper talked of his past and future after being acquitted of criminal mischief, reckless endangerment and operating a vessel while intoxicated. He was convicted of negligent discharge of oil. His lawyers stood by as he spoke, blocking detailed comments about the events of March 24, 1989, when his ship went aground in Prince William Sound spilling nearly 11 million gallons of oil. Civil suits remain to be faced. Hazelwood remembered his feelings when the tanker hit a charted reef. ``It was just like a big punch in the gut, like the wind's knocked out of you but there's no recovering,'' he said. Soon, there were headlines alleging he was drunk while in command _ an issue that stings Hazelwood even though jurors rejected it, noting that blood-alcohol tests on the captain weren't done until more than 10 hours after the grounding. ``I resented it, yeah,'' he said. ``The dragging in of my private life into a public arena. ... Alcohol didn't have anything to do with this. It's the biggest red herring. ... It made for nice splashy headlines. If I was an ax murderer ashore, would that have made this a splashier grounding?'' The tall, balding Hazelwood, clad in a red and white rugby shirt and tan corduroy slacks in the hotel room interview, described himself as ``a reasonably normal, anonymous person'' before the grounding. ``I'm Joe Schmo, a boat driver basically, and you get thrust into this limelight, catapulted into this starring role. I wasn't equipped for it.'' Maybe, he said, Zsa Zsa Gabor could handle it, or Oliver North. But not Joe Hazelwood. Who was Joe Hazelwood? He was born in Hawkinsville, Ga. His father was a Marine Corps aviator and commercial 747 pilot. An older sister and one brother became lawyers. Another brother conducts the Battle Creek, Mich., symphony. The family moved to Long Island when Hazelwood was a teen-ager, and he still lives there, in Huntington, N.Y. His wife, Suzanne, is a former nurse and they have a 14-year-old daughter, Alison. The call of the sea came early. ``There was a romance to the sea when I started out,'' he said, recalling how he signed up at 14 to sail on fishing boats. ``I wanted to see what was over the horizon, and I found out,'' he said. Now, in the world of high tech, computerized tankers, ``It's developed into a pretty sterile atmosphere.'' ``It's not the captain lashed to the wheel or Errol Flynn flying through the rigging,'' he said. ``It's pretty low key. That was the biggest problem with the trial other than pretrial publicity, educating the jury on how ships operate.'' To accomplish that, Hazelwood turned to an old school chum, Michael Chalos, who was his classmate at the New York University Maritime Academy at Fort Schuyler, N.Y. Chalos, a jovial, outgoing lawyer, put together the defense team, and Hazelwood, quiet and reflective, grew as close as brothers. Asked what sustained him during the trial, Hazelwood said, ``Mostly it was Michael and his effervescent personality.'' Hazelwood said he will be paying court costs for a long time. His retirement savings and contributions from friends went into the defense. He said Exxon offered no financial help. For weeks at the trial, he sat and watched his former shipmates testify against him. How did that feel? ``They're shipmates and friends. They were just telling the truth,'' he said. ``I'm sure they didn't want to submarine me, do me any harm.'' He credited them with showing jurors what a topnotch crew had manned the Exxon Valdez, saying, ``They showed themselves to be professionals.'' Hazelwood even declines to fault the captains who took the stand for the prosecution and called him reckless. ``That was their opinion,'' he said. But he insisted that the procedure of a captain leaving the ship's bridge in the hands of other officers is not unusual _ ``It's standard operating procedure.'' Once, about 17 years ago, he sailed as a junior officer on a freighter from New York to South Africa. ``The captain said to me: `Can you find South Africa?' I said, `Yes, sir.' He said, `Call me when we get there,''' Hazelwood recalled. Does he think he was a scapegoat? ``I always thought scapegoat was kind of a strong word,'' he said. ``I was a convenient lightning rod for a lot of agendas. Using me served their purposes well to deflect the limelight. ... A year ago, many people were outraged and you had corporations, entities, these nameless, faceless organizations. ``Everyone wanted this person to relate to, another human being, not an office building. They wanted a person to vent their frustrations on and, unfortunately, it was me.'' Now, with the trial behind him, Hazelwood dreams again of the sea. ``I'd like to sail as the master of something again,'' he said, but is unsure whether he wants to fight for his old job with Exxon. ``I don't know,'' he said. ``I'm ambivalent about them.'' Asked to talk about his immediate future, Hazelwood seemed perplexed. He hasn't had times to make plans. Where would he like to be a year from now? ``At sea,'' he said. ``Going somewhere and coming from somewhere.''

DOC.HEAD: Texas Gubernatorial Candidate Compares Bad Weather to Rape
DOC.TEXT: Republican gubernatorial candidate Clayton Williams, preparing for a cattle round-up at his West Texas ranch Saturday, compared the rainy, cold weather spoiling the event to a rape. ``If it's inevitable, just relax and enjoy it,'' Williams said to ranchhands and reporters invited to the event. After the day's ranching activities, Williams apologized. ``This is a cow camp ... barnyard language and you came to the barn,'' Williams said. ``That's just a joke.'' Asked if some people be offended by his using the old joke, Williams said: ``I'm not going to give you a serious answer. It wasn't a serious deal. It wasn't a serious statement.'' William's wife, Modesta, defended him. ``If the word rape was in a joke, if sex was in a joke, it was just a joke,'' she said. ``He's as much a gentleman and as caring as there is.'' Asked if she thought the reporters' questions were unfair, Mrs. Williams said: ``I sure do ... Sitting out here around a campfire, and somebody says a joke, I just don't think that's right behavior.'' Williams said the episode may change the way he deals with reporters. ``You're out here to see what kind of person I am. If you try to take something like that and make it into a big deal, it's ridiculous,'' said Williams, who is making his first run for public office. ``I've been a cowboy most of my life. I didn't change myself. That's who I am, for better or for worse,'' Williams said. Williams won the March 13 primary over three major challengers, spending more than $6 million of his oil, ranching and business fortune on the campaign. He has said he owns no shoes, only cowboy boots, and his campaign TV commercials often featured him wearing a cowboy hat. Williams will face either state Treasurer Ann Richards or Attorney General Jim Mattox in the November general election. Ms. Richards and Mattox are in the April 10 run-off for the Democratic nomination.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian President Likens Republic to `Occupied Country'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS in 3rd graf pvs, `Young Lithuanians...' government suggestion that army deserters seek refuge in churches; SUBS one graf for 17th pvs, `We're not...' to CORRECT spelling of prime minister's name; pickup graf 18 pvs, `Many Lithuanians...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos VIL1,2,3, LaserColor VIL5
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's president likened his Baltic republic to an occupied land on Saturday and said a convoy of Soviet tanks that rumbled through the capital had heightened fears of a clash with Moscow. Nervous Lithuanian lawmakers voted to transfer their power to foreign soil if they were assaulted or arrested, and polls opened for multiparty elections to local governing councils. Young Lithuanians who deserted the Soviet army when their republic declared independence took refuge at a hospital Saturday night, hoping a pair of policemen and a few Red Cross signs would protect them from arrest by Soviet authorities. Lithuanian officials recommended they seek refuge in churches. In Moscow, the Soviet Foreign Ministry ordered foreign diplomats, including two Americans, out of Lithuania and said foreign journalists would be barred from traveling to the republic. There was no mention of foreign journalists already in Lithuania, meaning no news blackout was imposed. In Washington, President Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, warned that any Soviet use of force or intimidation in Lithuania ``would be counterproductive'' to U.S.-Soviet relations. About 100 Soviet military vehicles containing at least 1,000 paratroopers armed with automatic weapons rumbled along the main highway through the heart of Vilnius without stopping early Saturday, official Lithuanian sources said. There were at least 22 tanks and armored personnel carriers and dozens of green military trucks. The parliament's information department quoted witnesses as saying there were 59 tanks and 50 other vehicles. No incidents were reported. The convoy passed within about 100 yards of Lithuania's parliament building. Lawmakers called the maneuvers another Soviet attempt to rattle their nerves in the so-far peaceful campaign for independence. Since Lithuania declared independence from Moscow on March 11, Soviet leaders have repeatedly warned the republic to return to the Soviet Union. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has called the move illegal but said he would not use force against the republic of 3.8 million people. In referring to Saturday's maneuver, Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis told the Supreme Council legislature: ``We felt we were really in an occupied country. An alien power sent forces and we don't know why. ``Tension is rising with this demonstration of military force, with this frightening of people with Soviet soldiers.'' At a Saturday night news conference, deputy Prime Minister Kazimieras Motieka warned that political officers in the Soviet military were telling soldiers they may have to act to prevent a coup d'etat. He charged they were trying to prepare troops for attacking the democratically elected government of Lithuania. In Tokyo, Leonid Kravchenko, head of the official Soviet news agency Tass, said a state of emergency may be declared. He did not elaborate, but such a declaration by Gorbachev would give the newly strengthened president greater authority to reassert Soviet power in Lithuania. Meanwhile, lawmakers passed a resolution that would transfer power to the senior diplomat of independent Lithuania in Washington in case the Soviets prevent them from freely conducting government business. Lithuania, along with its Baltic neighbors Latvia and Estonia, enjoyed independence between the two world wars but was forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940 as part of a secret Nazi-Soviet pact. Vilnius was quiet Saturday after the military column rumbled through at 4 a.m., a time apparently calculated to avoid confrontations. A parliament spokesman said he saw the column enter a military base at Siaures Miestelis on the north side of the capital, where it stayed. ``We're not afraid, but we don't know what they want, and we don't know what they will do in the next few hours,'' Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene told reporters at the legislature. Many Lithuanians shrugged off the latest show of Soviet force. ``We were prepared, and the marching of tanks is nothing for us,'' said Arune Taunyte, a graphics designer. ``We were afraid for 50 years _ but not now,'' said Rimas Cequolis, a 56-year-old violinist. There were no reports of Soviet authorities moving in Saturday to arrest the estimated 900 deserters from the Soviet military, Gorbachev's deadline for their voluntary return to their posts. ``We cannot physically protect each young man where he is hiding,'' Landsbergis told the parliament. He suggested the young men avoid the homes of acquaintances and instead seek sanctuary in churches, a traditional shelter for fugitives. At least 28 deserters took refuge in a shelter organized by the Lithuanian government at the New Vilnius Psychiatric Hospital dormitory. ``We expect that nobody would dare to attack the Red Cross,'' said one of deserter there, 20-year-old Darius Baceulis. If troops do come after them, 19-year-old Arunas Vazinskas said, life would still ``be better in prison than in the army.'' Many deserters have complained they were beaten or harassed by comrades angry about their republic's drive for independence. Gorbachev has also demanded that Lithuania stop signing up volunteer forces and had sought a response from Landsbergis by Saturday. Landsbergis, in a telegram to Moscow on Saturday, said the volunteers would not replace Soviet KGB border guards and uniformed police, as Gorbachev had suggested. ``Vremya,'' a Soviet news program, said Saturday night that Interior Ministry authorities have seized 5,500 weapons in Lithuania. Gorbachev had demanded Lithuanians turn in their firearms. The seized weapons included 873 guns that military auxiliary units in Kaunus refused to surrender voluntarily, the Soviet program said. ``Only the intervention of military units'' enabled authorities to confiscate the weapons and 516,000 rounds of ammunition, it said. There was no indication of violence in the arms seizure. Romas Gudaitis, a Lithuanian representative to the national parliament in Moscow, said Soviet authorities had rejected a Lithuanian request for negotiations.

DOC.HEAD: Romania Appeals To Hungary During Ethnic Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Romania appealed to Hungary on Saturday to avoid exacerbating ethnic tension in Transylvania, where clashes between ethnic Hungarians and Romanians have killed at least seven people. Premier Petre Roman of Romania made the plea during a 90-minute meeting with Hungary's ambassador, Pal Szuts. ``We hope the Hungarian government will help us and not make the situation there more difficult by pronouncements which give the Romanians in Transylvania the feeling they are in danger,'' a government statement obtained by The Associated Press quoted Roman as saying. The Hungarian envoy had asked for the meeting because of mounting tension between the two Warsaw Pact allies over the rights of the 2 million-strong minority of ethnic Hungarians in Transylvania. In addition to the seven deaths, about 300 people have been wounded in the clashes over the past week in the town of Tirgu Mures. Interim President Ion Iliescu of Romania also appealed for calm. He rejected complaints that his government had not acted firmly enough to prevent violence. He said democratic methods are needed to solve ethnic conflicts. Romanians in Transylvania fear that a campaign by ethnic Hungarians for education in their own language is a veiled push for autonomy or even union with Hungary. Hungarians deny those assertions. Hungary ruled Transylvania for hundreds of years before 1920, when the victorious allied powers of World War I transferred it to Romania in return for help during the war. Romania and Hungary traded recriminations this week after the clashes in Tirgu Mures. The picturesque town about 160 miles north of Bucharest was reported calm Saturday. The daily Adevarul said members of both ethnic groups planned to demonstrate together Sunday to show they could cooperate. About 400 people gathered around the city hall building, where officials of Romania's post-revolutionary government met with representatives of the two communities to defuse the crisis. A cordon of tanks and troops kept the crowd clear of the building, as the demonstrators chanted, ``Down with Iliescu!'' They blame Iliescu, who took over leadership in December after the ouster of Communist dicatator Nicolae Ceausescu, for not doing enough to prevent ethnic strife. Late Thursday, the two sides approved a new county and municipal leadership composed of 13 Romanians and eight ethnic Hungarians. In a related development, press reports said Saturday that the Russian minority in the eastern province of Dobrogea was demanding that instruction in regional schools be in Russian. Ethnic Russians, who number about 100,000 and refer to themselves as ``Lipoveni,'' also want a seminary for Russian Orthodox priests and free travel to the Soviet Union, the Libera daily said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Step Up Patrols, Rebels Announce Pre-election General Strike
DOC.TEXT: Police anti-terrorist units patrolled Lima's streets Saturday after a wave of pre-election violence by leftist guerrillas prompted the government to declare a state of emergency in the capital. Also Saturday, Shining Path rebels briefly took over a Lima radio station and broadcast a recorded message urging people to boycott the elections and announcing plans for an ``armed strike'' on Wednesday. The term refers to a general strike and implies violence against people who don't participate. Political leaders condemned the recent assassinations of congressional candidates, and a governing party senator called on candidates to arm themselves because the government can't protect them. The increase in rebel violence comes two weeks before elections April 8 to pick a new president, senate and congress and elect members of new regional assemblies. A candidate for the governing, center-left Aprista party was shot to death at his home Thursday in Huancayo, 120 miles east of Lima in the Andes Mountains. In Lima Friday, Shining Path guerrillas gunned down a candidate for congress for the center-right Fredemo coalition led by writer and presidential front-runner Mario Vargas Llosa. A car bomb blew up in front of the economy ministry on a crowded downtown Lima street Friday night, killing a man and an 8-year-old boy, and wounding 12 people. Police blamed the Shining Path. On Saturday morning two dynamite bombs were thrown at the Lima home of Demetri Cisneros, candidate for Senate for a small, leftist party, according to police, who blamed the guerrillas. Cisneros was not injured but the bombs destroyed his car and damaged part of his house. Sen. Andres Quintana, a member of President Alan Garcia's populist Aprista party, said candidates should arm themselves against terrorist attacks because the government does not have enough police to provide security for all 5,000 people running for office. Quoted Saturday in the Lima newspaper Pagina Libre, Quintana said: ``I'm terribly disturbed by the (assassinations), but security is everybody's job, not just the police.'' The 30-day state of emergency was declared Friday in Lima and the nearby port of Callao. It revives a similar decree that expired Jan. 5. About a third of the country is under emergency status, mostly in the central Andean highlands and the northeastern jungle where the guerrillas are most active. The government has used state of emergency decrees to combat terrorism since 1982. Among restrictions implied in the decree are suspension of the right to free movement and assembly and guarantees against search and seizure. Lima police Chief Gen. Oswaldo Diaz said Saturday the suspension of rights to free assembly would not affect campaign rallies scheduled for the last two weeks of the campaign. The Shining Path began fighting Peru's elected governments 10 years ago, launching its first attack in the mountains near Ayacucho, 235 miles southeast of Lima. The group now operates throughout the Andean highlands and in the northeastern jungles, where authorities say it earns money from the illegal drug trade. A radical, dogmatic group, the Shining Path seeks to replace Peru's government with a worker-peasant state styled on the ideas of Mao Tse-tung. The rebels waged a bloody campaign of terror prior to November's nationwide municipal elections, killing more than 150 local government officials and candidates. The government says more than 18,000 people have died in the decade of political violence, including police, soldiers, rebels, government officials and civilians.

DOC.HEAD: Polish Prime Minister Looks For Economic Assistance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with rally. Pick up 3rd graf prv, `Earlier...
DOC.TEXT: Polish Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki hailed the beginning of a new era in U.S.-Polish relations Saturday during a visit to drum up support in the city with the largest Polish community outside Warsaw. Mazowiecki told a crowd of about 800 at the State of Illinois Building that Polish-Americans have a great role to play in building ``understanding and cooperation'' between the United States and Poland. ``We have come to America to open up a new chapter in the relationship between the United States and Poland,'' Mazowiecki said, speaking through an interpreter. Mazowiecki, making a three-day visit to Chicago, was greeted with traditional Polish dances and songs. Many in the crowd waved U.S. and Polish flags. ``Lots of people like us, people who emigrated to this country, are trying to help the country any way we can,'' said Harriet Nowacki, a member of the Polish-American chorus that sang several songs for Mazowiecki. ``We try to show that we are also Polish and we share our feelings with them and we are patriots of the country, even though we live in a foreign land.'' Earlier, Mazowiecki said at a news conference that Solidarity leader Lech Walesa's November visit to the United States, including a stop in Chicago, was ``important and triumphant.'' Mazowiecki, a former adviser to Walesa who heads a Solidarity-led government, said he was here to follow up on promises of economic aid from the U.S. government and investment by U.S. businesses offered during Walesa's visit. ``I have not come to the United States to ask for more help,'' Mazowiecki said, speaking through an interpreter. ``I have come here to look into the future and to make sure that you follow up and implement all that you've already agreed.'' Mazowiecki's visit to Chicago, with its estimated 800,000 to 1 million Polish-Americans, was seen as a key stop on his six-day trip to the United States. He arrived from Washington on Friday and was scheduled to leave for New York on Sunday. The prime minister's visit included meetings with business and civic leaders aimed at encouraging U.S. investment in Poland's struggling economy. Mazowiecki made a plea for investment Friday at a private dinner in the downtown Mid America Club. Mayor Richard M. Daley, U.S. Sen. Paul Simon, Cardinal Joseph Bernardin and executives from Amoco Oil Co., Motorola Inc. and other corporations were among those who attended. Mazowiecki, 62, a former Solidarity editor and political prisoner who in August became the leader of the first non-Communist government in Eastern Europe in more than 40 years, was honored Saturday morning during a convocation at DePaul University.

DOC.HEAD: Pact Joins Tribes to Fight Abrogation of Century-old Treaties
DOC.TEXT: Indian tribes from the United States and Canada gathered Saturday to sign a first-ever intertribal treaty rallying them to protect tribal rights and preserve their treaties with the government. The document was drafted in response to fears that federal, state and local governments intend to disregard their rights as sovereign nations and undermine treaties which grant the tribes land, hunting rights and sovereign jurisdiction. Representatives of 20 Indian nations or tribes, many wearing traditional tribal headdresses, signed the Indigenous Nations Treaty during a two-hour outdoor ceremony. Each briefly grasped a prayer staff before putting pen to paper. Afterwards, a ceremonial peace pipe brought by the Sioux Nation was passed to the beat of tom-toms and prayer songs. The document promises tribes will set aside differences and come to the defense of more than 400 treaties signed between the U.S. government and Indian tribes or nations over the past 200 years. Luke Duncan, chairman of Utah's Ute Tribe, said the peace pipe ceremony makes the document sacred. ``This is an important day,'' said Wendel Chino, chairman of the Mescalero Apache Tribe in New Mexico, who said past treaties deserve the same consideration as the U.S. Constitution or the Bill of Rights. ``We alone know what it means when the drums beat,'' he said. ``That is why we must rally around our treaties ... Let us say no to the subtle attempts to modify them.'' The ceremony took place the same day the Puyallup Tribe in Tacoma, Wash., signed away its claim to a valuable chunk of industrial land in a settlement that will give the tribe $162 million in cash, education and job assistance and improvements to the land the tribe retains. At the Utah gathering, tribal leaders said they hope their alliance will lead to a summit with President Bush where concerns over federal encroachment into tribal sovereignty could be discussed. ``Today we remember the deaths of our chiefs, our warriors, our women and children,'' said Glen Miller, vice-chairman of the Menominee tribe of Wisconsin. He was one of several speakers in a morning session held following a flag ceremony and prayer songs. ``Today we remember the price they paid for our reservations,'' he said. ``Our chiefs negotiated for peace and they were killed. Our women ran with their children and were killed. ``We must soothe their bones, revive their spirits and save their nation.'' It was the second gathering in a month as tribal officials attempt to focus attention on the issue. Indian leaders met in South Dakota last month to discuss strategy after a controversial gathering in Salt Lake City last January by local government officials _ meeting as part of the National Coalition on Federal Indian Policy _ worried about tribal influences. That meeting was sponsored by the Wisconsin Association of Counties. The Menominee tribe of Wisconsin is battling the county association over timber and fishing rights. ``There are things happening that make my heart feel heavy,'' said Paul Iron Cloud, former president of the Oglala Sioux from the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in South Dakota. ``I feel that for the survival of our people we are going to have to come together,'' Iron Cloud said. ``It is a very historical event.'' Duncan was critical of a Utah legislative task force set up to look into allegations that non-Indians living on the Ute-Ouray Reservation in Uintah and Duchesne counties are the victims of civil rights violations. Non-Indians also complain about a sliding 10 percent tribal severance tax on oil and gas taken from Indian lands. ``Non-Indians who live on our lands need to recognize our laws, just like we recognize theirs when we leave the reservation,'' he said. ``We are fighting for a way of life. All we're asking is to leave our treaties alone.'' ``The sovereignty of tribal nations has been under attack since 1492,'' said Roger A. Jourdain, chairman of the Red Lake, Minn., Chippewa Tribe.

DOC.HEAD: Puyallup Indians Sign $162 Million Land Claim Settlement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT name to John sted Henry.
DOC.TEXT: The Puyallup Tribe signed away its claim to much of its traditional land Saturday in exchange for cash, promises of jobs and education and a chunk of Tacoma's industrial waterfront. ``This is one of the most important events in our tribe's history,'' said tribe Chairman Henry John at a packed downtown ceremony. John said he did not expect the $162 million land claims settlement to solve all problems that have divided the Indian and white communities over the past century. But he said it gives a framework for resolving future disagreements. Under the agreement, the second-largest native land settlement in U.S. history, the Puyallups are abandoning their claim to 20,000 acres at the mouth of the Puyallup River. The land now forms the Port of Tacoma and most of the city's industrial land. It once was part of the tribe's reservation, but most was lost to white settlers in the late 1800s and early 1900s. In return, the tribe will receive a package that includes 900 acres, up to $20,000 cash for each of the tribe's 1,500 members, and trusts that promise a future of jobs, education and security. The only bigger native land settlement in the United States was the Alaska Native Claims Act. The signing ceremony, which included speeches by dignitaries and colorfully costumed dancers performing to tribal drums, took place after the tribe's attorneys appeared in U.S. District Court an hour earlier to ask for dismissal of a land-claims lawsuit filed in the early 1980s. John Bell, attorney for the tribe, told U.S. Judge John Coughenour that of all the features in the agreement approved by tribe members in 1988, the most important was the tribe's recognition by the larger community. ``The tribe and its rights have gained a measure of respect,'' he said. Sen. Daniel Inouye, D-Hawaii, and chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Indian Affairs, said that while many of the injustices against Indians will never be undone, the Puyallup agreement is a model for settling similar disputes. ``People in Tacoma have demonstrated there is an alternative'' to endless court battles over tribal claims, he said. Inouye, who made a dozen visits to Tacoma to help in negotiations, said he was approached by Rep. Norm Dicks, D-Wash., in 1987 to help resolve the dispute, after a 1986 tribal vote rejected a proposed settlement. He said he found bitterness on both sides, but felt it was an opportunity to show negotiation could work. ``Both sides would have to put their necks on the line,'' he said. While some tribal members will undoubtedly squander their share of the payoff, the majority will act responsibly ``because they know their brothers and sisters in Indian country will be watching,'' Inouye said. Dicks said the cooperation built into the agreement benefits not only the tribe but also landholders in Tacoma bypassed by development because Indian claims clouded land titles. ``The terms of this settlement will make the Puyallup tribe a major economic force in our community,'' he said. Eight to ten Indian protesters appeared outside the courthouse and the downtown hotel where the signing ceremony took place, with signs that read, ``Poor, Still Poor,'' ``Puyallup Tribe Never Gave Us Nothing,'' and ``No Delays, Pay Today.'' The protesters said they feared they would not get their individual payments. The tribe has said it will probably be at least 60 days before the payments are made. Of the $162 million, $51 million goes for dredging Blair Waterway on the industrial waterfront and improving roads in the area, including some that lead to 240 waterfront acres deeded to the tribe.
