Other major elements of the settlement include: _$24 million to provide the one-time payments to tribe members. _$22 million in a permanent trust fund for social, health and welfare needs of the tribe. _$37 million as total value of the 900 acres the tribe will receive. _$3.5 million for job training for 265 Puyallups and jobs promised for 115 tribe members in Pierce County private-sector businesses. _$11.5 million for economic development. _$10 million for fisheries enhancement. Contributors to the settlement include the federal government, Washington state, private businesses and nearby municipalities.

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Interviews Survivors of Sunken Fishing Vessel
DOC.TEXT: Coast Guard investigators on Saturday interviewed some of the 22 survivors of a fishing boat that sank in good weather in the icy Bering Sea. Nine of the crew are missing and presumed lost. The survivors remained in the Aleutian Island port of Dutch Harbor on Saturday because of poor flying weather. The 162-foot, 195-ton Aleutian Enterprise sank Thursday near the Pribilof Islands, about 250 miles northwest of Dutch Harbor. The survivors were exhausted and terribly shaken, said one Dutch Harbor resident who saw them Saturday. `They've been through hell. They're doing O.K. They are trying to maintain,'' said Marie, an employee of the Unisea Inn where some of the crewmen spent the night Friday. She refused to give her last name. Survivors arrived in Dutch Harbor, 800 miles south of Anchorage, on Friday aboard the Bering Enterprise, a sister ship of the one that went down, said Coast Guard spokesman Greg Robinson. A Coast Guard investigator from Anchorage began interviewing some of the crewmen as soon as they arrived in Dutch Harbor, he said. Informal interviews with the crew will continue through the weekend, said Robinson, and Marine Board of Investigation Chairman Rene Roussel, a Coast Guard captain from Seattle, will determine where and when a formal hearing is held to determine the cause of the sinking. The cod fishing and processing factory trawler was owned by Arctic Alaska Fisheries Corp. of Seattle. The company operates 21 fishing vessels in the North Pacific ranging in length from 115 feet to 335 feet.

DOC.HEAD: 38 Illegal Aliens Arrested In Rental Truck
DOC.TEXT: Police stopped a rental truck Saturday and learned it was carrying 38 illegal aliens who had left Mexico three days earlier. The men were all sent back to Mexico by airplane. An investigation was under way to determine why the Mexicans were in northeast Ohio, said Immigration & Naturalization Service official Robert Brown. ``We are going to pursue some of the leads we have and ultimately we will catch the people who brought them here,'' Brown said. Chardon police reported Saturday that a resident complained early in the morning about a rental truck seen in the village and men acting suspiciously. When police located the truck and interviewed the driver, they learned it was carrying 38 males, all illegal aliens from Mexico. The INS was contacted and took the Mexicans to INS officies in Cleveland. According to the INS, the Mexicans began their journey Wednesday from the vicinity of Tijuana, and they carried counterfeit Social Security and green cards, issued by the INS as documentation of an alien's permanent and legal U.S. residency. The INS said the cost of sending them back was about $11,000.

DOC.HEAD: Numerous Injuries in Westchester Bus Crash
DOC.TEXT: A tour bus returning to Massachusetts after a trip to a musical show in New York City overturned Saturday on Interstate 684, killing two people and injuring 32, officials said. The bus, chartered by the St. Paul African Methodist Episcopal Church in Cambridge, Mass., was involved in an accident with two cars, said state police Trooper Alen Fox. It was not immediately clear if the two who were killed had been on the bus or in the cars, Fox said. Several injured passengers told Nancy Kaufmann, an administrator at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, that the bus overturned when it swerved to avoid a car that had jumped the median, Ms. Kaufmann said. The passengers told her they had been to see ``Mama, I Want To Sing,'' at the Heckshear Theater in Harlem. Fifty people were on the annual excursion, said the Rev. Richard Richardson of the St. Paul A.M.E. Church.

DOC.HEAD: Asian Group Asks Mayor to Resign Over `Racist' Remark
DOC.TEXT: An Asian-American group demanded Mayor Bob Cox resign and the NAACP asked for an apology for Cox's remark that it was necessary to be ``free, white and 21'' to be mayor. ``Please avoid any further embarrassment by throwing in the towel now,'' Narine P. Sharma of the Asian-American Federation of Florida said in a letter to Cox on Friday. ``Your racist, bigoted remarks show how deep-rooted your discrimination is.'' After making the remark to a fourth-grade class at Edgewood Elementary School in February, Cox amended it by saying that being white is no longer required. The comment was publicized last week. ``I apologized for it a second after I said it,'' Cox said Friday. ``I said it's not like that any more, and it's a good thing. I corrected myself.'' Roosevelt Walters, president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said the group voted Thursday to ask for a public apology from Cox, 72, who plans to retire next year.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrations, Folk Music, New Resolve, Mark Valdez Anniversary
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 2nd graf pvs, `In Cordova...,' to UPDATW with San Diego protest. Pick up 3rd graf pvs, `And in Valdez...
DOC.TEXT: They feathered an oil-man effigy Saturday in Alaska's largest city and listened to ecology folk music in the fishing town of Homer. In Cordova, fishermen whose livelihood was threatened by the nation's worst oil spill put the first anniversary of the Exxon Valdez disaster behind them with a community breakfast of sourdough waffles. Women in Kodiak chose March 24 as a time to move on, to turn their oil spill support group into a political pressure group targeting federal and state spill bills. A small flotilla of boats motored back and forth near the Exxon Valdez during a demonstration in San Diego Bay, where the now-unnamed tanker is undergoing repairs. Protest banners were unfurled from the masts of sailboats in, and even a kayak was mounted with the sign: ``No drilling No spilling'' And in Valdez, symbolic ground zero, officials braced for the return of anti-oil activists. As Saturday afternoon wore on, the expected protest regatta of fishing vessels failed to materialize at the Port of Valdez, where the giant Exxon tanker took on a load of Alaska crude that later poured into Prince William Sound. Mayor Lynn Chrystal said his town was quiet. ``Most of us are trying to put it behind us,'' Chrystal said. ``We don't want to forget the spill, but we do want to learn from it and move on.'' The observances came a day after Joseph Hazelwood, the ship's captain, was sentenced to 1,000 hours of helping clean up some of the 11,000 gallons of oil that gushed out when the tanker grounded on Bligh Reef. The fired skipper _ convicted of the misdemeanor of negligent discharge of oil but acquitted of a felony and other misdemeanors _ also was ordered to pay $50,000 restitution. In Cordova, a fishing town whose residents were hurt economically by the spill, anger has faded somewhat. ``We wanted to do something healing,'' said Michelle O'Leary of Cordova District Fishermen United. ``With all the stress of the one-year anniversary, between all the media and then trying to get ready for the fishing season, we decided to have this sourdough breakfast, to do something just for us.'' In Homer, another fishing town, a pot-luck gathering was serenaded by folk singers who take ecological themes. A Kodiak group called the Crude Women met to plan strategy for legislative lobbying. In Anchorage, demonstrators chalked images of sea creatures on the median in front of Alyeska Pipeline Service Co., the company that operates the oil pipeline that fed the Exxon Valdez. They waved a huge Alaska state flag, reviled the oil-man mannequin and set out a bucket of congealed goo beneath a sign that said: ``Genuine Prince William Sound crude oil. Help yourself if it's for a good cause.''

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Protest U.S. Policy in Central America
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 4 grafs after pvs 5th graf bgng ``The marchers...'' to include California activities
DOC.TEXT: Thousands marched in front of the White House on Saturday to protest U.S. policies in Central America and mark the tenth anniversary of the assassination of a noted Salvadoran priest. Park Police estimated 10,000 people joined the demonstation. Police spokesman Sgt. J.P. Farrell said 83 protesters were arrested and charged with demonstrating without a permit. The group marched peacefully, waved banners and called for a halt to U.S. military aid to El Salvador as a light, steady snow fell. The march commemorated the assasination 10 years ago of Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero who was gunned down in the pulpit of the Salvadoran church where he frequently criticized right-wing death squads linked with the country's military. The marchers carried a huge bust of Romero and quoted from his speeches over a loudspeaker across the street from the White House. Meanwhile, in San Francisco, an estimated 5,000 people marched in a chilly fog from Jefferson Square Park to the plaza in front of City Hall. Protesters there carried signs remembering Romero, but many others advocated a nuclear freeze, saving the environment or ending the death penalty. Scott Harding, a member of the San Francisco Committee in Solidarity With the People of El Salvador, said the many causes expressed were appropriate on the anniversary of Romero's death. ``He was a very outspoken proponent of the need for peace. And he addressed the same causes of the war in El Salvador _ poverty and oppression,'' Harding said. Though evidence implicating extreme rightists' involvement in the assassination was compiled by the 1984-89 Christian Democratic government, no one was charged in the murder. ``Stop the bombing, stop the war. U.S. out of El Salvador,'' the protesters in Washington chanted as some of their number blocked the White House gates and were arrested. Some lay on the icy ground as riot-equipped police calmly picked them up and deposited them in paddy wagons. ``Arrest George Bush. Arrest Dan Quayle,'' the protesters chanted. Bush, who was spending the weekend at the presidential retreat in Camp David, Md., was not in the White House. Vice President Dan Quayle was traveling on a vacation with his family in Hawaii. ``Tacos not Tanks,'' read one giant banner carried by the demonstrators. Another read, ``Mao more than ever.'' Among the participants were actor Ed Asner, long active in Central America demonstrations, and Jennifer Casolo, the American churchwoman was arrested last year by the Salvadoran government. Casolo was accused of aiding left-wing guerrillas and arrested after a cache of weapons was found buried in her backyard. She denied knowing anythng about the arms but was expelled to the United States. Police barred traffic from passage in front of the White House and lined Pennsylvania Avenue as they stood quietly watching the demonstrators.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Approves Schwammberger Extradition to W. Germany
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court said Friday that accused Nazi war criminal Josef Schwammberger may be extradited to West Germany. Schwammberger, who is 78 years old and in poor health, faces charges by a Stuttgart court that he killed dozens of people at forced labor camps in occupied Poland. Schwammberger has lived under his own name in Argentina since 1949. He obtained citizenship in 1965 and has been jailed since his arrest in November 1987 on a 4-year-old warrant from the Stuttgart court. Schwammberger worked at a petrochemical company in La Plata, 30 miles south of Buenos Aires, until his retirement.

DOC.HEAD: Food Aid Program Sent To Congress
DOC.TEXT: The administration's 1990 farm bill proposal for food aid to needy countries has been sent to Congress, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Friday. ``The United States has a long history of generous food aid and we intend to have that tradition continue,'' Yeutter said. Three food aid programs are most likely to be considered during the farm bill debate, he said. Those include the Food for Peace, or P.L. 480, program, which provides up to 8 million metric tons of commodities to developing countries each year. Others are the Food for Progress program, which authorizes both credit sales and donations to help developing countries establish private-sector economies, and ``Section 416(b)'' which authorizes additional donations of surplus commodities owned by the Agriculture Department. Yeutter said the proposals include a change in Food for Peace Title I operations to allow direct grants at the discretion of the president for countries that meet the poverty criteria established by the World Bank for Civil Works Preference, currently those with per capita incomes of $545 a year or less. This would permit greater participation in food-aid grant programs by the poor countries, particularly by the impoverished sub-Saharan African nations, he said. As it is now, Title I of Food for Peace authorizes long-term credit sales but includes no grant authority. Also, Yeutter said multiyear agreements with Food for Peace countries should be standardized. Currently, various sections of the program have ``inconsistent authorities'' for multiyear agreements.

DOC.HEAD: F-16s Crash, Third Incident in One Week
DOC.TEXT: Two F-16A jet fighters crashed while on a night training mission, in the third incident involving Hill Air Force Base jet fighters in one week. Both Air Force Reserve pilots ejected safely after the accident Thursday 30 miles southeast of Wendover in northwest Utah, said spokeswoman Barbara Ann Vessels. Major Tom Ward, 37, of Layton and Capt. Ron Zimmerman, 36, of Bountiful were taken by helicopter to the Hill Air Force Base hospital and were in good condition Friday with no serious injuries, she said. The single-seat planes from the 419th Tactical Fighter Wing, a Reserve unit at Hill, were on a night refueling and air-intercept training mission when the crash occurred on the military's Wendover Range, she said. Vessels could not say whether the planes crashed because of a collision. Col. Glen Jepsen on Friday would neither confirm nor deny that the planes collided. The Tooele County Sheriff's Office said the site was remote and no officers were sent. An F-16A crashed four miles northeast of Wendover March 16. The pilot ejected after the plane's engine failed, the Federal Aviation Administration said. The Air Force said the plane had undergone maintenance at Hill and was on a test flight. It would not comment on the cause of the crash. About 10 minutes after the F-16A crash, a newer model F-16C made an emergency landing at Wendover, near the Nevada border, after catching fire. Col. Charles R. Heflebower, commander of Hill's 388th Tactical Fighter Wing, said this week that mechanics would try to fix the plane at Wendover. The 388th is about two-thirds complete in converting its 74 planes from the older A and B models to the newer C and D models.

DOC.HEAD: Kennedy To Visit Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., will visit the Soviet Union later this month and expects to meet with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, his office said Friday. Kennedy also hopes to make an address on Soviet television as well as see members of the Supreme Soviet, the nation's parliament. He will be in Moscow from March 25-March 28. ``This is obviously a time of great change and great challenge for the Soviet Union and for U.S.-Soviet relations,'' Kennedy said. ``I look forward to these meetings and to the opportunity in the coming weeks to work closely with Congress and the administration in formulating policies.'' The visit will be Kennedy's fourth to the Soviet Union. His most recent visit occurred in 1986 when he also met with Gorbachev.

DOC.HEAD: Eastman School's First Graduate Makes Multimillion Dollar Gift
DOC.TEXT: A multimillion-dollar gift from the Eastman School of Music's first graduate has pushed the school to the halfway mark in its fund-raising efforts, University of Rochester officials said. Eastman School Director Robert Freeman said the gift from Roslyn Weisberg Cominsky is ``by far the largest gift'' in the school's $15 million fund-raising campaign. He would not say how much Cominsky gave the school. Cominsky, who lives in New York, was the only member of the class of 1922, the music school's first graduating class. A Syracuse native, Cominsky came to the Eastman School in 1921 as a senior majoring in piano and graduated the following year. During her career as a pianist she performed with the Cincinnati Symphony, the Rochester Philharmonic and the Milwaukee Symphony. She was a three-time winner of a Juilliard Fellowship from the prestigious New York school. She was a member of the Metropolitan Opera National Council and the Women's Auxiliary board of the New York Philharmonic. The money will help fund the construction of a new dormitory, part of which will be named after Cominsky, and the purchase of Eastman Place, which houses the Sibley Music Library. Cominsky's late husband, Jacob Robert Cominsky, was publisher of the Saturday Review from 1942 until his retirement in 1968.

DOC.HEAD: Chile, Mexico Renew Diplomatic Relations After 15{ Years
DOC.TEXT: Chile and Mexico renewed diplomatic relations Friday, more than 15 years after they were broken in protest over the violent military coup that ousted elected President Salvador Allende. A ceremony marking the restoration of diplomatic ties was attended by Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari and his Chilean counterpart Patricio Aylwin. Mexico severed relations with Chile in November 1974 in protest over the coup the previous year led by Gen. Augusto Pinochet. The right-wing army commander gave up power 12 days ago and was suceeded by Aylwin, an elected civilian politician. Gortari is scheduled to leave Saturday for Ecuador. In a brief speech, Aylwin thanked ``the Mexican government and people for its solidarity with thousands of Chilean exiles'' who lived in Mexico during Pinochet's rule.

DOC.HEAD: INS Considering Concrete Posts on Border To Deter Illegal Immigration
DOC.TEXT: The government is considering installation of concrete posts along heavily traveled sections of the U.S.-Mexico border to deter illegal crossings and drug trafficking, officials said Friday. Verne Jervis, a spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service, said Commissioner Gene McNary was considering the concrete barriers in areas where there is heavy drive-through traffic, such as around ports of entry. ``We have no final details,'' Jervis said. ``It's just something we're considering at this point.'' Jervis said it was not known how many miles of the 2,000-mile-long border would be affected or how much the plan would cost. He described the posts as similar to those in front of the White House. McNary, who took over as INS commissioner late last year, helped shelve a controversial proposal by his predecessor, Alan Nelson, to dig a 4-mile drainage ditch in Southern California to discourage illegal border crossings from Mexico. McNary said then that he wanted to secure the border ``in a humane way'' and that repairing fences might be an alternative. He disclosed the idea for the concrete posts at a hearing of the House Appropriations subcommittee on Commerce, State, Justice and the judiciary on Wednesday. He said the barriers could be used to deter drug trafficking and to mark sections of the border. The drainage ditch proposal was opposed by hispanic organizations and the Mexican government. Opponents on both sides of the border likened it to the Berlin Wall, and several Mexican congressmen called it an unfriendly gesture. The Border Patrol had contended that the ditch, 8 feet deep and 14 feet wide, would make it harder for drivers to smuggle drugs and for illegal aliens to cross the desert near San Diego. McNary's comments on securing the border with concrete posts come as illegal immigration along the southwestern border has begun to climb again after a three-year decline. According to INS figures, apprehensions of illegal aliens _ considered the best indicator of illegal immigration _ were up in each of the past 10 months, compared with the same months a year ago. Jervis said the surge in arrests began in May 1989 and has continued through at least February. During the 10-month period, apprehensions totaled 801,937. That represented a 29.9 percent increase from 617,317 apprehensions during the same period a year ago. Apprehensions of illegal aliens began falling off in fiscal 1987, the first year after Congress passed the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986, which made employers subject to criminal and civil sanctions for knowingly hiring undocumented workers.

DOC.HEAD: HHS Proposes New Regulations
DOC.TEXT: The Department of Health and Human Services on Friday proposed new regulations putting the burden on the states to ensure that the mentally ill and mentally retarded get appropriate care in nursing homes. The proposal would implement a law passed by Congress in 1987 requiring states to set up programs to screen nursing home applicants and find more appropriate placements for mentally ill and mentally retarded applicants who do not need nursing facility care. Another proposed regulation would require nursing homes to meet new training and competency standards for nurse aides. The screening requirement took effect Jan. 1, 1989, although no regulations were in place. The Health Care Financing Administration notified state Medicaid directors at the time that compliance was required, and provided preliminary guidance to the states. Failure of a nursing home to meet the terms of the screening requirement could result in its termination from the Medicaid program. The proposed rule outlines the specific details of the preadmission screening programs and requires an annual review of current nursing home residents with mental illness and retardation. In the annual reviews, nursing homes are to identify mentally ill and retarded patients who need active treatment for those conditions. If a patient requires active treatment and has been in a nursing home less than 30 months and doesn't need nursing facility care, the state must arrange for active treatment of the patient in a setting that more appropriately meets his needs. Nursing home residents who have been in a home for more than 30 months but do not need nursing care may opt to stay there, and the state must provide or arrange for active treatment, under the rule. Nursing homes have been concerned about the screening requirement, and many said last year that mentally ill and retarded patients would be turned out of nursing homes into the streets. Linda Keegan, a spokeswoman for the American Health Care Association, said that ``we didn't see a lot of problems with the preadmission screening, but we don't know to what extent that was because of the flexibility states have had'' because detailed regulations aren't yet in place. Under the proposal concerning training of nurse aides, states must establish registries of nurse aides who meet training and competency requirements, including any findings that a nurse aide has abused or neglected patients or stolen property. Both sets of rules were published in the Federal Register and each will have a 60-day comment period before final rules are issued.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists Seek to Block Reactor Restart Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs `Catherine Kaliniak ...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with DOE comment. Picks up 5th graf pvs `The Savannah ...'
DOC.TEXT: The Energy Department plans to restart a Savannah River nuclear weapons reactor this year without bringing it into compliance with the nation's main water pollution law, two environmental groups said Friday. The Natural Resources Defense Council and the Energy Research Foundation, which contend the reactor is not needed, made the allegation in a letter to Energy Secretary James D. Watkins. The groups notified the department that they would sue if Watkins carried out his plan to restart the ``K'' reactor at Savannah River before completing work on a cooling tower. The tower, scheduled for completion in 1992, would bring the facility into compliance with the federal Water Pollution Control Act of 1972. Catherine Kaliniak, a department spokeswoman, said DOE was in compliance with the Clean Water Act under a consent order issued by South Carolina. ``During the construction of the cooling tower, `K' reactor can be restarted and operated under the consent order issued by the state,'' she said. The Savannah River production site near Aiken, S.C., along the banks of the Savannah River, is the nation's only source of tritium, a gas needed in nuclear warheads. All three reactors there have been closed for nearly two years for safety reasons. Watkins recently said he expected the ``K'' reactor to be back in production by the end of this year, although he cautioned that the timing is not firm. The two other reactors, to be restarted in 1991, circulate their heated water through man-made lakes before it reaches the river system. The environmental groups contend that untreated water from the ``K'' reactor, at temperatures of up to 180 degrees, interferes with fish migration and causes other environmental damage. The reactor began operating in 1954. ``Without the cooling tower, this reactor will dump scalding water directly into natural streams and damage valuable wetlands,'' said Frances Hart, chairwoman of the Energy Research Foundation, a public interest group in Columbia, S.C. In their letter to Watkins, the environmental groups said the Water Pollution Control Act provides an alternative to building the cooling tower. It says the president may exempt any federal facility from the law if he believes it is necessary to protect paramount national interests. President Bush has made no such determination. Dan Reicher, an attorney for the Natural Resources Defense Council, said such an exemption would be inappropriate because two other reactors at Savannah River could be restarted to meet the tritium requirements without violating the water pollution law.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says SDI Makes More Sense Than Ever
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Friday that the Star Wars program ``makes much more sense than ever before.'' Bush, marking the seventh anniversary of the start of the Strategic Defense Initiative, said SDI offers an opportunity to shift to ``a safer and more stable basis through greater reliance on strategic defenses.'' ``Morever, in a new international environment, as ballistic-missile capabilities proliferate, defense against third-country threats also becomes an increasingly important benefit,'' the president said in a statement. The program, he said, also could protect U.S. security against possible violations of agreements to reduce strategic arms. ``In the 1990s, strategic defenses make much more sense than ever before,'' Bush said.

DOC.HEAD: NBC Defends Brokaw Special on `New Hollywood'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs `Brokaw called ...' to ADDS first reference to Brokaw. INSERTS 3 grafs after 17th graf pvs `Any suggestion...' to UPDATE with Wright response. Picks up 18th graf pvs, `Rutledge said...'
DOC.TEXT: A Hollywood studio representative and NBC-TV exchanged verbal brickbats Friday over a network program dealing with a ``new'' Hollywood where small producers are likely to get sqashed by large _ sometimes foreign _ conglomerates. Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, said he was outraged over NBC's ``The New Hollywood,'' broadcast Wednesday night. Valenti said NBC criticized the Hollywood trend toward conglomerates pushing out the little guys, and international ownership and investment, but failed to disclose NBC's efforts in Washington to wrest back control of its programs from Hollywood producers. Tom Brokaw, who anchored the program, called Valenti's attack an insult to his journalistic integrity. Valenti, in a letter to NBC President Robert Wright, demanded a opportunity, in television prime time, to ``present a rebuttal to NBC's lack of disclosure.'' NBC spokesman Joe Rutledge said Valenti's demand was ``idiotic. That means no.'' Hollywood producers, including the major studios that make up the MPAA, have been involved in often-acrimonious negotiations for seven years over 1970 federal rules that prevent ABC, NBC and CBS from having a financial interest in the programs they broadcast or from selling those programs in the lucrative U.S. rerun market. The television industry is being pressured by Congress and the Federal Communications Commission to resolve their differences. Valenti, speaking at a news conference here, said NBC should have placed a disclaimer on the Brokaw program noting NBC's interest in the so-called financial interest and syndication talks. The program, he said, ``was the clearest and most visible example of how a network abuses its vast power.'' The FCC last week began a study of the financial interest and syndication rules, but said it would hold up the process for 90 days to give the studios and networks a final opportunity to work out their differences without government intervention. ``If enough bias can be created in Washington ... I think that might have an influence'' on the way the FCC or Congress decides the issue, Valenti said. ``Nowhere did the show, in its criticism of `conglomerates,' reveal that NBC itself is owned by a huge conglomerate, General Electric,'' he wrote in the letter to the network. Valenti emphasized that he was not questioning Brokaw's integrity. ``I don't think Tom Brokaw had a bias. ... I trust Tom Brokaw,'' Valenti told reporters. He said his quarrel with NBC was its failure to disclose that it was in a ``political struggle and a regulatory struggle'' with the studios it was criticizing. ``Any suggestion that `The New Hollywood' was an instrument of GE or NBC corporate policy is wrong, outrageous and personally insulting,'' Brokaw said in a statement. ``The documentary was conceived, produced an edited solely by NBC News.'' Wright, in a written response to Valenti, echoed Brokaw's words. ``Your assertion that I would direct NBC News to compromise its journalistic integrity to further NBC's or GE's business interests is appalling and an insult to Tom Brokaw and his colleagues,'' he wrote. ``There are enough real issues to debate without making up scurrilous accusations,'' Wright said. ``We are serious about achieving a reasonable solution to the financial interest and syndication rules. Let's get on with it.'' Rutledge said the program ``acknowleded that vertical integration is taking place and that foreign media conglomerates are buying up Hollywood at a rapid pace.'' ``Mr. Valenti is a lobbyist for those foreign companies,'' Rutledge said. ``He would no doubt prefer that the activities of his foreign clients were less visibly reported on.''

DOC.HEAD: Two Rivers Still Rising; Most Evacuees Still Homeless
DOC.TEXT: The lower reaches of two Florida Panhandle rivers kept rising Friday, a week after heavy rain inland over Alabama and Georgia, and most of the 2,500 people evacuated in the region remained homeless. Evacuees have started returning to sodden homes in Alabama, where up to 16 inches of rain fell. Eleven deaths in Alabama were blamed on the rain and flooding, and searchers took to the air in helicopters Friday looking for a possible 12th victim, a postal clerk whose car was found in a flooded ditch. In Georgia, less damage than expected was reported, as high water from flooding in the north flowed downstream to the sea. Minor flooding was reported in the Albany area Friday along the swollen Flint River. In Florida, the last of the evacuees were three families who left their homes Friday along the lower Apalachicola River in the Bloody Bluff area of Franklin County, said sheriff's Maj. Jimmy Williams. ``While no water had entered their homes they decided to leave while they could,'' Williams said. ``It's still coming this way about an inch every hour.'' Scores of people fled their homes farther up the Apalachicola near Wewahitchka in Gulf County where the river crested Friday. The Choctawhatchee River kept rising in southern Walton and Washington counties and a small portion of Bay County. It was receding only very slowly farther north at hard-hit Caryville, where about 600 people fled their homes. The National Weather Service reported the Choctawhatchee at Caryville was still at 17.6 feet, or 5.6 feet above flood stage, Friday after dropping 2 feet in 24 hours. Water remained in most Caryville homes but should recede Saturday when the river is expected to drop below 16 feet. Across Alabama, many flood victims have begun lining up in front of American Red Cross disaster centers. A scuffle erupted at a Red Cross relief center in Selma, where people had waited for hours to sign up for food, clothes and blankets. Howard Tinsley, who directs the Red Cross office in Selma, told the crowd to leave a makeshift shelter at a school gymnasium and go to another center. ``All I can do is apologize to them for the long wait, but we needed to move them away from the shelter to another location,'' Tinsley said after the altercation.

DOC.HEAD: Skinner Urged To Require Mandatory Alcohol Testing
DOC.TEXT: Two senators urged Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner on Friday to move quickly to require random alcohol testing of airline pilots and other transportation workers. ``There is no excuse for pilots drinking and flying,'' Sen. Ernest Hollings, D-S.C., and John Danforth, R-Mo., said in a letter to Skinner, citing the March 8 arrest of a Northwest Airlines cockpit crew. The senators sponsored legislation passed by the Senate that would require random alcohol tests, but the bill has been bottled up in the House Public Works Committee. ``We urge you to exercise the full extent of your authority to ensure that an incident such as that which occurred March 8th on Northwest Airlines never happens again,'' the senators wrote. The Transportation Department is reviewing comments it solicited from November through March 9 on alcohol testing before proposing a specific program, said Hal Paris, a Transportation Department spokesman. The department issued rules last November for testing transportation workers for drugs. Skinner said last year that ``a lot more thought needs to go into the idea of extending random drug testing to alcohol.'' Rep. Jim Oberstar, D-Minn., who chairs the House Public Works subcommittee on aviation, says random alcohol testing is unfair to workers because of the mistakes that can occur. The three-man Northwest crew flew a Boeing 727 with 91 passengers from Fargo, N.D., to Minneapolis on March 8 while legally intoxicated, investigators say. Capt. Norman Prouse, 51, of Conyers, Ga.; First Officer Robert Kirchner, 35, of Highland Ranch, Colo., and Second Officer Joseph Balzer, 34, of Antioch, Tenn. were fired by the airline and charged by federal and state officials with operating an aircraft while under the influence of alcohol. Tests taken after the arrests showed they had blood-alcohol levels ranging from 0.06 percent to 0.12 percent, investigators say. Federal regulations prohibit pilots from flying if they have alcohol levels higher than 0.04 percent. The legal limit for driving a vehicle is 0.10 in most states.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Says South African Reforms Come Up Short
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze said Friday that recent reforms in South Africa failed to make substantial changes. His comments differed from observations made Thursday by Secretary of State James A. Baker III and other U.S. officials following meetings in Cape Town with President F.W. de Klerk and black nationalists. Shevardnadze met with de Klerk in Namibia this week during ceremonies marking the nation's independence from 75 years of South African rule. He flew to Harare late Thursday on the fourth stop of a six-nation African tour. It is the first trip to the area by a Soviet foreign minister. The Soviets long supplied weapons to black nationalist guerrillas fighting the South African government. Moscow has no formal diplomatic relations with South Africa, having severed contact 34 years ago because of South Africa's apartheid policies of racial separation and white dominance. Shevardnadze told diplomats and government officials Friday in Harare that de Klerk reforms _ including release of African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela and legalizing the ANC and other anti-apartheid groups _ are not irreversible steps toward ending apartheid. ``No one should have either the reason for euphoria or hope that the situation inside South Africa has changed substantially,'' Shevardnadze said. He said Moscow supported peaceful solutions to South Africa's racial conflict and that there was ``a clear indication toward dialogue.'' ``But, in the meantime, the changes that have taken place so far have not yet become irreversible.'' He earlier told reporters de Klerk's reforms opened a new era for peace in southern Africa. Baker, after meeting with de Klerk on Thursday in Cape Town, said the president told him the reform process was ``irreversible.'' A U.S. official accompanying Baker said the secretary had doubted the government's commitment, but Thursday's meeting changed his mind. On the first visit there by an U.S. secretary of state in 12 years, Baker also met with Foreign Minister Pik Botha and a delegation of officials from the ANC and other anti-apartheid groups. The ANC is to hold preliminary talks with de Klerk on April 11 as a possible step toward formal negotiations on rewriting the constitution to give the black majority national voting rights. Shevardnadze met for nearly an hour Friday with President Robert Mugabe at the provincial town of Kadoma, 87 miles southwest of Harare, a Soviet Embassy spokesman said. The talks touched on conflicts in Angola and neighboring Mozambique, he reported. Shevardnadze is to leave Zimbabwe for Tanzania on Saturday. He will end his African tour in Nigeria.

DOC.HEAD: Cuba Withdraws Bid to Host Conference After U.S. Pressure
DOC.TEXT: Under U.S. pressure, Cuba announced Friday it has withdrawn its bid to play host to a major U.N. development conference. A Cuban official told the governing body of the U.N. Conference on Trade and Development that the event would take place in another Latin American country, according to the text of the speech. Eduardo Delgado criticized the ``stubborn and unjust position'' of the United States, which has now blocked three attempts to hold the conference in Cuba. U.S. officials have refused to attend the event if it is held there. The 168-nation conference is the main forum for dialogue between Third World countries and industrial nations on issues such as commodity prices, debt and economic cooperation. It takes place every four years, and its host site is supposed to rotate among developing countries. Raul Espana-Smith of Bolivia, leader of the conference's Latin American group, declared that all members of the U.N. forum had supported Cuba's bid to play host ``with the exception of one state,'' a reference to the United States. This state had ``exercised pressure and flaunted the U.N.'s fundamental principles, namely respect for the equality and sovereignty of each member state,'' he said. U.S. delegate Kyle Scott earlier told the meeting that Washington feared Cuba would use its ``role and influence as host country to politicize this conference and this organization.'' The last conference in 1987 was held in Geneva as a compromise site after the United States refused to go to Havana. The 1983 conference took place in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, for the same reason.

DOC.HEAD: Red Cross Explains Where The Money's Going
DOC.TEXT: The Red Cross says $33.8 million donated for relief after the Oct. 17 San Francisco earthquake will be distributed in Northern California, not used for disasters elsewhere. The $33.8 million, which will go to private and public programs in seven counties, is what remains of the $55.3 million donated to the Red Cross specifically as relief for the temblor, which killed 67 people and caused $7 billion in damage. The nonprofit international relief organization planned to use much of the remaining money for disasters elsewhere. But the Red Cross changed its mind after criticism from San Francisco Mayor Art Agnos and others, who said the money contributed for earthquake relief should be spent in Northern California. The city and county of San Francisco will receive the largest single allocation, $5.4 million, to help finance two centers for homeless people displaced when the earthquake ruined 700 inexpensive hotel rooms, the Red Cross announced Thursday. So far, the Red Cross has spent over $13 million on direct relief and expects to spend an additional $9.4 million for outstanding bills and continuing aid to earthquake victims. Agnos, who had sought up to $7.9 million to help the city's homeless, praised the Red Cross. ``As a mayor, I know the feeling of being on the receiving end of a barrage of criticism,'' Agnos said. ``I am grateful they listened to our ideas on how to help those affected by the earthquake.'' A 10-member Red Cross committee, which reviewed 80 requests from public and private organizations seeking a total of $78 million, granted 37 of the requests and will consider an additional 20, said Red Cross spokeswoman Barbara Lohman.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Report Says World's Poorest Countries Getting Poorer
DOC.TEXT: A new U.N. report painted a bleak picture Friday of the world's 42 poorest countries becoming poorer, with economic growth rates lagging behind the population explosion. It blamed domestic policy failures and lack of international help, and urged ``enormous endeavors'' to reverse the decline. The secretariat of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, which released the report, called for a relief program that would double development assistance and eliminate bilateral debt. Average annual growth of the countries' gross domestic product was 2.3 percent during 1980-88, compared to a 7.2 percent target set by a special U.N. conference in 1981, according to the 250-page report. Agricultural production, affected in some countries by drought or floods, grew by 2 percent annually, half the targeted growth. At the same time, the population increased by 2.4 percent every year to a present estimated total of 440 million. This would reach 882 million by the year 2015 if present demographic trends continue. For the Third World as a whole, the population increase is expected to total 65 percent the next 25 years to about 4.8 billion, the report said. The 42 countries surveyed were Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Benin, Bhutan, Botswana, Burkina Faso, Burundi, Cape Verde, Central African Republic, Chad, Comoros, North Yemen, South Yemen, Djibouti, Equatorial Guinea, Ethiopia, Gambia, Guinea, Guinea-Bissau, Haiti, Kiribati, Laos, Lesotho, Malawi, Maldives, Mali, Mauritania, Mozambique, Burma, Nepal, Niger, Ruanda, Samoa, Sao Tome and Principe, Sierra Leone, Somalia, Sudan, Togo, Tuvalu, Uganda, Tanzania and Vanuatu. Their share of world exports declined to 0.3 percent in 1988, down from 1.4 percent in 1960. Total outstanding debt doubled from 1982 to 1988 to $69 billion. A prime factor was the declining trend in world prices for primary commodities that still make up about two-thirds of their total exports, the report noted. But it also said domestic policies had been an ``important factor in restricting export development.'' The report said rising demand for food, water, land, firewood, and other natural resources had further aggravated an already precarious ecological balance in many of the countries. It said a new class of displaced persons have emerged in these countries in the 1980's _ ``environmental refugees.'' ``Growing human pressure on the natural environment has either rendered ecosystems more vulnerable or triggered off a self-reinforcing process of natural degradation, or both. As a result, more people are affected by natural catastrophes, such as landslides, cyclones, earthquakes and flood than before.'' Domestic economic adjustment programs failed to get enough outside financial support and achieved, ``at most, limited success,'' the report said. Lack of financial resources also forced cutbacks on spending for social services. It said ``the causes of the generally dismal performance are to a very large extent related to domestic policy shortcomings coupled with insufficient and inadequate international support.'' A special U.N. conference is to deal with the situation in the Least Developed Countries in Paris next September and consider possible action.

DOC.HEAD: Appellate Court Denies List's Bid for Change of Venue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Judge's name in 4th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: An appeals court Friday rebuffed attempts by John E. List, accused of killing his family 18 years ago, to move his trial and sequester the jury because of the notoriety his case has drawn. The three-judge panel of the Appellate Division also denied List's attorney's request for more peremptory challenges in choosing a jury. Lawyers use the challenges to dismiss potential jurors during selection. The lawyer, Elijah L. Miller Jr., repeatedly has asked the trial judge for a change of venue from nearby Elizabeth and a sequestered jury. Superior Judge William L'E. Wertheimer refused the requests in January and again this week when the jury of 12 and four alternates was chosen. Miller and Union County prosecutors made further arguments on the issues in the chambers here of appellate Judge William A. Dreier. Judges Nicholas Scalera and William D'Annunzio participated by conference call. Wertheimer ended jury selection on the second day Wednesday after Miller used up all 20 challenges allowed under state rules. The judge declined to allow him any more, despite having the discretion to do so. Since the beginning, Miller strenuously has argued that extensive publicity given the case guarantees that List won't receive a fair trial. During jury selection, a number of prospective panelists said they had read or seen news accounts of the case when the bodies of List's family were discovered in December 1971 and since List's arrest in June. The arrest followed a tip to a nationally television anti-crime show that featured his case. Some prospective jurors even said they remembered seeing that broadcast. Many of those who acknowledged being exposed to the news accounts were dismissed. Others were let on the panel after they assured the judge and attorneys that they could remain impartial. Opening statements are scheduled for Friday after Wertheimer decides whether to admit certain evidence to the trial. List says he is innocent because of his mental condition at the time of the murders of his wife, mother and three children. Police who entered their 18-room Westfield home found the bullet-ridden bodies. List, a mild-mannered accountant, devout churchgoer and Sunday school teacher, vanished into a new life as Robert Clark in Denver and most recently Midlothian, Va., a suburb of Richmond, where he was living with his wife of six years.

DOC.HEAD: Pilot-Alcohol Case Produces Jokes for Some, Pain for Others
DOC.TEXT: The case of three Northwest Airlines pilots accused of flying a passenger jet while intoxicated has been the source of jokes by some television comedians and airline passengers. For Northwest pilots, it's a bad joke. What pilots aren't laughing at are remarks such as one by television talk show host Pat Sajak: ``We had sleet and hail in Los Angeles last night. Either that or a Northwest Airlines cockpit crew was having frozen Margaritas.'' Pilots tell of embarking passengers poking their heads into the cockpit recently and jokingly asking, ``Do you mind if I smell your breath?'' ``You hear an awful lot of comments'' in the cockpit before a flight, said one Northwest pilot who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``You are supposed to have the door open and greet the people,'' he said. ``There are days now when you want to close the door and not deal with them.'' Rich Saikel of the Air Line Pilots Association said the union has been flooded with calls from upset pilots besieged by passenger comments. The union believes that some of the remarks border on accusations, which they say could ruin careers. ``In my opinion, if it is a clear-cut accusation, I would ask a law enforcement agency to detain the passenger to ascertain the basis for their comment and the crew member needs to be tested to prove their innocence,'' Saikel said. The jokes have been building since March 9, the day after the cockpit crew of a Northwest flight carrying 91 passengers from Fargo, N.D., to the Twin Cities was placed under citizen's arrest on suspicion of flying while intoxicated. The three allegedly had been drinking heavily in a bar in Moorhead the night before. Blood-alcohol tests after they landed in the Twin Cities showed that all three exceeded the legal limit of .04 percent, officials have said. The three, who were fired by Northwest and had their pilot licenses revoked by the Federal Aviation Administration, were charged Thursday by federal and state officials with operating an aircraft while under the influence of alcohol. The charges were filed by the U.S. attorney's office in Minneapolis and by North Dakota officials against Capt. Norman Prouse of Conyers, Ga.; First Officer Robert Kirchner of Highland Ranch, Colo., and Second Officer Joseph Balzer of Antioch, Tenn. Saikel said the incident has ``hurt innocent people. I have been flying commercial airlines around this world for 13 years, but there has not been a widespread problem. But the question has been raised in the public's mind of the integrity of the flight crews.'' In the meantime, the one-liners continue in the air and on the airwaves. On ``The Tonight Show,'' guest host Jay Leno made this observation about the Northwest crew: ``They wouldn't have got caught, but a group of passengers saw them riding around and around on the baggage carousel.''

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Commandant Says Hazelwood to Face License Hearing
With AM-Hazelwood Trial
DOC.TEXT: Former Exxon Valdez skipper Joseph Hazelwood will face hearings to determine if he should continue holding his maritime master's license, Coast Guard Commandant Paul Yost said Friday. ``I think there will be a procedure against the license of that master,'' Yost said at a news conference at which he also evaluated environmental damage to Prince William Sound, site of the nation's worst oil spill a year ago. The Exxon Valdez, a 987-foot tanker, ripped its hull open on a reef on March 24, 1989. Hazelwood was charged last year with a felony, criminal mischief, and three misdemeanors, but was convicted Thursday on only one count _ negligent discharge of oil. Yost said Hazelwood faces suspension, revocation or renewal of his license. Exxon fired him shortly after the disaster. Although Yost blamed human error for the spill, he appeared to partially absolve Hazelwood of responsibility. ``A fully qualified third mate ran the vessel aground,'' he said. It was clear from the trial and from other evidence that human error caused the grounding, Yost said. No matter what technological changes are introduced or what new laws are enacted, the Coast Guard cannot guarantee that similar groundings will not happen again, he said. ``We've got to be very careful we don't have a spasm response'' to the spill, he said. Yost denied claims that the Coast Guard's system of tracking vessels had failed before the spill. ``The system was never designed to track tankers outside the (Valdez) Arm,'' he said. Bligh Reef, which the tanker struck, is near the end of the arm but outside the normal shipping channels. The Exxon Valdez was outside the outbound channel to avoid floating ice. However, Yost said the Coast Guard would install a new radar system that will be better able to track tankers, especially in bad weather. The new radar probably will reach to Bligh Reef, although the area never has been considered difficult to navigate, he said. Congress is considering legislation that would allow the Coast Guard to conduct more detailed background investigations of prospective ship captains and mates, Yost said. Federal privacy statutes had kept the Coast Guard from delving sufficiently into the histories of merchant marine officers in the past, he said. Drug and alcohol abuse by applicants would be a major factor considered in the licensing process, he said. One of the accusations against Hazelwood was that he was intoxicated while in command of the vessel. Jurors did not buy that argument, however, because blood alcohol tests were not conducted until 10{ hours after the accident.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says Thornburgh Won't Have to Come to Wichita
DOC.TEXT: A lawsuit over a drug-laden plane leased to federal agents and linked to the Contras was settled out of court Friday, sparing U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh a trip to Wichita to testify. ``I approved the settlement this afternoon and the case is over,'' U.S. District Judge Patrick Kelly said, a week after ordering Thornburgh to appear in court April 2 to explain why the government abandoned an earlier settlement. Kelly said Friday that his approval of the settlement between government attorneys and the plaintiffs makes moot the issue of Thornburgh's appearance. A spokesman for the Justice Department in Washington, Michael Robinson, confirmed the settlement but had no other comment. The case involved a twin-engine Beech King Air ditched in the Caribbean Sea on Jan. 3, 1983. The pilot, convicted smuggler Michael Toliver, later testified that he flew arms to Nicaragua's Contra rebels and illegal drugs back to the United States several times under the supervision of federal agents. The judge canceled a civil trial over the plane's loss, set for January, after being told in November that the case had been settled through mediation. Then last week, Richard Montague, an assistant U.S. attorney general from Washington, told Kelly that Justice Department officials had never approved that settlement. Montague said the case should go to trial. Kelly then ordered Thornburgh to appear and straighten out the lawsuit's status. The judge said at the time that he also was frustrated with the government's response to Toliver's disclosures and that he thought the case involved criminal conduct by the United States. Montague objected, saying Toliver was the only witness making such statements and that his credibility was questionable. He also said the insurance case had nothing to do with those statements and that the question of whether a criminal investigation was warranted was up to the attorney general, not the judge. Toliver, serving a marijuana smuggling sentence in North Carolina, was granted immunity in exchange for his testimony. He testified in Kelly's court in 1987 that he made two trips to Honduras and Colombia the previous year with arms for the Contras and returned to the United States with loads of cocaine and marijuana. He said he landed at Homestead Air Force Base, Fla., with one drug load and that he worked as an informant and contract employee under federal supervision. Toliver testified that he wasn't working for the government when he crashed the plane. He said he had disconnected a U.S. Customs Service homing device aboard the plane and took off in another direction with a load of marijuana. He ditched the craft off Grand Cayman Island when he ran out of fuel trying to avoid storms. The lawsuit was filed by Midland National Bank of Newton, Kan., which said it had a $198,000 lien on the plane. The defendants included the plane's owner, Walter Conlogue, who said his company, American Aircraft Co. of Newton, leased the aircraft to U.S. Customs agents to help in an undercover investigation. Puritan Insurance Co. of Stamford, Conn., refused to pay a claim on the plane's $225,000 insurance policy, saying Conlogue lied about the plane's use. Conlogue said he was warned that if he did not do so, ``innocent people would suffer and be killed.'' The insurance company was both a plaintiff and a defendant in the lawsuit. The government was also a defendant. The judge was so alarmed by Toliver's statements in 1987 that he ordered transcripts sent to the FBI, CIA and to then-President Reagan.

DOC.HEAD: Australian Prime Minister Tries for Record Fourth Term
DOC.TEXT: More than 10 million Australians went to the polls Saturday in an election to decide Labor Party Prime Minister Bob Hawke's quest for an unprecedented fourth term. Polling organizations predicted a close race between Labor and Andrew Peacock's conservative coalition unifying the Liberal and National parties. Peacock, 51, on Saturday predicted at least a 12-seat victory in the House of Representatives. If Hawke prevails, he will become the first Labor leader to win a fourth term of office. Hawke, 60, has been in office seven years. The election is for 148 seats in the House of Representatives seats and 40 in the Senate. Labor had 85 seats in the outgoing house, the Liberal Party 45 and its coalition partner the National Party, 18. A pre-election Morgan Gallup poll had the opposition leading the government by 42 percent to 39.5 percent of the popular vote. Australia has 10.6 million eligible voters, and voting is compulsory. Polling booths close at 6 p.m. in the eastern states. The state of Western Australia is two hours behind. Saturday's weather was sunny over most of Australia, which is about the size of the United States. The economy was the main issue of the five-week campaign. Labor ran on its record of economic management, despite a foreign debt of $100 billion and record 18 percent interest rates that hurt home buyers and small businesses. Peacock asked Australians to dump Labor for a government that will help the ``battlers,'' as Australians call poorer working people. He warns the country faces a recession. Australia's metropolitan daily newspapers were divided Saturday over which side is best equipped to govern for the next three years. Rupert Murdoch's flagship, The Australian, said: ``The future may be uncertain and unsettling, but we know what life would be like under Labor: the future would resemble the past. And that past _ the painful, grinding, wasted years of its third term _ has been unacceptable.'' The Sydney Morning Herald said: ``It is a time for tough leadership. Labor under Mr. Hawke and (Federal Treasurer) Paul Keating seems more likely than the coalition under Mr. Peacock to provide.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Tanker Captains Laud Hazelwood Verdict
With AM-Hazelwood Trial
DOC.TEXT: Joseph Hazelwood faltered in the difficult task of skippering the Exxon Valdez, but the greatest blame for the nation's worst oil spill rests elsewhere, two professional mariners said Friday. And as long as ships laden with oil continue to ply coastal shipping lanes for a fuel-hungry public, accidents are possible, they said. An Alaska jury acquitted Hazelwood on Thursday of charges of being drunk, recklessness and criminal mischief in connection with the nearly 11 million gallon spill in Prince William Sound one year ago Saturday. He was convicted of negligently discharging oil, a misdemeanor. ``I'm glad that Hazelwood got released from that burden,'' said Olaf Meyer, 82, of San Pedro, whose 54-year maritime career included shepherding tankers in Alaska for Standard Oil and working as a Los Angeles Port pilot. Meyer said that although Hazelwood erred in leaving the bridge while the ship was out of its normal shipping channel to avoid floating ice, he did not deserve conviction on criminal charges. Meyer said Exxon shouldn't necessarily reverse its decision to fire Hazelwood. His decision to leave the bridge, and questions about his sobriety, are justification for keeping him from a captain's post, Meyer said. Prosecutors tried unsuccessfully to prove that Hazelwood was drunk at the time of the accident. He underwent an alcohol-rehabilitation program in 1985 after two drunken-driving convictions. ``Exxon already gave him a lot of latitude,'' Meyer said. Carl McCormick, 38, a Los Angeles Harbor pilot and vice president of the Los Angeles Port Pilots Local 68, was stronger in his defense of Hazelwood and critical of the oil industry's role in such accidents. ``Hazelwood was being judged before the facts came out,'' McCormick said. ``He made a poor judgment decision by leaving the bridge when he did. But you have to look beyond why someone who makes thousands of sound decisions makes one bad one. ``We think that is due to (crew cutbacks) and the extreme number of hours and extreme pressure put on people forced to work beyond safe limits.'' McCormick, who said Hazelwood was unfairly fired and deserves his job back, called Exxon ``the guilty party'' in the spill. The company has called the spill an accident and denied any culpability. The public is unaware of the stress faced by those responsible for guiding vessels that can be as long as three football fields, said McCormick, who has worked for several oil companies. Sixteen-hour days, increasingly heavy paperwork and burdensome technology take a heavy toll, he said. ``You look at Hazelwood and think, `There but for the grace of God goes me or any other tanker captain.' It's not a situation nobody else has been in; he happened to be the unlucky one.''

DOC.HEAD: Fish Broker Sentenced in Salmon-Smuggling Plot
DOC.TEXT: A Taiwanese fish broker who admitted arranging to smuggle 500 tons of illegally caught salmon into this country was sentenced Friday to nearly six years in prison. Patrick Lee, 42, whose arrest July 18 was part of a dual action on the high seas and outside a major Seattle bank, also was ordered by U.S. District Judge Carolyn R. Dimmick to pay $66,000 in restitution. But the judge said that amount might be reduced by the amounts five others are ordered to pay when they are sentenced. ``No further fine will be imposed because he is unable to pay it,'' the judge said. Lee apologized ``for the mistake I have committed'' and promised to work for greater wildlife protection measures by the Taiwanese government. He could have faced as much as 30 years in prison and $1 million in fines. U.S. fishermen have complained that Taiwanese and others are ``overfishing'' salmon by catching them in driftnets supposedly set for other species, such as squid. The case was based on the Lacey Act, which bars the importing of illegally caught fish or wildlife. The judge ruled that a Taiwanese administrative ban on salmon fishing by Taiwanese vessels constituted a foreign law, making the fish contraband under U.S. law. Defense attorney Mark Mestel said he would appeal that ruling, which resulted in Lee pleading guilty to conspiracy, smuggling and money-laundering. ``Mr. Lee could not have been prosecuted in Taiwan'' because the regulation applied only to the vessel operator and skipper, he told Dimmick. ``The fish broker could not be punished.'' However, Assistant U.S. Attorney Robert Chadwell said Lee knew he was violating U.S. law during the six-month ``sting'' that led to his arrest. The sting, which involved agents from the National Marine Fisheries Service, Coast Guard and Customs Service, began in March 1989 after Lee offered to sell a U.S. seafood processor large quantities of salmon caught in driftnets used by Taiwanese vessels to catch squid. Lee, who had been in business about two years, subsequently agreed to sell an undercover agent 500 metric tons of salmon for $1.3 million. The trap was sprung July 18 as two Taiwanese squid fishing boats delivered salmon to a refrigerator ship chartered by two undercover agents in the middle of the Pacific Ocean. Three of Lee's associates were arrested on the U.S. vessel, and Lee and two others were arrested after examining $1.3 million in a bank safe deposit box in Seattle and leaving with $330,000. The $66,000 Lee was ordered to repay represented money one of his associates had accepted as an advance payment. Lee was sentenced to 70 months for money laundering and 60 months each for conspiracy and smuggling, all three to be served concurrently. Counting time served and good time in prison, he could be released in less than 4{ years, said Mestel.

DOC.HEAD: Retired General Jumps Bond in Bribery Case
DOC.TEXT: A retired Dominican Republic general has jumped bond and returned to his homeland rather than face trial here for his role in an alleged bribery scheme to free seized drug planes, federal officials said Friday. Joaquin Pou, 55, was indicted and arrested in November along with the former chairman of Florida's Democratic Party, Alfredo Duran, and Pou's aide Jose Guasch. Pou and the others were charged with violating the federal Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. Freed on $50,000 bond, Pou failed to report as required on Feb. 21, and was declared a fugitive, according to court documents released Friday. Pou's attorney, Jeffrey Swartz, told The Associated Press he had flown to Santo Domingo to persuade his client to return. ``I told him that while I could make no guarantees, I felt certain that he would be acquitted and that he should certainly return to Miami,'' Swartz said, saying he felt hopeful Pou would return. He also noted that even if convicted, his client would only serve 2{ to three years in prison. Pou reportedly went on television on his homeland to explain why he refused to submit to a U.S. trial. When Pou was first arraigned, he had to surrender all travel documents and sign a waiver agreeing not to fight extradition back to the United States. Diane Cossin, spokeswoman for the U.S. attorney's office, said she could not comment on Pou's case, but said it was the department's policy to pursue all extradition cases. Also on Friday, Robert Gurin, a Miami airplane recovery specialist named in the original federal complaint but never indicted, pleaded guilty to conspiracy to violate the same act. Sentencing was set for May 23. Gurin has cooperated with federal investigators, according to sources who spoke on condition of anonymity. According to affidavits filed in the case, the government investigated Gurin because of allegations he had bribed high-ranking military officials in the Dominican Republic and other Caribbean countries to recover drug planes. The government used an informant to pose as an agent for the owner of a plane seized by the Dominican military. Gurin allegedly told the informant that Duran would channel the money to Dominican generals through his escrow account, the affidavit said. Between February and October, the informant met with Gurin, Pou, Guasch and Duran to iron out details of the bribery scheme, the affidavit said. Most of the meetings were tape-recorded or videotaped by FBI and Customs officials. Duran, who headed the state Democratic Party from 1976 to 1980, has denied the allegations, and has accused U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen, a former Republican state senator, of political motivations in the case. Lehtinen's office has denied that charge, saying the case was presented to and approved by a federal grand jury.

DOC.HEAD: Cuban Domestic Aircraft Burns on Takeoff; 20 Injured
DOC.TEXT: A Cuban domestic aircraft caught fire when it tried to take off Friday from the interior city of Santiago and 20 people were injured, Cuba's official news agency Prensa Latina said. The dispatch, monitored in Mexico City, said at least three of the injured were in serious condition. Prensa Latina said most of the 41 people on the Havana-bound flight, including 18 of the injured, were Mexican tourists. It said the AN-26 aircraft was unable to lift off and fell into a depression on the right side of the runway at the airport in Santiago, about 500 miles southeast of Havana.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Cookies Recalled After Razor Blade Found in Box
DOC.TEXT: Dare Foods Ltd. said Friday it has recalled a U.S.-packaged brand of animal crackers, sold only in Canada, because an 11-year-old girl found part of a metal blade in a box of the cookies. Dare School Bus Animal Cookies were being removed from store shelves across Canada, said Gary MacLeod, vice president of sales for Dare, of Kitchener, Ontario. ``We've contacted our warehouses and asked them to isolate shipments and have asked our sales representatives to pull the product from the stores,'' MacLeod said. Customers can return the cookies to stores for refunds, he added. The girl was not injured and no other problems have been reported, he said. MacLeod said Dare receives the cookies fully packaged from Dairy State Foods Inc. of Milwaukee and distributes them to stores in every Canadian province. The cookies are made exclusively for Dare and sold only in Canada. He said he could not estimate how many boxes of crackers were in distribution but expected it would take about 10 days to clear the product from the market. Federal Health and Welfare spokesman Doreen Moore said officials suspect the piece of blade could have accidently gotten into the box during packaging before the crackers were shipped to Canada. ``It might have been (from the blade of a utility knife) used to open a box,'' MacLeod said. The box did not appear to have been tampered with, but Ms. Moore said officials have not ruled out sabotage. Denise Shaughnessy said her 11-year-old daughter, Crystal-Ann, discovered the metal piece in the box of cookies while walking home from school. ``She just took it out and put it into her pocket _ not realizing how dangerous it could have been _ and kept eating,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: First Week of Jury Selection Yields 42 Prospective Jurors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after the 5th, ``Khashoggi,'' to UPDATE with Khashoggi interview.
DOC.TEXT: The first week of jury selection in the fraud trial of Imelda Marcos and Adnan Khashoggi ended Friday with the judge having chosen 45 potential jurors. The prospective jurors, selected from a pool of 150, will be considered for the final panel of 12 jurors and six alternates to be chosen Tuesday when the trial resumes in federal court. Mrs. Marcos, 60, is charged in the alleged illegal transfer of more than $160 million from the Manila government and defrauding banking institutions of $165 million more. Her husband, former Philippine president Ferdinand Marcos, was named in the original October 1988 indictment but died in Hawaii on Sept. 28. Khashoggi, a Saudi financier once described as the world's richest man, is accused of helping the Marcoses conceal a series of New York real estate deals allegedly financed in part with money stolen from the Philippines' treasury. In an interview with Khashoggi broadcast Friday on ABC's ``20-20,'' Barbara Walters said he told her that he never dealt directly with the Marcoses, but rather with an aide to Mrs. Marcos. Walters said Khashoggi told her the real estate deal was a straight business swap _ ownership of New York City buildings for shares of an oil mining project in the Sudan. He said the deal made sense because it would have provided the Philippines with a source of oil it needs to import. Judge John F. Keenan told defense lawyers Friday to follow court rules that allow them to discuss only what has been revealed in court. Prosecutors had complained Thursday that Mrs. Marcos' lawyer, Gerald Spence, was talking too much to the press. ``Lawyers are supposed to conduct themselves under the rules. If they don't, sanctions will be imposed,'' Keenan said. ``I've never been one to back off from a fight.''

DOC.HEAD: Council of Europe Discusses Help to Fledgling Eastern Democracies
DOC.TEXT: The 23-nation Council of Europe met in special session Friday and discussed ways to help Eastern Europe's fledgling democracies. Diplomats from seven East European countries also are attending the meeting, billed the biggest all-European forum since World War II. But the two-day session will be fully open to them only on Saturday. On Friday, the officials also discussed ways of raising the institution's profile and the possibility of forging closer links with the United States and Canada. A working paper presented on Friday suggested the council could in time become a trans-Atlantic watchdog for human rights set out by the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe in the 1977 Helsinki accords. The idea to meet East bloc perestroika with a new look for the Council of Europe, the oldest postwar organization working for European unity, was advanced by Secretary-General Catherine Lalumiere and the chairman, Portuguese Foreign Minister Joao de Deus Pinheiro. The council, founded in 1949, has been largely overshadowed by the more influential European Community, a separate 12-nation organization which began as the European Common Market, but expanded from its trading bloc status. With the rush toward democracy in Eastern Europe and toward German unification, Ms. Lalumiere says the council has gained stature as the only European organization flexible enough to adapt quickly. ``Most delegates said it was ridiculous to create a new code and control mechanism, because one already exists,'' she told a news conference after the first day of meetings. The council's 1950 Human Rights Convention already protects individual Europeans with a sophisticated commission and court mechanism and its proponents argue it could be easily extended to cover Eastern Europe and North America. Hungary, Poland, Yugoslavia and the Soviet Union have already acquired what council officials call ``special guest status,'' and Bulgaria, East Germany and Czechoslovakia have applied. Hungary, Poland and Yugoslavia also requested full membership. Romania has made no applications and will not attend the Lisbon meeting. ``For (East European countries), the Council of Europe constitutes the symbol of democratic values from which they have been cut off for 40 years,'' Deus Pinheiro told delegates Friday. ``They need vital support to help build their democracies.'' The working paper Friday also proposed possible association status to the council for the United States and Canada. U.S. and Canadian officials have participated to some extent in the council's work but have focussed more on the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. That organization includes North America and all European countries except Albania as the major East-West forum. In East Europe, the council has already sent experts to help Hungary organize local elections and could help Eastern Europe revamp oppressive penal codes and overhaul previously rubber-stamp parliaments. Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany told the meeting official contacts should begin to forge closer links with North America. ``We need the United States and Canada in the CSCE (Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe) and we want them in the Council of Europe,'' said Genscher. He said more North American involvement would be welcomed also by Moscow, which once regarded the Strasbourg-based council as a mouthpiece for the capitalist West and its North Atlantic Treaty Organization military alliance. The Soviet Union sees the council as a possible foundation for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's vision of a common European home that could eventually replace the NATO and the Warsaw Pact with trans-Atlantic security forum.

DOC.HEAD: Connecticut First to Get EPA Approval for Ground Water Protection Plan
DOC.TEXT: Connecticut has become the first state in the nation to gain federal approval for a plan to protect underground drinking water, state and federal environmental officials said Friday. Under the program, known as the Wellhead Protection Plan, the state will more accurately map out its underground water supplies and will implement regulations aimed at preventing pollution near underground water supplies. ``During the 1990s, under the program, we anticipate a partnership with our communities to develop land use controls to more adequately protect ground water resources,'' said state Environmental Protection Commissioner Leslie Carothers. Carothers was joined at a news conference by Julie Belaga, regional administrator for the federal Environmental Protection Agency. ``The federal government and the EPA are very proud of Connecticut,'' Belaga said. ``The program we are honoring today is really a national model.''

The United States is protesting the ouster of U.S. diplomats from Lithuania and President Bush is cautioning the Soviets that force against the secessionists would be ``bound to backfire.'' The protests were delivered Friday in Washington and in Moscow after two American consular officials were given 12 hours to leave Vilnius, the capital of the breakaway Baltic republic. The Soviet foreign ministry gave no explanation in telephoning the order to the U.S. embassy in Moscow, U.S. officials said. The two Americans, Douglas Wake and Jon Purnell, had gone to Vilnius from Leningrad to assess the standoff between local authorities demanding national recognition and Soviets determined to hold the USSR together.

U.S.-backed Nicaraguan Contra rebels agree to begin immediate disbanding of their forces in Honduras, breaking a deadlock in the way of the peaceful transition of power in their homeland. The agreement, reached Friday after talks by the Contras, Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo and representatives of President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, was praised by President Daniel Ortega, whose Sandinistas have fought the rebels for nine years. ``This is an accord that recognizes a national consensus and this national consensus that will put an end to the war and bring peace to Nicaragua,'' Ortega said in Managua, the Nicaraguan capital. The Contras agreed Friday to begin demobilizing the 12,000 troops in Honduran base camps immediately and said they should all be back in Nicaragua by April 20, five days before Mrs. Chamorro's pro-U.S. government is inaugurated. The Contras said another 4,000 fighters in Nicaragua would move into ``security zones.''

Joseph Hazelwood's attorney accused the judge of ``Hazelwood bashing'' in ordering the Exxon Valdez's ex-skipper to pay $50,000 and help clean beaches fouled when his tanker hit a reef a year ago today. Hazelwood's lawyers said the 1,000 hours of community service ordered Friday by Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone are excessive and the amount in restitution is illegal and arbitrary punishment for a single misdemeanor conviction for negligence. Defense attorney Thomas Russo accused Johnstone of playing to the media and trying to override the jury's verdict Thursday that absolved Hazelwood of more serious intoxication and recklessness charges. During sentencing, the judge denounced Hazelwood for drinking before his ship sailed and for being off the bridge when it went aground and caused the nation's worst oil spill.

Conservative and moderate Democrats hoping to guide their party back to the White House are hearing from the party's liberal wing today as Jesse Jackson addresses the annual convention of the Democratic Leadership Council. Jackson's scheduled speech followed an admonition by Virginia Gov. L. Douglas Wilder that all Democrats must strongly support the party's presidential nominee in 1992.
