The meeting of the leadership council, formed by conservative and moderate Democrats to counter the party's purported leftward drift, occurs as the party's governing Democratic National Committee continues its spring meeting in Indianapolis. Wilder, the nation's first black elected governor, told the council, ``Those who lose our primaries must reject the temptation to cling to a sense of personal injury and defeat. They must unite behind the party's candidate.''

The Bush administration has its first payoff after 10 months of pressuring the Japanese to buy more American products, but members of Congress are warning much more needs to be done. The administration announced Friday an agreement designed to boost sales of U.S.-manufactured supercomputers in Japan by removing some restrictions imposed by the Japanese government. The agreement, which is expected to be formally signed in April, should open a $130 million-market for supercomputers purchased by Japanese universities and other government agencies. The breakthrough came late Thursday night following two days of intensive negotiations. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said the new pact ``should give us full and effective access'' to the Japanese government market.

DOC.HEAD: Where's The Big Recession?
DOC.TEXT: Trained to believe that general recessions are inevitable, many economists have searched diligently over the past two years for supporting evidence. Occasionally they think they find that evidence and they make a quick grab for it. But then, just as a youngster opens his squeezed fist and finds he didn't catch the grasshopper, they discover they have nothing. Month by month, bit by bit, the evidence seems to be presented: lagging car sales, lower stock prices, weak retail sales, lowered investor confidence, home starts off. Then the opposite occurs; the numbers reverse themselves. No trend there. It's been that way for two years now, but rather than being discouraged, some searchers are more convinced than ever that the beast is out there, ready to pounce. ``It's been seven long years,'' they say. ``It has to come.'' In fact, some of them are convinced it must come. Recessions are not all bad, these theorists say. Recessions might even be necessary to kill off excesses of demand or expectations or borrowing. They are corrective. The theorists are correct about the seven years. Measured nationally, no recession has occurred in that time. National figures, they say, are the only evidence. That's the way they were trained; that's the way they believe. National statistics don't lie, they say, and you tend to agree. In spite of lapses, corrections, revisions and adjustments, United States economic figures are usually conceded to be the world's most accurate. No, they may not lie, but some critics contend the economic numbers hide the facts, at least from those who read them in a certain way _ from those who by habit look for certain evidence and ignore other evidence. The habitual way of proving recession is to examine the national readings for gross national product, which is the total output of goods and services. If the GNP shrinks for two successive quarters you have a recession. By that definition there has been no recession since the fall of 1982. But what about regional recessions, or economic shrinkages that affected some of the country but not all of it? Or industrywide recessions that didn't spread to the general economy? By that measure there have been lots of them. In that time period farm states have had a recession. Simultaneously, mining and manufacturing states were down too. Several states had deep recessions due to oil pricing. Real estate has been off in several areas. At one point, Sindlinger & Co., an economics researcher, told clients that more than 30 states could be considered in recession. But this important recession never showed up in the national numbers. Coastal booms offset it. Those who work in specific industries can relate their recession woes. Among these industries: farming, mining, homebuilding, defense, automobiles. Remember the oil patch problems and the rust belt? Right now, there is a recession in the securities industry; more than half the brokerage houses on the New York Stock Exchange lost money in the fourth quarter of 1989. Savings and loans are in bad shape. New England banks, too. To say there has been no recession in seven years is to ignore the evidence of regional and industry recessions. This is the contention of those who support the rolling readjustment or traveling recession theory. They say that for reasons not fully understood _ perhaps it has something to do with a better understanding of economics at the Federal Reserve _ the nation has had its recession here and there a bit at a time, piecemeal. The beast, they say, might have changed its habits. Rather than crashing out of the jungle with a leap and a roar, it stalks the edges of the economy, nibbling here and there, getting its way that way, and covering its tracks.

DOC.HEAD: Peanut Butter Enthusiasts Celebrating 100-Year Anniversary
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: It's official: Peanut butter now has been sticking to the roofs of our mouths for a century. Chunky or creamy, eaten plain or with jelly, bananas, mayonnaise or marshmallows, peanut butter has stood the test of time _ and that doesn't just mean a long day in a hot school lunch box. This month, peanut butter enthusiasts are celebrating the 100th anniversary of the creation of the ideal family food _ cheap, filling and nutritious, despite the high fat content _ that celebrities also love. For starters, there's Elvis Presley. His favorite sandwich was peanut butter and bananas, grilled in butter. According to biographer Albert Goldman, Presley and his cronies once flew to Colorado just to pick up a batch of gourmet peanut butter sandwiches. Tennis player Chris Evert was said to eat peanut butter on whole-grain bread as a last-minute snack before matches. Conservative columnist George Will says he eats a peanut butter-and-sweet-pickle sandwich, a family tradition, twice a week. Former President Ford is among the 50,000 members of the Adult Peanut Butter Lovers Fan Club, and retired Sen. Barry Goldwater once used peanut butter for shaving cream while on a camping trip. Peanut butter, in short, is an American classic _ and a $1 billion industry. Still, its origins remain something of a mystery. The Atlanta-based Peanut Advisory Board knows that a St. Louis doctor is responsible for peanut butter's debut in March 1890 and that patents for peanut grinding machines were issued several years later. But it doesn't have a name for the man who first ground peanuts into paste and spread them on a slice of bread. ``Nobody thought it was a big deal back then,'' said Suzanne Corbett, a culinary historian in St. Louis who says she's close to solving the case. ``They decided it was great-tasting and cheap, but the emphasis was on commercialism, not invention.'' According to the Peanut Advisory Board, the St. Louis doctor created peanut butter as a nutritious protein substitute for his elderly patients whose teeth were so poor they could not eat meat. The doctor, who made his peanut butter with a kitchen hand-grinder, then went for mass marketing. George A. Bayle Jr., owner of a food products company, packaged and sold the spread, for 6 cents a pound. Bayle peanut butter cans from the 1910s bear the inscription: ``A sandwich a day keeps your children at play.'' Since December, Corbett has been poring over the Bayle company files, which are scattered over the St. Louis area, and has been in contact with a woman in her 70s who worked for the Bayle company. She's narrowed the possibilities down to four men and is working on the supposition that the inventor of peanut butter worked for a sanitarium near Bayle's factory. ``It's sort of like peeling wallpaper off an old room,'' Corbett said. ``You keep going down and down and down. I feel like I'm right there.'' Corbett is certain the credit should not go to Dr. John Harvey Kellogg of Battle Creek, Mich., a surgeon who patented the first peanut butter grinder. Kellogg made peanut butter around the same time in his search for a vegetarian food for patients at his sanitarium. According to Kellogg Co. archives, Kellogg and his brother, W.K. Kellogg _ famous for his cereal company _ bought 10 pounds of peanuts, roasted them in the oven, put the nuts in a pillow case to remove the hulls, weeded out the husks and then put the remaining material through grain rollers to make peanut butter. W.K. Kellogg, the business manager of the sanitarium, opened Sanitas Nut Co. and supplied foods like peanut butter to the sanitarium and local grocery stores. But after a while, John Kellogg changed the formula and decided to steam the peanuts instead. ``It tasted terrible,'' Corbett said. ``So they said, `To heck with that, let's concentrate on cereal.''' Peanut butter was a big seller at the 1904 World's Fair in St. Louis, but didn't really take off until much later. In the 1920s, the process of stabilization was discovered, allowing it to be stored without refrigeration. The biggest boost may have come during World War II. The government fed peanut butter to GIs, who then came home, started the baby boom and fed the stuff to their kids. Peanut butter was a regionalized industry until 1955, when Procter & Gamble Co. bought Big Top peanut butter and reintroduced it as Jif, the No. 1 seller, and Best Foods bought Skippy. More peanut fun facts: _Peanuts, primarily grown in eight southern states, are the nation's 12th largest cash crop. They're a $500 million-a-year crop in Georgia, which produces nearly half the nation's supply. _It takes 548 peanuts to make a 12-ounce jar and an acre of peanuts will yield 30,000 peanut butter sandwiches. _About half the 4 billion-pound annual crop is devoted to the production of peanut butter and the other half is almost equally split between salted nuts, candy and peanut oil. _Ninety percent of a jar of peanut butter must be peanuts, but it also may contain salt, sweeteners and hydrogenated vegetable oil as a stabilizer. _George Washington Carver discovered the peanut plant also could be used in shaving cream, ink, paint, explosives, shampoo, pet litter, fire logs, lipstick and soap. _Americans are expected to eat 800 million pounds of peanut butter this year, more than double the 350 million pounds consumed in 1960, according to the peanut board. That's an average of 3.3 pounds per person. _Although it's portrayed as a kid's food, adults actually consume 55 percent. Not everyone loves peanut butter, of course. In fact, there's even a word for the phobia of getting peanut butter stuck to the roof of the mouth: arachibrityraphobia. The search for peanut butter's inventor continues. Coming up with a name may not mean much for sales, but Corbett is convinced it is important research. ``Food history is something we can all relate to,'' Corbett said. ``Food transports one back in time. Combine the smells and the taste, and it's an instant flashback.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Japanese Stock Markets Going Separate Ways _ For Now
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: Wall Street has shown it is capable of defying the gravitational pull of the sliding Tokyo stock market, challenging notions of global interdependence. But many securities strategists say it is foolish to conclude the two largest stock markets are going separate ways. The securities boom of the 1980s gave rise to the view that the world has become one big 24-hour trading floor, with buying and selling moving seamlessly each day from the Far East to Western Europe to the United States. Insomniac traders are linked around the globe by telephone and computer. The most powerful and scary example of this globalization occurred in the October 1987 market collapse, as panic selling reverberated from continent to continent. But in the past month or so, tidal waves sweeping the Tokyo market have turned into ripples _ or less _ by the time they reached New York. Naysayers of globalization said the so-called inextricable links were unraveling. Some strategists even argued that Tokyo's malaise is New York's health tonic. They argue that Japanese investors, panicky about further weakening of stocks in their own country, have been selling them and buying U.S. shares instead. Some of the trading sessions last week seemed to reflect this theory. On Monday, for example, Wall Street dropped initially but shrugged off the third-biggest daily drop in Tokyo's key Nikkei stock average. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials finished the day higher. On Tuesday, after another steep dive in Tokyo, the New York market finished only mildly lower. On Thursday, when the Tokyo market sank to the lowest close since Christmas eve of 1988, Wall Street sold off as well, but the drop was by no means catastrophic. Some strategists said it was a technical correction. ``I think we've delinked ourselves from Tokyo,'' said Larry Wachtel, an analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ``They're two different markets now.'' Nonetheless, Wachtel and others believe, that could change if Japanese investors were forced to sell their U.S. stocks to raise cash for obligations at home. ``If the declines in (the Japanese) markets become too severe . .. that's when all of the markets around the world will be negatively impacted,'' said Hugh Johnson, senior vice president of First Albany Corp. in Albany, N.Y. ``At some point, they're going to look like they've recoupled.'' The tight connections between the Japanese and U.S. economies mean their markets won't go separate ways indefinitely, some observers believe. The resilience Wall Street has been showing in the face of Tokyo's travails springs largely from foreign institutional investors _ mainly Japanese and European _ who have moved chunks of capital out of the Tokyo market and into New York. A major reason for the decline in Japan has been the weakening yen, which makes stocks there worth less and increases inflation. The Bank of Japan raised its key discount rate by one percentage point Tuesday to 5.25 percent _ the fourth in a series of increases intended mainly to fight inflation, but it didn't do much to help the faltering Japanese currency. Against that background, foreign investors have been ``seeking comfort in our financial markets,'' Johnson said. That's why even negative economic news in the United States, like government reports last week on rising inflation and an intractable trade deficit, haven't perturbed Wall Street too much. The dollar is relatively strong at the moment and the economic grass, for now, seems to be greener on the American side.

DOC.HEAD: Classes Liven Up with Events in Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: American teachers are scrambling for effective ways to interpret the democratic reforms in Eastern Europe for students who think of the red scare as a bad skin rash. ``That is like a whole different world to them,'' said Linda Hillestad, a geography teacher at Brookings Middle School in South Dakota. ``Some are impressed and excited. `It's really neat,' they say. But I don't know if they see that it's going to have any effect on their future.'' Ms. Hillestad said a weekly filmstrip called ``News Currents'' keeps students up to date with events in Eastern Europe, Africa and other parts of the world. Judy Butler, social studies and international education specialist for the Arkansas Department of Education in Little Rock, said students appear too nonchalant about the move toward democracy in the Soviet bloc. She points to her own 15-year-old son as an example. ``For him, it's just the nightly news,'' said Ms. Butler. ``He's probably more aware of current events than most people because of his mother. It's like `Oh, that's interesting,' but he doesn't race to the television like we do. I don't see that voraciousness. ``I still don't think they have a full grasp of what it means. For people my age that grew up with the red scare ... It's things we've talked about for years but it's like hard to face.'' Ms. Butler said Arkansas had two Japanese internment camps during World War II, yet ``the kids don't understand why there is fear with reunification of Germany.'' Part of the reason for American students' indifference is their lack of knowledge about geography and social studies. A recent study by the congressionally mandated National Assessment of Educational Progress said that while 85 percent of high school seniors recognized the Soviet Union on a world map, only 37 percent could find Southeast Asia. The best score on the entire test was 59 percent. Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers, bemoaned the indifference and ignorance of American students ``whose future is now freer of the constant menace of war between two superpowers.'' In a newspaper column, Shanker wrote about an honors history class that was discussing the plight of satellite countries struggling to free themselves from Soviet domination. One student asked if ``this talk of satellites'' had anything to do with ``satellite dishes,'' Shanker said. Leslie Jean Roche of Wheaton High School in a Maryland suburb searches for creative ways to teach. For example, last Halloween, before the Berlin Wall fell, Ms. Roche dressed as an ``Eastern Bloc Buster,'' complete with a green dollar sign painted on one cheek and a symbol representing a ballot box on the other cheek. ``This provoked discussion,'' she said. ``I asked the students to interpret me based on what was going on. I asked them if the issues motivating the changes that were just beginning to occur were economic or political. ``They were quite capable of understanding what was going on. It interested them more than the Jacksonian Democracy that we were studying.'' Ms. Roche said she cried about the Berlin Wall because ``it's such a vivid part of my memory. I remember the bomb drills. I got the students to hide under their desks and asked them what they were worried about, to describe their emotions.'' ``Not only the students but the teachers are in the proces of learning,'' she said. Ms. Hillestad acknowledged that ``I'm not focusing on this as I should'' because ``I need to feel like I know a little about it. So I need to do a lot more reading. I would think that a lot of teachers would be uncomfortable with it. Other than world history, I don't have a real strong background in that part of the world.'' Nancy Nemchik, librarian at the Kenmore Middle School in Landover, Md., said many of the teachers ``had to go back and do some work to determine where those countries were located'' in Eastern Europe because ``it wasn't part of the curriculum.'' A number of states are beefing up their studies in history, geography and social studies. Ms. Butler said Arkansas elementary schools focus mainly on general skills that include location of places in the world, the role of leaders, necessary laws and responsibilities that go with the law. Middle school children learn more about current events. Global studies are required in high school and teachers are encouraged to focus on themes like values, culture, conflicts, world hunger and population problems. ``For us to be a basically agricultural state, global studies has really caught on real well,'' said Ms. Butler. Other teachers point to the heavy curricular requirements either on the state or local level as roadblocks to teachers who want to deviate some to teach about the current events. Any delays could put teachers behind schedule. Keith Crawley, social studies specialist with the Arizona Department of Education, said the state began about two years ago what is called ``essential skills'' for all students. But he admitted ``most teachers are struggling'' with the concept to select turning points in history to study in depth. ``It's difficult because people in history are used to a chronological sequence. The teachers have to come to grips with the idea that events don't come about unless other things come to bear. But we're excited in Arizona becasue of the new framework,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tuesday AMs, March 27

DOC.HEAD: Eight Try To Trade Congress for Top Title in Statehouse
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Eight members of Congress are trying to prove this year that you can go home again _ as governor. Potomac fever rarely goes into remission, but among those politicians who have had enough of Capitol Hill, an increasingly popular career path leads to places like Little Rock, Tallahassee, Hartford and Montgomery. Seven members of Congress won governorships from 1982 to 1989, about a third of those who tried. Those odds are hardly comparable to the 98 percent return rate for members of Congress who seek re-election, but the higher risk hasn't discouraged a crop of eight new gubernatorial aspirants this year. ``You can do more in an afternoon as governor than you can in a career in Congress,'' said one gubernatorial hopeful, Republican Rep. John Rowland of Connecticut, attributing the quip to former Delaware Gov. Pete du Pont. It is theme sounded often among those hoping to return home. Many say they want to take on greater challenges, test their executive skills, set their own agendas and leave their marks on education, drug abuse, budgets, the business climate and the environment. ``I've spent the last seven years pushing and pulling, trying to get the federal government to deal with its deficit. It's a very difficult process,'' said Democratic Rep. Bruce Morrison, another Connecticut gubernatorial hopeful. ``The federal government has lost its capacity to really be the source of solutions to many problems.'' Larry Sabato, a University of Virginia political scientist who wrote a book about the American governorship, calls Congress ``an increasingly depressing place to work.'' ``The budget deficit is a permanent excuse for inaction. Democrats and many Republicans are frustrated. The money isn't there to do what they want to do, and the will to raise taxes isn't there,'' Sabato said. In contrast, he said, ``the states have both the resources and the will to innovate. Being in a state capitol is much more invigorating than it was 25 years ago.'' The desire to head home to the statehouse may run even deeper in Congress than what is apparent on the surface. ``For everyone that runs for governor out of Congress, there is generally a substantial number greater than that who are thinking about it, particularly in the off-years,'' said Rep. Joseph Brennan, a Maine Democrat who is trying to reclaim his old job as governor. ``Many people here, if they had a choice, would prefer to be the chief executive of a state.'' Members of Congress cite career advancement and personal fulfullment as primary reasons to return to the statehouse. But they also see the move as a chance to escape the pressures they face in Congress from constant travel, continuous fund-raising and little time for family. ``The pace and the back and forth and the commitments are a hardship on any family, but it's even worse on a young family,'' said Rowland, who has children aged 5, 3 and 1 who live in Connecticut. Roots are another element of the pull towards home. Rowland, for instance, said his family has lived in Connecticut for 150 years. Democratic Rep. Ronnie Flippo, hoping to become governor of Alabama, tells home state audiences he can't get used to ``a place that serves their tea hot and their green beans cold.'' Other members of Congress running for governor this year are Republican Sen. Pete Wilson of California and Reps. Bill Nelson, D-Fla.; Tommy Robinson, R-Ark.; and Wes Watkins, D-Okla. At least two more members are eyeing other state jobs as potential stepping stones. Republican Sen. Gordon Humphrey of New Hampshire is retiring from the Senate and considering a run for a $100-a-year job in the part-time state Senate while he awaits a shot at the governorship. That won't be until his friend, Republican Gov. Judd Gregg, decides to retire, which might not be until 1996. Rep. Michael DeWine, R-Ohio, considered a gubernatorial bid this year and opted to try for lieutenant governor on a ticket with former Cleveland mayor George Voinovich. DeWine, whose family moved back to Ohio last year, would take a pay cut from $96,600 to $51,000 if the GOP ticket wins. The tradeoff, he said, is ``a greater opportunity to get things done.'' He'll also have a statewide organization to activate when it's his turn to run for governor or senator.

DOC.HEAD: Medley of Circumstances Contribute to U.S. Bond Market's Appeal
DOC.TEXT: International investors have many motivations for backing U.S. government bonds. Sometimes single factors, such as the sheer size of the huge American market, are enough to steer money into the United States. Yield, or the return on a bond, is among the first considerations for globally minded investors in deciding where to put their funds. Inflation rates rank high because no one wants to watch the worth of a fixed-income investment eroded by rising prices. Currency values also are crucial. ``It's more of a stew of events rather than one main course that we can sink our teeth into,'' said Robert Brusca, an economist at Nikko Securities Co. International Inc. The relative importance of the reasons to favor one country's bonds over another's are constantly adjusted depending on world economic and political events. When the U.S. bond market benefited this past week from a modest ``flight to quality,'' investors were focusing on the dollar's recent strenth and the outlook for further appreciation, especially against the Japanese yen. A profound slump on the Tokyo Stock Exchange has chipped away value of the once rock-hard yen. The failure of the yen to regain any ground against the dollar despite a one percentage point interest rate increase by the Bank of Japan last Tuesday reinforced the pessimistic attitude toward the yen. ``People are adverse to buying yen-denominated bonds because the currency is dropping,'' said economist Elliott Platt of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. ``The interest rates might appear attractive but receiving returns in depreciated yen is not.'' Brusca said Japan's stock market dwarfs its bond market, the opposite of the U.S. situation. The vast sums pulled out of stocks cannot be absorbed fully by the Japanese bond market. ``When the stock market goes bad that's a real problem,'' he said. ``Money seems to be migrating out of Tokyo.'' Platt said Japanese are buying bonds denominated in dollars or West German marks. West German bonds are in favor because unification with East Germany is expected to bolster the mark. It is anticipated that ultimately German unity will contributed to faster economic activity there, leading to higher interest rates. The risk that rapid growth will spur inflation has curbed some of the enthusiasm for mark-based investments. The U.S. bond market, by far the world's biggest, historically has been a haven for investors looking for stability and lower risk. Its size creates the ability to absorb funds without a hiccup that could unsettle prices. Investors wanting to play their investment decisions close to their chests often prefer the anonymity that a large market affords. There's less chance of noticing a large influx of cash into the United States than into Italy, for example. The U.S. bond market is estimated to be twice the size of the next biggest market. According to the report ``How Big is the World Bond Market'' by Salomon Brothers Inc., the top five bond markets in terms of 1988 capitalization were: the United States, $4.5 trillion; Japan, $2.2 trillion; West Germany, $753.5 billion; Italy, $53 billion; and Britain, $34 billion. William Brachfeld, an executive vice president at aiwa Securities Inc., said a country like Japan with a giant trade surplus has more capital that the country itself can handle. The capital represents the money flowing into Japan to pay for the country's exports of merchandise and services. ``All those funds are not needed in Japan _ they have to be invested abroad,'' Brachfeld said. ``A considerable portion of funds come here because they almost have to come here, there's almost no place else to put them.''

DOC.HEAD: Hectic Week Teaches Tokyo Traders That Every Bubble Must Burst
DOC.TEXT: As a hectic week of pessimism and repeated plunges shaved more than 6.9 percent off the main index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the message to traders was clear: Every bubble must burst. ``Over the past few years the stock market in this country has been a repetition of share prices going up because of buying, and buying because of share prices going up,'' said an editorial in the Nihon Keizai Shimbun, an influential economic journal. ``As excessive price-earnings ratios indicate, share prices have been detached from actual industrial conditions, and the bubble has grown larger and larger. But every bubble must burst,'' the editorial said Friday. ``That time has come.'' The Nikkei Stock Average closed the week Friday at 30,372.16 points, down a combined 2,773.1 points during the three previous trading days. After closing for a national holiday Wednesday, the market on Thursday fell below the psychological 30,000-point barrier. The 225-issue Nikkei index closed Thursday at 29,843.34, its lowest finish since 29,741.28 on Dec. 24, 1988. That put the Nikkei, which rose 8,756.87 points in 1989, down 9,072.93 points, or 23 percent, for the year. But by week's end there were buyers in the market. On Thursday, the Nikkei had been down by nearly 1,900 points at one time but rebounded to finish only 963 points below the previous close. On Friday, the market rose 528.82 points, or 1.77 percent. ``The bottom is almost here,'' said Kenji Maeshiro, a stock analyst with Yamaichi Securities Co. The week's plunges prompted Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto to lament that his ministry was monitoring the markets ``with anguish.'' Both he and Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno agreed that the stock and currency markets were driving each other down. Seeking to avert inflation and stabilize the financial markets, Mieno on Tuesday announced a long-awaited hike in Japan's discount rate, boosting it by 1 percentage point to 5.25 percent. Mieno said results from the increase should not be expected to appear immediately. The increase failed to stop the rise of the dollar, which gained 2.87 yen over the last six trading days. Although Friday's rebound in the Nikkei hinted at confidence returning to the market, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry began action to assess the effects of the losses so far. MITI decided to launch a nationwide survey to gauge the impact on companies' investment in equipment and facilities, profits, and prices of imported raw materials, said a ministry official. The ministry action came as Mazda, a leading automaker, reportedly decided to scale back sales targets for a new luxury car because of fears the bearish market and weak yen might spill over and dampen consumer extravagance in general. ``As far as I know, this is the first such survey by MITI,'' said the official, requesting anonymity. ``But this does not mean we think the situation very serious. We worry, rather, that our moves might accelerate the public anxiety and worsen their economic prospects for the future, so we are trying not to make a fuss about it.'' After Friday's rally, some traders also expressed confidence in a recovery, pointing out that investors may seek the buy opportunites created by major falls. ``The market is slowly but gradually recovering, helped by relative stability in the currency and bond markets,'' said Akira Shimoda, an equity analyst with Yamaichi Securities. He said the market would be helped by the Finance Ministry's approval Thursday of a measure that allows Japan's four major brokerage houses to handle more than 30 percent of the purchase orders of any particular stock in a month. Japan's four major securities firms _ Nomura Securitiies, Daiwa Securities, Nikko Securities and Yamaichi Securities _ had asked the Finance Ministry to ease the restriction, a rule intended to curb insider trading. The four securities firms account for about half of the market's total trading volume, a market analyst said. Securities companies, meanwhile, have decided not to underwrite new stock, bond and warrant issues so that available funds instead would go toward bolstering prices of existing stocks. At least nine companies recently canceled plans to issue new stock shares because of concern over the fluctuations in stock prices and the Nikkei's sharp declines. Nevertheless, concern remained that money that had been flowing into stocks could still be diverted elsewhere because of the market's perceived instability.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, March 25

DOC.HEAD: Fiat Venture In Soviet Union Extended
DOC.TEXT: Fiat SpA has agreed to expand its joint auto venture with the Soviet Union to include the manufacture of engines and transmissions for the entire projected annual production of cars at the Yelabuga plant outside Moscow, a Fiat spokesman said Friday. As a result, Fiat will roughly triple the amount of engines and parts to be manufactured at the joint-venture plant, the spokesman said. Under terms of the initial agreement, Fiat agreed to provide machinery and parts for the annual production of 300,000 A-93 mid-size cars starting in late 1993 or 1994. The Soviets were to furnish the engines and transmissions for the remaining two-thirds of total annual production. The joint-venture agreement was signed last fall during Soviet President Mikail Gorbachev's visit to Italy. This week, a visiting delegation of Soviet officials asked Fiat also to provide machinery for an additional 600,000 cars a year at the plant, the Fiat spokesman said. These will be sub-compacts and upscale models. The Soviet delegation visited Fiat plants and viewed a model of the A-93 to be produced at Yelabuga. The A-93 is a small sedan based on Fiat's popular Panda model.

DOC.HEAD: Vacancy Rates Soar Amid Wall Street Recession
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS employment figures to thousands in 11th graf
DOC.HEAD: Graphic in AP Access under EMPTYSPACE
DOC.TEXT: The 25th floor of the south tower of the luxurious World Financial Center is empty save for a few boxes. So are the 26th, 27th and 28th floors. In the booming mid-1980s, Merrill Lynch & Co. expected to fill the space easily. The nation's largest securities firm booked two full towers in the ultra-modern complex in lower Manhattan that opened in 1986, using conservative estimates of employment growth. Then Merrill scaled back to one tower plus about half the second. After the 1987 stock market crash even that was too much, and now the firm plans to sublet nine floors, including the four undeveloped ones. On Wall Street _ and Broad Street and Greenwich Street and Battery Place _ a securities industry recession has created an office-space glut in the world's premier financial district. Vacancy rates are soaring in the maze of silver office towers and aging stone monoliths where stock trading began almost 200 years ago under a buttonwood tree. Property brokers compare the slump to the mid-1970s, when New York teetered on bankruptcy. ``We're still headed south,'' said Robert F.R. Ballard, an executive vice president with the real estate firm Cushman & Wakefield, who has worked in the Wall Street building market since 1959. ``We haven't bottomed out yet.'' Manhattan real estate brokers say the vacancy rate in the downtown financial district is approaching 20 percent, vs. 8 percent to 12 percent in 1985 during the securities industry boom. Put another way, the 14 million square feet of available office space downtown equals three empty buildings, each as big as a 110-story World Trade Center tower. The glut is expected to worsen because hundreds of thousands of square feet to be abandoned by firms such as Merrill, Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., Salomon Inc. and collapsed Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. haven't been tallied yet. Unprecedented growth in stock trading and investment banking gave rise to hand-over-fist hiring and expansion by Wall Street firms in the 1980s. Average daily trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange shot up from 32.2 million shares in 1979 to 189 million shares in 1987, while employment in in New York's securities and commodities industries grew from 74,000 to 163,000. During that period, Wall Street firms set ambitious expansion plans, tied to the seemingly limitless possibilities of another boom. Building ``world headquarters'' seemed logical to accomodate technological advances that required more space for more computers for more trading into the 21st century. ``Many of the financial firms don't indulge in what we call intelligent strategic planning regarding their space needs,'' said Joel Wechsler, a managing director of the real estate firm Edward S. Gordon & Co. ``They're getting a little more sophisticated in that area now.'' Stock market volume, securities underwriting, mergers and takeovers and other financial businesses are down sharply. Since the crash, the securities industry has lost more than 40,000 jobs. ``The vacancy rates are directly related to the shrinkage in the financial services industry,'' said Anthony M. Saytanides, Edward S. Gordon's chief operating officer. Ballard put it less gently: ``The developers built too much space. The tenants rented too much space. The market took a nosedive.'' During the decline, several projects were abandoned and other overly ambitious ones have cost firms hundreds of millions of dollars. Salomon took a $150 million accounting charge against earnings after dropping out of a major project. Two firms that named buildings for themselves _ E.F. Hutton & Co. and Thomson McKinnon Securities Inc. _ are history. Shearson, the No. 2 brokerage behind Merrill, spent $450 million to build a 39-story office tower known as Shearson Lehman Hutton Plaza. The firm plans to fill the building, which opened late last year, but also is firing up to 5,000 workers this year, which could lead to more unused space. Workers in reduced Shearson departments say they can roam floors almost undisturbed. The firm's new tower is adorned with a Parthenon-like frieze, and some wags say it too could wind up a monument to a golden age. ``There may be some discussion in hindsight whether it was the most effective use of the firm's money at the time,'' a Shearson official privately conceded, adding that it is evaluating space needs as part of an overhaul. Merrill decided to move in the early '80s, when its headcount was growing by 13 percent annually. It booked the World Financial Center space anticipating only half that growth. But since the crash, Merrill has slashed its work force back to a 1980 level. More cuts are planned. The firm took a $470 million charge against earnings last quarter for its restructuring _ $220 million to cover real estate commitments, nearly all of that in New York. ``The growth has certainly gone in the other direction,'' Merrill spokesman Fred Yager said. ``Our fixed costs have been reduced considerably and one of our biggest fixed costs is real estate.'' For the real estate market, the glut's the thing. While modern office spaces such as the World Financial Center and World Trade Center complexes are almost fully occupied, older buildings are bearing the brunt as firms move out. The average asking rent downtown is falling, but not in proportion to available space. Brokers say top-line offices still command around $35 per square foot, among the highest in the country. Some prices for older buildings, though, have fallen into the single digits, just like in the 1970s. Brokers estimate the downtown vacancy rate will climb well above 20 percent once a rash of moves _ some across New York waterways to cheaper Brooklyn or New Jersey _ are completed. In the mid-'70s, the rate was about 25 percent, brokers said. Among the untallied moves: the Securities Industry Automation Corp.'s move to new quarters, abandoning 200,000 square feet; Salomon's shift to 7 World Trade Center, leaving 500,000 square feet behind; the consolidation by Merrill and Shearson; and about 1.5 million square feet by Drexel. During its junk-bond driven heyday, Drexel planned to build new headquarters downtown. The firm wisely scrapped the project after settling securities fraud charges with the government last April and trimming 4,000 employees by selling its retail brokerage operations. Unwisely, in retrospect, Drexel last fall extended the lease on its main Broad Street offices until 2004. Six weeks ago, Drexel's parent entered bankruptcy proceedings, listing more than $470 million in domestic lease commitments outstanding. Some brokers say the market has even further to fall because at least one sure sign of desperation has yet to take hold. ``During the '70s a lot of the older buildings were turned into apartments,'' Ballard said. ``That hasn't happened yet, and if that hasn't happened we haven't hit bottom.''

DOC.HEAD: Some Say Hazelwood Verdict Could Hurt Exxon
DOC.TEXT: Joseph Hazelwood's future seemed less murky after a jury acquitted the skipper of serious charges stemming from the Alaska oil spill, but lawyers say the verdict may dump more trouble onto his ex-boss Exxon Corp. ``I guess the jurors thought it was Exxon's fault and decided not make the captain the goat,'' said Melvin Belli, a celebrity attorney famous for winning multimillion-dollar judgments, who represents 500 clients suing Exxon. ``It won't hurt my case at all,'' he said in a telephone interview after the Hazelwood verdict was announced this past week. ``It might help my case. They let the captain off. Now let's get the people who are really responsible.'' The captain of the Exxon Valdez tanker that hit a reef a year ago and spewed oil into Prince William Sound was convicted of only a simple misdemeanor count of negligence for his role in the nation's worst oil spill. He was sentenced to help clean up the mess and pay $50,000 in restitution. Jurors at a trial in Anchorage, Alaska, said there wasn't enough evidence to convict him on the more substantial counts of criminal mischief, reckless endangerment and operating a vessel while drunk. The verdict stunned much of the nation, including attorneys who said the lynch-mob atmosphere created by the oil spill had made convictions seem a foregone conclusion. Exxon, which fired Hazelwood after the disaster, said it was pleased his ordeal was over and that the verdict suggested the grounding was an accident. Hazelwood even said he would try to renegotiate his old job back. But specialists in corporate liability law said Hazelwood's conviction on the negligence charge might be bad news for Exxon, because it could be used by the hundreds of plaintiffs suing the company for civil damages as solid evidence that the company, through one of its employees, was to blame. Some also suggested that the jury's failure to convict on the more serious charges didn't mean they wouldn't be raised again in civil litigation, in which the rules of evidence are much less stringent than in criminal proceedings. ``Exxon gets very little benefit out of this,'' said David Leebron, a professor of corporate liability law at Columbia University Law School. ``Exxon would be responsible for the negligence of its employees,'' he said. ``They might have been hoping that the employee did something so unpredictable it would get them out of liability. So in this case, the jury finding of negligence hurts them.'' Belli, whose clients range from Alaskan boatbuilders to Japanese canneries hurt by a post-spill fishing ban around the Alaskan coast, said the verdict only strengthened his legal arsenal. He predicted Exxon would attempt to settle most of the lawsuits. ``The damages aren't measured in millions,'' he said. ``They're in billions.'' Daniel D. Polsby, a professor of law at Northwestern University in Chicago, speculated that the Hazelwood verdict would shift the focus of litigation away from who was responsible. Now, he said, ``the question is going to be who has got a right to complain.'' That could mean many years of tangled lawsuits and questions over who was hurt financially by the spill and what will be required to clean it up. Exxon already has spent about $2 billion in a cleanup, but its future liability is undetermined. Some lawyers suggested Exxon also faces the tricky problem of whether to rehire Hazelwood. He was dismissed for violating company policy after post-spill tests revealed he had been legally drunk. But the jury said the evidence wasn't there to back that up. Andrew Kramer, chairman of the labor section at the law firm Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue, said if Exxon rehired Hazelwood, it might undermine the company's contention that the skipper acted irresponsibly. On the other hand, Kramer said, Exxon executives might reason that ``if we don't rehire him, he is a potential witness against us.'' In other business and economic news this past week: _Southland Corp., the nation's largest convenience store operator, agreed to sell control to a Japanese company because of crushing debt burdens stemming from a junk-bond-financed buyout. The deal announced by the founder of the 7-Eleven chain was one of the most dramatic examples of credit crises faced by U.S. companies that have relied heavily on junk financing. _President Bush's savings & loan bailout plan hit a potentially crippling snag when a judge prevented a government takeover of an ailing Chicago thrift on grounds that federal regulators in charge of the bailout were appointed unconstitutionally. An appeals court temporarily blocked the order and Bush moved to blunt it as well by nominating a new thrift-office director to be confirmed by the Senate. _Japan's mighty financial markets plunged, bolstering the view that what goes up must come down. But the decline had a limited impact on U.S. stock prices, reviving the question of whether the globalization of securities trading is as important as earlier believed.
DOC.NOTE: End adv for weekend editions March 24-25.

DOC.HEAD: Bull Market Could Be Driven Out as Quarter Ends
DOC.TEXT: Like Arturo Di Modica's renegade bull statue, Wall Street's latest bull market may soon be driven away, at least for a while. After a vigorous runup recently, the market rally stalled this past Tuesday as traders fretted about corporate earnings at home and interest rates in Japan. Stocks recovered on Friday, boosted by strong bond prices and a mild rebound on the troubled Tokyo stock market. Strategists expect the first-quarter earnings of many U.S. companies, due early next month, to show worse-than-expected results that would depress the value of American stocks. The earnings reports ``will look pretty horrendous,'' said Larry Wachtel, an analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. In addition, as the first quarter approaches its end this coming week, many institutional investors could sell to take profits to put on their books. Rumblings from the Far East could heighten the market's skittishness. For the past month or so, steep declines in the Tokyo stock market have failed to shake up Wall Street _ at least not too much. The familiar domino effect from one market to the other seems to have been put on hold. But the effect could come roaring back, some experts believe, if the Tokyo market falls so severely that Japanese investors are forced to sell their U.S. stocks to raise cash for obligations at home. ``We may run into some rough sledding,'' said Bill Raftery, an analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. ``That's where the selling pressure could come in.'' Much will depend on the dollar. Its strength has helped fuel the market's recent rally. The dollar's gains are seen as a testimony to the stability and favorable long-term prospects of the U.S. economy, at a time when the world political and economic landscape is changing fast. But a downturn in the currency could prompt Wall Street to throw out the bull even more vehemently. The bull statue, by the way, was hauled away from the front of the New York Stock Exchange in mid-December after standing there less than a day. Di Modica, its sculptor, said he was donating ``The Charging Bull'' to the city as a Christmas present, but the exchange couldn't bear having it there. The irrepressible bronze bull later resurfaced at Bowling Green, not far from Wall Street, in view of the federal bankruptcy court. The city told Di Modica he could sell the three-ton statue to a company, which could then donate it to New York. The bull market also is expected to come back, after a period of what strategists call ``consolidation''. ``This economy is showing surprising pockets of strength,'' said Frank Cappiello, a principal of McCullough, Andrews & Cappiello Inc. in Baltimore. ``People see this as a market of preference.'' Di Modica agrees. ``The economy is strong and will get stronger. I would never be negative about that,'' he said from his studio in lower Manhattan. For the week, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 36.94 points to 2,704.28. The New York Stock Exchange composite index slipped 2.47 to 185.45; the NASDAQ composite index of over-the-counter trading lost 4.91 to 437.25, and the American Stock Exchange's market value index dropped 2.57 to 361.61. Volume on the Big Board averaged 151.72 million shares a day, compared with 159.84 million the week before.

DOC.HEAD: Spanish-Language Magazine Launched in Conjunction with TV Programs
DOC.TEXT: An ambitious multimedia effort aimed at Hispanics gets underway Monday, enabling advertisers to reach the nation's fast-growing Spanish-speaking market by magazine, television and telephone. Creators of the service say 90 percent of the $10 million in annual ad time and space has been sold. Media analysts and competitors said the service could draw renewed attention to the Spanish-language market. Some media and advertising executives have argued that U.S. advertisers are missing a profitable opportunity by failing to spend more on reaching the 20 million-plus Hispanics in the United States in their native language. ``We frankly welcome this competition because we want to make Spanish print media better known and accepted,'' said Alberto Abdo, a marketing executive with Miami-based America Publishing Group, a leading Spanish-language publisher with 16 magazines sold in the United States. The new multimedia service will reach an estimated 500,000 Hispanic magazine readers and nearly 90 percent of Hispanic homes with television, says its developer, Whittle Communications of Knoxville, Tenn. Starting later this spring, advertisers will also be mentioned when operators answer calls to a toll-free telephone service for Hispanics seeking information on topics ranging from recipes to immigration. The operator will answer calls by saying the hotline service is ``brought to you by ...'' Among the sponsors who are paying $500,000 a year under two-year contracts for a basic package that includes television and telephone time and space in the magazine are American Airlines, Procter & Gamble, American Telephone & Telegraph and Kinney Shoes. The conerstone of the service is the magazine La Familia de Hoy, published every other month. It is distributed free to 10,500 medical waiting rooms and beauty parlors in Hispanic neigborhoods in 45 markets. Whittle executives said the magazine will offer information that can help Hispanics live better in the United States. That is a big break from other Spanish-language magazines circulated here that often rely mainly on ``gossip, entertainment and fashion,'' said editor Patricia Duarte. The March-April issue has stories on recognizing when your children may be abusing drugs and what to do about it, handling finances, cooking tips, relating to your spouse and staying healthy. It also has a profile of President Bush's daughter-in-law, Colomba Bush, who is from Mexico. Whittle is also producing two-minute informational programs that will run 31 times a week on the Spanish-language television network Univision, which reaches 6.4 million Spanish-speaking households in the United States. Each program will identify the sponsor at the start and finish and include a commercial of 30 to 45 seconds. Many of the programs will be drawn from subjects covered in the magazine. A typical program starts with an introduction by former Univision Network News anchor Teresa Rodriguez. After the commercial, an expert may discuss a topic, often leaving a number or address for more information. In one program, a physician offers health tips for pregnant women; in another, Ms. Rodriguez toured a museum designed for children. F. Ashley Shomaker, who is overseesing the project for Whittle, said advertisers are also being mentioned at other times of the day on the Univision network to draw attention to upcoming shows. Advertisers will also be rotated regularly on the telephone announcement. Richard Hamilton, an advertising executive with D'Arcy Masius, Benton & Bowles in New York, said marketers are starting to pay more attention to the Hispanic market because it is growing rapidly in size, per capita income and willingness to buy recognized brands. He said they are turning to Spanish-language media because research indicates ``many Hispanics prefer communications in Spanish'' to English. But America Publishing's Abdo said that while Hispanics make up nearly 10 percent of the U.S. population, advertisers spend less than 1 percent of their ad budgets in Spanish-language media. ``They spend mostly on TV. The amounts dedicated to print are very low,'' he said. Nonetheless, he said ad pages at his company's magazines are up 36 percent this year from a year ago. He credited more aggressive marketing and greater awareness among advertisers of the market's potential.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, March 26

DOC.HEAD: Winnebago Industries Reports Widening Loss, Discloses Credit Problems
DOC.TEXT: Winnebago Industries Inc. reported Friday that its losses more than doubled in the second quarter of its fiscal year and disclosed problems arranging credit with banks and financial institutions. The $5.3 million loss in the quarter ended Feb. 24 reflected a weak market for motor homes, losses from a new division that makes trucks for delivery businesses and continued losses from its Cycle-Sat subsidiary that delivers commercials to television stations by satellite. Frank Rolfes, who follows Winnebago for the Minneapolis securities firm of Dain Bosworth, said the results were in line with his projections, ``which are very negative.'' ``They're not doing very well down there,'' he said. ``It doesn't appear to be getting better.'' On Wall Street, the report appeared to be shrugged off as the New York Stock Exchange-listed Winnebago ended the day unchanged at $5.25 a share. John K. Hanson, the founder and chairman of the Forest City manufacturer, said recent negotiations with the company's banks and financial institutions failed to achieve ``acceptable'' credit terms. ``As a result, Winnebago has reduced its outstanding short-term borrowing through the liquidation of the company's marketable securities portfolio and sale of Winnebago Acceptance Corporation's dealer receivables,'' Hanson said. Winnebago Acceptance Corp. provides financing to buyers of its motor homes and recreational vehicles. Its receivables are the loan agreements it holds. Spokeswoman Sheila Davis said the company had sold its entire securities portfolio. The company did not release its securities losses or put a value on the securities sold. But Ms. Davis said that at the end of its first fiscal quarter Winnebago had $30.6 million in cash and securities. Rolfes said he did not believe the company was in danger of collapse because it has little long-term debt, but added, ``they've got to do something to turn things around.'' In its annual report, the company listed total short-term debt of about $5.7 million and long-term debt of $6.4 million as of Aug. 26, 1989. Rolfes said Winnebago had been losing money on its securities portfolio for years and may have decided it was putting that investment to better use by buying down its short-term debt to reduce interest expenses. The $5.3 million loss in the second quarter of the fiscal year came to 21 cents a share and compared with a loss of almost $2.6 million, or 10 cents a share, in the same period a year earlier. Revenue for the period fell almost 25 percent to $80.6 million from $107.1 million. ``The results for the quarter were caused by losses in RV operations due to lower motor home sales volume, substantial inventive and promotion costs, a shift in product mix to lower priced motor homes, and continuing losses by Winnebago subsidiary, Cycle-Sat, start-up costs for the commercial vehicle division and losses in financial investments,'' Hanson said. For the first half of the fiscal year, Winnebago reported a loss of nearly $10 million, or 40 cents a share, compared with a profit of $6.3 million, or 25 cents a share, in the same period a year earlier. Revenue fell by 32 percent to $159.6 million from $235.1 million.

DOC.HEAD: General Dynamics Settles Suit Against AT&T For $125 Million
DOC.TEXT: General Dynamics Corp. said Friday it has received $125 million from American Telephone & Telegraph Co. and its former regional operating companies as part of a settlement of an 8-year-old antitrust lawsuit. Chris Schildz, a spokesman for the St. Louis-based defense contractor, said it was not clear exactly what effect the settlement will have on earnings, but that it is likely the after-tax benefit would be less than $2 a share. The suit, filed in federal court in Chicago in 1982, claimed that AT&T acted to prevent competitors from making and selling phone equipment from 1972 to 1980 by using ``illegal'' and anticompetitive'' activities. At the time, General Dynamics owned General Dynamics Telephone Systems Center, formerly Stromberg-Carlson Corp., and General Dynamics Communications Co. The company sold its telecommunications business in 1982. The settlement acknowledges that AT&T and its subsidiaries did not act in collusion to prevent competition, Schildz said.

DOC.HEAD: Michigan Businessmen, Firms Plead Innocent in Bribery Case
DOC.TEXT: Two Michigan businessmen and three companies they control pleaded innocent Friday to charges they bilked a Scott Paper Co. mill out of up to $1 million by bribing an engineer and putting his wife on their payroll. Federal prosecutors say Gerald M. Chernow, 49, and William M. Engelman, 52, cheated the S.D. Warren mill in Westbrook by persuading maintenance engineer David Hilt to buy unneeded maintenance and roofing equipment that was marked up by up to 20 times its cost. Initially, Hilt was given merchandise, gift certificates and money orders, and later, his wife, Ellen, was put on the payroll of one of the Michigan companies, First Assistant U.S. Attorney Jack Gleason said. Chernow and Engelman, both of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., entered innocent pleas before U.S. Magistrate David Cohen. Chernow and Engelman were freed on their own recognizance, but they must hand over their passports and will be required to pay $50,000 bond if they fail to show up to any court proceedings, Gleason said. The two businessmen had appeared in court without being arrested. The two are charged with conspiracy, mail fraud and the use of interstate facilities in furtherance of private bribery. Both businessmen declined to comment on the case, as did defense attorney Julian Sweet of Lewiston. Also named as defendants in the 21-count indictment are Modern Research Corp. and Lincoln Technical Services Inc., both of Troy, Mich., and ABC Chemical Co. of Detroit. If Chernow and Engelman are convicted on all counts, they face up to 105 years in prison and fines totaling $5.25 million each, the prosecutor said. Modern Research and Lincoln Technical Service each face up to $10.5 million in fines, while ABC Chemical could face $6.5 million in fines. Philadelphia-based Scott Paper lost between $750,000 and $1 million in the scheme, the government says.

DOC.HEAD: Reformulated Gasoline Goes on Sale in Southeastern Michigan
DOC.TEXT: Marathon Petroleum Co. will make southeastern Michigan a test market for a gasoline intended to help meet demands for reduced air pollution from autos, the company said Friday. Marathon will start selling its ``Amaraclean'' gasolines Monday in three unleaded grades at 161 stations in eight southeastern Michigan counties. If the gasolines sell in the Detroit area, Marathon will start marketing them sometime next year in other cities such as Cleveland, St. Louis, Cincinnati and Akron, Ohio, the company said. The introduction of cleaner gasolines has followed a proposal by President Bush last June 5 that would have required selling millions of cars that run on fuels other than gasoline, such as natural gas or methanol. William Reilly, head of the Environmental Protection Agency, confirmed last month the Bush administration was telling Senate leaders that reformulated gasolines might be an acceptable alternative. The compromise clean-air bill being debated in the Senate this week would require reformulated, cleaner-burning gasolines in the country's smoggiest cities by 1995, said Charles Gray, head of the EPA's Ann Arbor testing laboratory. Atlantic Richfield Co. already is selling reformulated gasoline in California. In Denver, Conoco and Shamrock sell gasoline blended to reduce carbon monoxide emissions. Amoco isn't marketing a reformulated gasoline yet but that ``is a major consideration among the alternate fuels that are being looked at,'' said spokesman Neil Geary in Chicago. Geary said oil companies are experimenting with various fuels. He said Amoco expects within a month to begin test marketing compressed natural gas at four Denver locations. White said motorists probably won't notice any difference in price or performance with the Amaraclean gasolines. But the gasoline will evaporate less easily in hot weather, cutting down on a major cause of smog. The fuels are a step toward reduced volatility levels the EPA proposes to require for all gasolines by 1992, Gray said. The fuel is also formulated to burn more completely, and cancer-causing chemicals normally used to boost octane have been eliminated. Marathon said the blends cut hydrocarbon emissions about 20 percent and carbon monoxide 14 percent.
